abstract: The New Journalism is a 1973 [[anthology|anthology]] of journalism edited by [[Tom Wolfe|Tom Wolfe]] and E. W. Johnson. The book is both a [[manifesto|manifesto]] for a new type of journalism by Wolfe, and a collection of examples of [[New Journalism|New Journalism]] by American writers, covering a variety of subjects from the frivolous (baton twirling competitions) to the deadly serious (the [[Vietnam War|Vietnam War]]). The pieces are notable because they do not conform to the standard [[dispassionate and even-handed|Objectivity (journalism)]] model of [[journalism|journalism]]. Rather they incorporate [[literary devices|Literary technique]] usually only found in fictional works.
title: The New Journalism

abstract: How Opal Mehta Got Kissed, Got Wild, and Got a Life is a [[young adult novel|young adult fiction]] by Kaavya Viswanathan, who wrote it just after she graduated from high school. Its 2006 debut was highly publicized while she was enrolled at [[Harvard University|Harvard University]], but the book was withdrawn after it was discovered that portions had been [[plagiarized|plagiarism]] from several sources, including the works of [[Salman Rushdie|Salman Rushdie]] and [[Meg Cabot|Meg Cabot]]. Viswanathan apologized and said any similarities were "completely unintentional and unconscious." All shelf copies of Opal Mehta were ultimately recalled and destroyed by the publisher, and Viswanathan's contract for a second book was canceled.
title: How Opal Mehta Got Kissed, Got Wild, and Got a Life

abstract: Mr. Tickle is the first book in the [[Mr. Men|Mr. Men]] series by [[Roger Hargreaves|Roger Hargreaves]], published 10 August 1971.
title: Mr. Tickle

abstract: 20th Century Ghosts is American author [[Joe Hill|Joe Hill (writer)]]'s first published book-length work. A collection of [[short stories|short story]], it was first published in October 2005 in the United Kingdom and released in October 2007 in the United States.
title: 20th Century Ghosts

abstract: Mr. Midnight is a children's horror fiction book series written by Jim Aitchison under the pseudonym of [[James Lee|James Lee (writer)]]. The series is published by Angsana Books, Flame Of The Forest Publishing. There are currently 115 books in the series, including 19 Special Edition titles, with more being written and released around every two to four months. It has been translated into Burmese, Malay, Indonesian, simplified Chinese, and traditional Chinese.
title: Mr. Midnight

abstract: The 85 Ways to Tie a Tie () is a book by [[Thomas Fink|Thomas Fink]] and [[Yong Mao|Yong Mao]]. The authors were [[research fellow|research fellows]] at Cambridge University’s [[Cavendish Laboratory|Cavendish Laboratory]]. It was published by [[Fourth Estate|HarperCollins#Imprints]] on Nov 4, 1999, and subsequently published in nine other languages.
title: The 85 Ways to Tie a Tie

abstract: The Biographies of Exemplary Women () is a book compiled by the [[Han Dynasty|Han Dynasty]] scholar [[Liu Xiang|Liu Xiang (scholar)]] c. 18 BC. It includes 125 biographical accounts of exemplary women in ancient China, taken from early Chinese histories including [[Chunqiu|Spring and Autumn Annals]], [[Zuozhuan|Zuozhuan]], and the [[Records of the Grand Historian|Records of the Grand Historian]]. The book served as a standard [[Confucianist|Confucianist]] textbook for the moral education of women in traditional China for two millennia.
title: Biographies of Exemplary Women

abstract: Die Natürlichen Pflanzenfamilien (1887–1915) by [[Adolf Engler|Adolf Engler]] and [[Karl Anton Prantl|Karl Anton Prantl]] is a complete revision of plant families down to generic level and often even further. As such it forms part of the [[Engler system|Engler system]] of [[plant taxonomy|plant taxonomy]].
title: Die Natürlichen Pflanzenfamilien

abstract: In Defense of Global Capitalism (in [[Swedish|Swedish language]]: Till världskapitalismens försvar) is a book by [[Swedish|Sweden]] writer [[Johan Norberg|Johan Norberg]] promoting [[economic globalization|economic globalization]] and [[free trade|free trade]]. The book was originally published in May 2001 by the Swedish think tank [[Timbro|Timbro]]. Since then, a number of translations into other languages have followed.
title: In Defense of Global Capitalism

abstract: Short Trips: Zodiac is a [[Big Finish|Big Finish Productions]] original anthology edited by [[Jacqueline Rayner|Jacqueline Rayner]] and based on the long-running British [[science fiction television|science fiction on television]] series [[Doctor Who|Doctor Who]].
title: Short Trips: Zodiac

abstract: Short Trips: Repercussions is a [[Big Finish|Big Finish Productions]] original anthology edited by [[Gary Russell|Gary Russell]] and based on the long-running British [[science fiction television|science fiction on television]] series [[Doctor Who|Doctor Who]]. The collection explores the theme of unforeseen consequences.
title: Short Trips: Repercussions

abstract: The Price of Privilege is a non-fiction book by [[Madeline Levine|Madeline Levine]]. The book’s primary [[thesis|thesis]] is that teenagers from affluent families have more intense psychological problems than expected.
title: The Price of Privilege

abstract: Fablehaven is [[The New York Times|The New York Times]] best-selling [[children's literature|children's literature]] [[fantasy|fantasy]] series written by [[Brandon Mull|Brandon Mull]]. The book series, which includes [[Fablehaven|Fablehaven (book)]], [[Fablehaven: Rise of the Evening Star|Fablehaven: Rise of the Evening Star]], [[Fablehaven: Grip of the Shadow Plague|Fablehaven: Grip of the Shadow Plague]], [[Fablehaven: Secrets of the Dragon Sanctuary|Fablehaven: Secrets of the Dragon Sanctuary]], and [[Fablehaven: Keys to the Demon Prison|Fablehaven: Keys to the Demon Prison]], is published by Shadow Mountain in hardcover and [[Simon & Schuster|Simon & Schuster]] in paperback.
title: Fablehaven

abstract: Xiandai Hanyu Cidian (), also known as A Dictionary of Current Chinese or Contemporary Chinese Dictionary is an important one-volume [[dictionary|dictionary]] of [[Standard Mandarin Chinese|Standard Mandarin]] published by the [[Commercial Press|Commercial Press]], now into its 7th (2016) edition. It was originally edited by [[Lü Shuxiang|Lü Shuxiang]] and Ding Shengshu as a reference work on modern Standard Chinese. Compilation started in 1958 and trial editions were issued in 1960 and 1965, with a number of copies printed in 1973 for internal circulation and comments, but due to the [[Cultural Revolution|Cultural Revolution]] the final draft was not completed until the end of 1977, and the first formal edition was not published until December 1978. It was the first [[People's Republic of China|People's Republic of China]] dictionary to be arranged according to [[Hanyu Pinyin|Hanyu Pinyin]], the phonetic standard for [[Standard Chinese|Standard Chinese]], with explanatory notes in [[simplified Chinese|simplified Chinese]]. The subsequent second through seventh editions were respectively published in 1983 (Reorganized Edition- now seen as the '2nd edition'), 1996 (Revised Edition- now seen as the '3rd edition'), 2002 (2002 Supplemental Edition- now seen as the '4th edition'), 2005 (5th edition), 2012 (6th edition) and 2016 (7th edition).
title: Xiandai Hanyu Cidian

abstract: The QI Book of the Dead (sold as The Book of the Dead in the United States) is the fourth title in a series of books based on the intellectual British [[panel game|panel game]] [[QI|QI]], written by series-creator [[John Lloyd|John Lloyd (writer)]] and head-researcher [[John Mitchinson|John Mitchinson (researcher)]]. It is a book of "quite interesting" [[obituaries|obituary]].
title: The QI Book of the Dead

abstract: The Fellowship of the Ring is the first of three volumes of the epic novel [[The Lord of the Rings|The Lord of the Rings]] by the English author [[J. R. R. Tolkien|J. R. R. Tolkien]]. It is followed by [[The Two Towers|The Two Towers]] and [[The Return of the King|The Return of the King]]. It takes place in the [[fictional universe|fictional universe]] of [[Middle-earth|Middle-earth]]. It was originally published on 29 July 1954 in the United Kingdom.
title: The Fellowship of the Ring

abstract: [[Easwaran's|Eknath Easwaran]] Mantram Handbook provides an introduction to the practice of repeating [[mantram|mantrams]] and/or [[holy names|Names of God]], terms the author uses interchangeably. The book offers the author's practical guidance for choosing a mantram and using it for personal centering and spiritual growth. In the opening chapters, the author recommends selecting a single mantram (such as those in the table at right), and suggests that the reader "take your time choosing a mantram..... then, once you have chosen a mantram, do not change it." Most of the remainder of the book discusses how to integrate the mantram into daily living to improve skills and solve various types of problems. Late in the book, Easwaran describes how the mantram can be combined with other spiritual practices, such as meditation. Easwaran's approach is distinctive, in that he recommends a [[method of sitting meditation|Passage Meditation]] that does not focus on the mantram. Accordingly, the entire concern of the Mantram Handbook is in how to use a mantram throughout the day, at times apart from sitting meditation.
title: Mantram Handbook

abstract: Dangerous Angels, also known as the Weetzie Bat series, is a [[young adult fiction|young adult fiction]] series by [[Francesca Lia Block|Francesca Lia Block]]. It consists of seven novels: [[Weetzie Bat|Weetzie Bat]], [[Witch Baby|Witch Baby]], [[Cherokee Bat and the Goat Guys|Cherokee Bat and the Goat Guys]], [[Missing Angel Juan|Missing Angel Juan]], [[Baby Be-Bop|Baby Be-Bop]], [[Necklace of Kisses|Necklace of Kisses]], and [[Pink Smog: Becoming Weetzie Bat|Pink Smog: Becoming Weetzie Bat]]. The books describe the lives of main character Weetzie Bat and her friends and family members in Los Angeles. The books include supernatural elements such as witches, genies, and ghosts and can be described as [[magical realism|magical realism]] or [[mythpunk|mythpunk]].
title: Dangerous Angels

abstract: Marching Men is a 1917 novel by American author [[Sherwood Anderson|Sherwood Anderson]]. Published by [[John Lane|John Lane (publisher)]], the novel is Anderson's second book; the first being the 1916 novel [[Windy McPherson's Son|Windy McPherson's Son]]. Marching Men is the story of Norman "Beaut" McGregor, a young man discontented with the powerlessness and lack of personal ambition among the miners of his hometown. After moving to Chicago he discovers his purpose is to empower workers by having them march in unison. Major themes of the novel include the organization of laborers, eradication of disorder, and the role of the exceptional man in society. The latter theme led post-World War II critics to compare Anderson's militaristic approach to homosocial order and the fascists of the War's [[Axis powers|Axis powers]].
title: Marching Men

abstract: It is universal that published books' prefaces are something like expectances that this book could sell well or praises for the authors' great talents by another several masters. However, the content of the Like a Speeding Youth's preface differs from the majority. The content of the preface can be divided into four parts.
title: Like a Speeding Youth

abstract: In Mexico is the second [[photo book|photo book]] by [[American visual artist|visual art of the United States]] [[Jessica Lange|Jessica Lange]], published by RM in United States, [[Mexico|Mexico]], [[Spain|Spain]] and [[United Kingdom|United Kingdom]], respectively, in 2010. As such, her monograph that followed a pattern of its predecessor [[50 Photographs|50 Photographs]] (2008), was issued on the [[Spanish-speaking market|List of countries where Spanish is an official language]] under an alternate title, En México.
title: In Mexico

abstract: The Complete TurtleTrader: How 23 Novice Investors Became Overnight Millionaires (2009) is an [[international bestseller|international bestseller]] written by [[Michael Covel|Michael Covel]]. Covel recounts the story of Wall Street’s [[Richard Dennis|Richard Dennis]] and his disciples, the Turtles.
title: The Complete TurtleTrader

abstract: Modern Cookery for Private Families is an English [[cookery book|cookery book]] by [[Eliza Acton|Eliza Acton]] (1799–1859). It was first published by Longmans in 1845, and was a best-seller, running through 13 editions by 1853, though its sales were later overtaken by [[Mrs Beeton|Mrs Beeton]]. On the strength of the book, [[Delia Smith|Delia Smith]] called Acton "the best writer of recipes in the English language", while [[Elizabeth David|Elizabeth David]] wondered why "this peerless writer" had been eclipsed by such inferior and inexperienced imitators.
title: Modern Cookery for Private Families

abstract: The Devil in a Forest is a short novel by American writer [[Gene Wolfe|Gene Wolfe]] about the conflict between Christianity and an earlier Pagan religion in Europe during the Middle Ages. The hero of the story, Mark, is an adolescent, an orphan, and the apprentice to a weaver very near a small holy Christian shrine. The shrine is within the King's Forest, and the very small village where he lives is on the edge of the forest. During the course of the novel the village is occupied by both a brutal squad of the King's foresters, and a mob of the pagan charcoal burners who eke out a living in the forest.
title: The Devil in a Forest

abstract: A World Not to Come: A History of Latino Writing and Print Culture is a 2013 history book by Raúl Coronado about the development of Latino identity through the use of writing and print culture in the 19th century.
title: A World Not to Come

abstract: Authorship of With the Century is disputed with claims that it was written by [[professional writers|Ghostwriter]] instead of Kim Il-sung himself.
title: With the Century

abstract: Cross on Evidence is an authoritative [[textbook|textbook]] on the law of [[evidence|evidence (law)]] in [[Australia|Law of Australia]].
title: Cross on Evidence

abstract: Allan's Illustrated Edition of Tyneside Songs and Readings is a book of Tyneside popular and traditional songs consisting of approximately 400 song lyrics on over 600 pages, published in 1891. It was reprinted in 1972 by Frank Graham, Newcastle upon Tyne, with an introduction by David Harker.
title: Allan's Illustrated Edition of Tyneside Songs and Readings

abstract: At the time Seeing with the Eyes of Love was published in 1991, [[Eknath Easwaran|Eknath Easwaran]] had served as a spiritual teacher in California since the 1960s. Easwaran taught a [[nonsectarian|religious pluralism]] [[method of meditation|Passage Meditation]] used by spiritual aspirants within many major religious traditions, both eastern and western. Easwaran's writings include commentaries on both eastern and western scriptures and spiritual figures.
title: Seeing with the Eyes of Love

abstract: Feng Menglong collected and slightly modified works from the Song, Yuan and Ming dynasties, such as changing characters’ names and locations to make stories more contemporary. The writing style of the series of stories is [[written vernacular|Written vernacular Chinese]], or baihua, the everyday language of people at that time. The 40 stories are divided into 3 sections, one section collects Song and Yuan dynasty tales, one collects Ming dynasty stories, and the last is the stories created by Feng Menglong himself. The success of Stories Old and New published (1620), also known as Yushi Mingyan (Illustrious Words to Instruct the World) led Feng to edit and publish JIngshi Tongyan ([[Stories to Caution the World|Stories to Caution the World]]) in 1624, and Xingshi Hengyan ([[Stories to Awaken the World|Stories to Awaken the World]]) in 1627. Each collection contained forty stories. The title of each collection ended with the word "yan" (word), so they are often referred to as a group: Sanyan (). The stories in these three books are in a format called [[Huaben|Huaben]] (话本), a novella or short novel.
title: Stories Old and New

abstract: Breaking Clean is a [[memoir|memoir]] by [[Judy Blunt|Judy Blunt]], published in 2002, after a decade in the writing. The book is about Blunt's life in the [[countryside|Rural area]] of eastern [[Montana|Montana]], in the [[United States|United States]]. In the book the author describes her childhood, and how growing up on a [[ranch|ranch]] conditioned her whole life.
title: Breaking Clean

abstract: Let Them Eat Precaution: How Politics is Undermining the Genetic Revolution in Agriculture is a 2005 book edited by American author and journalist [[Jon Entine|Jon Entine]], about how politics is affecting the use of genetically modified food. The 10 contributing authors from the United States and the United Kingdom provide insights into the benefits of agricultural biotechnology, offer an international perspective on why some groups are opposed to it, and suggest potential solutions to the controversy.
title: Let Them Eat Precaution

abstract: The President's Keepers: Those Keeping Zuma in Power and out of Prison (2017) is a book by [[Jacques Pauw|Jacques Pauw]], an [[investigative journalist|investigative journalist]] from [[South Africa|South Africa]] about allegedly corrupt and compromised power networks in the government of [[President|President of South Africa]] [[Jacob Zuma|Jacob Zuma]].
title: The President's Keepers

abstract: Skeleton Crew is a collection of short fiction by American writer [[Stephen King|Stephen King]], published by Putnam in June 1985. A limited edition of a thousand copies was published by Scream/Press in October 1985 (), illustrated by J. K. Potter, containing an additional short story, "The Revelations of 'Becka Paulson", which had originally appeared in [[Rolling Stone|Rolling Stone]] magazine (July 19 – August 2, 1984), and was later incorporated into King's 1987 novel [[The Tommyknockers|The Tommyknockers]]. The original title of this book was Night Moves.
title: Skeleton Crew

abstract: Crime and Punishment focuses on the mental anguish and moral dilemmas of [[Rodion Raskolnikov|Rodion Raskolnikov]], an impoverished ex-student in [[Saint Petersburg|Saint Petersburg]] who formulates a plan to kill an unscrupulous pawnbroker for her money. Before the killing, Raskolnikov believes that with the money he could liberate himself from poverty and go on to perform great deeds; but afterwards he finds himself racked with confusion, paranoia, and disgust for what he has done. His moral justifications disintegrate completely as he struggles with guilt and horror, and confronts the real world consequences of his deed.
title: Crime and Punishment

abstract: The Brothers Karamazov is a passionate [[philosophical novel|philosophical novel]] set in 19th-century Russia, that enters deeply into the [[ethical|ethical]] [[debates of God|Problem of evil]], [[free will|free will]], and [[morality|morality]]. It is a spiritual drama of moral struggles concerning faith, doubt, judgment, and [[reason|reason]], set against a modernizing Russia, with a plot which revolves around the subject of [[patricide|patricide]]. Dostoevsky composed much of the novel in [[Staraya Russa|Staraya Russa]], which inspired the main setting. Since its publication, it has been acclaimed as one of the supreme achievements in [[world literature|world literature]].
title: The Brothers Karamazov

abstract: After a long list of works written earlier in his career, including [[Troilus and Criseyde|Troilus and Criseyde]], [[House of Fame|House of Fame]], and [[Parliament of Fowls|Parlement of Foules]], The Canterbury Tales is near-unanimously seen as Chaucer's [[magnum opus|Masterpiece]]. He uses the tales and descriptions of its characters to paint an ironic and critical portrait of English society at the time, and particularly of the Church. Chaucer's use of such a wide range of classes and types of people was without precedent in English. Although the characters are fictional, they still offer a variety of insights into customs and practices of the time. Often, such insight leads to a variety of discussions and disagreements among people in the 14th century. For example, although various social classes are represented in these stories and all of the pilgrims are on a spiritual quest, it is apparent that they are more concerned with worldly things than spiritual. Structurally, the collection resembles Giovanni Boccaccio's [[The Decameron|The Decameron]], which Chaucer may have read during his first diplomatic mission to [[Italy|Italy in the Middle Ages]] in 1372.
title: The Canterbury Tales

abstract: Pride and Prejudice is an 1813 romantic novel by [[Jane Austen|Jane Austen]]. It charts the emotional development of the protagonist [[Elizabeth Bennet|Elizabeth Bennet]], who learns the error of making hasty judgments and comes to appreciate the difference between the superficial and the essential. The comedy of the writing lies in the depiction of manners, education, marriage and money during the [[Regency era|Regency era]] in Britain.
title: Pride and Prejudice

abstract: The Code of Laws of the United States of America (variously abbreviated to Code of Laws of the United States, United States Code, U.S. Code, U.S.C., or USC) is the official compilation and [[codification|Codification (law)]] of the general and permanent [[federal statutes|Law of the United States#Federal law]] of the [[United States|United States]]. It contains 53 titles (Titles 1–54, excepting Title 53, it being reserved). The main edition is published every six years by the [[Office of the Law Revision Counsel|Office of the Law Revision Counsel]] of the [[House of Representatives|United States House of Representatives]], and cumulative supplements are published annually. The official version of those laws not codified in the United States Code can be found in [[United States Statutes at Large|United States Statutes at Large]].
title: United States Code

abstract: Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone is a [[fantasy novel|fantasy novel]] written by British author [[J. K. Rowling|J. K. Rowling]]. The first novel in the [[Harry Potter|Harry Potter]] series and Rowling's [[debut novel|debut novel]], it follows [[Harry Potter|Harry Potter (character)]], a young [[wizard|Wizard (fantasy)]] who discovers his magical heritage on his eleventh birthday, when he receives a letter of acceptance to [[Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry|Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry]]. Harry makes close friends and a few enemies during his first year at the school, and with the help of his friends, Harry faces an attempted comeback by the dark wizard [[Lord Voldemort|Lord Voldemort]], who killed Harry's parents, but failed to kill Harry when he was just 15 months old.
title: Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone

abstract: Around the World in Eighty Days () is an [[adventure novel|adventure novel]] by the [[French writer|French literature]] [[Jules Verne|Jules Verne]], published in 1873. In the story, [[Phileas Fogg|Phileas Fogg]] of [[London|London]] and his newly employed [[French|French people]] [[valet|valet]] [[Passepartout|Jean Passepartout]] attempt to [[circumnavigate|Circumnavigation]] the world in 80 days on a £20,000 [[wager|Gambling]] (£2,075,400 in 2017) set by his friends at the [[Reform Club|Reform Club]]. It is one of Verne's most acclaimed works.
title: Around the World in Eighty Days

abstract: The Egyptian (Sinuhe egyptiläinen, Sinuhe the Egyptian) is a [[historical novel|historical novel]] by [[Mika Waltari|Mika Waltari]]. It was first published in [[Finnish|Finnish language]] in 1945, and in an abridged [[English|English language]] translation by Naomi Walford in 1949, from Swedish rather than Finnish. So far, it is the only Finnish novel to be adapted into a [[Hollywood film|The Egyptian (film)]], which happened in 1954. It's regarded as "one of the greatest books in Finnish literary history".
title: The Egyptian

abstract: Either/Or portrays two [[life views|world view]]. Each life view is written and represented by a fictional pseudonymous author, with the prose of the work reflecting and depending on the life view being discussed. For example, the aesthetic life view is written in short essay form, with poetic imagery and [[allusion|allusions]], discussing aesthetic topics such as [[music|music]], [[seduction|seduction]], [[drama|drama]], and [[beauty|beauty]]. The ethical life view is written as two long letters, with a more argumentative and restrained prose, discussing [[moral responsibility|moral responsibility]], [[critical reflection|Human self-reflection]], and [[marriage|marriage]]. The views of the book are not neatly summarized, but are expressed as lived experiences embodied by the pseudonymous authors. The book's central concern is the primal question asked by [[Aristotle|Aristotle]], "How should we live?" His book was certainly informed by [[Epictetus|Epictetus]]; "Consider first, man, what the matter is, and what your own nature is able to bear. If you would be a wrestler, consider your shoulders, your back, your thighs; for different persons are made for different things. Do you think that you can act as you do and be a philosopher, that you can eat, drink, be angry, be discontented, as you are now? You must watch, you must labor, you must get the better of certain appetites, must quit your acquaintances, be despised by your servant, be laughed at by those you meet; come off worse than others in everything—in offices, in honors, before tribunals. When you have fully considered all these things, approach, if you please—that is, if, by parting with them, you have a mind to purchase serenity, freedom, and tranquillity. If not, do not come hither; do not, like children, be now a philosopher, then a publican, then an orator, and then one of Caesar’s officers. These things are not consistent. You must be one man, either good or bad. You must cultivate either your own reason or else externals; apply yourself either to things within or without you—that is, be either a philosopher or one of the mob." His motto comes from [[Plutarch|Plutarch]], "The deceived is wiser than one not deceived."
title: Either/Or

abstract: Winesburg, Ohio (full title: Winesburg, Ohio: A Group of Tales of Ohio Small-Town Life) is a 1919 [[short story cycle|short story cycle]] by the American author [[Sherwood Anderson|Sherwood Anderson]]. The work is structured around the life of protagonist George Willard, from the time he was a child to his growing independence and ultimate abandonment of Winesburg as a young man. It is set in the fictional town of Winesburg, Ohio (not to be confused with the [[actual Winesburg|Winesburg, Ohio (town)]]), which is based loosely on the author's childhood memories of [[Clyde, Ohio|Clyde, Ohio]].
title: Winesburg, Ohio

abstract: On the Road is a novel by American writer [[Jack Kerouac|Jack Kerouac]], based on the travels of Kerouac and his friends across the United States. It is considered a defining work of the postwar [[Beat|Beat Generation]] and [[Counterculture|Counterculture of the 1960s]] generations, with its protagonists living life against a backdrop of jazz, poetry, and drug use. The novel, published in 1957, is a [[roman à clef|roman à clef]], with many key figures of the Beat movement, such as [[William S. Burroughs|William S. Burroughs]] (Old Bull Lee), [[Allen Ginsberg|Allen Ginsberg]] (Carlo Marx) and [[Neal Cassady|Neal Cassady]] (Dean Moriarty) represented by characters in the book, including Kerouac himself as the narrator Sal Paradise.
title: On the Road

abstract: The series consists of two groups. The first group consists of books 1-28, in which [[Morgan Le Fay|Morgan Le Fay]] sends Jack and Annie Smith, two normal children who are siblings from the fictional small town of Frog Creek, Pennsylvania, on numerous adventures and missions with a magical tree house. The second group, referred to as the Magic Tree House "Merlin Missions," begins with book 29, Christmas in Camelot. In the Merlin Missions, Jack and Annie have quests from the ancient wizard [[Merlin the Magician|Merlin the Magician]]. These books are longer than the previous 28, and some take place in fantasy realms like [[Camelot|Camelot]]. Kathleen and Teddy are two apprentices who befriend Jack and Annie during their adventures, with one of these adventures being to free Teddy from a spell. The two occasionally join Jack and Annie, and, when they don't, provide them support instead. During Super Edition #1, Teddy sends them on a mission instead of Morgan or Merlin. The companion "Magic Tree House Fact Trackers" are co-written by Mary Pope Osborne with her husband Will Osborne or her sister Natalie Pope Boyce.
title: Magic Tree House

abstract: Lorna Doone: A Romance of Exmoor is a novel by English author [[Richard Doddridge Blackmore|Richard Doddridge Blackmore]], published in 1869. It is a romance based on a group of historical characters and set in the late 17th century in [[Devon|Devon]] and [[Somerset|Somerset]], particularly around the [[East Lyn Valley|East Lyn Valley]] area of [[Exmoor|Exmoor]]. In 2003, the novel was listed on the BBC's survey [[The Big Read|The Big Read]].
title: Lorna Doone

abstract: The Swarm War is a novel set in the [[Star Wars expanded universe|Star Wars expanded universe]]. It is the third and final book in [[Troy Denning|Troy Denning]]'s [[Dark Nest|Dark Nest Trilogy]] Trilogy. The book is set 35 years after the events of [[Star Wars Episode IV: A New Hope|Star Wars Episode IV: A New Hope]].
title: The Swarm War

abstract: The [[tenth edition of this book|10th edition of Systema Naturae]] (1758) is considered the starting point of [[zoological nomenclature|zoological nomenclature]]. In 1766–1768 Linnaeus published the much enhanced [[12th edition|12th edition of Systema Naturae]], the last under his authorship. Another again enhanced work in the same style and entitled "" was published by [[Johann Friedrich Gmelin|Johann Friedrich Gmelin]] between 1788 and 1793. Since at least the early 1900s zoologists commonly recognized this as the last edition belonging to this series. It was also officially regarded by the [[ICZN|International Commission on Zoological Nomenclature]] in Opinion 296 (26 Oct 1954) as the 13th edition of Systema Naturae.
title: Systema Naturae

abstract: Anne's House of Dreams is a novel by [[Canadian|Canadians]] author [[Lucy Maud Montgomery|Lucy Maud Montgomery]]. It was first published in 1917 by [[McClelland, Goodchild and Stewart|McClelland and Stewart]].
title: Anne's House of Dreams

abstract: Anne of Windy Poplars—published as Anne of Windy Willows in the UK, Australia, and Japan—is an [[epistolary novel|epistolary novel]] by Canadian author [[L. M. Montgomery|L. M. Montgomery]]. First published in 1936 by [[McClelland and Stewart|McClelland and Stewart]], it details [[Anne Shirley|Anne Shirley]]'s experiences over three years teaching at a high school in [[Summerside, Prince Edward Island|Summerside, Prince Edward Island]]. The novel features a series of letters Anne sends to her intended, [[Gilbert Blythe|Gilbert Blythe]], who is completing medical school. Chronologically, the book is fourth in the series, but it was the seventh book written.
title: Anne of Windy Poplars

abstract: Vestiges of the Natural History of Creation is an 1844 work of speculative [[natural history|natural history]] and philosophy by [[Robert Chambers|Robert Chambers (publisher born 1802)]]. Published anonymously in England, it brought together various ideas of [[stellar evolution|stellar evolution]] with the progressive [[transmutation of species|transmutation of species]] in an accessible narrative which tied together numerous scientific theories of the age.
title: Vestiges of the Natural History of Creation

abstract: The Book of the Long Sun (1993–1996) is a series of four [[science fantasy|science fantasy]] novels or one four-volume novel by the [[American|United States]] author [[Gene Wolfe|Gene Wolfe]]. It is set in the same universe as [[The Book of the New Sun|The Book of the New Sun]] series that Wolfe inaugurated in 1980, and the Internet Science Fiction Database catalogs them both as sub-series of the "Solar Cycle", along with other writings.
title: The Book of the Long Sun

abstract: The Science Fiction Hall of Fame, Volume One, 1929–1964 is a 1970 anthology of English language [[science fiction|science fiction]] short stories, edited by [[Robert Silverberg|Robert Silverberg]]. Author [[Lester del Rey|Lester del Rey]] said that "it even lives up to its subtitle", referring to the volume's boast of containing "The Greatest Science-Fiction Stories of All Time".
title: The Science Fiction Hall of Fame, Volume One, 1929–1964

abstract: Theory of Colours (German: Zur Farbenlehre) is a book by [[Johann Wolfgang von Goethe|Johann Wolfgang von Goethe]] about the poet's views on the nature of [[colours|color]] and how these are perceived by humans. It was published in German in 1810 and in English in 1840. The book contains detailed descriptions of phenomena such as [[coloured shadows|Complementary colors]], [[refraction|refraction]], and [[chromatic aberration|chromatic aberration]].
title: Theory of Colours

abstract: A Treatise of Human Nature (1738–40) is a book by Scottish philosopher [[David Hume|David Hume]], considered by many to be Hume's most important work and one of the most influential works in the history of philosophy. The Treatise is a classic statement of philosophical [[empiricism|empiricism]], [[skepticism|skepticism]], and [[naturalism|Naturalism (philosophy)]]. In the introduction Hume presents the idea of placing all science and philosophy on a novel foundation: namely, an [[empirical investigation|Empirical evidence]] into [[human nature|human nature]]. Impressed by [[Isaac Newton|Isaac Newton]]'s achievements in the physical sciences, Hume sought to introduce the same experimental method of reasoning into the study of human psychology, with the aim of discovering the "extent and force of human understanding". Against the philosophical [[rationalists|Rationalism]], Hume argues that passion rather than reason governs human behaviour. He introduces the famous [[problem of induction|problem of induction]], arguing that inductive reasoning and our beliefs regarding [[cause and effect|Causality]] cannot be justified by reason; instead, our faith in induction and causation is the result of mental habit and custom. Hume defends a [[sentimentalist|Moral sense theory]] account of morality, arguing that ethics is based on sentiment and passion rather than reason, and famously declaring that "reason is, and ought only to be the slave to the passions". Hume also offers a skeptical theory of [[personal identity|personal identity]] and a [[compatibilist|Compatibilism]] account of free will.
title: A Treatise of Human Nature

abstract: Horrible Science is a similar [[series|book series]] of books to [[Horrible Histories|Horrible Histories]], written by [[Nick Arnold|Nick Arnold (writer)]] (with the exception of Evolve or Die, which is written by Phil Gates), illustrated by Tony de Saulles and published in the [[UK|United Kingdom]] and India by [[Scholastic|Scholastic Press]]. They are designed to get children interested in [[science|science]] by concentrating on the trivial, unusual, gory, or unpleasant. The books are in circulation in 24 countries, and over 4 million books have been sold in the UK alone.
title: Horrible Science

abstract: The Historian has been described as a combination of genres, including [[Gothic novel|Gothic fiction]], [[adventure novel|adventure novel]], [[detective fiction|detective fiction]], [[travelogue|Travel literature]], [[postmodern|postmodern]] historical novel, [[epistolary|epistolary novel]] [[epic|Epic poetry]], and historical [[thriller|Thriller (genre)]]. Kostova was intent on writing a serious work of literature and saw herself as an inheritor of the [[Victorian|Victorian era]] style. Although based in part on [[Bram Stoker|Bram Stoker]]'s [[Dracula|Dracula]], The Historian is not a horror novel, but rather an eerie tale. It is concerned with history's role in society and representation in books, as well as the nature of good and evil. As Kostova explains, "Dracula is a metaphor for the evil that is so hard to undo in history." The evils brought about by religious conflict are a particular theme, and the novel explores the relationship between the Christian West and the Islamic East.
title: The Historian

abstract: The Civil War: A Narrative (1958–1974) is a three volume, 2,968-page, 1.2 million-word history of the [[American Civil War|American Civil War]] by [[Shelby Foote|Shelby Foote]]. Although previously known as a [[novelist|novelist]], Foote is most famous for this non-fictional narrative history. While it touches on political and social themes, the main thrust of the work is [[military history|military history]]. The individual volumes include Fort Sumter to Perryville (1958), Fredericksburg to Meridian (1963), and Red River to Appomattox (1974).
title: The Civil War: A Narrative

abstract: Power: A New Social Analysis by Bertrand Russell (1st imp. London 1938, [[Allen & Unwin|Allen & Unwin]], 328 pp.) is a work in [[social philosophy|social philosophy]] written by [[Bertrand Russell|Bertrand Russell]]. Power, for Russell, is one's ability to achieve goals. In particular, Russell has in mind [[social power|Power (sociology)]], that is, power over people.
title: Power: A New Social Analysis

abstract: Thirteen Reasons Why is a [[young adult novel|young adult fiction]] written in 2007 by [[Jay Asher|Jay Asher]]. It is the story of a young high school student as she descends into despair brought on by betrayal and [[bullying|School bullying]], culminating with her [[suicide|suicide]]. She details the thirteen reasons why in an audio diary which is mailed to a friend two weeks after her death.
title: Thirteen Reasons Why

abstract: Galactic North is a collection of [[science fiction|science fiction]] short stories by British author [[Alastair Reynolds|Alastair Reynolds]], published by [[Gollancz|Victor Gollancz Ltd]] in 2006. It comprises most of Reynold's short stories and novellas set in the [[Revelation Space universe|Revelation Space universe]].
title: Galactic North

abstract: Zorba the Hutt's Revenge is the third book of the [[Jedi Prince|Jedi Prince]] series by [[Paul Davids|Paul Davids]] and Hollace Davids, and was released in July 1992. It is preceded by the novel [[The Lost City of the Jedi|The Lost City of the Jedi]] and followed by the novel [[Mission from Mount Yoda|Mission from Mount Yoda]].
title: Zorba the Hutt's Revenge

abstract: Prophets of the Dark Side is the sixth book of the [[Jedi Prince|Jedi Prince]] series by [[Paul Davids and Hollace Davids|Paul Davids]], and was released in May 1993.
title: Prophets of the Dark Side

abstract: Systems of Survival: A Dialogue on the Moral Foundations of Commerce and Politics is a book written by American urban activist [[Jane Jacobs|Jane Jacobs]] in 1992.
title: Systems of Survival

abstract: Short Trips: A Christmas Treasury is a [[Big Finish|Big Finish Productions]] original anthology edited by [[Paul Cornell|Paul Cornell]] and based on the long-running British [[science fiction television|science fiction on television]] series [[Doctor Who|Doctor Who]]. The collection is the first [[Christmas|Christmas]] book in the [[Short Trips|Big Finish Short Trips]] range.
title: Short Trips: A Christmas Treasury

abstract: The Bluejacket's Manual is the basic handbook for [[United States Navy|United States Navy]] personnel. First issued in 1902 to teach new recruits about [[naval|naval]] procedures and life and offer a reference for active sailors, it has become the "bible" for Navy personnel, providing information about a wide range of Navy topics. The current version, issued in 2017, is the 25th Edition and is given to all enlistees.
title: The Bluejacket's Manual

abstract: El Llano en llamas (translated into English as "The Burning Plain and other Stories" and as "The Plain in Flames") is a collection of short stories written in Spanish by Mexican author [[Juan Rulfo|Juan Rulfo]] and first published in 1953.
title: El Llano en llamas

abstract: When You Reach Me is a [[Newbery Medal|Newbery Medal]]-winning science fiction and [[mystery|Mystery fiction]] novel by [[Rebecca Stead|Rebecca Stead]], published in 2009. It takes place in the [[Upper West Side|Upper West Side]] in New York during 1978 and 1979 and follows the protagonist, Miranda Sinclair. She receives a strange note asking her to record future events and write down to the location of her spare key. As the novel progresses, Miranda receives three more notes with requests. The novel contains three story lines   — the appearance of Miranda's mom on the game show, [[The $20,000 Pyramid|Pyramid (game show)]], Miranda's best friend Sal suddenly not talking with Miranda, and the appearance of a laughing man. Central themes in the novel include independence, redemption and friendship. Stead also wanted to demonstrate the possibilities that she saw in time travel. The author hoped to show her children what New York was like in her childhood, and demonstrate how in an earlier time children were more independent.
title: When You Reach Me

abstract: The Oxford Book of English Madrigals was edited by [[Philip Ledger|Philip Ledger]], and published in 1978 by the [[Oxford University Press|Oxford University Press]]. It contains words and full music for some 60 of the [[madrigal|madrigal (music)s]] and songs of the [[English Madrigal School|English Madrigal School]].
title: The Oxford Book of English Madrigals

abstract: The Natural History and Antiquities of Selborne, or just The Natural History of Selborne is a book by English [[naturalist|natural history]] and [[ornithologist|Ornithology]] [[Gilbert White|Gilbert White]]. It was first published in 1789 by his brother [[Benjamin|Benjamin White (publisher)]]. It has been continuously in print since then, with nearly 300 editions up to 2007.
title: The Natural History and Antiquities of Selborne

abstract: Venus Preserved is a 2003 [[fantasy|fantasy]]/[[science fiction|science fiction]] novel by [[World Fantasy Award|World Fantasy Award]] and [[British Fantasy Award|British Fantasy Award]] winner [[Tanith Lee|Tanith Lee]]. Set in a doomed state of a fictitious, alternate [[Venice|Venice]], Venus Preserved is the fourth installment in Lee's The Secret Books of Venus series. The novel, set centuries in the future, follows the main character, Picaro, as he follows his cursed fate to the undersea city of Venus. Over the course of the story, the city, controlled by a futuristic computer automated network, is experimenting with human revitalization, which ultimately takes a turn for an absurdly shocking worse.
title: Venus Preserved

abstract: Gaiman won both the British [[Carnegie Medal|Carnegie Medal (literary award)]] and the American [[Newbery Medal|Newbery Medal]] recognizing the year's best children's books, the first time both named the same work. The Graveyard Book also won the annual [[Hugo Award for Best Novel|Hugo Award for Best Novel]] from the [[World Science Fiction Convention|World Science Fiction Convention]] and [[Locus Award for Best Young Adult Book|Locus Award for Best Young Adult Book]] selected by [[Locus magazine|Locus magazine]] subscribers.
title: The Graveyard Book

abstract: Feeling Very Strange: The Slipstream Anthology is an anthology of [[slipstream|slipstream (genre)]] fiction, edited by [[James Patrick Kelly|James Patrick Kelly]] and [[John Kessel|John Kessel]], published in 2006 by [[Tachyon Publications|Tachyon Publications]].
title: Feeling Very Strange: The Slipstream Anthology

abstract: Ten Birds is a picture book written and illustrated by Cybèle Young and published in 2011. The children’s [[fable|fable]] is about ten birds trying to find a way to cross the river. Using numbers and clever ways of thinking, the birds cross the river one at a time. The story is aimed towards children in grades 1-3 to teach them valuable skills, from counting to the importance of critical thinking. Cybèle’s book received the [[2011 Governor General's Awards|2011 Governor General's Awards]] . Illustrations in the book were drawn with pen and ink, making the pictures very intricate as well as black and white.
title: Ten Birds

abstract: Paws and Whiskers is a 2014 fundraising anthology for the [[Battersea Dogs and Cats Home|Battersea Dogs and Cats Home]], featuring some of the best children's stories about cats and dogs of all time, selected by multi-award-winning and best-selling children's author [[Jacqueline Wilson|Jacqueline Wilson]], with illustrations by [[Nick Sharratt|Nick Sharratt]]. Published 13 February 2014 by Doubleday Children's, the book includes a new story by Wilson, Leonie's Pet Cat, as well as extracts from such classics as [[The Hundred and One Dalmatians|The Hundred and One Dalmatians]], by Dodie Smith, and [[Through the Looking Glass|Through the Looking Glass]] by Lewis Carroll.
title: Paws and Whiskers

abstract: 1001 Vrouwen uit de Nederlandse geschiedenis is a compilation of 1001 biographies of famous women of the Netherlands spanning roughly 1700 years.
title: 1001 Vrouwen uit de Nederlandse geschiedenis

abstract: Phaidon Design Classics is a British three volume set of [[reference books|Reference work]] on [[industrial design|industrial design]] since the 17th century.
title: Phaidon Design Classics

abstract: The Gates Ajar is an 1868 religious novel by [[Elizabeth Stuart Phelps|Elizabeth Stuart Phelps Ward]] (later Elizabeth Phelps Ward) that was immensely popular following its publication. It was the second [[best-selling|best-selling]] religious novel of the 19th century. 80,000 copies were sold in America by 1900; 100,000 were sold in England during the same time period. Sequels Beyond the Gates (1883) and The Gates Between (1887) were also bestsellers, and the three together are referred to as the author's "Spiritualist novels."
title: The Gates Ajar

abstract: Traci Lords: Underneath It All is an [[autobiography|autobiography]] by American actress and singer [[Traci Lords|Traci Lords]], first published on July 8, 2003 by [[HarperCollins|HarperCollins]]. It was [[reissue|reissued]] as a [[paperback|paperback]] on June 29, 2004, with an additional chapter and photos. The book primarily details Lords' career in the [[adult film industry|Pornography]], when she appeared underage in dozens of [[pornographic film|pornographic films]] and became one of the most notable [[pornstars|Pornographic film actor]] of the 1980s. It also chronicles her childhood, transition to mainstream films and musical career.
title: Traci Lords: Underneath It All

abstract: The Essential Book of K9 is a [[science fiction|science fiction]] anthology book by Paul M. Tams and [[Bob Baker|Bob Baker (scriptwriter)]] based-off the television series [[Doctor Who|Doctor Who]] and focuses on the character [[K9|K9 (Doctor Who)]]. The book was released in 2015 and published by Meteoric Books.
title: The Essential Book of K9

abstract: Imaginary Lives (original [[French|French language]] title: Vies imaginaires) is a collection of twenty-two semi-biographical [[short stories|short stories]] by [[Marcel Schwob|Marcel Schwob]], first published in book form in 1896. Mixing known and fantastical elements, it was one of the first works in the genre of [[biographical fiction|Biography in literature]]. The book is an acknowledged influence in [[Jorge Luis Borges|Jorge Luis Borges]]'s first book [[A Universal History of Infamy|A Universal History of Infamy]]. Borges also translated the last story "Burke and Hare, Assassins" into Spanish.
title: Imaginary Lives

abstract: An Ember in the Ashes is a [[fantasy novel|fantasy novel]] written by Pakistani-American author [[Sabaa Tahir|Sabaa Tahir]]. It was published on April 28, 2015 by [[Razorbill|Penguin Group]], an imprint of [[Penguin Random House|Penguin Random House]]. It is the first book in the [[An Ember in the Ashes|An Ember in the Ashes (series)]] series, followed by [[A Torch Against the Night|A Torch Against the Night]]. In a fantasy world inspired by [[Ancient Rome|Ancient Rome]], the story follows a girl named Laia spying for rebels against the reigning empire in exchange for their help in rescuing her captive brother; and a boy named Elias struggling to free himself from being an enforcer of a tyrannical regime. The novel is narrated in the [[first-person|First-person narrative]], alternating between the points of view of Laia and Elias.
title: An Ember in the Ashes

abstract: In part, Political Animals and Animal Politics arose from a [[workshop|academic workshop]] that Wissenburg and Schlosberg organised at the 2012 [[European Consortium for Political Research|European Consortium for Political Research]] Joint Sessions [[conference|academic conference]], though not all attendees contributed to the volume and not all contributors presented at the workshop. Footage of the workshop appeared in De Haas in de Marathon (The Pacer in the Marathon), a 2012 documentary about the Dutch [[Party for the Animals|Party for the Animals]]. Political Animals and Animal Politics was published as part of the [[Palgrave Macmillan Animal Ethics Series|Palgrave Macmillan Animal Ethics Series]], edited by [[Andrew Linzey|Andrew Linzey]] and [[Priscilla Cohn|Priscilla Cohn]].
title: Political Animals and Animal Politics

abstract: Compendium ferculorum, albo Zebranie potraw (A Collection of Dishes) is a cookbook by [[Stanisław Czerniecki|Stanisław Czerniecki]]. First put in print in 1682, it is the earliest cookery book published originally in Polish. Czerniecki wrote it in his capacity as [[head chef|head chef]] at the court of the [[house of Lubomirski|house of Lubomirski]] and dedicated it to Princess [[Helena Tekla Lubomirska|Helena Tekla Lubomirska]]. The book contains more than 300 recipes, divided into three chapters of about 100 recipes each.
title: Compendium ferculorum, albo Zebranie potraw

abstract: Whitney, My Love is the first book published by author [[Judith McNaught|Judith McNaught]]. While written first, it the second novel in the Westmoreland Dynasty Saga, preceded by [[A Kingdom of Dreams|A Kingdom of Dreams]] (1989) and followed by Until You (1994), "Miracles" (1995/7), and Someone Like You (2017).
title: Whitney, My Love

abstract: The Governance of China is a Chinese political book in two volumes written by [[Xi Jinping|Xi Jinping]], the [[general secretary|General Secretary of the Communist Party of China]] of the [[Communist Party of China|Communist Party of China]] and current [[president|President of the People's Republic of China]] of the [[People's Republic of China|People's Republic of China]]. The first volume was published in 2014, and the second volume was published in 2017. The work is a collection of several dozen speeches and writings by Xi on a variety of topics, which present an official [[party line|party line (politics)]] for China's development in the 21st century. In these respects, Governance of China is a literary successor to [[Mao Zedong|Mao Zedong]]'s [[Quotations from Chairman Mao Tse-tung|Quotations from Chairman Mao Tse-tung]].
title: The Governance of China

abstract: Euclid's Elements has been referred to as the most successful and influential textbook ever written. It was one of the very earliest mathematical works to be printed after the [[invention of the printing press|movable type]] and has been estimated to be second only to the [[Bible|Bible]] in the number of editions published since the first printing in 1482, with the number reaching well over one thousand. For centuries, when the [[quadrivium|quadrivium]] was included in the curriculum of all university students, knowledge of at least part of Euclid's Elements was required of all students. Not until the 20th century, by which time its content was universally taught through other school textbooks, did it cease to be considered something all educated people had read.
title: Euclid's Elements

abstract: Quotations from Chairman Mao Tse-tung () is a book of statements from speeches and writings by [[Mao Zedong|Mao Zedong]] (formerly [[romanized|Romanization of Chinese]] as Mao Tse-tung), the former [[Chairman of the Communist Party of China|Chairman of the Communist Party of China]], published from 1964 to about 1976 and widely distributed during the [[Cultural Revolution|Cultural Revolution]].
title: Quotations from Chairman Mao Tse-tung

abstract: The Canon of Medicine remained a medical authority for centuries. It set the standards for medicine in Medieval Europe and the Islamic world and was used as a standard medical textbook through the 18th century in Europe. It is still used in [[Yunani medicine|Yunani medicine]], a form of traditional medicine practiced in India.
title: The Canon of Medicine

abstract: Etymologiae ([[Latin|Latin]] for "The Etymologies"), also known as the Origines ("Origins") and usually abbreviated Orig., is an [[etymological|etymology]] [[encyclopedia|encyclopedia]] compiled by [[Isidore of Seville|Isidore of Seville]] (c.   560–636) towards the end of his life. Isidore was encouraged to write the book by his friend [[Braulio, Bishop of Saragossa|Braulio of Zaragoza]]. The Etymologies summarized and organized a wealth of knowledge from hundreds of classical sources; three of its books are derived largely from [[Pliny the Elder|Pliny the Elder]]'s [[Natural History|Natural History (Pliny)]]. Isidore acknowledges Pliny, but not his other principal sources, namely Cassiodorus, Servius and Solinus. The work contains whatever Isidore, an influential [[Christian|Christianity]] bishop, thought worth keeping. Its subject matter is extremely diverse, ranging from grammar and rhetoric to the earth and the cosmos, buildings, metals, war, ships, humans, animals, medicine, law, religions and the hierarchies of angels and saints.
title: Etymologiae

abstract: The book originated as the short story "[[Ender's Game|Ender's Game (short story)]]", published in the August 1977 issue of [[Analog Science Fiction and Fact|Analog Science Fiction and Fact]]. Elaborating on characters and plot lines depicted in the novel, Card later wrote additional books to form the [[Ender's Game series|Ender's Game (series)]]. Card released an updated version of Ender's Game in 1991, changing some political facts to reflect the times more accurately; e.g., to include the collapse of the [[Soviet Union|Soviet Union]] and the end of the [[Cold War|Cold War]].
title: Ender's Game

abstract: The story has been made into [[the 1962 feature film of the same name|The Day of the Triffids (film)]], three radio drama series (in 1957, 1968 and 2008), and two TV series (in [[1981|The Day of the Triffids (1981 TV series)]] and [[2009|The Day of the Triffids (miniseries)]]). It was nominated for the [[International Fantasy Award|International Fantasy Award]] in 1952, and in 2003 the novel was listed on the [[BBC|BBC]]'s survey [[The Big Read|The Big Read]].
title: The Day of the Triffids

abstract: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets is a [[fantasy novel|fantasy novel]] written by British author [[J. K. Rowling|J. K. Rowling]] and the second novel in the [[Harry Potter|Harry Potter]] series. The plot follows [[Harry|Harry Potter (character)]]'s second year at [[Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry|Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry]], during which a series of messages on the walls of the school's corridors warn that the "[[Chamber of Secrets|Chamber of Secrets]]" has been opened and that the "heir of [[Slytherin|Slytherin]]" would kill all pupils who do not come from all-magical families. These threats are found after attacks which leave residents of the school petrified. Throughout the year, Harry and his friends [[Ron|Ron Weasley]] and [[Hermione|Hermione Granger]] investigate the attacks.
title: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets

abstract: How to Solve It suggests the following steps when solving a [[mathematical problem|mathematical problem]]:
title: How to Solve It

abstract: The Éléments de géométrie algébrique ("Elements of [[Algebraic Geometry|algebraic geometry]]") by [[Alexander Grothendieck|Alexander Grothendieck]] (assisted by [[Jean Dieudonné|Jean Dieudonné]]), or EGA for short, is a rigorous treatise, in French, on [[algebraic geometry|algebraic geometry]] that was published (in eight parts or [[fascicles|fascicle (book)]]) from 1960 through 1967 by the [[Institut des Hautes Études Scientifiques|Institut des Hautes Études Scientifiques]]. In it, Grothendieck established systematic foundations of algebraic geometry, building upon the concept of [[schemes|Scheme (mathematics)]], which he defined. The work is now considered the foundation stone and basic reference of modern algebraic geometry.
title: Éléments de géométrie algébrique

abstract: Michael O'Donoghue (January 5, 1940   – November 8, 1994) was an American writer and performer. He was known for his [[dark and destructive style of comedy|Black comedy]] and humor, was a major contributor to [[National Lampoon magazine|National Lampoon (magazine)]], and was the first head writer of [[Saturday Night Live|Saturday Night Live]]. He was also the first performer to utter a line on that series.
title: Michael O'Donoghue

abstract: Mrs Beeton's Book of Household Management, also published as Mrs Beeton's Cookery Book, is an extensive guide to [[running a household|household management]] in [[ Victorian|Victorian era]] Britain, edited by [[Isabella Beeton|Isabella Beeton]] and first published as a book in 1861. Previously published in parts, it originally bore the title Beeton's Book of Household Management, as one of the series of guide-books published by her husband, [[Samuel Beeton|Samuel Beeton]]. The recipes were highly structured, in contrast to those in earlier cookbooks. It was illustrated with many monochrome and colour plates.
title: Mrs Beeton's Book of Household Management

abstract: Tetrabiblos () 'four books', also known in [[Greek|Ancient Greek]] as Apotelesmatiká () "Effects", and in [[Latin|Latin]] as Quadripartitum "Four Parts", is a text on the philosophy and practice of [[astrology|astrology]], written in the 2nd century AD by the [[Alexandria|Alexandrian]] scholar [[Claudius Ptolemy|Ptolemy]] ( AD 90– AD 168).Ptolemy's [[Almagest|Almagest]] was an authoritative text on [[astronomy|astronomy]] for more than a thousand years, and the Tetrabiblos, its companion volume, was equally influential in [[astrology|astrology]], the study of the effects of astronomical cycles on earthly matters. But whilst the Almagest as an astronomical authority was superseded by acceptance of the [[heliocentric model|heliocentric model]] of the [[solar system|solar system]], the Tetrabiblos remains an important theoretical work for astrology.
title: Tetrabiblos

abstract: The Art of Star Wars is a [[series of books|book series]] by various editors featuring concept art from the [[Star Wars|Star Wars]] motion picture saga. The books mainly feature artwork accompanied by a short explanation of the scene and the artist's ideas, but also script notes, posters and other information. The first books were published by [[Ballantine Books|Ballantine Books]], a subsidiary of [[Random House|Random House]], with later editions appearing under the [[DelRey|Del Rey Books]] and [[LucasBooks|LucasBooks]] [[imprint|Imprint (trade name)s]]. Later titles were published by [[Harry N. Abrams|Harry N. Abrams]].
title: The Art of Star Wars

abstract: Banglapedia: the National Encyclopedia of [[Bangladesh|Bangladesh]] is the first Bangladeshi encyclopedia. It is available in print, [[CD-ROM|CD-ROM]] format and online, in both [[Bengali|Bengali language]] and English. The print version comprises ten 500-page volumes. The first edition was published in January 2003 by the [[Asiatic Society of Bangladesh|Asiatic Society of Bangladesh]], with a plan to update it every two years. The second edition was issued in 2012.
title: Banglapedia

abstract: [[Sarah Elizabeth Utterson|Sarah Elizabeth Utterson]] Brown (1781–1851), wife of [[literary|Literature]] [[antiquary|antiquary]], collector and [[editor|Editing]] [[Edward Vernon Utterson|Edward Vernon Utterson]] (c. 1776–1856), translated the majority of Tales of the Dead from a French collection of ghost stories as "the amusement of an idle hour". Three of the stories from the French she omitted as they "did not appear equally interesting" to her. She also noted she had "considerably curtailed" her translation of "L'Amour Muet", "as it contained much matter relative to the loves of the hero and heroine, which in a compilation of this kind appeared rather misplaced". To these, Utterson added a story of her own, "The Storm" based on an incident told to her by "a female friend of very deserved literary celebrity" as having actually occurred. It was published anonymously in 1813 by White, Cochrane, and Co., replacing the original [[epigraph|Epigraph (literature)]] "Falsis terroribus implet. — [[HORAT|Horace]]" (meaning roughly "he fills [his breast] with imagined terrors") with the following quote from [[William Shakespeare|William Shakespeare]]'s [[The Tempest|The Tempest]]:
title: Tales of the Dead

abstract: Fantasmagoriana is a French anthology of [[German|Germany]] ghost stories, translated anonymously by [[Jean-Baptiste Benoît Eyriès|Jean-Baptiste Benoît Eyriès]] and published in 1812. Most of the stories are from the first two volumes of [[Johann August Apel|Johann August Apel]] and [[Friedrich Laun|Friedrich Laun]]'s (1811), with other stories by [[Johann Karl August Musäus|Johann Karl August Musäus]] and [[Heinrich Clauren|Heinrich Clauren]].
title: Fantasmagoriana

abstract: This is the sixth le Carré spy novel featuring George Smiley. [[Tinker Tailor Soldier Spy|Tinker Tailor Soldier Spy]], The Honourable Schoolboy and [[Smiley's People|Smiley's People]] were later published as an [[omnibus edition|omnibus edition]] titled [[Smiley Versus Karla|Smiley Versus Karla]] in 1982.
title: The Honourable Schoolboy

abstract: Rees's Cyclopædia, in full The Cyclopædia; or, Universal Dictionary of Arts, Sciences, and Literature was an important 19th-century [[British|British people]] [[encyclopædia|encyclopædia]] edited by Rev. [[Abraham Rees|Abraham Rees]] (1743–1825), a [[Presbyterian|Presbyterian]] minister and scholar who had edited previous editions of [[Chambers's Cyclopædia|Chambers's Cyclopaedia]].
title: Rees's Cyclopædia

abstract: The Book of Jin is an official Chinese historical text covering the history of the [[Jin dynasty|Jin dynasty (265-420)]] from 265 to 420. It was compiled in 648 by a number of officials commissioned by the imperial court of the [[Tang dynasty|Tang dynasty]], with [[chancellor|Chancellor (China)]] [[Fang Xuanling|Fang Xuanling]] as the lead editor, drawing mostly from official documents left from earlier archives. A few essays in volumes 1, 3, 54 and 80 were composed by the Tang dynasty's [[Emperor Taizong|Emperor Taizong of Tang]] himself. The contents of the Book of Jin, however, included not only the history of the Jin dynasty, but also that of the [[Sixteen Kingdoms|Sixteen Kingdoms]] period, which was contemporaneous with the Eastern Jin dynasty.
title: Book of Jin

abstract: The Spartacus International Gay Guide is an international gay travel guidebook published annually since 1970, originally by John D. Stamford, currently by [[Bruno Gmünder Verlag|Bruno Gmünder Verlag]] in [[Berlin, Germany|Berlin, Germany]].
title: Spartacus International Gay Guide

abstract: The Sketch Book of Geoffrey Crayon, Gent., commonly referred to as The Sketch Book, is a collection of 34 essays and short stories written by the American author [[Washington Irving|Washington Irving]]. It was published serially throughout 1819 and 1820. The collection includes two of Irving's best-known stories, attributed to the fictional Dutch historian [[Diedrich Knickerbocker|Diedrich Knickerbocker]]: "[[The Legend of Sleepy Hollow|The Legend of Sleepy Hollow]]" and "[[Rip Van Winkle|Rip Van Winkle]]". It also marks Irving's first use of the [[pseudonym|pseudonym]] Geoffrey Crayon, which he would continue to employ throughout his literary career.
title: The Sketch Book of Geoffrey Crayon, Gent.

abstract: The London Plan is the statutory [[spatial development|spatial planning]] strategy for the [[Greater London|Greater London]] area in the United Kingdom that is written by the [[Mayor of London|Mayor of London]] and published by the [[Greater London Authority|Greater London Authority]].
title: London Plan

abstract: Mr. Mystery is a mystery-fiction book series written by Jim Aitchison under the pseudonym of [[James Lee|James Lee (writer)]] (also the author of the [[Mr. Midnight|Mr. Midnight]] series). Unlike [[Mr. Midnight|Mr. Midnight]], it has a fixed group of main characters. The series is published by Angsana Books, Flame Of The Forest Publishing. 32 books in the series, including 6 Special Edition titles, have been published.
title: Mr. Mystery

abstract: God Speaks, The Theme of Creation and Its Purpose () is the principal book by [[Meher Baba|Meher Baba]], and the most significant [[religious text|religious text]] used by his followers. It covers Meher Baba's view of the process of Creation and its purpose and has been in print continuously since 1955.
title: God Speaks

abstract: The English-language title, "The Broken Spears", comes from a phrase in one version ([[BnF|Bibliothèque nationale de France]] MS 22bis) of the [[Annals of Tlatelolco|Annals of Tlatelolco]], xaxama[n]toc omitl. According to historian [[James Lockhart|James Lockhart (historian)]], this is a [[mistranslation|mistranslation]] resulting from confusion between the Nahuatl words mitl "arrow", "dart" or "spear", and omitl "bone"; an alternative translation is thus "broken bones".
title: The Broken Spears

abstract: The Edmonds Cookery Book is a [[recipe book|recipe book]] focusing on traditional [[New Zealand cuisine|New Zealand cuisine]]. It was first published as The Sure to Rise Cookery Book in 1908 as a marketing tool by [[baking powder|baking powder]] manufacturer [[Thomas Edmonds|Thomas Edmonds (manufacturer)]] (today part of [[Goodman Fielder|Goodman Fielder]]), but it is now known as a [[Kiwi icon|Kiwiana]].
title: Edmonds Cookery Book

abstract: The List of Seven is a 1993 novel by [[Mark Frost|Mark Frost]]. Though initially an occult murder mystery, the story brings in conspiracy theory, [[vendetta|Feud]], horror, history, and [[Theosophy|Theosophy (Blavatskian)]]. The main character is a real historical person (albeit engaging in fictional actions) and several other historical figures appear in the story.
title: The List of Seven

abstract: Economic Freedom of the World is an annual survey published by the [[libertarian|libertarian]] Canadian think tank [[Fraser Institute|Fraser Institute]]. The survey attempts to measure the degree of [[economic freedom|economic freedom]] in the world's nations. It has been used in peer-reviewed studies some of which have found a range of beneficial effects of more economic freedom.
title: Economic Freedom of the World

abstract: Short Trips: The Centenarian is a [[Big Finish|Big Finish Productions]] original anthology edited by [[Ian Farrington|Ian Farrington]] and based on the long-running British [[science fiction television|science fiction on television]] series [[Doctor Who|Doctor Who]]. The collection follows the life of a man, Edward Grainger, from his birth through to his death and explores the history of the twentieth century.
title: Short Trips: The Centenarian

abstract: Short Trips: Past Tense is a [[Big Finish|Big Finish Productions]] original [[anthology|anthology]] edited by Ian Farrington and based on the long-running British [[science fiction television|science fiction on television]] series [[Doctor Who|Doctor Who]]. The collection's theme is [[history|history]] with each story being set before the year 2000.
title: Short Trips: Past Tense

abstract: Syllabus der Pflanzenfamilien (1892–) by [[Adolf Engler|Adolf Engler]] (1844–1930) is a complete revision of plant families down to generic level and often even further. As such it forms part of the [[Engler system|Engler system]] of [[plant taxonomy|plant taxonomy]].
title: Syllabus der Pflanzenfamilien

abstract: Bumper Crop is a collection of short stories by [[Joe R. Lansdale|Joe R. Lansdale]] published in 2004 by [[Golden Gryphon Press|Golden Gryphon Press]]. In his introduction, he cites it as the companion piece to [[High Cotton|High Cotton]], because he had so many stories which didn't quite fit in with the "Best of" but were more like "personal favorites." Initially issued as a hardcover, it has been reissued as a [[trade paperback|Paperback#Trade paperback]].
title: Bumper Crop

abstract: For nearly four decades, [[Easwaran|Eknath Easwaran]] taught a method of meditation, known as [[passage meditation|Passage Meditation]], which involves focusing the mind on inspiring sacred texts, such as the [[23rd Psalm|Psalm 23]] or the Buddha's [[Discourse on Good Will|Metta Sutta]]. Throughout this time, he received inquiries about whether various texts were suitable passages for meditation. He taught that passages should meet the criteria he had learned to trust in his own practice: a passage should be "positive, practical, universal, and inspiring". and drawn from a scripture or a person whose words and life attest to spiritual realization. God Makes the Rivers to Flow grew as a collection of such passages.
title: God Makes the Rivers to Flow

abstract: Varieties of Capitalism: The Institutional Foundations of Comparative Advantage is a 2001 book on [[economics|economics]] authored by [[ political economists|political economy]] Peter A. Hall and [[David Soskice|David Soskice]].
title: Varieties of Capitalism

abstract: Death from the Skies!: These Are The Ways The World Will End is a book by the American astronomer [[Phil Plait|Phil Plait]], also known as "the Bad Astronomer". The book was published in 2008 and explores the various ways in which the human race could be rendered [[extinct|Human extinction]] by astronomical phenomena.
title: Death from the Skies!

abstract: And Then There Were None is a [[mystery novel|mystery fiction]] by English writer [[Agatha Christie|Agatha Christie]], her best selling novel and described by her as the most difficult of her books to write. It was first published in the United Kingdom by the [[Collins Crime Club|Collins Crime Club]] on 6 November 1939, as Ten Little Niggers, after the [[British blackface song|Ten Little Indians#Derivative songs and books]], which serves as a major plot point.
title: And Then There Were None

abstract: Rossetti and His Circle is a book of twenty-three [[caricatures|caricatures]] by English [[caricaturist|Caricature]], essayist and [[parodist|Parody]] [[Max Beerbohm|Max Beerbohm]]. Published in 1922 by [[William Heinemann|Heinemann (book publisher)]], the drawings were Beerbohm's humorous imaginings concerning the life of [[Dante Gabriel Rossetti|Dante Gabriel Rossetti]] and his fellow [[Pre-Raphaelites|Pre-Raphaelite Brotherhood]], the period, as he put it, "just before oneself." The book is now considered one of Beerbohm's masterpieces.
title: Rossetti and His Circle

abstract: The An Nam chí lược (literally Abbreviated Records of An Nam) is a historical text that was compiled by the [[Vietnamese|Vietnamese people]] historian [[Lê Tắc|Lê Tắc]] during his exile in [[China|China]] in early 14th century. Published for the first time in 1335 during the reign of the [[Yuan Dynasty|Yuan Dynasty]], An Nam chí lược became one of the few historical books about Đại Việt that survive from the 14th and 15th centuries and it is considered the oldest historical work by a Vietnamese that has been preserved.
title: An Nam chí lược

abstract: 50 Photographs is a [[photo book|photo book]] by [[American visual artist|visual art of the United States]] [[Jessica Lange|Jessica Lange]], published by [[powerHouse Books|powerHouse Books]] on November 18, 2008. Featuring an [[introduction|introduction (essay)]] written by the [[National Book Award|National Book Award for Nonfiction]]-winner [[Patti Smith|Patti Smith]], the [[art work|work of art]] distributed by [[Random House|Random House]] is the Lange's official debut as a [[photographer|photographer]].
title: 50 Photographs

abstract: The book was originally published in French in 1984 as Le Dalí d'Amanda. It has since been translated into no less than six languages and released in Europe, Asia and the USA. The first English language edition was released by [[Virgin Books|Virgin Books]] as My Life with Dalí in the UK in 1985. In 2004, an updated and expanded edition was released in France, entitled Mon Dalí. The book was dedicated to "[[Gala|Gala Dalí]], the patient, loving wife".
title: My Life with Dalí

abstract: The Gurkha's Daughter is a collection of short stories by [[Prajwal Parajuly|Prajwal Parajuly]], describing and dramatizing the experiences of the [[Nepalese people|Nepalese people]] and the [[Nepalese diaspora|Non Resident Nepali]]. The Hindustan Times described it as the "best short story collection you have read in a while".
title: The Gurkha's Daughter

abstract: The Essential Tagore is the largest collection of [[Rabindranath Tagore|Rabindranath Tagore]]'s works available in English. It was published by [[Harvard University Press|Harvard University Press]] in the United States and [[Visva-Bharati University|Visva-Bharati University]] in India to mark the 150th anniversary of Tagore’s birth. Dr [[Fakrul Alam|Fakrul Alam]] and Radha Chakravarty edited the anthology. Among the notable contributors who translated Tagore's works for this anthology are [[Amitav Ghosh|Amitav Ghosh]], [[Amit Chaudhuri|Amit Chaudhuri]], [[Sunetra Gupta|Sunetra Gupta]], [[Syed Manzoorul Islam|Syed Manzoorul Islam]], and [[Kaiser Haq|Kaiser Haq]]. [[Martha Nussbaum|Martha Nussbaum]], a philosopher, writer and critic proposed the book as the 'Book of the Year' in the [[New Statesman|New Statesman]] published on November 21, 2011.
title: The Essential Tagore

abstract: Other books about Madonna's life and career had been based on previously published material, but Taraborrelli's biography was the result of research spanning a decade and includes exclusive interviews with Madonna's close friends, business associates, family members, and her father, Tony Ciccone. These interviews were conducted by the author himself, as well as his team of private investigators. Taraborrelli also interviewed Madonna over the course of years, and often drew from his first-hand experiences while writing the book. Madonna: An Intimate Biography received a mixed response from critics. Some considered it a compelling piece on Madonna's life, while others thought Taraborrelli's writing was unprofessional.
title: Madonna: An Intimate Biography

abstract: Karma Cola is a non-fiction book about India written by [[Gita Mehta|Gita Mehta]] originally published in 1979.
title: Karma Cola

abstract: The Oxford Book of Science Fiction Stories is a book of [[science fiction|science fiction]] stories edited by [[Tom Shippey|Tom Shippey]], reissued in 2003.
title: The Oxford Book of Science Fiction Stories

abstract: The Plant is an unfinished [[serial novel|serial novel]] by American writer [[Stephen King|Stephen King]], published in 1982–1985 privately and in 2000 as a commercial [[e-book|e-book]].
title: The Plant

abstract: Pesme bratstva, detinjstva & potomstva: Antologija ex YU rok poezije 1967 - 2007 (trans. Songs of Brotherhood, Childhood & Offspring: Anthology of [[Ex YU|SFRY]] [[Rock|Rock music]] Poetry 1967 - 2007) is a book by [[Serbia|Serbian]] author, journalist and music critic [[Petar Janjatović|Petar Janjatović]]. Published in 2008, the book is the second, expanded edition of Janjatović's 1993 book Pesme bratstva & detinjstva: Antologija rok poezije SFR Jugoslavije 1967 - 1991 (Songs of Brotherhood & Childhood: Anthology of Rock Poetry in SFR Yugoslavia 1967 - 1991). The book features lyrics by acts from the [[former Yugoslav rock scene|Popular music in the Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia]] and the scenes of the successor states.
title: Pesme bratstva, detinjstva & potomstva: Antologija ex YU rok poezije 1967 - 2007

abstract: Tortall and Other Lands: A Collection of Tales is a collection of [[short stories|short story]] by [[young adult|young adult fiction]] [[fantasy|fantasy]] author [[Tamora Pierce|Tamora Pierce]]. The anthology includes stories set in Tortall, a fantasy kingdom appearing in many of Pierce's works, as well as stories set in the real world. In addition, besides gathering together Pierce's seven previously published short stories, Tortall and Other Lands includes three original stories written specifically for this collection.
title: Tortall and Other Lands

abstract: The Bronx Memoir Project: Vol. 1 is a [[published|Publishing]] [[anthology|anthology]] by The [[Bronx Council on the Arts|Bronx Council on the Arts]] and brought forth through a series of workshops meant to empower Bronx residents and shed the stigma on the Bronx's burning past.
title: Bronx Memoir Project: Vol. 1

abstract: Fortune Smiles is a 2015 collection of short stories by American author and novelist [[Adam Johnson|Adam Johnson (writer)]]. It is Johnson's second published short story collection, after his 2002 book [[Emporium|Emporium (short stories)]] and his first book after winning the [[Pulitzer Prize|Pulitzer Prize for Fiction#2010s]] for [[The Orphan Master's Son|The Orphan Master's Son]]. The collection includes six stories, several of which have won awards.
title: Fortune Smiles

abstract: Faithfull: An Autobiography is an [[autobiography|autobiography]] by English singer, songwriter and actress [[Marianne Faithfull|Marianne Faithfull]], written in collaboration with [[David Dalton|David Dalton (writer)]]. It was first published on 1 August 1994 by [[Little, Brown and Company|Little, Brown and Company]] and [[reissue|reissued]] as a [[paperback|paperback]] in July 1995. The book was also accompanied by the release of a compilation album Faithfull: A Collection of Her Best Recordings (1994). Faithfull: An Autobiography chronicles her childhood, career as a teenage pop star during the 1960s, relationship with [[Mick Jagger|Mick Jagger]], [[heroin addiction|Opioid use disorder]] in the 1970s, and her comeback to music industry with her album [[Broken English|Broken English (album)]] (1979).
title: Faithfull: An Autobiography

abstract: It's About a Little Bird is a [[2013|2013 in literature]] children's [[picture book|picture book]] written and illustrated by American actress-photographer [[Jessica Lange|Jessica Lange]]. The [[fairy tale|fairy tale]], however, partly based on a true story includes such [[literary genre|literary genre]] as [[fantasy|fantasy literature]], featuring also elements of [[adventure novel|adventure novel]] and [[mystery fiction|mystery fiction]]. The main [[story|short story]] itself, it revolves around friendship, love and family determination, imagination and exploration.
title: It's About a Little Bird

abstract: Ex YU rock enciklopedija 1960 - 2006 (trans.
