[[Ex YU|SFRY]] [[Rock|Rock music]] Encyclopedia 1960 - 2006) is a book by [[Serbia|Serbian]] author, journalist and music critic [[Petar Janjatović|Petar Janjatović]]. Published in 2007, the book represents the third, expanded edition of Janjatović's 1998 book Ilustrovana YU rock enciklopedija 1960 - 1997 (Illustrated YU Rock Encyclopedia 1960 - 1997). The book features information about most important acts of the [[rock scene of Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia|Popular music in the Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia]], as well as of scenes of the successor states.
title: Ex YU rock enciklopedija 1960 - 2006

abstract: Atmavritanta is an autobiography written by [[Gujarati|Gujarati language]] writer [[Manilal Nabhubhai Dwivedi|Manilal Nabhubhai Dwivedi]] (1858–1898). Its publication was prevented for many years by his family members and friends because it contains explicit details of his extramarital relations and controversial views on morals.
title: Atmavritanta

abstract: The Quality of Nationality Index (QNI) ranks the quality of nationalities based on internal and external factors. Each nationality receives an aggregated score based on their economic strength, human development, ease of travel, political stability and overseas employment opportunities for their citizens. The data is collected from various sources with quantifiable data. The QNI was created by Dimitry Kochenov, an expert in citizenship, nationality and immigration law and constitutional law of the European Union at the [[University of Groningen|University of Groningen]] and [[Christian Kälin|Christian Kälin]], chairman of [[Henley & Partners|Henley & Partners]].
title: The Quality of Nationality Index

abstract: Surfin' Guitars: Instrumental Surf Bands of the Sixties is a book by Robert J. Dalley which covers the instrumental side of the [[surf genre|Surf music]] in the 1960s and looks at groups and artists from that era. It has been published three times with the first version published in 1988 and the third in 2015. It has been quoted and referred to multiple times in books relating to surf music.
title: Surfin' Guitars: Instrumental Surf Bands of the Sixties

abstract: Shouting out to the World!: A Run for the Dream, Bigbang's 13,140 Days Challenge is a book released by South Korean group, [[BIGBANG|Big Bang (South Korean band)]], on January 28, 2009. The book is actually more a book about self-development than one that is of Bigbang’s autobiography. It's a story about 5 teenagers achieving their dreams. Each member tell the story of their own journey & growth as they pursued their dreams. They also tell their feelings after realizing their dreams and their thought about what comes afterwards.
title: Shouting out to the World!

abstract: Themple Thurston's original book opens with the author dreaming of escape to the English countryside and trying to buy a narrowboat from which to see it. After meeting with scepticism and warnings about the unsavoury nature of canal people, he is advised to go to [[Oxford|Oxford]] to view The Flower of Gloster. The boatyard owner, similarly sceptical, advises him to hire 'some decent fellar with an horse, what'll look after yer going through the locks.'. He introduces him to Eynsham Harry who, after some protracted negotiations in The Nags Head, agrees to be Temple Thurston's guide and mentor.
title: The Flower of Gloster

abstract: Right Through the Pack: A Bridge Fantasy is a 1947 book about the game of [[contract bridge|contract bridge]] by Robert Darvas and Norman de Villiers Hart. It includes 52 deals in which each of the 52 cards of the pack plays a significant role, described by and interspersed with comments from the playing cards themselves, the [[anthropomorphic|anthropomorphic]] "People of the Pack".
title: Right Through the Pack

abstract: Ini Njan Urangatte (And Now Let Me Sleep) is a [[Malayalam-language novel|Malayalam literature]] written by [[P. K. Balakrishnan|P. K. Balakrishnan]] in 1973. The novel's inspiration is the Sanskrit epic [[Mahabharata|Mahabharata]]. It may be regarded as a historically notable Malayalam-language novel as it has become a yardstick for epic Malayalam fiction, spawning many Mahabharata based-novels.
title: Ini Njan Urangatte

abstract: Hard Merchandise is the final book in [[The Bounty Hunter Wars|The Bounty Hunter Wars]] trilogy of books in the [[Universe|Star Wars expanded universe]]. It was written by [[K. W. Jeter|K. W. Jeter]].
title: Hard Merchandise

abstract: War of the Spider Queen is a [[fantasy|Fantasy fiction]] series of [[novel|novels]] set in the [[Forgotten Realms|Forgotten Realms]] universe published by [[Wizards of the Coast|Wizards of the Coast]]. The series contains [[six books|Hexalogy]] focused on the [[drow|Drow (Dungeons & Dragons)]] and their principal deity [[Lolth|Lolth]]. Each of the six novels in the series is written by a different author with veteran Forgotten Realms author [[R. A. Salvatore|R. A. Salvatore]] overseeing the project. Cover art for each book in the series was designed by [[Gerald Brom|Gerald Brom]] who has done other Forgotten Realms work including reprints of [[The Avatar Series|The Avatar Series]].
title: War of the Spider Queen

abstract: The Indian in the Cupboard is a [[low fantasy|low fantasy]] children's novel by the British writer Lynne Reid Banks. It was published in 1980 with illustrations by Robin Jacques (UK) and Brock Cole (US). It was later adapted as a 1995 children's film under the same name. Later books in the series were illustrated by [[Piers Sanford|Piers Sanford]] (later).
title: The Indian in the Cupboard

abstract: Bagombo Snuff Box is a collection of 23 [[short stories|short stories]] written by [[Kurt Vonnegut|Kurt Vonnegut]]. The stories were originally published in US periodicals between 1950 and 1962. This collection was published in 1999 by [[G. P. Putnam's Sons|G. P. Putnam's Sons]].
title: Bagombo Snuff Box

abstract: Nearly all of The Railway Series stories were based upon real-life events. As a lifelong railway enthusiast, Awdry was keen that his stories should be as realistic as possible. The engine characters were almost all based upon real classes of locomotive, and some of the railways themselves were directly based upon real lines in the British Isles.
title: The Railway Series

abstract: Jonathan Strange & Mr Norrell is the [[debut novel|debut novel]] by British writer [[Susanna Clarke|Susanna Clarke]]. Published in 2004, it is an [[alternative history|alternate history]] set in 19th-century England around the time of the [[Napoleonic Wars|Napoleonic Wars]]. Its premise is that magic once existed in England and has returned with two men: Gilbert Norrell and Jonathan Strange. Centred on the relationship between these two men, the novel investigates the nature of "Englishness" and the boundaries between reason and unreason, [[Anglo-Saxon|Anglo-Saxons]] and [[Anglo-Dane|Danelaw]], and Northern and Southern English cultural tropes/stereotypes. It has been described as a [[fantasy|fantasy]] novel, an alternative history, and a historical novel. It inverts the [[Industrial Revolution|Industrial Revolution]] conception of the [[North-South divide in England|North–South divide (England)]]: in this book the North is romantic and magical, rather than rational and concrete.
title: Jonathan Strange & Mr Norrell

abstract: The Unseen Queen is a [[science fiction|science fiction]] novel set in the [[Star Wars|Star Wars]] [[Star Wars expanded universe|Star Wars expanded universe]]. It is the second book in the [[Dark Nest Trilogy|Dark Nest Trilogy]] by [[Troy Denning|Troy Denning]]. It is set 35 years after the Battle of Yavin (35 ABY). In the chronology of the Star Wars novels, it is set after the first book of the Dark Nest trilogy, which is [[The Joiner King|The Joiner King]], and before the third book of the Dark Nest trilogy, which is [[The Swarm War|The Swarm War]].
title: The Unseen Queen

abstract: The Joiner King is a [[science fiction|science fiction]] novel set in the [[Star Wars expanded universe|Star Wars expanded universe]]. It is the first book in the [[Dark Nest|Dark Nest Trilogy]] trilogy of novels by [[Troy Denning|Troy Denning]]. It is set 35 years after the Battle of Yavin (35 ABY). In the chronology of the Star Wars novels, The Joiner King takes place after the final book of [[The New Jedi Order|The New Jedi Order]] series, which is [[The Unifying Force|The Unifying Force]], and before the second book of the Dark Nest trilogy, which is [[The Unseen Queen|The Unseen Queen]].
title: The Joiner King

abstract: The Brightonomicon is a novel by British [[fantasy|fantasy]] author [[Robert Rankin|Robert Rankin]]. The title parodies that of the fictional [[grimoire|grimoire]] [[Necronomicon|Necronomicon]] from the [[Cthulhu Mythos|Cthulhu Mythos]]. The author lives in [[Brighton|Brighton]], [[England|England]], and the book is set in an accurate fictional depiction of the town. The book is based on "The Brighton Zodiac", a map consisting of carriageway constellations found in the city of [[Brighton and Hove|Brighton and Hove]], similar to the purported [[landscape zodiac|landscape zodiacs]] of [[Glastonbury|Temple of the Stars]] and Kingston. The 2010 edition features a new cover design and internal illustrations by Rankin himself, who studied at the Ealing School of Art and worked briefly as an illustrator in the 1970s.
title: The Brightonomicon

abstract: The Bacta War (1997) is the fourth installment to the [[Star Wars|Star Wars]] [[X-wing|Star Wars: X-wing (book series)]] series of novels. It is a [[science fiction novel|list of science fiction novels]] written by [[Michael Stackpole|Michael Stackpole]]. It is set at the beginning of the New Republic Era in the Star Wars universe and focuses on the beginning of the conflict known as the Bacta War.
title: The Bacta War

abstract: City at the End of Time is a 2008 science fiction novel by American writer [[Greg Bear|Greg Bear]]. It was published in August 2008 by [[Del Rey|Del Rey Books]] in the United States, and [[Gollancz|Victor Gollancz Ltd]] in the United Kingdom. The story follows three drifters in present-day [[Seattle|Seattle]] who are tormented by strange dreams of the Kalpa, a city one hundred trillion years in the future. The Kalpa is attempting to ward off the Typhon, an inexplicable entity that has consumed the rest of the ancient universe and broken down the laws of physics.
title: City at the End of Time

abstract: Love & Respect: The Love She Most Desires; The Respect He Desperately Needs was written in 2004 by Dr. Emerson Eggerichs. The book suggests a direct connection between the [[emotion|emotional]] needs of men and women and a verse of scripture found in the [[Bible|Bible]], that when adhered to, can strengthen and transform [[relationships|Intimate relationship]].
title: Love & Respect

abstract: The Đại Việt sử ký (, Annals of Đại Việt) is the official historical text of the [[Trần dynasty|Trần dynasty]], that was compiled by the royal historian [[Lê Văn Hưu|Lê Văn Hưu]] and was finished in 1272. Considered the first comprehensive account of the [[history of Vietnam|history of Vietnam]], the 30-volume book covered the period from [[Triệu Đà|Triệu Đà]], the first king of the [[Triệu dynasty|Triệu dynasty]], to [[Lý Chiêu Hoàng|Lý Chiêu Hoàng]] which was the empress regnant and the last ruler of the [[Lý dynasty|Lý dynasty]]. Although it was lost during the [[Fourth Chinese domination|Fourth Chinese domination of Vietnam]] in Vietnam, the contents of the Đại Việt sử ký, including Lê Văn Hưu's comments about various events in the history of Vietnam, were used by other Vietnamese historians as a base for their works, notably the [[Đại Việt sử ký toàn thư|Đại Việt sử ký toàn thư]] by [[Ngô Sĩ Liên|Ngô Sĩ Liên]].
title: Đại Việt sử ký

abstract: Alternate Tyrants is a 1997 [[Tor|Tor Books]] [[alternate history|alternate history]] [[anthology|anthology]], edited by [[Mike Resnick|Mike Resnick]]. Each story is by a different author, and presents a scenario where an individual becomes a [[tyrant|tyrant]] or [[dictator|dictator]] in a way that did not occur in real life.
title: Alternate Tyrants

abstract: The Collected Stories of Frank Herbert is the sixth, and first posthumous, anthology of short [[science fiction|science fiction]] stories by American author [[Frank Herbert|Frank Herbert]], released by [[Tor Books|Tor Books]] on November 18, 2014.
title: The Collected Stories of Frank Herbert

abstract: Anne of Green Gables is a 1908 novel by Canadian author [[Lucy Maud Montgomery|Lucy Maud Montgomery]] (published as L. M. Montgomery). Written for all ages, it has been considered a classic children's novel since the mid-twentieth century. Set in the late 19th century, the novel recounts the adventures of [[Anne Shirley|Anne Shirley]], an 11-year-old [[orphan|orphan]] girl, who is mistakenly sent to two middle-aged siblings; Matthew and Marilla Cuthbert, originally intending to [[adopt|adopt]] a boy to help them on their farm in the fictional town of Avonlea on [[Prince Edward Island|Prince Edward Island]]. The novel recounts how Anne makes her way through life with the Cuthberts, in school, and within the town.
title: Anne of Green Gables

abstract: Nightmares & Dreamscapes is a short story collection by American writer [[Stephen King|Stephen King]], published in 1993.
title: Nightmares & Dreamscapes

abstract: The Jungle Book (1894) is a collection of stories by the English author [[Rudyard Kipling|Rudyard Kipling]]. Most of the characters are animals such as [[Shere Khan|Shere Khan]] the tiger and [[Baloo|Baloo]] the bear, though a principal character is the boy or "man-cub" [[Mowgli|Mowgli]], who is raised in the jungle by wolves. The stories are set in a forest in [[India|British India]]; one place mentioned repeatedly is "Seonee" ([[Seoni|Seoni]]), in the [[central|Central India]] state of [[Madhya Pradesh|Madhya Pradesh]].
title: The Jungle Book

abstract: The Dictionary of American Naval Fighting Ships (DANFS for short) is the official [[reference work|reference work]] for the basic facts about [[ship|ships]] used by the [[United States Navy|United States Navy]].
title: Dictionary of American Naval Fighting Ships

abstract: "Ode to a Nightingale" is a personal poem which describes Keats's journey into the state of [[negative capability|negative capability]]. The tone of the poem rejects the optimistic pursuit of pleasure found within Keats's earlier poems and, instead, explores the themes of nature, [[transience|wikt:transience]] and mortality, the latter being particularly personal to Keats.
title: Ode to a Nightingale

abstract: The Hound of the Baskervilles is the third of the four [[crime novel|Detective fictions]] written by Sir [[Arthur Conan Doyle|Arthur Conan Doyle]] featuring the detective [[Sherlock Holmes|Sherlock Holmes]]. Originally [[serialised|serial (literature)]] in [[The Strand Magazine|The Strand Magazine]] from August 1901 to April 1902, it is set largely on [[Dartmoor|Dartmoor]] in [[Devon|Devon]] in England's [[West Country|West Country]] and tells the story of an attempted murder inspired by the [[legend|legend]] of a fearsome, diabolical [[hound|Black dog (ghost)]] of supernatural origin. Sherlock Holmes and his companion [[Dr. Watson|Dr. Watson]] investigate the case. This was the first appearance of Holmes since his apparent death in "[[The Final Problem|The Final Problem]]", and the success of The Hound of the Baskervilles led to the character's eventual revival.
title: The Hound of the Baskervilles

abstract: The Selfish Gene is a 1976 book on [[evolution|evolution]] by [[Richard Dawkins|Richard Dawkins]], in which the author builds upon the principal theory of [[George C. Williams|George C. Williams (biologist)]]'s [[Adaptation and Natural Selection|Adaptation and Natural Selection]] (1966). Dawkins uses the term "selfish gene" as a way of expressing the [[gene-centred view of evolution|gene-centered view of evolution]] as opposed to the views focused on the organism and the [[group|Group selection]], popularising ideas developed during the 1960s by [[W. D. Hamilton|W. D. Hamilton]] and others. From the gene-centred view, it follows that the more two individuals are genetically related, the more sense (at the level of the genes) it makes for them to behave selflessly with each other.
title: The Selfish Gene

abstract: The idea of the Great Soviet Encyclopedia emerged in 1923 on the initiative of [[Otto Schmidt|Otto Schmidt]], a member of the [[Russian Academy of Sciences|Russian Academy of Sciences]]. In early 1924 Schmidt worked with a group which included [[Mikhail Pokrovsky|Mikhail Pokrovsky]], (rector of the [[Institute of Red Professors|Institute of Red Professors]]), [[Nikolai Meshcheryakov|Nikolai Meshcheryakov]] (Head of [[Gosizdat|Gosizdat]], the State Publishing House), [[Valery Bryusov|Valery Bryusov]] (poet), [[Veniamin Kagan|Veniamin Kagan]] (mathematician) and [[Konstantin Kuzminsky|Konstantin Kuzminsky]] to draw up a proposal which was agreed by the in April 1924. Also involved was [[Anatoly Lunacharsky|Anatoly Lunacharsky]], Commissar of Enlightenment ([[Narkompros|Narkompros]]), who had previously been involved with a proposal by [[Alexander Bogdanov|Alexander Bogdanov]] and [[Maxim Gorky|Maxim Gorky]] to produce a Workers' Encyclopedia.
title: Great Soviet Encyclopedia

abstract: Foundation's Triumph (1999) is a science fiction novel by [[David Brin|David Brin]], set in [[Isaac Asimov|Isaac Asimov]]'s [[Foundation|The Foundation Series]] universe. It is the third book of the Second Foundation trilogy, which was written after Asimov's death by three authors, authorized by the Asimov estate. Brin synthesizes dozens of Foundation-Empire-Robots novels and short stories by [[Isaac Asimov|Isaac Asimov]], [[Roger MacBride Allen|Roger MacBride Allen]], and authorized others into a consistent framework. Foundation's Triumph includes an appendix chronology compiled by Attila Torkos.
title: Foundation's Triumph

abstract: The Rest of the Robots is a collection of eight [[short stories|short stories]] and two full-length [[novel|novels]] by American writer [[Isaac Asimov|Isaac Asimov]], published in 1964. The stories, centred on [[positronic robots|positronic brain]], are all part of the [[Robot series|Robot series (Asimov)]], most of which take place in the [[Foundation universe|Foundation series]]. Another collection of short stories about robots, [[I, Robot|I, Robot]], was re-published in the previous year, which is why Asimov chose to title the collection as The Rest of the Robots. None of the short stories in this collection were in I, Robot, however all of them were later included in [[The Complete Robot|The Complete Robot]], and both novels about [[Elijah Baley|Elijah Baley]] were also published separately.
title: The Rest of the Robots

abstract: The book has been adapted as a [[prize-winning 1984 film|Ronia, the Robber's Daughter (film)]], a Danish and a German musical, and a [[Japanese anime|Ronja, the Robber's Daughter (anime)]]. It has been translated into at least 39 languages.
title: Ronia, the Robber's Daughter

abstract: Tar: A Midwest Childhood is a 1926 fictionalized memoir by American author [[Sherwood Anderson|Sherwood Anderson]]. It was originally published by [[Boni & Liveright|Boni & Liveright]] and has since been republished several times including a 1969 critical edition. The book is made up of episodes in the childhood of Edgar Moorehead (nicknamed Tar-heel, or Tar, because of his father's [[North Carolina|North Carolina]] origin). The fictional location of Tar: A Midwest Childhood bears a resemblance to [[Camden, Ohio|Camden, Ohio]] where Sherwood Anderson was born, despite him having spent only his first year there. An episode from the book later appeared, in a revised form, as the short story "[[Death in the Woods|Death in the Woods]]" (1933).
title: Tar: A Midwest Childhood

abstract: Note: "Abecedar" is also the name of the [[primer|Primer (textbook)]] (1st grade school book) in [[Romanian|Romanian language]].The Abecedar was a [[school book|textbook]] first published in [[Athens|Athens]], [[Greece|Greece]] in 1925. The book became the subject of controversy with [[Bulgaria|Bulgaria]] and [[Serbia|Serbia]] when cited by [[Greece|Greece]] as proof it had fulfilled its international obligations towards its [[Slavic|Slavic language (Greece)]]-speaking minority, because it had been printed in the [[Latin alphabet|Latin alphabet]] rather than the [[Cyrillic|Cyrillic script]] used by the Slavic languages of the southern [[Balkans|Balkans]]. The book was initially published for the [[Slavic Macedonians|Slavic speakers of Greek Macedonia]] in the [[Lerin dialect|Prilep-Bitola dialect]], and today it is published in [[Standard Macedonian|Standard Macedonian]], [[Standard Greek|Standard Modern Greek]] and [[Standard English|Standard English]].
title: Abecedar

abstract: Last Bus to Woodstock is a [[crime novel|Crime fiction]] by [[Colin Dexter|Colin Dexter]], the first of 13 novels in his [[Inspector Morse|Inspector Morse]] series.
title: Last Bus to Woodstock

abstract: The Stories of Eva Luna () is a collection of Spanish-language short stories by the [[Chilean-American|Chilean-American]] writer [[Isabel Allende|Isabel Allende]]. It consists of stories told by the title character of Allende's earlier novel [[Eva Luna|Eva Luna]]. The literary critic [[Barbara Mujica|Barbara Mujica (writer)]] wrote: "The Chilean author presents her stories through the age-old device used by Scheherazade: the narrator tells them to her lover to entertain him. Like the famous Arabic tales, these stories combine fantasy with biting social satire and psychological insight."
title: The Stories of Eva Luna

abstract: Basketball (and Other Things) was published by [[Abrams Image|Abrams Books]] on October 10, 2017. It is the second collaboration between Serrano and Torres, following their 2015 [[New York Times|New York Times]] best-seller [[The Rap Year Book|The Rap Year Book]]. Basketball (and Other Things) shares a title with a previous email newsletter from Serrano and Torres; begun in March 2016, the [[newsletter|newsletter]] had over 30,000 subscribers as of May 2016.
title: Basketball (and Other Things)

abstract: The Wish Maker is the [[first novel|first novel]] by Pakistani author [[Ali Sethi|Ali Sethi]]. Published in 2009 by [[Riverhead Books|Riverhead Books]], it tells the story of Zaki Shirazi, a young boy from [[United States|United States]] who returned to Lahore, Pakistan after finishing his studies to celebrate the wedding of his childhood friend Samar Api and observe a completely new Pakistan. The story is set against the backdrop of tumultuous events, from the [[Zia-ul-Haq|Muhammad Zia-ul-Haq]] reign to [[Zulfiqar Bhutto|Zulfiqar Bhutto]]'s execution and [[Benazir Bhutto|Benazir Bhutto]] elections, it also dictates [[United States|Operation Cyclone]] help to [[Afghan mujahideen|Afghan mujahideen]] during the [[Soviet military intervention|Soviet–Afghan War]] in [[Afghanistan|Afghanistan]].
title: The Wish Maker

abstract: In Their Lives: Great Writers on Great Beatles Songs is a collection of essays in which twenty-nine authors and musicians discuss their favorite [[Beatles|Beatles]] songs. The book is edited by Andrew Blauner, and features an introductory note by [[Paul McCartney|Paul McCartney]].
title: In Their Lives: Great Writers on Great Beatles Songs

abstract: Mr. Peabody's Apples was released in over 150 countries and 36 languages worldwide. It was Madonna's second children book authored by her, following [[The English Roses|The English Roses]]. She partnered with [[Audible|Audible (store)]] stores and [[Apple Music|Apple Music]] for promotion, and also appeared on US talk shows. Critics gave mostly negative review of the book, panning the storytelling and the absence of joy in it. The book debuted at number one on [[The New York Times Best Seller list|The New York Times Best Seller list]].
title: Mr. Peabody's Apples

abstract: To mark the 18th anniversary of its foundation, Bilimkurgu Kulübü (The Science-Fiction Club) has compiled a collection of science fiction stories to be published in 2018 under the title The Earth Museum, an anthology featuring 18 Turkish science-fiction writers who contributed to the book with 18 short stories. The work has also been endorsed with a message by the legendary sci-fi and fantasy author [[Ursula K. Le Guin|Ursula K. Le Guin]]. This message, of which the Turkish translation adorns the back cover of the book, also has historical value as her last words published before the author’s death on 22 January 2018.
title: The Earth Museum

abstract: Xiandai Hanyu Guifan Cidian () is a dictionary of [[Standard Chinese|Standard Chinese]] created as part of proposal in the [[Eighth Five-year Plan|Five-year plans of China#Eighth Plan (1991–1995)]] of China that is very similar to [[Xiandai Hanyu Cidian|Xiandai Hanyu Cidian]] but with notable divergences. The third edition has entries for 12,000 characters and 72,000 words, with over 80,000 example usages.
title: Xiandai Hanyu Guifan Cidian

abstract: Guinness World Records, known from its inception from 1955 until 2000 as The Guinness Book of Records and in previous United States editions as The Guinness Book of World Records, is a [[reference book|reference book]] published annually, listing [[world record|world records]] both of human achievements and the extremes of the natural world. The brainchild of Sir [[Hugh Beaver|Hugh Beaver]], the book was co-founded by brothers [[Norris|Norris McWhirter]] and [[Ross McWhirter|Ross McWhirter]] in [[Fleet Street|Fleet Street]], London in August 1954.
title: Guinness World Records

abstract: Everything's Eventual is a collection of 14 [[short stories|short story]] by American writer [[Stephen King|Stephen King]], published in 2002.
title: Everything's Eventual

abstract: Although Wuthering Heights is now a classic of English literature, contemporary reviews were deeply polarised; it was controversial because of its unusually stark depiction of mental and physical cruelty, and it challenged strict Victorian ideals regarding religious [[hypocrisy|hypocrisy]], [[morality|morality]], [[social classes|social class]] and [[gender inequality|gender inequality]]. The English poet and painter [[Dante Gabriel Rossetti|Dante Gabriel Rossetti]], although an admirer of the book, referred to it as "A fiend of a book   – an incredible monster   [...] The action is laid in hell,   – only it seems places and people have English names there."
title: Wuthering Heights

abstract: The Salmon of Doubt: Hitchhiking the Galaxy One Last Time is a [[posthumous|wikt:posthumous]] collection of previously published and unpublished material by [[Douglas Adams|Douglas Adams]]. It consists largely of essays about technology and life experiences, but its major selling point is the inclusion of the incomplete novel on which Adams was working at the time of his death, The Salmon of Doubt (from which the collection gets its title, a reference to the [[Irish myth|Irish mythology]] of the [[Salmon of Knowledge|Salmon of Knowledge]]).
title: The Salmon of Doubt

abstract: Bleak House is a novel by English author [[Charles Dickens|Charles Dickens]], first published as a [[serial|Serial (literature)]] of 20 episodes between March 1852 and September 1853. The novel has many characters and several sub-plots, and the story is told partly by the novel's heroine, Esther Summerson, and partly by an [[omniscient narrator|omniscient narrator]]. At the centre of Bleak House is a long-running legal case, [[Jarndyce and Jarndyce|Jarndyce and Jarndyce]], which came about because someone wrote several conflicting wills. Dickens uses this case to satirise the English judicial system. Though the legal profession criticised Dickens's satire as exaggerated, this novel helped support a judicial reform movement, which culminated in the enactment of [[legal reform|Judicature Acts]] in the 1870s.
title: Bleak House

abstract: The Adventures of Sherlock Holmes is a collection of twelve short stories by [[Arthur Conan Doyle|Arthur Conan Doyle]], featuring his fictional detective [[Sherlock Holmes|Sherlock Holmes]]. It was first published on 14 October 1892; the individual stories had been serialised in [[The Strand Magazine|The Strand Magazine]] between July 1891 and June 1892. The stories are not in chronological order, and the only characters common to all twelve are Holmes and [[Dr. Watson|Dr. Watson]]. The stories are related in [[first-person narrative|first-person narrative]] from Watson's point of view.
title: The Adventures of Sherlock Holmes

abstract: Verbal Behavior is a 1957 book by [[psychologist|psychologist]] [[B. F. Skinner|B. F. Skinner]], in which he inspects [[human behavior|human behavior]], describing what is traditionally called [[linguistics|linguistics]]. The book Verbal Behavior is almost entirely theoretical, involving little experimental research in the work itself. It was an outgrowth of a series of lectures first presented at the University of Minnesota in the early 1940s and developed further in his summer lectures at Columbia and [[William James|William James]] lectures at Harvard in the decade before the book's publication. A growing body of research and applications based on Verbal Behavior has occurred since its original publication, particularly in the past decade.
title: Verbal Behavior

abstract: The story pivots a tragic triangle linking Devdas, an archetypal lover in viraha (separation); Paro, his forbidden childhood love; and [[Chandramukhi|Chandramukhi (character)]], a reformed courtesan. Devdas was adapted on screen 19 times.
title: Devdas

abstract: The Australian Dictionary of Biography (ADB or AuDB) is a national co-operative enterprise founded and maintained by the [[Australian National University|Australian National University]] (ANU) to produce authoritative biographical articles on eminent people in Australia's history. Initially published in a series of twelve hard-copy volumes between 1966 and 2005, the dictionary has been published online since 2006.
title: Australian Dictionary of Biography

abstract: Accelerando is a 2005 science fiction novel consisting of a series of interconnected short stories written by British author [[Charles Stross|Charles Stross]]. As well as normal hardback and paperback editions, it was released as a free [[e-book|e-book]] under the [[CC BY-NC-ND license|Creative Commons licenses#Types of licenses]]. Accelerando won the [[Locus Award|Locus Award]] in 2006, and was nominated for several other awards in 2005 and 2006, including the [[Hugo|Hugo Award]], [[Campbell|John W. Campbell Memorial Award for Best Science Fiction Novel]], [[Clarke|Arthur C. Clarke Award]], and [[British Science Fiction Association Award|British Science Fiction Association Awards]].
title: Accelerando

abstract: Wedge's Gamble (1996) is the second novel in the [[Star Wars: X-wing|Star Wars: X-wing (book series)]] series. It was written by [[Michael A. Stackpole|Michael A. Stackpole]]. It is set at the beginning of the New Republic era of the Star Wars universe and tells the story of [[Rogue Squadron|Rogue Squadron]]'s covert [[intelligence|Military intelligence]] mission to [[Coruscant|Coruscant]] as a first wave for the Rebel Alliance's invasion.
title: Wedge's Gamble

abstract: Daddy's Roommate is a [[children's book|children's book]] written by [[Michael Willhoite|Michael Willhoite]] and published by [[Alyson Books|Alyson Books]] in 1990. One of the first children's books to address the subject of homosexuality, the story follows a young boy whose [[divorce|divorced]] father now lives with his [[life partner|life partner]]. The book's depiction of a gay household has led to its inclusion in many educational programs, and Willhoite's work was awarded a [[Lambda Literary Award|Lambda Literary Award]] in 1991.
title: Daddy's Roommate

abstract: Bloodletting & Miraculous Cures is a [[short story|short story]] collection by [[Vincent Lam|Vincent Lam]], published in 2006. The book, inspired by Lam's own experiences in [[medical school|medical school]] and as a professional physician, is a volume of interconnected short stories about the lives and relationships of Fitzgerald, Ming, Chen and Sri, four young medical students in [[Toronto|Toronto]].
title: Bloodletting & Miraculous Cures

abstract: Tales from the Expat Harem: Foreign Women in Modern Turkey () is a nonfiction anthology by 32 [[expatriate|expatriate]] women about their lives in modern [[Turkey|Turkey]], published by [[Seal Press|Seal Press]] in North America (2006, ) and [[Doğan Kitap|Doğan Kitap]] in Turkey (2005, Turkish edition, English edition).
title: Tales from the Expat Harem

abstract: During the [[Fourth Chinese domination|Fourth Chinese domination (History of Vietnam)]], many valuable books of [[Đại Việt|Đại Việt]] were taken away by the [[Ming Dynasty|Ming Dynasty]] including [[Lê Văn Hưu|Lê Văn Hưu]]'s [[Đại Việt sử ký|Đại Việt sử ký]] (大越史記, Annals of Đại Việt), the official historical text of the [[Trần Dynasty|Trần Dynasty]] and the most comprehensive source of the history of Vietnam up to that period. However, the contents of the Đại Việt sử ký and Lê Văn Hưu's comments about various historical events was fully collected by the historian [[Phan Phu Tiên|Phan Phu Tiên]] in writing the first official annals of the [[Lê Dynasty|Lê Dynasty]] after the order of the Emperor [[Lê Nhân Tông|Lê Nhân Tông]] in 1455. The new Đại Việt sử ký of Phan Phu Tiên was supplemented the period from 1223 with the coronation of [[Trần Thái Tông|Trần Thái Tông]] to 1427 with the retreat of the Ming Dynasty after the victory of [[Lê Lợi|Lê Lợi]]. Phan Phu Tiên's ten-volume work had other names such as Đại Việt sử ký tục biên (大越史記續編序, Supplementary Edition of the Annals of Đại Việt) or Quốc sử biên lục. During the reign of [[Lê Thánh Tông|Lê Thánh Tông]], who was an emperor famous for his interest in learning and knowledge, the scholar and historian Ngô Sĩ Liên was appointed to the Bureau of History in 1473. Under the order of Thánh Tông, he based on the works of Lê Văn Hưu and Phan Phu Tiên to write the Đại Việt sử ký toàn thư which was compiled in 15 volumes (quyển) and finished in 1479. In compiling the Đại Việt sử ký toàn thư, Ngô Sĩ Liên also drew elements from other books such as [[Việt điện u linh tập|Việt điện u linh tập]] (Compilation of the potent spirits in the Realm of Việt) or [[Lĩnh Nam chích quái|Lĩnh Nam chích quái]] (Extraordinary stories of Lĩnh Nam) which were collections of folk legend and myth but still considered by Ngô Sĩ Liên good sources for history because of their reliable system of citation. This was the first time such sources were used in historiography by a Vietnamese historian. Đại Việt sử ký toàn thư was finally completed in 1479 with the accounts that stopped by the coronation of [[Lê Thái Tổ|Lê Thái Tổ]] in 1428. According to [[Lê Quý Đôn|Lê Quý Đôn]], Ngô Sĩ Liên also compiled an historical text about the reigns of Thái Tổ, [[Thái Tông|Lê Thái Tông]] and [[Nhân Tông|Lê Nhân Tông]] named Tam triều bản ký (Records of the Three Reigns).
title: Đại Việt sử ký toàn thư

abstract: The Day of the Djinn Warriors is the fourth installment of the [[Children of the Lamp|Children of the Lamp]] series. The author, [[Philip Kerr|Philip Kerr]], has said on his website that he is planning to write a total of six books although he hasn't decided what the titles of the remaining books will be.
title: The Day of the Djinn Warriors

abstract: Like most of Bhyrappa's novels, Aavarana too generated tremendous debate and discussion. Many prominent intellectuals believe Aavarana dangerously advanced the fundamentalist agenda by tilting at the windmills of history, and that it seeks to divide society on communal lines. On the other hand, the writer's original posit that the Truth needs to be told has connected with the readers that it has seen repeated reprintings. The author has vigorously protested the tag that the book is inflammatory by challenging the reviewers to refute the points made in the book. It is also pertinent to note that the author anticipated the criticism that the book would receive and has worked in the book, the reasons why books and criticisms should not be banned or suppressed.
title: Aavarana

abstract: The Songs of a Sentimental Bloke is a [[verse novel|verse novel]] by Australian novelist and poet [[C. J. Dennis|C. J. Dennis]]. The work was first published in book form in 1915 and sold over 60,000 copies in nine editions within the first year.
title: The Songs of a Sentimental Bloke

abstract: Miles to Go is an [[autobiography|autobiography]] by [[Miley Cyrus|Miley Cyrus]], co-written by [[Hilary Liftin|Hilary Liftin]] and published by [[Disney Hyperion|Disney Hyperion]] in March 2009. The memoir discusses Cyrus' relationship with her parents, her thoughts on the media, her love life, her future ambitions and milestones she still has to reach in her life. Miles to Go reached #1 on the [[New York Times|New York Times Best Seller list]] children’s best seller list. A second edition to the book was released in Australia in December 2009 and in the UK on 1 March 2010.
title: Miles to Go

abstract: The Almost Complete Collection of True Singapore Ghost Stories (also True Singapore Ghost Stories or TSGS) is one of the bestselling book series in [[Singapore|Singapore]]. With over 1.5 million copies sold, the series has become a household name since its inception in 1989. [[Russell Lee|Russell Lee (writer)]], a Singaporean author, compiles reports, stories and interviews about the supernatural. Light and entertaining, each book, which comprises about 30 stories, appeals to both children and mature readers.
title: True Singapore Ghost Stories

abstract: Falsifiers of History was a book published by the [[Soviet Information Bureau|Soviet Information Bureau]], edited and partially re-written by [[Joseph Stalin|Joseph Stalin]], in response to documents made public in January 1948 regarding German–Soviet relations before and after the [[Molotov–Ribbentrop Pact|Molotov–Ribbentrop Pact]].
title: Falsifiers of History

abstract: The Early Stories: 1953–1975, published in 2003 by [[Knopf|Alfred A. Knopf]], is a [[John Updike|John Updike]] book collecting much of his short stories written from the beginning of his writing career, when he was just 21, until 1975. Only four stories published in this entire time period have been omitted from this collection by John Updike himself: "Intercession" (collected in The Same Door), and "The Pro", "One of My Generation", and "God Speaks" (collected in Museums and Women and Other Stories). The majority of the stories were originally published in [[The New Yorker|The New Yorker]] magazine. In 2004, the book received the [[PEN/Faulkner Award for Fiction|PEN/Faulkner Award for Fiction]].
title: The Early Stories: 1953–1975

abstract: [[María Ruiz de Burton|María Ruiz de Burton]]'s Who Would Have Thought It? (1872) was the first novel to be written in English by a Mexican living in the United States. After a long period in which Ruiz de Burton's work was almost completely unknown, the novel was rediscovered by critics interested in the history of [[Chicano literature|Chicano literature]], and republished to acclaim in 1995. Yet Ruiz de Burton's life was not particularly typical of the Mexican-American experience, as she married a prominent US officer, Captain [[Henry S. Burton|Henry S. Burton]], in the aftermath of the [[Mexican–American War|Mexican–American War]]. The novel reflects her ambiguous position between the [[Californio|Californio]] elite and the Anglo-Saxon majority of the United States.
title: Who Would Have Thought It?

abstract: Dancing the Dream was published by [[Doubleday|Doubleday (publisher)]] on June 18, 1992, seven months after the release of Jackson's 1991 [[Dangerous|Dangerous (Michael Jackson album)]] album. It was not a significant commercial success. The book was reissued by the British publisher [[Transworld|Transworld (company)]] on July 27, 2009, following [[Jackson's death|Death of Michael Jackson]] the previous month on June 25, 2009.
title: Dancing the Dream

abstract: The Way of Kings is an [[epic fantasy|epic fantasy]] novel written by American author [[Brandon Sanderson|Brandon Sanderson]] and the first book in [[The Stormlight Archive|The Stormlight Archive]] series. The novel was published on August 31, 2010 by [[Tor Books|Tor Books]]. The Way of Kings consists of one prelude, one prologue, 75 chapters, an epilogue and 9 interludes. It was followed by [[Words of Radiance|Words of Radiance]] in 2014.
title: The Way of Kings

abstract: Ocean of Words is a short story collection by [[Ha Jin|Ha Jin]]. It is his first published book. The stories are set along the [[China-Soviet border|China–Russia border#The Sino-Soviet border (1917–1991)]] in the 1970s after the nations [[split|Sino-Soviet split]] political ties.
title: Ocean of Words

abstract: Words of Radiance is an [[epic fantasy|epic fantasy]] novel written by American author [[Brandon Sanderson|Brandon Sanderson]] and the second book in [[The Stormlight Archive|The Stormlight Archive]] series. The novel was published on March 4, 2014 by [[Tor Books|Tor Books]]. Words of Radiance consists of one prologue, 89 chapters, an epilogue and 14 interludes. It is preceded by [[The Way of Kings|The Way of Kings]] and followed by [[Oathbringer|Oathbringer]].
title: Words of Radiance

abstract: Malhotra intends to give a critique of western culture, by comparing it with Indian culture, as seen from a 'Dharmic point of view.' To accomplish this goal, he postulates a set of characteristics of western culture, and a set of characteristics of Indian culture and religion, characterised as "Dharmic." Malhotra explains that in Being Different,
title: Being Different

abstract: The Muslim 100: The Lives, Thoughts and Achievements of the Most Influential Muslims in History is a 2008 book, written by [[Muhammad Mojlum Khan|Muhammad Mojlum Khan]] and published by Kube Publishing, listing the biographies of the 100 most influential Muslims in history.
title: The Muslim 100

abstract: British Bangladeshi Who's Who is an annual publication highlighting the accomplishments, contributions and achievements of successful [[British Bangladeshi|British Bangladeshis]]. It was established in 2008 and also holds an annual award ceremony in [[London|London]], [[England|England]].
title: British Bangladeshi Who's Who

abstract: The 500 Most Influential Muslims (also known as The Muslim 500) is an annual publication first published in 2009, which ranks the most influential Muslims in the world.
title: The 500 Most Influential Muslims

abstract: The main character is Tuva-Lisa Johansson, a Swedish girl who is 12 years old (nearly 13). Her parents work in theater, and she has written her own plays for the stage and wants to become an actress. Her friend is Jessica.
title: Tuva-Lisa

abstract: In Persuasion Nation is short story writer [[George Saunders|George Saunders]]’s third full length [[short story collection|short story collection]]. Composed of 11 stories originally published between 1999 and 2005, the collection incorporates elements of [[satire|satire]] and [[science fiction|science fiction]] and deals with themes of discontent in turn-of-the-millennium America. The collection has stories that appeared in different forms in [[The New Yorker|The New Yorker]], [[Harper's|Harper's]], [[Esquire|Esquire (magazine)]], and [[McSweeney's|McSweeney's]]. As a whole, the collection was a finalist for the 2006 [[Story Prize|Story Prize]].
title: In Persuasion Nation

abstract: CivilWarLand in Bad Decline is a book of short stories and a novella by the American writer [[George Saunders|George Saunders]]. Published in 1996, it was Saunders's first book. Many of the stories initially appeared in different forms in various magazines, including [[Kenyon Review|Kenyon Review]], [[Harper's|Harper's]], [[The New Yorker|The New Yorker]] and [[Quarterly West|Quarterly West]]. The collection was listed as a [[New York Times|New York Times]] Notable Book of 1996, as well as a finalist for the 1996 [[PEN/Hemingway Award|PEN/Hemingway Award]].
title: CivilWarLand in Bad Decline

abstract: The three volumes or "parts" of The Politics of Nonviolent Action contain a total of 14 chapters, as well as a preface by the author, and an introduction by [[Thomas C. Schelling|Thomas C. Schelling]]. Each part begins with an introduction by the author. The first volume or "part" addresses the theory of power that implicitly or explicitly underlies [[nonviolent action|nonviolent resistance]]; Volume 2 offers a detailed analysis of the methods of nonviolent action; and the Volume 3 analyzes the dynamics of nonviolent action.
title: The Politics of Nonviolent Action

abstract: Van Dale's Great Dictionary of the Dutch Language (, ), called for short, is the leading [[dictionary|dictionary]] of the [[Dutch language|Dutch language]].
title: Van Dale

abstract: Gandhi as a Political Strategist is a book about the political strategies used by [[Mahatma Gandhi|Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi]], and their ongoing implications and applicability outside of their original [[Indian context|Indian independence movement]]. Written by [[Gene Sharp|Gene Sharp]], the book was originally published in the United States in 1979. An Indian edition was published in 1999. The book has been reviewed in several professional journals.
title: Gandhi as a Political Strategist

abstract: Mr. Stink is a book published in October 2009 and written by [[David Walliams|David Walliams]] and illustrated by [[Quentin Blake|Quentin Blake]]. The book has been adapted as a stage musical and has been made into a [[television film of the same name|Mr Stink (film)]] by the [[BBC|BBC]] shown during Christmas 2012 on BBC1.
title: Mr Stink

abstract: The Grammata Serica Recensa is a dictionary of [[Middle Chinese|Middle Chinese]] and [[Old Chinese|Old Chinese]] published by the Swedish sinologist [[Bernard Karlgren|Bernard Karlgren]] in 1957.
title: Grammata Serica Recensa

abstract: Why Nations Fail: The Origins of Power, Prosperity, and Poverty, first published in 2012, is a non-fiction book by Turkish-American [[economist|economist]] [[Daron Acemoglu|Daron Acemoglu]] from the [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology|Massachusetts Institute of Technology]] and British political scientist [[James A. Robinson|James A. Robinson (economist)]] from the [[University of Chicago|University of Chicago]].
title: Why Nations Fail

abstract: The cover art and the images inside were painted by Russian illustrator [[Gennady Spirin|Gennady Spirin]] who chose [[Baroque painting|Baroque painting]] as inspiration for crafting the characters and the scenery. Like her previous endeavors, Madonna promoted the release by appearing on talk show and reading to children at a hospital in London. Critics gave mixed review of the book, with reviews being mostly negative about Madonna's writing but praised Spirin's illustrations. Three weeks after its release, Yakov and the Seven Thieves debuted at number seven on [[The New York Times Best Seller list|The New York Times Best Seller list]] in the category for Children's Picture books.
title: Yakov and the Seven Thieves

abstract: Sarpa Manav: Nagmoni Rohosyo () is a [[Bengali|Bengali language]] [[Science fiction|Science fiction]]-[[fantasy|fantasy]] [[mystery|Mystery fiction]] [[novel|novel]] written by [[Suman Sen|Suman Sen]] and published by Diganto Publication. It is the first installment of Sarpa Manav series. The book was published at [[Star Theatre, Kolkata|Star Theatre, Kolkata]] on 29 December 2017. The book is among the very few science-fiction works made in [[Bengali language|Bengali language]].
title: Sarpa Manav: Nagmoni Rohosyo

abstract: Beyond the Aquila Rift is a 2016 collection of [[science fiction|science fiction]] short stories and novellas by British author [[Alastair Reynolds|Alastair Reynolds]], published by [[Gollancz|Victor Gollancz Ltd]], and edited by [[Jonathan Strahan|Jonathan Strahan]] and William Schafer. It contains works previously published in other venues. The collection features several stories connected to Reynolds's previous stories and novels. "Great Wall of Mars", "Weather", Last Log of the Lachrymosa, and Diamond Dogs take place in the [[Revelation Space universe|Revelation Space universe]], Thousandth Night takes place in the same universe as [[House of Suns|House of Suns]], and "The Water Thief" takes place in the Poseidon's Children universe.
title: Beyond the Aquila Rift

abstract: To Save Humanity is a 2015 collection of 96 essays on [[global health|global health]] from a collection of authors who range from heads of states, movie stars, scientists at leading universities, activists, and [[Nobel Prize|Nobel Prize]] winners. Each contributor was asked the same question: "What is the single most important thing for the future of global health over the next fifty years?" The collection was edited by [[Julio Frenk|Julio Frenk]] and Steven J. Hoffman.
title: To Save Humanity

abstract: Journey to Same-Sex Parenthood is a nonfiction book by author and activist [[Eric Rosswood|Eric Rosswood]]. The work focuses on [[adoption|adoption]], [[foster care|foster care]], [[assisted reproduction|assisted reproduction]], [[surrogacy|surrogacy]], and [[co-parenting|co-parenting]] advice for LGBT couples. The foreword is written by [[Melissa Gilbert|Melissa Gilbert]] and the introduction by [[Charlie Condou|Charlie Condou]].
title: Journey to Same-Sex Parenthood

abstract: The Hour of Peril: The Secret Plot to Murder Lincoln Before the Civil War () is a book by [[Daniel Stashower|Daniel Stashower]] published by [[Minotaur Books|Minotaur Books]] (Under [[St. Martin's Press|St. Martin's Press]] which is now held by [[Macmillan Publishers|Macmillan Publishers]]) on 29 January 2013 & later won 4 [[literary award|literary awards]].
title: The Hour of Peril: The Secret Plot to Murder Lincoln Before the Civil War

abstract: The Berliner Philharmonie is a [[concert hall|concert hall]] in [[Berlin|Berlin]], [[Germany|Germany]] and home to the [[Berlin Philharmonic|Berlin Philharmonic]] Orchestra.
title: Berliner Philharmonie

abstract: The Governor Nelson A. Rockefeller Empire State Plaza (known commonly as the Empire State Plaza, and also as the South Mall) is a complex of several state government buildings in downtown [[Albany|Albany, New York]], [[New York|New York (state)]].
title: Empire State Plaza

abstract: The Al Seef Towers is a cluster of three residential buildings in the [[Jumeirah Lake Towers|Jumeirah Lake Towers]] in [[Dubai|Dubai]], [[United Arab Emirates|United Arab Emirates]]. The complex has two towers that will be 35 floors and one tower 40 floors. Construction of the Al Seef Towers was completed in 2008.
title: Al Seef Towers

abstract: The Svalbard Global Seed Vault () is a secure [[seed bank|seed bank]] on the [[Norwegian|Norway]] island of [[Spitsbergen|Spitsbergen]] near [[Longyearbyen|Longyearbyen]] in the remote [[Arctic|Arctic]] [[Svalbard|Svalbard]] [[archipelago|archipelago]], about from the [[North Pole|North Pole]]. Conservationist [[Cary Fowler|Cary Fowler]], in association with the Consultative Group on International Agricultural Research ([[CGIAR|CGIAR]]), started the vault to preserve a wide variety of plant seeds that are duplicate samples, or "spare" copies, of seeds held in [[gene bank|gene banks]] worldwide. The seed vault is an attempt to ensure against the loss of seeds in other genebanks during large-scale regional or [[global crises|Risks to civilization, humans, and planet Earth]]. The seed vault is managed under terms spelled out in a tripartite agreement between the [[Norwegian government|Politics of Norway]], the [[Crop Trust|Crop Trust]] and the [[Nordic Genetic Resource Center|Nordic Genetic Resource Center]] (NordGen).
title: Svalbard Global Seed Vault

abstract: The first building, known as Bankers Hall East, is located at 855 2nd Street SW and was completed in 1989. It was followed in 2000 by Bankers Hall West, at 888 3rd Street SW. After its completion, they became the tallest twin buildings in Canada.
title: Bankers Hall

abstract: Laguna City is built along Lam Tin's waterfront. Part of Laguna City is built on [[reclaimed land|Land reclamation in Hong Kong]]. The development is adjacent to [[Cha Kwo Ling|Cha Kwo Ling]] Village, one of the last [[squatter villages|shanty town]] in Hong Kong.
title: Laguna City

abstract: Ferens Hall is the original and oldest [[hall of residence|Residence hall]] on a complex known as "[[The Lawns|The Lawns]]" for the [[University of Hull|University of Hull]], [[England|England]]. The motto engraved on the Ferens Hall Shields is "Ferendo non Feriendo" (By bearing not by striking).
title: Ferens Hall

abstract: The city of Miami approved the construction of 300 Grove Bay Residences in September 2007. This approval was controversial, as opponents of the project argued that the city did not provide them with due legal process to contest the planned development and had thus committed procedural violations. In late 2007, various parties, including the [[Vizcaya Museum and Gardens|Villa Vizcaya]] and individual Coconut Grove residents, sued the city to block the development's construction. The Vizcaya Museum argued that the approved development would block scenic oceanfront views from the Villa Vizcaya, while local residents felt that the large, high-rise development would be out-of-place in the more suburban Coconut Grove region of Miami.
title: 300 Grove Bay Residences

abstract: Baltimore Lifeboat Station is situated in [[Baltimore|Baltimore, County Cork]], [[Ireland|Ireland]] and was established in 1919. The station currently runs two lifeboats, , a All-Weather lifeboat, and , a inshore lifeboat.
title: Baltimore Lifeboat Station

abstract: The Palace of Tranquil Longevity (Chinese:), literally, "peaceful old age palace," also called the Qianlong Garden, Qianlong Palace, Qianlong District or the Palace of Tranquility and Longevity, is a palace in [[Beijing|Beijing]], [[China|China]], located in the northeast corner of the [[Inner Court of the Forbidden City|Forbidden City#Inner Court]].
title: Palace of Tranquil Longevity

abstract: Barry Dock Lifeboat Station (based in [[Barry|Barry, Vale of Glamorgan]], [[Vale of Glamorgan|Vale of Glamorgan]], [[Wales|Wales]]) opened in 1901. In 1922, the station received its first motor lifeboat and in 1973 the station received a second lifeboat (which was eventually withdrawn from service in 1979)
title: Barry Dock Lifeboat Station

abstract: Weston-super-Mare Lifeboat Station is a [[lifeboat|Lifeboat (rescue)]] station at [[Weston-super-Mare|Weston-super-Mare]] in Somerset, England. Split between two sites on [[Birnbeck Pier|Birnbeck Pier]] and at Knightstone Harbour, it is operated by the [[Royal National Lifeboat Institution|Royal National Lifeboat Institution]] (RNLI). The first lifeboat was stationed in the town in 1882 and since 1969 it has only operated inshore lifeboats (ILBs), currently a and a smaller .
title: Weston-super-Mare Lifeboat Station

abstract: Burry Port Lifeboat Station (near [[Llanelli|Llanelli]], [[Carmarthenshire|Carmarthenshire]], [[Wales|Wales]]) first opened in 1887, with all funds coming from a legacy left by Mr and Mrs Barclay. The station was moved to Burry Port, due to the original lifeboat based at Llanelli being deemed too far away to be helpful; and the previous station based in Pembrey put at risk due to storms.
title: Burry Port Lifeboat Station

abstract: Torbay Lifeboat Station is the base for [[Royal National Lifeboat Institution|Royal National Lifeboat Institution]] (RNLI) search and rescue operations at [[Brixham|Brixham]], Devon in England. Brixham Lifeboat Station was opened in 1866 but since 1924 it has been known as 'Torbay'. Since 2005 it has operated a all-weather [[lifeboat|Lifeboat (rescue)]] (ALB) together with a inshore lifeboat (ILB).
title: Torbay Lifeboat Station

abstract: Poole Lifeboat Station is the base for [[Royal National Lifeboat Institution|Royal National Lifeboat Institution]] (RNLI) search and rescue operations at [[Poole|Poole]], Dorset in England. The first [[lifeboat|Lifeboat (rescue)]] was stationed at Poole Harbour in 1865 and the present station was opened in 1988. Since November 2016 it has operated two inshore lifeboats, an Atlantic 85 and a D class.
title: Poole Lifeboat Station

abstract: Fowey Lifeboat Station is the base for [[Royal National Lifeboat Institution|Royal National Lifeboat Institution]] (RNLI) search and rescue operations at [[Fowey|Fowey]] on the south coast of [[Cornwall|Cornwall]] in the United Kingdom. The first [[lifeboat|Lifeboat (rescue)]] was stationed in the area in 1859 and the present station was opened in 1997. It operates a [[Trent Class|Trent class lifeboat]] all weather boat (AWB) and a [[D class (IB1)|D class lifeboat (IB1)]] inshore lifeboat (ILB).
title: Fowey Lifeboat Station

abstract: Burnham-on-Sea Lifeboat Station is the base for [[Royal National Lifeboat Institution|Royal National Lifeboat Institution]] (RNLI) search and rescue operations at [[Burnham-on-Sea|Burnham-on-Sea]], [[Somerset|Somerset]] in England. A [[lifeboat|Lifeboat (rescue)]] was stationed in the town from 1836 until 1930. The present station was opened in 2003. It operates two inshore lifeboats (ILBs), a B Class rigid-inflatable boat and an inflatable D Class.
title: Burnham-on-Sea Lifeboat Station

abstract: Angle Lifeboat Station, [[Angle, Pembrokeshire|Angle, Pembrokeshire]], [[Wales|Wales]], first opened in 1868 after a letter from the local Coastguard requested a lifeboat station within the [[Milford Haven Waterway|Milford Haven Waterway]]. Originally called Milford Lifeboat Station until 1892 when it was officially changed at a [[Royal National Lifeboat Institution|Royal National Lifeboat Institution]] committee meeting.
title: Angle Lifeboat Station

abstract: Falmouth Lifeboat Station is the base for [[Royal National Lifeboat Institution|Royal National Lifeboat Institution]] (RNLI) search and rescue operations at [[Falmouth|Falmouth, Cornwall]], [[Cornwall|Cornwall]] in the United Kingdom. The first [[lifeboat|Lifeboat (rescue)]] was stationed in the town in 1867 and the present station was opened in 1993. It operates a [[Severn Class|Severn class lifeboat]] all-weather boat (AWB) and an [[Atlantic 75|Atlantic 75 class lifeboat]] inshore lifeboat (ILB).
title: Falmouth Lifeboat Station

abstract: Australia 108 (previously 70 Southbank Boulevard) is a residential [[supertall|Supertall structure]] [[skyscraper|skyscraper]] currently under construction in the [[Southbank|Southbank, Victoria]] precinct of [[Melbourne|Melbourne]], [[Victoria|Victoria (Australia)]], Australia. When completed, it will become the tallest building in Australia by roof height, surpassing the [[Eureka Tower|Eureka Tower]], and the second-tallest building in Australia by full height, surpassed by [[Q1|Q1 (building)]]. The [[World Class Land|World Class Land]] development project consists of a apartment building with 1,105 apartments over 100 floors. Construction of the revised [[Fender Katsalidis Architects|Fender Katsalidis Architects]]–design by [[Brookfield Multiplex|Brookfield Multiplex]] commenced in 2015, with completion expected in 2020.
title: Australia 108

abstract: The theatre was built in the mid-1960s on the initiative of the city's mayor of the time [[Alish Lambaranski|Alish Lambaranski]]. The Green Theatre was built as a venue intended for important cultural events.
title: Green Theatre

abstract: Eyemouth Lifeboat Station is a [[Royal National Lifeboat Institution|Royal National Lifeboat Institution]] (RNLI) marine-rescue facility in [[Eyemouth|Eyemouth]], [[Berwickshire|Berwickshire]], [[Scotland|Scotland]].
title: Eyemouth Lifeboat Station

abstract: Lowestoft Lifeboat Station is a [[Royal National Lifeboat Institution|Royal National Lifeboat Institution]] (RNLI) operated lifeboat station in the town of [[Lowestoft|Lowestoft]] in the English county of [[Suffolk|Suffolk]]. The station is located at the mouth of [[Lowestoft's outer harbour|Port of Lowestoft]] on the South pier. It is one of the oldest lifeboat stations in the British Isles, having been established in 1801.
title: Lowestoft Lifeboat Station

abstract: Pwllheli Lifeboat Station (based in [[Pwllheli|Pwllheli]], [[Gwynedd|Gwynedd]], [[Wales|Wales]]) was first established by the [[Royal National Lifeboat Institution|Royal National Lifeboat Institution]] (RNLI) in 1891 at a cost of £480. The station currently operates a all-weather lifeboat and a lifeboat.
title: Pwllheli Lifeboat Station

abstract: South Broads Lifeboat Station was an [[RNLI|RNLI]] operated lifeboat station located on [[Oulton Broad|Oulton Broad]] in the town of [[Lowestoft|Lowestoft]] in the English county of [[Suffolk|Suffolk]]. The station operated between 2001 and 2011. The station covered the southern area of [[The Broads|The Broads]] network, an area of over of inland waterways including the [[River Waveney|River Waveney]].The station performed 194 rescues.
title: South Broads Lifeboat Station

abstract: The Former Residence of Jia Yi or Jia Yi's Former Residence() was built during the [[Qing Dynasty|Qing Dynasty]] (1644–1911). It is located in [[Tianxin District|Tianxin District]] of [[Changsha|Changsha]], [[Hunan|Hunan]], [[China|China]]. It has an area of about and a building area of about . It contains buildings such as the gate, the Grand Preceptor Hall (), the Grand Preceptor Temple (), the Xunqiu Cottage (), the Old Tablet Pavilion (), the Stone Tablets (), the Grand Preceptor Well ().
title: Former Residence of Jia Yi

abstract: Hunstanton Lifeboat Station is an [[RNLI|RNLI]] operated lifeboat station located in the village of [[Old Hunstanton|Old Hunstanton]] in the English county of [[Norfolk|Norfolk]]. This is the only lifeboat station on the east coast of England which faces westward, being positioned on the east side of the square-mouthed bay and [[estuary|estuary]] known as the [[Wash|The Wash]].
title: Hunstanton Lifeboat Station

abstract: Trearddur Bay Lifeboat Station is located in [[Trearddur|Trearddur]], [[Anglesey|Anglesey]], [[Wales|Wales]] and opened in 1967 as an inshore lifeboat station.
title: Trearddur Bay Lifeboat Station

abstract: Present day Constantinsborg was constructed around 1400 when it was owned by Erik Jensen Munk and known as Stadsgaard. In 1210 a forest named Stad in the area is mentioned in the records of the [[Ancient See of Aarhus|Ancient See of Aarhus]] who owned the forest at the time so it's possible the original farm dates back further. When Erik Jensen Mun died his son Peder Lykke inherited the estate and managed it until his death in 1464. The manor stayed in the Lykke family until 1583 when Valdemar Parsberg traded the manor to [[King Frederik II|Frederick II of Denmark]].King Frederik II obtained the manor in order to expand his hunting grounds around [[Skanderborg Palace|Skanderborg Palace]]. When Constantinsborg became [[crown land|crown land]] it was made a part of [[Havreballegård|Marselisborg]] Fief. In 1661 the Fief - and Constantinsborg - was given to the [[Dutch|Netherlands]] merchant [[Gabriel Marselis|Gabriel Marselis]] as part of payments for debts incurred by the Danish state during the [[Second Northern War|Second Northern War]]. In 1667 Gabriel Marselis' son Constantin Marselis moved to Denmark to manage his father's many new estates. He moved into Constantinsborg which he had named after himself. In 1683 Constantinsborg was officially recognized as a manor with privileges which indicates it was a substantial estate at the time.
title: Constantinsborg

abstract: 10 Downing Street, colloquially known in the United Kingdom as Number 10, is the headquarters of the [[Government of the United Kingdom|Government of the United Kingdom]] and the official residence and office of the [[First Lord of the Treasury|First Lord of the Treasury]], a post which, for much of the 18th and 19th centuries and invariably since 1905, has been held by the [[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom|Prime Minister of the United Kingdom]].
title: 10 Downing Street

abstract: The Royal Concertgebouw (, ) is a concert hall in [[Amsterdam|Amsterdam]], [[Netherlands|Netherlands]]. The Dutch term "concertgebouw" literally translates into English as "concert building". On 11 April 2013, on occasion of the building's 125th anniversary, [[Queen Beatrix|Beatrix of the Netherlands]] bestowed the Royal Title "[[Koninklijk|Koninklijk]]" upon the building, as she did previously (in 1988) to the [[Royal Concertgebouw Orchestra|Royal Concertgebouw Orchestra]]. Because of its highly regarded [[acoustics|Architectural acoustics]], the Concertgebouw is considered one of the finest [[concert hall|concert halls]] in the world, along with places such as Boston's [[Symphony Hall|Symphony Hall, Boston]] and the [[Musikverein|Musikverein]] in Vienna.
title: Concertgebouw

abstract: The Riga Radio and TV Tower () in [[Riga|Riga]], [[Latvia|Latvia]] is the tallest tower in the [[European Union|European Union]]. It was built between 1979 and 1989 with funding from the central government of the [[Soviet Union|Soviet Union]]. Its highest point reaches , which makes it the third tallest tower in [[Europe|Europe]] (after the [[Ostankino Tower|Ostankino Tower]] at and the [[Kiev TV Tower|Kiev TV Tower]] at ) and the [[15th tallest|List of tallest towers in the world]] self-supporting tower in the world.
title: Riga Radio and TV Tower

abstract: 25 Bank Street is an office tower in [[Canary Wharf|Canary Wharf]], in the [[Docklands|London Docklands]] area of [[London|London]]. It is currently home to the European headquarters of the investment bank [[JPMorgan Chase|JPMorgan Chase]].
title: 25 Bank Street

abstract: The site now occupied by Belfast City Hall was once the home of the White Linen Hall, an important international Linen Exchange. The street that runs from the back door of Belfast City Hall through the middle of [[Linen Quarter|Linen Quarter, Belfast]] is Linen Hall Street.Plans for the City Hall began in 1888 when Belfast was awarded [[city status|City status in the United Kingdom]] by [[Queen Victoria|Queen Victoria]]. This was in recognition of Belfast's rapid expansion and thriving [[linen|Irish linen]], [[rope-making|Rope]], [[shipbuilding|shipbuilding]] and engineering industries. During this period Belfast briefly overtook [[Dublin|Dublin]] as the most populous city in [[Ireland|Ireland]].
title: Belfast City Hall

abstract: The Singapore Flyer is a giant [[Ferris wheel|Ferris wheel]] in [[Singapore|Singapore]]. Described by its operators as an [[observation wheel|Ferris wheel#Observation wheels]], it opened in 2008, construction having taken about 2½ years. It carried its first paying passengers on 11 February, opened to the public on 1 March, and was officially opened on 15 April. It has 28 air-conditioned capsules, each able to accommodate 28 passengers, and incorporates a three-storey terminal building.
title: Singapore Flyer

abstract: Sutro Tower is a three-pronged TV and radio [[antenna tower|Radio masts and towers]] in [[San Francisco|San Francisco]], [[California|California]]. Rising from a hill between [[Twin Peaks|Twin Peaks (San Francisco)]] and [[Mount Sutro|Mount Sutro]] near Clarendon Heights, it is a prominent feature of the city skyline and a landmark for city residents and visitors. The tower was the tallest structure in San Francisco from the time of its completion until 2017, when it was surpassed by the [[Salesforce Tower|Salesforce Tower]].
title: Sutro Tower

abstract: The complex opened in 2003 as Qwest Center Omaha, and adopted the name of CenturyLink Center Omaha on July 15, 2011, as part of a buyout of [[Qwest|Qwest]] by [[CenturyLink|List of CenturyLink operating companies]] (formerly CenturyTel). In July 2018, [[CHI Health|CHI Health]] bought the naming rights to the arena under a 20-year agreement worth $23.6 million, and the arena was renamed CHI Health Center Omaha effective September 1, 2018.
title: CHI Health Center Omaha

abstract: The Dorint Hotel Tower is the best-known high-rise building in the [[German|Germany]] city of [[Augsburg|Augsburg]] and visible throughout the city. At 115 m (167 m with the antenna) it is the highest building in the Augsburg area and among the ten highest in [[Bavaria|Bavaria]]. It is located at the intersection of Gögginger Straße and Imhofstraße, in the borough of Göggingen. In its vicinity are the Congress Hall and Wittelsbacher Park.
title: Dorint Hotel Tower

abstract: The Rudelsburg is a ruined [[hill castle|hill castle]] located on the east bank of the river [[Saale|Saale]] above [[Saaleck|Saaleck (Naumburg)]], a village in the borough of [[Naumburg|Naumburg]] in the county of [[Burgenlandkreis|Burgenlandkreis]] in [[Saxony-Anhalt|Saxony-Anhalt]], [[Germany|Germany]]. The Rudelsburg was built in the [[Middle Ages|Middle Ages]] by the [[Bishop of Naumburg|Bishop of Naumburg]] and served to secure trade routes such as the [[Via Regia|Via Regia]] through the Saale Valley.
title: Rudelsburg

abstract: The Federal Reserve Bank of Boston, commonly known as the Boston Fed, is responsible for the [[First District|Federal Reserve Bank]] of the [[Federal Reserve|Federal Reserve]], which covers [[New England|New England]]: [[Maine|Maine]], [[Massachusetts|Massachusetts]], [[New Hampshire|New Hampshire]], [[Rhode Island|Rhode Island]], [[Vermont|Vermont]] and all of [[Connecticut|Connecticut]] except [[Fairfield County|Fairfield County, Connecticut]]. It is headquartered in a distinctive tall, 32-story [[Federal Reserve Bank Building|Federal Reserve Bank Building (Boston)]] at 600 [[Atlantic Avenue|Atlantic Avenue (Boston)]], [[Boston|Boston]]. Designed by [[architecture|architecture]] firm [[Hugh Stubbins & Associates|Hugh Stubbins & Associates]], the tower portion of the building is suspended between two towers on either side.The code of the Bank is A1, meaning that dollar bills from this Bank will have the letter A on them. Its current president is [[Eric S. Rosengren|Eric S. Rosengren]], who replaced [[Cathy E. Minehan|Cathy Minehan]] in July 2007. The Boston Fed describes its mission as promoting "growth and financial stability in New England and the nation". The Boston Fed also includes the New England Public Policy Center.
title: Federal Reserve Bank of Boston

abstract: The Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta, (informally referred to as the Atlanta Fed and the Bank), is the sixth district of the 12 [[Federal Reserve Banks|Federal Reserve Banks]] of the United States and is headquartered in [[midtown|Midtown Atlanta]] [[Atlanta, Georgia|Atlanta]].
title: Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta

abstract: [[St Albans Abbey|St Albans Abbey]] claimed rights to the [[manor of Cashio|Liberty of St Albans]] (then called "Albanestou"), which included Watford, dating from a grant by [[King Offa|King Offa]] of Mercia in AD 793. When King [[Henry VIII of England|Henry VIII of England]] dissolved the monasteries in 1539, Watford was divided from Cashio, and the King made himself [[lord of the manor|lord of the manor]] of Cassiobury. In 1546, he granted the manor to [[Sir Richard Morrison|Richard Morrison (ambassador)]], who started to build Cassiobury House in the extensive gardens, but had not made much progress by 1553, when he went into exile abroad. The estate grounds were much larger than they are today, reaching as far as [[North Watford|North Watford]] and southwards almost to [[Moor Park|Moor Park (house)]]. After the death of his father in 1556, [[Sir Charles Morrison|Charles Morison (MP for Tavistock)]] (1549–1599) continued building and completed the mansion, which had 56 rooms, a long gallery, stables, a dairy, and a [[brewhouse|brewhouse]]. Sir Charles was succeeded by his son, [[Sir Charles Morrison, 1st Baronet|Sir Charles Morrison, 1st Baronet]] (1587–1628); the younger Charles had a daughter, Elizabeth Morrison (1610–1660).
title: Cassiobury House

abstract: The Nebraska State Capitol is the seat of government for the U.S. State of [[Nebraska|Nebraska]] and is located in downtown [[Lincoln|Lincoln, Nebraska]]. It was designed by New York architect [[Bertram Grosvenor Goodhue|Bertram Goodhue]] in 1920 and was constructed of [[Indiana limestone|Indiana limestone]] from 1922 to 1932. The capitol houses the primary executive and judicial offices of Nebraska and is home to the [[Nebraska Legislature|Nebraska Legislature]]—the only state [[unicameral|Unicameralism]] legislature in the [[United States|United States]].
title: Nebraska State Capitol

abstract: Blyth Lifeboat Station is operated by the [[Royal National Lifeboat Institution|Royal National Lifeboat Institution]] and currently operates a [[D Class (IB1)|D class lifeboat (IB1)]] "Jennie B".
title: Blyth Lifeboat Station

abstract: Cromer Lifeboat Station is an [[RNLI|RNLI]] station located in the town of [[Cromer|Cromer]] in the [[English|England]] county of [[Norfolk|Norfolk]]. The station operates two [[lifeboat|Lifeboat (rescue)s]] - one for inshore work and the other for offshore work.
title: Cromer Lifeboat Station

abstract: The Tianjin Tower, or Jin Tower (), or Tianjin World Financial Center () is a modern [[supertall skyscraper|supertall skyscraper]] located in the [[Heping District|Heping District, Tianjin]] of [[Tianjin|Tianjin]], [[China|China]], on the banks of the [[Hai River|Hai River]]. The mixed-use tower is tall and contains 74 floors above ground and 4 below, with an observation deck at . The area of the glass [[unitized curtain wall|unitized curtain wall]], manufactured by [[Jangho Group|Jangho Group]], is 215,000m². It is notable as the first office building in Tianjin to be equipped with double decker elevators.
title: Tianjin World Financial Center

abstract: North Berwick Lifeboat Station is a [[Royal National Lifeboat Institution|Royal National Lifeboat Institution]] (RNLI) marine-rescue facility in [[North Berwick|North Berwick]], [[East Lothian|East Lothian]], [[Scotland|Scotland]].
title: North Berwick Lifeboat Station

abstract: The Residences is a complex of 18 residential towers in the [[Downtown Dubai|Downtown Dubai]] development in [[Dubai|Dubai]], [[United Arab Emirates|United Arab Emirates]]. Ten have been completed and eight more were under construction but have been canceled.
title: The Residences

abstract: The historic Abbe Creek School is a [[one-room schoolhouse|one-room schoolhouse]] museum located one mile west of [[Mt. Vernon, Iowa|Mt. Vernon, Iowa]], on E48. It is believed to be the oldest standing one room brick schoolhouse in [[Iowa|Iowa]]. The school is located on land claimed by [[William Abbe|William Abbe]], the first white settler in [[Linn County, Iowa|Linn County, Iowa]].
title: Abbe Creek School

abstract: The Southfield Town Center is a cluster of five interconnected skyscrapers forming a contemporary office complex in the [[Detroit|Detroit]] suburb of [[Southfield, Michigan|Southfield, Michigan]]. It includes the [[Westin|Westin Hotels]] Southfield Detroit Hotel, restaurants, a fitness center, and a major [[conference center|conference center]] for up to 1,000 attendees. This office-hotel complex is situated along Town Center Drive off [[M-10|M-10 (Michigan highway)]] (Lodge Freeway), across from [[Lawrence Technological University|Lawrence Technological University]] in [[Metro Detroit|Metro Detroit]], with many of its tallest buildings named after their addresses along the road. Separately, there is a 33-story luxury [[residential|residential]] [[high-rise|high-rise]] at 5000 Town Center. The [[American Center|American Center]], another 26-story office tower near the confluence of [[Interstate 696|Interstate 696]] (I-696) and M-10, is not part of the complex.
title: Southfield Town Center

abstract: The Louvre Palace (, ) is a former [[royal palace|royal palace]] located on the [[Right Bank|Right Bank]] of the [[Seine|Seine]] in [[Paris|Paris]], between the [[Tuileries Gardens|Tuileries Gardens]] and the church of [[Saint-Germain l'Auxerrois|Saint-Germain l'Auxerrois]]. Originally a fortress built in the medieval period, it became a royal palace in the fourteenth century under [[Charles V|Charles V of France]] and was used from time to time by the [[kings of France|kings of France]] as their main Paris residence. Its present structure has evolved in stages since the 16th century. In 1793 part of the Louvre became a public museum, now the [[Musée du Louvre|Musée du Louvre]], which has expanded to occupy most of the building.
title: Louvre Palace

abstract: The Grand Hotel Prishtina is a hotel situated in the Mother Theresa Boulevard in downtown [[Pristina|Pristina]], the capital of [[Kosovo|Kosovo]].
title: Grand Hotel Prishtina

abstract: Torre de Cali ("Cali Tower") is a 46-story [[skyscraper|skyscraper]] in downtown [[Cali|Cali]], [[Colombia|Colombia]]. The tower has a full height of 211 metres if the communication masts atop are counted. However, roof height is 183.5 metres, making it the third tallest in [[Colombia|Colombia]] after the 196-metre, 52-story "[[Torre Colpatria|Torre Colpatria]]" and the 190-metre "[[Centro de Comercio Internacional|Centro de Comercio Internacional]]" in downtown [[Bogotá|Bogotá]].
title: Cali Tower

abstract: Snowhill, as it is spelt by the developers, is a [[mixed-use development|mixed-use development]] in the [[Colmore business district|Colmore Row]], known historically as Snow Hill, in Central [[Birmingham|Birmingham]], England. The area, between Snow Hill Queensway and [[Birmingham Snow Hill station|Birmingham Snow Hill railway station]], is being redeveloped by the [[Ballymore Group|Ballymore Group]]. The £500   million phased scheme has been partly completed on the site of a former surface car park adjacent to the railway station and Midland Metro terminus.
title: Snowhill

abstract: One Congress Plaza is a skyscraper in [[Downtown|Downtown Austin]] [[Austin|Austin, Texas]], the state capital of [[Texas|Texas]] in the [[United States|United States]]. Standing 390 feet (119 meters) tall and containing 30 floors, standing as the eighth tallest building in Austin. The building contains a sunken plaza, which include [[trees|trees]], a food court, water features, and park [[bench|Bench (furniture)es]], as well as the location for the [[AMOA|Austin Museum of Art]] Art Show.
title: One Congress Plaza

abstract: The Evergreen Maritime Museum () is a [[maritime museum|maritime museum]] in [[Zhongzheng District|Zhongzheng District]], [[Taipei City|Taipei City]], [[Taiwan|Taiwan]].
title: Evergreen Maritime Museum

abstract: The Rufer House at Schließmanngasse 11 in Vienna, was designed by architect [[Adolf Loos|Adolf Loos]] in 1922 for [[Josef|Josef Rufer]] and Marie Rufer. It is considered to be the first example of the new style of Raumplan. Raumplan was very different from its predecessor Free Plan in its internal spatial organization. While not as well known as some of other of Loos’ houses, this set the precedent for his later designs.
title: Rufer House

abstract: Selsey Lifeboat Station is an [[RNLI|RNLI]] station located in the town of [[Selsey|Selsey]] in the [[English|England]] [[county|county]] of [[West Sussex|West Sussex]] in the [[United Kingdom|United Kingdom]].
title: Selsey Lifeboat Station
