The [[Belgian|Belgian]] girl group [[K3|K3 (band)]] also recorded a [[Dutch|Dutch language]] version of the song for the movie. Animation production was split between [[A. Film A/S|A. Film A/S]] in Denmark, [[Munich Animation|Munich Animation]] in Germany and [[Terraglyph Interactive Studios|Terraglyph Interactive Studios]] in Dublin, Ireland.
title: Help! I'm a Fish

abstract: So Proudly We Hail! is a 1943 American [[war film|war film]] directed and produced by [[Mark Sandrich|Mark Sandrich]] and starring [[Claudette Colbert|Claudette Colbert]], [[Paulette Goddard|Paulette Goddard]] – who was nominated for an [[Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress|Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress]] for her performance – and [[Veronica Lake|Veronica Lake]]. Also featuring [[George Reeves|George Reeves]], it was produced and released by [[Paramount Pictures|Paramount Pictures]].
title: So Proudly We Hail!

abstract: The Care Bears Adventure in Wonderland is a 1987 Canadian-American [[animated|animation]] [[fantasy film|fantasy film]] and the third theatrically released film in the [[Care Bears|Care Bears]] franchise. It was released in the United States and Canada on August 7, 1987, by [[Cineplex Odeon Films|Cineplex Odeon Films]], and is based on [[Lewis Carroll|Lewis Carroll]]'s [[Alice|Alice's Adventures in Wonderland]] stories. The fourth feature film made at Toronto's [[Nelvana|Nelvana]] studio, it was directed by staff member Raymond Jafelice and produced by the firm's founders ([[Michael Hirsh|Michael Hirsh (producer)]], [[Patrick Loubert|Patrick Loubert]] and [[Clive A. Smith|Clive A. Smith]]). It starred the voices of [[Keith Knight|Keith Knight (actor)]], [[Bob Dermer|Bob Dermer]], [[Jim Henshaw|Jim Henshaw]], [[Tracey Moore|Tracey Moore]] and [[Elizabeth Hanna|Elizabeth Hanna]]. In the film, the Care Bears must rescue the Princess of Wonderland from the Evil Wizard and his assistants, Dim and Dumb. After the [[White Rabbit|White Rabbit]] shows them her photo, the Bears and Cousins search around the Earth for her before enlisting an unlikely replacement, an ordinary girl named Alice, to save her true look-alike. Venturing into Wonderland, the group encounters a host of strange characters, among them a [[rapping|hip hop music]] [[Cheshire Cat|Cheshire Cat]] and the [[Jabberwocky|Jabberwocky]].
title: The Care Bears Adventure in Wonderland

abstract: Karan Arjun is a [[1995|Bollywood films of 1995]] Indian [[action|Action film]] [[drama film|Drama (film and television)]] starring [[Shah Rukh Khan|Shah Rukh Khan]], [[Salman Khan|Salman Khan]], [[Kajol|Kajol]], [[Rakhee|Rakhee Gulzar]], [[Mamta Kulkarni|Mamta Kulkarni]], [[Amrish Puri|Amrish Puri]], [[Aashif Sheikh|Aashif Sheikh]] and [[Ranjeet|Ranjeet]]. The film was directed by [[Rakesh Roshan|Rakesh Roshan]] and written by [[Sachin Bhowmick|Sachin Bhowmick]], Ravi Kapoor and Anwar Khan. Karan Arjun is a mix of an upbeat [[Bollywood|Bollywood]] [[musical|Musical film]], and an action movie, with religious overtones. It was the [[second-highest-grossing Indian film|List of highest-grossing Indian films]] of 1995, after [[Dilwale Dulhania Le Jayenge|Dilwale Dulhania Le Jayenge]], which also starred [[Shah Rukh Khan|Shah Rukh Khan]] and [[Kajol|Kajol]].
title: Karan Arjun

abstract: Hard Target was Woo's first American film and was also the first major Hollywood film made by a Chinese director. [[Universal Pictures|Universal Studios]] was nervous about having Woo direct a feature, and sent in director [[Sam Raimi|Sam Raimi]] to look over the film's production and to take Woo's place as director if he were to fail. Woo went through several scripts finding mostly [[martial arts film|martial arts films]] with which he was not interested. After deciding on Chuck Pfarrer's script for Hard Target, Woo wanted to have actor [[Kurt Russell|Kurt Russell]] in the lead role, but found Russell too busy with other projects. Woo then went with Universal's initial choice of having Jean-Claude Van Damme star. Woo got along with Van Damme during filming and raised the amount of action in the film as he knew that Van Damme was up for it.
title: Hard Target

abstract: Walk the Line previewed at the [[Telluride Film Festival|Telluride Film Festival]] on September 4, 2005, and went into wide release on November 18. The film was nominated for five Oscars at the [[78th Academy Awards|78th Academy Awards]], including [[Best Actor|Academy Award for Best Actor]] (Phoenix), [[Best Actress|Academy Award for Best Actress]] (Witherspoon, which she won), and [[Best Costume Design|Academy Award for Best Costume Design]] ([[Arianne Phillips|Arianne Phillips]]). The film grossed more than $186 million worldwide.
title: Walk the Line

abstract: Operation Dumbo Drop is a 1995 American [[war|war film]] [[comedy film|comedy film]] directed by [[Simon Wincer|Simon Wincer]] that explores war, politics, and animal welfare. The storyline was conceived from a screenplay written by [[Gene Quintano|Gene Quintano]] and [[Jim Kouf|Jim Kouf]] based on a true story by United States Army Major Jim Morris. The film stars [[Danny Glover|Danny Glover]] and [[Ray Liotta|Ray Liotta]] as [[Green Berets|Special Forces (United States Army)]] during the [[Vietnam War|Vietnam War]] in 1968, who attempt to transport an elephant through jungle terrain to a local South Vietnamese village which in turn helps American forces monitor [[Viet Cong|Viet Cong]] activity.
title: Operation Dumbo Drop

abstract: Care Bears Movie II: A New Generation is a 1986 Canadian-American [[animated|animation]] [[fantasy film|fantasy film]] produced by [[LBS Communications|Lexington Broadcast Services Company]] and [[Nelvana|Nelvana]]. The third animated feature from Nelvana, it was directed by Dale Schott, written by [[Peter Sauder|Peter Sauder]] and produced by Nelvana's three founders ([[Michael Hirsh|Michael Hirsh (producer)]], [[Patrick Loubert|Patrick Loubert]] and [[Clive A. Smith|Clive A. Smith]]). It stars the voices of [[Alyson Court|Alyson Court]], [[Cree Summer|Cree Summer]], [[Maxine Miller|Maxine Miller]] and [[Hadley Kay|Hadley Kay]]. In the second film based on the [[Care Bears|Care Bears]] franchise, a character called The Great Wishing Star (voiced by [[Chris Wiggins|Chris Wiggins]]) tells the origins of the Care Bears, and the story of their first Caring Mission. True Heart Bear and Noble Heart Horse lead the other Care Bears and Care Bear Cousins, as they come to the aid of Christy, a young orphan camper who is tempted by an evil shape-shifting figure named Dark Heart. This is also the first appearance of the Care Bear Cubs, who also had their own line of toys.
title: Care Bears Movie II: A New Generation

abstract: Teeny Little Super Guy (TLSG) was created by animator [[Paul Fierlinger|Paul Fierlinger]] as a series of 13 installments for [[PBS|PBS]]'s Sesame Street in 1982. The first Teeny Little Super Guy cartoon took two months to create. The series of segments were frequently shown on Sesame Street for several years. However, in the late 1990s the segments were shown sporadically (eventually not appearing on the show at all from 1997–2000). The segments reappeared briefly on Sesame Street in 2001 and a short clip (a part of the theme song only) was shown on Sesame Street's 35th anniversary Special, The Street We Live On. The shorts have not appeared on Sesame Street since that time.
title: Teeny Little Super Guy

abstract: Andarivaadu (Man of the Masses) is a 2005 [[Tollywood|Cinema of Andhra Pradesh]] [[action|action film]] [[comedy-drama|comedy-drama]] film directed by [[Srinu Vytla|Srinu Vytla]]. The film stars [[Chiranjeevi|Chiranjeevi]], [[Rimi Sen|Rimi Sen]], [[Tabu|Tabu (actress)]], [[Prakash Raj|Prakash Raj]], and [[Pradeep Rawat|Pradeep Rawat (actor)]]. It has been dubbed in Hindi as Ek Aur Himmathwala.
title: Andarivaadu

abstract: Dhoom was the first action film produced by [[Yash Raj Films|Yash Raj Films]] in 16 years, since [[Yash Chopra|Yash Chopra]] directed [[Vijay|Vijay (1988 film)]] (1988). It tells the story of a motorbike gang committing robberies throughout Mumbai and the police officer who teams up with a motorbike dealer to stop them.
title: Dhoom

abstract: Sepet is a 2005 Malaysian [[teen|teen film]] [[romantic|romance film]] [[comedy-drama|comedy-drama]] film set in [[Ipoh|Ipoh]], [[Malaysia|Malaysia]]. Directed by [[Yasmin Ahmad|Yasmin Ahmad]], it tells a tale of a love that blooms between a [[Chinese|Chinese Malaysian]] boy and a [[Malay|Malay people]] girl. Sepet is a [[Malay|Malay language]] word which, in this context, refers to the 'slit eyes' of the Chinese.
title: Sepet

abstract: Death Machine is a 1994 British-Japanese [[cyberpunk|Cyberpunk]] [[horror film|horror film]] written and directed by [[Stephen Norrington|Stephen Norrington]]. It stars [[Brad Dourif|Brad Dourif]], [[Ely Pouget|Ely Pouget]], [[William Hootkins|William Hootkins]], [[John Sharian|John Sharian]], and [[Richard Brake|Richard Brake]]. [[Rachel Weisz|Rachel Weisz]], still early in her career at the time of the film's release, appears in a brief supporting role. The film was the directorial debut of Norrington, who had previously worked as a special effects artist on films such as [[Lifeforce|Lifeforce (film)]], [[Aliens|Aliens (film)]], [[Hardware|Hardware (film)]], [[The Witches|The Witches (1990 film)]], and [[Split Second|Split Second (1992 film)]].
title: Death Machine

abstract: C'était un rendez-vous (English: It Was a Date) is a 1976 French [[short film|short film]] directed by [[Claude Lelouch|Claude Lelouch]], showing a high-speed drive through [[Paris|Paris]].
title: C'était un rendez-vous

abstract: New Police Story is a 2004 [[Hong Kong action film|Hong Kong action cinema]] produced and directed by [[Benny Chan|Benny Chan (film director)]], and also produced by and starring [[Jackie Chan|Jackie Chan]]. The film was released in the Hong Kong on 24 September 2004. The film is a [[reboot|Reboot (fiction)]] of the [[Police Story series|Police Story (film series)]] and is the fifth film in the series. New Police Story relies much more on drama and heavy action than its predecessors.
title: New Police Story

abstract: Free Jimmy ([[No|Norwegian language]]: Slipp Jimmy fri) is a 2006 Norwegian-British [[adult|adult animation]] [[computer-animated|computer animation]] [[comedy film|comedy film]] first released in [[Norwegian|Norwegian language]] in 2006, and later in English in 2008. The film was written and directed by acclaimed Norwegian [[subculture|subculture]] [[comic book|comic book]] artist [[Christopher Nielsen|Christopher Nielsen]] and features a number of characters from Nielsen's dark humor-laden comic books. The plot is an [[adult|adult]]-oriented [[black comedy|black comedy]] in which different groups of varying nationalities, and motives, all attempt to find a wayward and drug-addicted elephant in the Norwegian [[wilderness|tundra]] before the others do. The film explores a wide number of themes including addiction, [[drug abuse|drug abuse]], [[freedom|Political freedom]], [[nature|nature]], [[tragedy|tragedy]], crime, [[materialism|materialism]], [[urban decay|urban decay]], [[animal cruelty|animal cruelty]] and [[animal rights|animal rights]].
title: Free Jimmy

abstract: Atlantis, the Lost Continent is a 1961 American [[science fiction film|science fiction film]] in [[Metrocolor|Metrocolor]] from [[Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer|Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer]], produced and directed by [[George Pal|George Pal]], that stars Sal Ponti (under the screen name of Anthony Hall), [[Joyce Taylor|Joyce Taylor]], and [[John Dall|John Dall]].
title: Atlantis, the Lost Continent

abstract: Koshish is considered a landmark movie in the history of [[Indian cinema|Indian cinema]]. It stars [[Sanjeev Kumar|Sanjeev Kumar (actor)]] and [[Jaya Bhaduri|Jaya Bhaduri]]. The movie depicts a deaf and mute couple and their conflicts, pain and struggle to carve out a niche for themselves in a desensitized society. It is a remake of the Japanese film Happiness of Us Alone (1961). The film was later remade in Tamil as [[Uyarndhavargal|Uyarndhavargal]] in 1977 with [[Kamal Haasan|Kamal Haasan]] and [[Sujatha|Sujatha (actress)]].
title: Koshish

abstract: Highlander: The Search for Vengeance is an [[animated|animation]] film and an anime installment of the cult [[Highlander|Highlander (franchise)]] franchise. The film was directed by [[Yoshiaki Kawajiri|Yoshiaki Kawajiri]] ([[Ninja Scroll|Ninja Scroll]], [[Vampire Hunter D: Bloodlust|Vampire Hunter D: Bloodlust]]) and was written by David Abramowitz, also the writer for [[Highlander: The Series|Highlander: The Series]], [[Highlander: The Raven|Highlander: The Raven]] and [[Highlander: The Source|Highlander: The Source]]. The film was a [[joint venture|joint venture]] between [[Imagi Animation Studios|Imagi Animation Studios]] and [[Madhouse Studio|Madhouse (company)]], with Imagi providing the script and the soundtrack, while Madhouse produced the animation. It was produced in association with Davis-Panzer Productions and distributed by [[Manga Entertainment|Manga Entertainment]] on June 5, 2007. It aired July 30, 2007 on [[Sci Fi|Syfy]]'s [[Ani-Monday|Ani-Monday]] block.
title: Highlander: The Search for Vengeance

abstract: The Care Bears' Big Wish Movie is a 2005 children's direct-to-video [[animated|animated]] feature film, produced by [[Nelvana|Nelvana]] Limited and released by [[Lions Gate Home Entertainment|Lions Gate Entertainment]]. Directed by Larry Jacobs and Ron Pitts, and written by Jeffrey Alan Schechter, the film is a follow-up to the [[Care Bears|Care Bears]]' previous efforts in 2004's [[Journey to Joke-a-lot|Care Bears: Journey to Joke-a-lot]]. It was the fifth film to feature the Bears, and the second to be computer-animated.
title: The Care Bears' Big Wish Movie

abstract: Beneath Clouds is a film by Australian director [[Ivan Sen|Ivan Sen]]. It is the feature film debut by the two lead actors. Damian Pitt was approached by Sen on the streets of [[Moree, New South Wales|Moree, New South Wales]], and had never acted before. Dannielle Hall was cast through a more traditional method, via an audition tape. Much of the support cast were local residents from Pitt's hometown of Moree.
title: Beneath Clouds

abstract: Production started on October 12, 2004 with a final release date of July 29, 2005. Critics opinions were mostly negative but indicated that the actors were not to blame. Must Love Dogs took the fifth spot on its opening weekend and has grossed more than $58 million worldwide. The film was released on VHS and DVD on December 20, 2005.
title: Must Love Dogs

abstract: Above the Rim is a 1994 American [[sports film|List of sports films]] co-written, storied and directed by [[Jeff Pollack|Jeff Pollack]] in his directorial debut. The screenplay was written by [[Barry Michael Cooper|Barry Michael Cooper]], from a story by [[Benny Medina|Benny Medina]].
title: Above the Rim

abstract: Devasuram ([[Malayalam|Malayalam]]: ദേവാസുരം; ) is a [[1993|List of Malayalam films of 1993]] [[India|Indian]] [[Malayalam-language|Malayalam cinema]] [[drama film|Drama (film and television)]] directed by [[I. V. Sasi|I. V. Sasi]] and written by [[Ranjith|Ranjith (director)]]. It stars [[Mohanlal|Mohanlal]], [[Revathi|Revathi]], [[Nedumudi Venu|Nedumudi Venu]], [[Innocent|Innocent (actor)]], [[Napoleon|Napoleon (actor)]], [[V. K. Sreeraman|V. K. Sreeraman]], [[Manian Pillai Raju|Manian Pillai Raju]], and [[Augustine|Augustine (actor)]]. The songs featured in the film are composed by [[M. G. Radhakrishnan|M. G. Radhakrishnan]], while [[S. P. Venkatesh|S. P. Venkatesh]] composed the [[background score|Film score]].
title: Devasuram

abstract: Filmed at [[Pinewood Studios|Pinewood Studios]] and the surrounding areas in [[Buckinghamshire|Buckinghamshire]], England, The Watcher in the Woods was one of several live-action films produced by [[Walt Disney Productions|Walt Disney Pictures]] in the 1980s, when the studio was targeting [[young adult|young adult fiction]] audiences. The film had its premiere at the [[Ziegfeld Theatre|Ziegfeld Theatre (1969)]] in New York City in April 1980, but was pulled from release after ten days, and future screenings were canceled by the studio due to an overwhelming negative response from critics and audiences. Several changes were made thereafter, including the excision of a pre-credits sequence, as well the filming of an entirely new ending, which was directed by [[Vincent McEveety|Vincent McEveety]] without Hough's involvement. Disney re-released the revised cut of the film on October 9, 1981, and it grossed $5 million.
title: The Watcher in the Woods

abstract: Kamal Amrohi's PR man said: "Shah Jahan made Taj Mahal for his wife, Kamal Sahab wanted to do the same with Pakeezah." The concept, Kamal Amrohi says was irretrievably fixed with his love for his wife Meena Kumari. According to Kamal Amrohi, he hoped to create a film which would be worthy of her as an actress, and worthy of the love he felt for her as a woman. Meena Kumari regarded the film as Kamal Amrohi's tribute to her.
title: Pakeezah

abstract: Vanaprastham - The Last Dance () is a 1999 Indian-[[French|France]]-[[German|Germany]] co-production [[Malayalam language|Malayalam]] drama film directed by [[Shaji N. Karun|Shaji N. Karun]]. It stars [[Mohanlal|Mohanlal]], [[Suhasini|Suhasini Mani Ratnam]], [[Mattannur Sankarankutty Marar|Mattannur Sankarankutty Marar]], [[Kalamandalam Gopi|Kalamandalam Gopi]], and [[Venmani Haridas|Venmani Haridas]]. The film's music is composed by [[Zakir Hussain|Zakir Hussain (musician)]]. The film follows the tale of a lower-caste [[Kathakali|Kathakali]] artist Kunhikuttan (Mohanlal) during the 1940s era in [[Travancore|Travancore]]. Subhadra (Suhasini), a member of an aristocratic family, falls in love with the character [[Arjuna|Arjuna]] played by Kunhikuttan. She views Kunhikuttan and the character he plays as separate individuals. Their affair eventually leads to the birth of a son, who is hidden away by Subhadra from Kunhikuttan for almost a lifetime.
title: Vanaprastham

abstract: Dragon Ball: Curse of the Blood Rubies, known in Japan as Dragon Ball during its initial theatrical release and later retitled for its home video release, is a 1986 Japanese [[anime|anime]] [[fantasy|fantasy film]] [[martial arts|martial arts film]] [[adventure film|adventure film]] and the first alternate continuity in a series of [[feature films|feature film]] in the [[Dragon Ball|Dragon Ball (anime)]] anime franchise, based on the [[manga of the same name|Dragon Ball]] by [[Akira Toriyama|Akira Toriyama]]. The film is a modified adaptation of the initial story arc in the manga, with the original character King Gurumes substituting [[Emperor Pilaf|Emperor Pilaf]]'s role as the main antagonist. Like in the manga, it depicts how [[Goku|Goku]] meets up with [[Bulma|Bulma]], as well as [[Oolong|Oolong (Dragon Ball)]], [[Yamcha|Yamcha]], [[Puar|Pu'ar]] and finally [[Master Roshi|Master Roshi]] during his first search for the Dragon Balls.
title: Dragon Ball: Curse of the Blood Rubies

abstract: Chitchor (also transliterated as Chit Chor) is a [[1976|Bollywood films of 1976]] Indian [[Hindi|Hindi]] romantic [[musical film|musical film]], written and directed by Basu Chatterjee. The film's title means "Heart Stealer" in Hindi. The film is a [[Rajshri Productions|Rajshri Productions]] film produced by [[Tarachand Barjatya|Tarachand Barjatya]]. It is based on a Bengali story, Chittachakor by [[Subodh Ghosh|Subodh Ghosh]]. K. J. Yesudas and Master Raju won the [[National Film Awards 1976|24th National Film Awards]] for Best Male Playback Singer and Best Child Artist respectively.
title: Chitchor

abstract: The Wrong Guy is a [[1997|1997 in film]] [[Canadian|Cinema of Canada]] [[comedy film|comedy film]] directed by [[David Steinberg|David Steinberg]]. It was co-written by [[Dave Foley|Dave Foley]] of [[The Kids in the Hall|The Kids in the Hall]] and [[Newsradio|Newsradio]] fame, along with [[David Anthony Higgins|David Anthony Higgins]] and [[Jay Kogen|Jay Kogen]] (the latter of [[The Simpsons|The Simpsons]] writing fame). Foley also stars in the picture, along with [[David Anthony Higgins|David Anthony Higgins]], [[Jennifer Tilly|Jennifer Tilly]], [[Colm Feore|Colm Feore]] and [[Joe Flaherty|Joe Flaherty]].
title: The Wrong Guy

abstract: Greatest Video Hits 1 was the first [[Queen|Queen (band)]] video collection on DVD. Most of the content was released previously on VHS and the long defunct [[CED Videodisc|CED Videodisc]] format as Greatest Flix in 1981. It was released in October 2002, and included video hits of the band between 1973 and 1981.
title: Greatest Video Hits 1

abstract: Qayamat is a [[1983|Bollywood films of 1983]] Indian Hindi film directed by [[Raj N. Sippy|Raj N. Sippy]]. It is an Indian version of the 1962 Hollywood film [[Cape Fear|Cape Fear (1962 film)]]. The film stars [[Dharmendra|Dharmendra]] as a man who goes to jail and holds his police officer friend ([[Shatrughan Sinha|Shatrughan Sinha]]) responsible for the jailing. On his return after a long sentence he sets about taking revenge, targeting the officer and his family ([[Smita Patil|Smita Patil]] and [[Poonam Dhillon|Poonam Dhillon]]). [[Jaya Prada|Jaya Prada]] appears in flashbacks as Dharmendra's wife. The film was remade in Telugu as [[Nippulanti Manishi|Nippulanti Manishi (1986 film)]] with [[Nandamuri Balakrishna|Nandamuri Balakrishna]].
title: Qayamat

abstract: Our Wife is a 1931 American [[pre-Code|Pre-Code Hollywood]] [[Hal Roach|Hal Roach]] comedy film starring [[Laurel and Hardy|Laurel and Hardy]]. It was directed by James W. Horne and released by [[Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer|Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer]].
title: Our Wife

abstract: Ayee Milan Ki Bela is a [[1964|Bollywood films of 1964]] Indian Hindi film directed by Mohan Kumar. The film was produced by [[J. Om Prakash|J. Om Prakash]]. The music is by [[Shankar Jaikishan|Shankar Jaikishan]]. The movie has stars; [[Rajendra Kumar|Rajendra Kumar]], [[Saira Banu|Saira Banu]], [[Shashikala|Shashikala]] and [[Dharmendra|Dharmendra]] (in his only role as a villain). The film became a "super hit" at the box office. The film was remade in Tamil as [[Oru Thaai Makkal|Oru Thaai Makkal]].
title: Ayee Milan Ki Bela

abstract: Aetbaar ([[Hindi|Hindi]]: ऐतबार, [[Urdu|Urdu]]: اعتبار, ) is an Indian [[psychological thriller|Psychological thriller]] film, released in 2004. The film is directed by [[Vikram Bhatt|Vikram Bhatt]] and stars [[Amitabh Bachchan|Amitabh Bachchan]], [[John Abraham|John Abraham (actor)]], [[Bipasha Basu|Bipasha Basu]] and [[Supriya Pilgaonkar|Supriya Pilgaonkar]]. Business tycoon [[Ratan Tata|Ratan Tata]] entered [[Bollywood|Bollywood]] by producing Aetbaar. Aetbaar is inspired by the Hollywood film [[Fear|Fear (1996 film)]]. Vikram Bhatt had earlier directed another movie based on the Hollywood film [[Fear|Fear (1996 film)]] called [[Inteha|Inteha (2003 film)]] which had released just 3 months earlier.
title: Aetbaar

abstract: Chalo Ishq Ladaaye (English: Come, Let's Fall In Love) is a 2002 Indian comedy film directed by [[Aziz Sejawal|Aziz Sejawal]], starring [[Govinda|Govinda (actor)]], [[Rani Mukerji|Rani Mukerji]], [[Zohra Sehgal|Zohra Sehgal]] and [[Kader Khan|Kader Khan]].
title: Chalo Ishq Ladaaye

abstract: Larry the Cable Guy: Health Inspector is a 2006 [[comedy film|comedy film]] starring American stand-up comedian [[Larry the Cable Guy|Larry the Cable Guy]]. Larry, a municipal restaurant [[health inspector|health inspector]], is assigned a new rookie partner after recklessly closing restaurants for code violations, Amy Butlin ([[Iris Bahr|Iris Bahr]]), by his boss, Bart Tatlock ([[Tom Wilson|Thomas F. Wilson]]). Together, Larry and Amy work to solve a series of food poisonings at four-star restaurants.
title: Larry the Cable Guy: Health Inspector

abstract: Tere Pyar Mein ([[Urdu|Urdu]]: تیرے پیار میں) (lit: In Your Love) is a [[Pakistani|Pakistan]] film which was released in December 2000. It launched the career of [[Zara Sheikh|Zara Sheikh]] in [[Lollywood|Lollywood]].
title: Tere Pyar Mein

abstract: Jhankaar Beats is a 2003 Indian [[Bollywood|Bollywood]] musical comedy film directed by [[Sujoy Ghosh|Sujoy Ghosh]] and released by [[Pritish Nandy Communications|Pritish Nandy Communications]]. It stars [[Juhi Chawla|Juhi Chawla]], [[Sanjay Suri|Sanjay Suri]], [[Rahul Bose|Rahul Bose]], debutant [[Shayan Munshi|Shayan Munshi]], [[Rinke Khanna|Rinke Khanna]] and [[Riya Sen|Riya Sen]]. The soundtrack of the film features the popular song "Tu Aashiqui Hai" sung by playback singer [[KK|Krishnakumar Kunnath]] and written by [[Vishal Dadlani|Vishal Dadlani]]).
title: Jhankaar Beats

abstract: Kissi Se Na Kehna (, [[Urdu|Urdu]]: کسی سے نا کہنا, ) [[1983|1983 in film]] [[Hindi-language|Bollywood]] [[Indian|India]] [[romantic comedy|romantic comedy]] [[feature film|feature film]] [[directed|Film director]] by [[Hrishikesh Mukherjee|Hrishikesh Mukherjee]]. It stars [[Farooq Shaikh|Farooq Shaikh]], [[Deepti Naval|Deepti Naval]] and [[Utpal Dutt|Utpal Dutt]]. The movie is loosely based on the 1976 Bengali movie Mohunbaganer Meye.
title: Kissi Se Na Kehna

abstract: Confession of Pain is a 2006 Hong Kong crime drama film directed by [[Andrew Lau|Andrew Lau]] and [[Alan Mak|Alan Mak (director)]], starring [[Tony Leung|Tony Leung Chiu-wai]], [[Takeshi Kaneshiro|Takeshi Kaneshiro]], [[Shu Qi|Shu Qi]] and [[Xu Jinglei|Xu Jinglei]].
title: Confession of Pain

abstract: Asterix & Obelix: Mission Cleopatra (), also known as Asterix and Obelix Meet Cleopatra, is a 2002 French/Italian [[fantasy|Fantasy film]] [[comedy film|comedy film]] written and directed by [[Alain Chabat|Alain Chabat]] and adapted from the [[comic book|comic book]] series [[Asterix|Asterix]] by [[René Goscinny|René Goscinny]] and [[Albert Uderzo|Albert Uderzo]]. Based on the book [[Asterix and Cleopatra|Asterix and Cleopatra]], which had previously been adapted into a [[1968 animated film|Asterix and Cleopatra (film)]], it also acts as a sequel to the 1999 movie [[Asterix & Obelix Take On Caesar|Asterix & Obelix Take On Caesar]].
title: Asterix & Obelix: Mission Cleopatra

abstract: Metade Fumaca (; literally: Half cigarette) is a 1999 Hong Kong [[drama film|drama film]] directed by Riley Yip and starring [[Eric Tsang|Eric Tsang]] and [[Nicholas Tse|Nicholas Tse]].
title: Metade Fumaca

abstract: Chura Liyaa Hai Tumne (Captured by You) is an Indian [[Hindi|Bollywood]] [[thriller film|thriller film]] which is directed by [[Sangeeth Sivan|Sangeeth Sivan]] and released on 21 March 2003. [[Zayed Khan|Zayed Khan]], the son of actor and director [[Sanjay Khan|Sanjay Khan]] made his film debut with this film.
title: Chura Liyaa Hai Tumne

abstract: The Kuroshakai trilogy, also known as the Black Society trilogy, is a series of films directed by Japanese filmmaker [[Takashi Miike|Takashi Miike]] involving Chinese [[triads|Triad society]] and Japanese [[yakuza|yakuza]].
title: Black Society trilogy

abstract: Behind the Camera: The Unauthorized Story of Three's Company is a 2003 American [[made-for-television movie|television movie]], made by [[NBC|NBC]], documenting the success of the [[sitcom|sitcom]] [[Three's Company|Three's Company]], as well as the interpersonal conflicts that occurred among its staff and cast. Former Three's Company cast member [[Joyce DeWitt|Joyce DeWitt]] served as co-producer and host.
title: Behind the Camera: The Unauthorized Story of Three's Company

abstract: Ten Canoes is a 2006 [[Australian|Cinema of Australia]] [[drama film|Historical period drama]] directed by [[Rolf de Heer|Rolf de Heer]] and Peter Djigirr and starring Crusoe Kurddal. The title of the film arose from discussions between de Heer and [[David Gulpilil|David Gulpilil]] about a photograph of ten canoeists poling across the [[Arafura Swamp|Arafura Swamp]], taken by anthropologist [[Donald Thomson|Donald Thomson]] in 1936. It is the first ever movie entirely filmed in Australian Aboriginal languages. The film is partly in colour and partly in black and white, it is in docu-drama style largely with a narrator explaining the story. The overall format is that of a moral tale.
title: Ten Canoes

abstract: Angel Wars is an [[animated|animated]] action adventure series from TeleStoryTOONS and [[EMI CMG|EMI CMG]] and more recently [[Twentieth Century Fox|Twentieth Century Fox]]. Since its introduction in late 2004, the series has presented Christian-based storylines through [[3D animation|3D animation]] provided by the LA based Backyard Digital Studios.
title: Angel Wars

abstract: Vishwatma is a [[1992|1992 in film]] Indian action thriller film directed by [[Rajiv Rai|Rajiv Rai]] and starring [[Naseeruddin Shah|Naseeruddin Shah]], [[Sunny Deol|Sunny Deol]], [[Chunky Pandey|Chunky Pandey]], [[Sonam|Sonam]] and Jyotsna Singh in the lead roles and [[Divya Bharti|Divya Bharti]] in her Hindi film debut. The film was a moderate box office success and sixth highest grossing film of the year.. The music of the film was very successful, especially the song "Saat Samundar", which became a favorite and gave Divya Bharti the limelight in Bollywood.
title: Vishwatma

abstract: A Chinese Ghost Story: The Tsui Hark Animation () is a 1997 [[Hong Kong|Cinema of Hong Kong]] animated film. It was written and produced by [[Tsui Hark|Tsui Hark]] and his production company, [[Film Workshop|Film Workshop]]. The animation was produced by Japanese animation studio, [[Triangle Staff|Triangle Staff]]. It is also referred to as "Xiao Qian", "Little Pretty", "Chinese Ghost Story Xiao Qian".
title: A Chinese Ghost Story: The Tsui Hark Animation

abstract: In Search of the Second Amendment is a [[documentary film|documentary film]] on the [[Second Amendment|Second Amendment to the United States Constitution]] of the [[United States Constitution|United States Constitution]]. It was produced and directed by American author and attorney [[David T. Hardy|David T. Hardy]]. He argues the individual rights model of the Second Amendment. Hardy also discusses the [[Fourteenth Amendment|Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution]].
title: In Search of the Second Amendment

abstract: Deewaanapan (English: Insanity) is a [[Bollywood|Bollywood]] movie, released on 16 November 2001. It stars [[Arjun Rampal|Arjun Rampal]] and [[Dia Mirza|Dia Mirza]] and is directed by [[Ashu Trikha|Ashu Trikha]]. [[Om Puri|Om Puri]] and [[Vinod Khanna|Vinod Khanna]] have supporting roles.
title: Deewaanapan

abstract: Bharatham is a 1991 Indian [[Malayalam|Malayalam]] [[musical|musical film]]-[[drama|Drama (film and television)]] film written by [[A. K. Lohithadas|A. K. Lohithadas]] and directed by [[Sibi Malayil|Sibi Malayil]]. Produced by [[Mohanlal|Mohanlal]] for [[Pranavam Arts|Pranavam Arts]], it stars himself, along with [[Urvashi|Urvashi (actress)]], [[Nedumudi Venu|Nedumudi Venu]], [[Lakshmi|Lakshmi (actress)]], and [[Murali|Murali (Malayalam actor)]]. The film is especially known for its music that is largely [[Carnatic|Carnatic music]] classical and semi classical. The songs were composed by [[Raveendran|Raveendran]].
title: Bharatham

abstract: Mallammana Pavaada () is a 1969 [[Kannada film|Cinema of Karnataka]] directed by [[Puttanna Kanagal|Puttanna Kanagal]].
title: Mallammana Pavaada

abstract: Gejje Pooje is a 1969 Indian [[Kannada language|Kannada language]] film directed by [[Puttanna Kanagal|Puttanna Kanagal]] and produced by Rashi Brothers. The film stars [[Kalpana|Kalpana (Kannada actress)]], [[Gangadhar|Gangadhar (Kannada actor)]] and [[Leelavathi|Leelavathi (actress)]] in lead roles. Gejje means [[anklet|anklet]] and pooje means worship but in this context of the film, it means a mock marriage. The film is based on the novel Gejje Pooje by [[M. K. Indira|M. K. Indira]]. The film was remade in Tamil as Thaaliya Salangaiya, in Telugu as [[Kalyana Mandapam|Kalyana Mandapam]] and in Hindi as [[Ahista Ahista|Ahista Ahista (1981 film)]] which further inspired the 2007 Hindi movie [[Laaga Chunari Mein Daag|Laaga Chunari Mein Daag]].
title: Gejje Pooje

abstract: The Three Mesquiteers is the umbrella title for a [[Republic Pictures|Republic Pictures]] series of 51 [[Western|Western (genre)]] [[B-movies|B-movies]] released between 1936 and 1943, including eight films starring [[John Wayne|John Wayne]]. The name was a play on words, referring to [[mesquite|mesquite]], a plant common in the Western states, and [[The Three Musketeers|The Three Musketeers]]. Each film featured a trio of stars, with the composition of the trio varying according to the individual movie. The series was based on a series of [[Western novels|western fiction]] by [[William Colt MacDonald|William Colt MacDonald]], which began with [[The Law of 45's|The Law of 45's]] in 1933.
title: The Three Mesquiteers

abstract: Anbulla Rajinikanth () is a 1984 [[Tamil language|Tamil language]] film directed by [[K. Natraj|K. Natraj]]. The film stars [[Rajinikanth|Rajinikanth]], [[Meena|Meena Durairaj]], and [[Ambika|Ambika (actress)]] with [[Jaishankar|Jaishankar]], [[Raadhika|Raadhika]] and [[Bhagyaraj|K. Bhagyaraj]] in guest roles. It received positive reviews, with praise towards Meena's performance and mainly Rajinikanth's acting.
title: Anbulla Rajinikanth

abstract: Chor Machaye Shor is a [[1974|Bollywood films of 1974]] Hindi movie produced by N. N. Sippy and directed by Ashok Roy. The film stars [[Shashi Kapoor|Shashi Kapoor]], [[Mumtaz|Mumtaz (actress)]], [[Danny Denzongpa|Danny Denzongpa]], [[Madan Puri|Madan Puri]] and Asit Sen. [[Asrani|Asrani]] earned a [[Filmfare|Filmfare]] nomination for best performance in a comic role, the only nomination for the film. The music is by [[Ravindra Jain|Ravindra Jain]]. The film became a "superhit" and earned the second spot at the box office in 1974. Because of the film's success, the film's producer (N.N. Sippy), cast (Shashi Kapoor, Danny Denzongpa, Asrani, Madan Puri) and music composer (Ravindra Jain) teamed up again for [[Fakira|Fakira (film)]] (1976), which also became a box office hit. "Le Jayenge Le Jayenge" is a very popular song from the film, which had a key tagline that [[Dilwale Dulhaniya Le Jayenge|Dilwale Dulhaniya Le Jayenge]] turned into a later blockbuster film title.
title: Chor Machaye Shor

abstract: Jwaar Bhata () is a [[1973|Bollywood films of 1973]] [[Hindi|Hindi]] film. Produced by Hargobind and N. Bhansali, the film stars [[Dharmendra|Dharmendra]], [[Saira Banu|Saira Banu]], Jeevan, [[Rajindernath|Rajindernath]] and Sujit Kumar. The film's music is by [[Laxmikant Pyarelal|Laxmikant Pyarelal]]. The film was a remake of Telugu film [[Dagudu Moothalu|Dagudu Moothalu]].
title: Jwaar Bhata

abstract: Bhakta Kanakadasa () is a 1960 Indian [[Kannada language|Kannada language]] film directed by [[Y. R. Swamy|Y. R. Swamy]]. It depicts the spiritual journey of [[Kanakadasa|Kanakadasa]] who was a devotee of the Hindu deity [[Krishna|Krishna]], and a poet belonging to the Dasa sect. The film stars [[Rajkumar|Rajkumar (actor)]], [[Krishnakumari|Krishna Kumari (actress)]], [[Udaykumar|Udaykumar]] in major roles. This film, officially marked the 100th production/release of Kannada cinema, since its inception in 1934.
title: Bhakta Kanakadasa

abstract: Vandae Maatharam is a 2010 Indian [[bilingual|Multiple-language version]] [[action film|action film]] directed by T. Aravind. The film features [[Mammootty|Mammootty]] in the lead role and [[Arjun|Arjun Sarja]], [[Sneha|Sneha (actress)]] in supporting roles along with [[Shraddha Arya|Shraddha Arya]], [[Rajkapoor|Raj Kapoor (Tamil film director)]], [[Nassar|Nassar]], [[Jai Akash|Jai Akash]], [[Jagadish|Jagadish]], Deepak J. D. and [[Rajan P. Dev|Rajan P. Dev]]. The film was simultaneously made and released in [[Malayalam|Malayalam]] and [[Tamil|Tamil language]] and was later dubbed in [[Telugu|Telugu language]]. The story revolves around the investigation and how two police officers, played by Mammootty and Arjun, eradicate the terrorists from entering the border. The film was released overseas on 10 September 2010 and later in India on 17 September 2010.
title: Vandae Maatharam

abstract: The April Fools is a 1969 American [[romantic comedy film|romantic comedy]] starring [[Jack Lemmon|Jack Lemmon]] and [[Catherine Deneuve|Catherine Deneuve]]. It was directed by [[Stuart Rosenberg|Stuart Rosenberg]].
title: The April Fools

abstract: All Cats Are Grey () is a 2014 Belgian [[coming-of-age|Coming-of-age film]] [[drama film|drama film]] directed by [[Savina Dellicour|Savina Dellicour]] and co-written by Dellicour and Matthieu de Braconier. All Cats Are Grey had its world premiere at the [[32nd Turin Film Festival|Turin Film Festival]]. It also screened as a special presentation during the [[2015 Santa Barbara International Film Festival|Santa Barbara International Film Festival]], where it won Best International Film. Critical response was generally strong and the film received nine nominations at the [[6th Magritte Awards|6th Magritte Awards]], including [[Best Film|Magritte Award for Best Film]] and [[Best Director|Magritte Award for Best Director]] for Dellicour.
title: All Cats Are Grey

abstract: Apnapan ([[English|English language]]: Kinship; [[Hindi|Hindi]]: अपनापन) is a [[1977|Bollywood films of 1977]] Indian [[Bollywood|Bollywood]] [[drama film|drama film]], produced and directed by [[J. Om Prakash|J. Om Prakash]] under the FILMYUG Pvt. Ltd. banner. It stars [[Sanjeev Kumar|Sanjeev Kumar (actor)]], [[Jeetendra|Jeetendra]], [[Reena Roy|Reena Roy]], [[Sulakshana Pandit|Sulakshana Pandit]] in the lead roles and music composed by [[Laxmikant Pyarelal|Laxmikant Pyarelal]]. The film is recorded as a Super Hit at the box office. This film was remade in [[Telugu|Telugu language]] as Illalu (1981), starring [[Shoban Babu|Shoban Babu]], [[Sridevi|Sridevi]], [[Jayasudha|Jayasudha]] in the pivotal roles.
title: Apnapan

abstract: Good Guys Wear Black is a 1978 American [[action film|action film]] starring [[Chuck Norris|Chuck Norris]] and directed by [[Ted Post|Ted Post]].
title: Good Guys Wear Black

abstract: The Brothers Bloom, orphaned at a young age, begin performing [[confidence tricks|confidence tricks]] as young children; Stephen dreams up elaborate scenarios and his younger brother, Bloom, creates trust with the marks. Stephen creates his first con as a way of encouraging his brother to talk to girls.
title: The Brothers Bloom

abstract: Aap Ke Deewane ([[English|English language]]: Crazy for You; [[Hindi|Hindi]]: आप के दीवाने) is a [[1980|Bollywood films of 1980]] [[Bollywood|Bollywood]] [[Romantic film|Romantic film]], produced by Vimal Kumar under the Film Krafts banner, presented by [[Rakesh Roshan|Rakesh Roshan]] and directed by Surendera Mohan. It stars [[Rishi Kapoor|Rishi Kapoor]], [[Rakesh Roshan|Rakesh Roshan]], [[Tina Munim|Tina Munim]] in the lead roles while [[Jeetendra|Jeetendra]] has given a guest appearance and the music was composed by [[Rajesh Roshan|Rajesh Roshan]].
title: Aap Ke Deewane

abstract: Bugs & Daffy: The Wartime Cartoons is a 1989 direct-to-video program by [[MGM/UA Home Video|MGM/UA Home Video]], containing 11 [[Looney Tunes|Looney Tunes]] and [[Merrie Melodies|Merrie Melodies]] shorts, all of which are centered on [[World War II|World War II]]. Film critic [[Leonard Maltin|Leonard Maltin]] ([[Entertainment Tonight|Entertainment Tonight]]) tells trivia and facts about each animated short.
title: Bugs & Daffy: The Wartime Cartoons

abstract: Audace colpo dei soliti ignoti (also known as Fiasco in Milan or Hold-up à la milanaise) is a [[1959|1959 in film]] [[Italian|Italy]] [[comedy|comedy film]] [[crime film|crime film]] directed by [[Nanni Loy|Nanni Loy]]. The film stars [[Vittorio Gassman|Vittorio Gassman]], [[Renato Salvatori|Renato Salvatori]] and [[Claudia Cardinale|Claudia Cardinale]].
title: Audace colpo dei soliti ignoti

abstract: Kannappanunni is a [[1977|Malayalam films of 1977]] [[Indian|Cinema of India]] [[Malayalam|Malayalam language]] film based on [[Kalaripayattu|Kalaripayattu]], the traditional martial art of [[India|India]]. It was the 100th film featuring [[Prem Nazir|Prem Nazir]] and [[Sheela|Sheela]] as the leading pair. It was [[Udaya Studio|Udaya Studio]]'s 75th film. The film was directed and produced by [[Kunchako|Kunchako]]. The film stars [[Prem Nazir|Prem Nazir]], [[Sheela|Sheela]], [[Sukumari|Sukumari]] and [[Jayabharathi|Jayabharathi]] in the lead roles. The film has musical score and songs by [[K. Raghavan|K. Raghavan]].
title: Kannappanunni

abstract: I Married a Woman is a 1958 American [[comedy film|comedy film]] made in 1956, starring [[George Gobel|George Gobel]] and [[Diana Dors|Diana Dors]], produced by Gobel's company Gomalco Productions. The film also features [[John Wayne|John Wayne]] in a cameo role as himself. It was filmed in [[RKO|RKO]]-Scope and black and white except for one of Wayne's two scenes, which was shot in [[Technicolor|Technicolor]]. The film's original title was "So There You Are".
title: I Married a Woman

abstract: Kahin Aar Kahin Paar is a [[1971|List of Bollywood films of 1971]] [[Bollywood|Bollywood]] [[romance film|romance film]]. The film stars [[Joy Mukherjee|Joy Mukherjee]] and [[Nadira|Nadira]].
title: Kahin Aar Kahin Paar

abstract: Crush and Blush premiered at the 13th [[Pusan International Film Festival|Pusan International Film Festival]], and went on general release in [[South Korea|South Korea]] on October 16, 2010.
title: Crush and Blush

abstract: Amar Bhoopali (English : The Immortal Song, France : Le Chant Immortel) is a 1951 Indian film, produced and directed by [[V. Shantaram|V. Shantaram]], written by [[Vishram Bedekar|Vishram Bedekar]]. It is a true story about a simple cow herder who has an innate gift of poetry set in waning days of [[Maratha confederacy|Maratha confederacy]] c. early 19th century. It is an ode to the saffron flag of Marathas, calling on people to rise again against the foreign enemy. It was nominated in the category of [[Grand Prize of the Festival|Palme d'Or]] at the [[1952 Cannes Film Festival|1952 Cannes Film Festival]].
title: Amar Bhoopali

abstract: The Rock 'n' Roll Dreams of Duncan Christopher was filmed in and near [[Tulsa, Oklahoma|Tulsa, Oklahoma]], in the fall of 2008. It was in post-production for most of 2009. It premiered in 2010 on March 27 at the [[Method Fest Independent Film Festival|Method Fest Independent Film Festival]], where it was nominated for Best Low Budget Feature Film and won the award for Best Marketing Campaign. The movie went on to win 10 awards with 7 of them Best Feature, Jury or Audience Awards, including the Best Okie Feature at the 2010 [[deadCENTER Film Festival|deadCENTER Film Festival]]. It was an Official Selection at several prestigious film festivals around the world, including [[Mar del Plata Film Festival|Mar del Plata Film Festival]] in Argentina, STARZ Denver Film Festival, San Diego International Film Festival, and the [[Heartland Film Festival|Heartland Film Festival]].
title: The Rock 'n' Roll Dreams of Duncan Christopher

abstract: The Burial Society tells the story of Sheldon Kasner, whose existence has recently turned to one of quiet anxiety. His workload is mounting as his reimbursement for it continues to diminish, and Sheldon justifiably falls into a deep depression. Despite being a highly unlikely candidate for organized crime, he is drawn into a complicit [[money-laundering|money-laundering]] scam that doesn't run as planned. With a two-million-dollar debt on his hands, Sheldon devises a complicated plan: staging his own death with the help of the Chevrah Kadisha, or the "Burial Society," a mysterious group of devout Jewish men who have dedicated themselves to preparing dead bodies for their final resting place. Unbeknownst to Sheldon, the Burial Society sees the incompetent businessman as the only hope for the continued existence of their tradition. As they initiate him into their peculiar, ritualistic world, Sheldon believes his life is leisurely getting back on track; however, the men of the Burial Society may have something else in mind for him.
title: The Burial Society

abstract: Megamind is a 2010 American [[3D|3D Film]] [[computer-animated|Computer-animated film]] [[superhero|Superhero film]] [[comedy film|comedy film]] directed by [[Tom McGrath|Tom McGrath (animator)]], produced by [[DreamWorks Animation|DreamWorks Animation]] and distributed by [[Paramount Pictures|Paramount Pictures]]. The film premiered on October 28, 2010, in [[Russia|Russia]], while it was released in the United States in [[Digital 3D|Digital 3D]], [[IMAX 3D|IMAX 3D]] and 2D on November 5, 2010. It features the voices of [[Will Ferrell|Will Ferrell]], [[Tina Fey|Tina Fey]], [[Jonah Hill|Jonah Hill]], [[David Cross|David Cross]], and [[Brad Pitt|Brad Pitt]].
title: Megamind

abstract: The Man on Lincoln's Nose is a 2000 American [[short|short film]] [[documentary film|documentary film]] directed by [[Daniel Raim|Daniel Raim]] about [[Hollywood|Cinema of the United States]] [[art director|art director]] [[Robert F. Boyle|Robert F. Boyle]]. It was nominated for an [[Academy Award|Academy Award]] for [[Best Documentary Short|Academy Award for Best Documentary (Short Subject)]]. The title is derived from the [[Alfred Hitchcock|Alfred Hitchcock]] film [[North by Northwest|North by Northwest]] (1959), which has a [[climactic|Climax (narrative)]] scene of two characters dangling from the carving of [[Abraham Lincoln|Abraham Lincoln]]'s face on [[Mount Rushmore|Mount Rushmore]]. One of the producers was Hitchcock's daughter, [[Patricia Hitchcock|Patricia Hitchcock]].
title: The Man on Lincoln's Nose

abstract: Chetna is a [[1970|Bollywood films of 1970]] [[Bollywood|Bollywood]] [emotional drama] directed by [[B.R. Ishara|B.R. Ishara]]. The film stars [[Shatrughan Sinha|Shatrughan Sinha]], [[Anil Dhawan|Anil Dhawan]] and [[Rehana Sultan|Rehana Sultan]]. The film focuses on the subject of rehabilitation of [[prostitute|prostitutes]]. However, the film is more famous for its bold scenes of the actress [[Rehana Sultan|Rehana Sultan]]. The film virtually ended her film career as she was [[typecast|Typecasting (acting)]] thereafter. One of its songs, "Main To Har Mod Par Tujhko Doonga Sada," is singer [[Mukesh|Mukesh (singer)]]'s all-time memorable and popular song.
title: Chetna

abstract: Holi Ayee Re (meaning:"The Festival of Colors Has Come") is a [[1970|Bollywood films of 1970]] [[Bollywood|Bollywood]] [[romance film|romance film]] directed by Harsukh Jagneshwar Bhatt. The film stars [[Shatrughan Sinha|Shatrughan Sinha]] and [[Mala Sinha|Mala Sinha]].
title: Holi Ayee Re

abstract: Insaan Aur Shaitan is a [[1970|Bollywood films of 1970]] [[Bollywood|Bollywood]] [[action film|action film]] directed by Aspi Irani. The film stars [[Sanjeev Kumar|Sanjeev Kumar]] and [[Aruna Irani|Aruna Irani]].
title: Insaan Aur Shaitan

abstract: Talentime is a 2009 Malaysian drama film written and directed by [[Yasmin Ahmad|Yasmin Ahmad]]. Yasmin, in her blog, has described it "as a story full of joy and pain, hope and despair, a host of beautifully-written songs, and rich characters". A [[Hindu|Hindu]] open [[cremation|cremation]] and a scene reminiscent of the [[2001 Kampung Medan riots|2001 Kampung Medan riots]] are included in the film.
title: Talentime

abstract: Do Raha () is a [[1971|List of Bollywood films of 1971]] [[Hindi|Hindi]]-language [[drama film|drama film]]. The film stars [[Shatrughan Sinha|Shatrughan Sinha]], [[Anil Dhawan|Anil Dhawan]] and [[Radha Saluja|Radha Saluja]].
title: Do Raha

abstract: Patanga is a [[1971|List of Bollywood films of 1971]] [[Bollywood|Bollywood]] [[drama film|drama film]] directed by Kedar Kapoor. The film stars [[Shashi Kapoor|Shashi Kapoor]], [[Vimi|Vimi]] and [[Rajendra Nath|Rajendra Nath]] in lead roles. The music was composed by Shankar Jaikishan. The film was a moderate success at the box office.
title: Patanga

abstract: Pyaar Diwana is a [[1972|List of Bollywood films of 1972]] [[Bollywood|Bollywood]] [[comedy film|comedy film]] directed by Samar Chatterjee. The film stars [[Kishore Kumar|Kishore Kumar]] and [[Mumtaz|Mumtaz (actress)]] .
title: Pyaar Diwana

abstract: Vaaname Ellai () is a 1992 Indian [[Tamil language|Tamil language]] [[drama film|Drama (film and television)]], directed by [[K. Balachander|K. Balachander]], starring [[Anand Babu|Anand Babu]], [[Ramya Krishnan|Ramya Krishnan]], [[Madhoo|Madhoo]], Vishali Kannadasan, [[Rajesh|Rajesh (actor)]] and [[Babloo Prithviraj|Babloo Prithviraj]].
title: Vaaname Ellai

abstract: Agni Rekha is a [[1973|Bollywood films of 1973]] [[Bollywood|Bollywood]] [[drama film|drama film]] directed by Mahesh Kaul. The film stars [[Bindu|Bindu (actress)]] and [[Sanjeev Kumar|Sanjeev Kumar]] .
title: Agni Rekha

abstract: Badhti Ka Naam Dadhi (That Which Grows is a Beard) is a [[1974|Bollywood films of 1974]] [[Bollywood|Bollywood]] [[comedy film|comedy film]] directed by [[Kishore Kumar|Kishore Kumar]]. The name is similar to a previous Kishore Kumar film [[Chalti Ka Naam Gaadi|Chalti Ka Naam Gaadi]].
title: Badhti Ka Naam Dadhi

abstract: Rani Aur Lalpari is a [[1975|Bollywood films of 1975]] [[Bollywood|Bollywood]] children's [[musical film|musical film]], produced by Hari Prasad Nagaich and Rani Nagaich of Guru Enterprising Movies and directed by [[Ravikant Nagaich|Ravikant Nagaich]]. The film starred Baby Raani in the lead role, [[Rajendra Kumar|Rajendra Kumar]], [[Asha Parekh|Asha Parekh]], [[Jeetendra|Jeetendra]], [[Feroz Khan|Feroz Khan (actor, born 1939)]], [[Reena Roy|Reena Roy]], [[Neetu Singh|Neetu Singh]] many others, a huge star cast including special appearances and music composed by Vasant Desai.
title: Rani Aur Lalpari

abstract: Bundal Baaz is a [[1976|Bollywood films of 1976]] [[Bollywood|Bollywood]] fantasy and [[romantic comedy|romantic comedy]] film directed by [[Shammi Kapoor|Shammi Kapoor]]. The film stars [[Rajesh Khanna|Rajesh Khanna]] in the lead role and had Sulakshana Pandit, Shammi Kapoor, Ranjeet, Johnny Walker and others in the supporting roles. Khanna was impressed with the character of Phantom and hence he designed an entire sequence in this film around it. This film was not commercially successful at the time of its release, but was critically acclaimed. However, over the years, this film has gained a cult following and appreciation from audiences upon its screening in television.
title: Bundal Baaz

abstract: Khaan Dost is a [[1976|Bollywood films of 1976]] [[Bollywood|Bollywood]] [[action film|action film]] directed by Dulal Guha. The film was remade in Telugu as [[Mosagadu|Mosagadu]].
title: Khaan Dost

abstract: Shaque () is a [[1976|Bollywood films of 1976]] [[Bollywood|Bollywood]] [[drama film|drama film]] directed by Aruna-Vikas. The film stars [[Vinod Khanna|Vinod Khanna]], [[Shabana Azmi|Shabana Azmi]] and [[Utpal Dutt|Utpal Dutt]].
title: Shaque

abstract: Kuchhe Dhaage is a 1973 [[Bollywood|Bollywood]] [[action film|action film]] directed by [[Raj Khosla|Raj Khosla]]. The film stars [[Vinod Khanna|Vinod Khanna]], [[Moushumi Chatterjee|Moushumi Chatterjee]] and [[Kabir Bedi|Kabir Bedi]]. The music was scored by Laxmikant Pyarelal with lyrics penned by Anand Bakshi.
title: Kuchhe Dhaage

abstract: Gehri Chaal ([[English|English language]]:Deep Trap; [[Hindi|Hindi]]: गहरी चाल) is a [[1973|Bollywood films of 1973]] [[Bollywood|Bollywood]] [[Action thriller|Action thriller]] film, produced and directed by [[C.V. Sridhar|C.V. Sridhar]] under the Chithrakala Pictures banner. It stars [[Amitabh Bachchan|Amitabh Bachchan]], [[Jeetendra|Jeetendra]], [[Hema Malini|Hema Malini]] in the lead roles and music composed by [[Laxmikant-Pyarelal|Laxmikant-Pyarelal]].
title: Gehri Chaal

abstract: Hamara Sansar is a [[1978|1978 in film]] [[Hindi-language|Bollywood]] [[Indian|Cinema of India]] [[feature film|feature film]] [[directed|Film director]] by T. Prakesh Rao produced under Usha Productions, starring [[Nutan|Nutan]], [[Parikshit Sahni|Parikshit Sahni]], [[Sarika|Sarika]] and [[Mithun Chakraborty|Mithun Chakraborty]].
title: Hamara Sansar

abstract: Heera-Moti is a [[1979|Bollywood films of 1979]] [[Bollywood|Bollywood]] [[film|film]] directed by Chand and produced by Ratan Mohan. It stars [[Shatrughan Sinha|Shatrughan Sinha]] and [[Reena Roy|Reena Roy]].
title: Heera-Moti

abstract: Jhoota Kahin Ka is a [[1979|Bollywood films of 1979]] [[Bollywood|Bollywood]] [[film|film]] directed by [[Ravi Tandon|Ravi Tandon]]. It stars [[Rishi Kapoor|Rishi Kapoor]] and [[Neetu Singh|Neetu Singh]] in pivotal roles.
title: Jhoota Kahin Ka

abstract: Magroor is a [[1979|Bollywood films of 1979]] [[Bollywood|Bollywood]] [[film|film]] directed by Brij. It stars [[Shatrughan Sinha|Shatrughan Sinha]] and [[Vidya Sinha|Vidya Sinha]].
title: Magroor

abstract: Apocalypse II: Revelation is a 1999 [[Christian|Christianity]]/[[thriller|Thriller (genre)]], starring [[Jeff Fahey|Jeff Fahey]]. The film was written and produced by [[Paul Lalonde|Paul Lalonde]] & Peter Lalonde and directed by André van Heerden. It is a sequel to [[Apocalypse|Apocalypse (film)]] and part of the [[Apocalypse (film series)|Apocalypse (film series)]]. Like all other films in the franchise, Apocalypse II was produced and distributed by [[Cloud Ten Pictures|Cloud Ten Pictures]]
title: Apocalypse II: Revelation

abstract: The plot centers on former CIA agent Black Dynamite, who must avenge his brother's death while cleaning the streets of a new drug that is ravaging the community. The film is a [[parody|parody film]] of the [[blaxploitation|blaxploitation]] genre. It had a trailer and funding even before a script was written. Black Dynamite was shot in 20 days in [[Super 16|16 mm film]] format. The film was released in the United States on October 16, 2009, for only two weeks (with an "official" premiere at the [[Toronto After Dark|Toronto After Dark]] film festival) and was well received by critics. It was released on home video on February 16, 2010.
title: Black Dynamite

abstract: Bomma Borusa ([[Telugu|Telugu language]]: బొమ్మా బొరుసా) ([[English|English language]] title Heads or Tails?) is a 1971 Indian [[Telugu language|Telugu language]] [[Comedy|Comedy film]] / [[Drama film|Drama film]] directed by [[Padma Shri|Padma Shri]] awardee [[K. Balachander|Kailasam Balachander]]. It is a remake of the Tamil film [[Poova Thalaiya|Poova Thalaiya]], directed by K. Balachander himself. The film stars [[Chandra Mohan|Chandra Mohan (Telugu actor)]], [[S. Varalakshmi|S. Varalakshmi]], [[Chalam|Chalam]], Vennirade Nirmala, [[Allu Ramalingaiah|Allu Ramalingaiah]], [[Mukkamala|Mukkamala]], [[Raja Babu|Raja Babu (actor)]] and [[Ramaprabha|Ramaprabha]]. It was produced by [[Avichi Meiyappa Chettiar|Avichi Meiyappa Chettiar]] and distributed by [[AVM Productions|AVM Productions]]. The film music was composed by R. Goverdhanam and lyrics were written by [[Kosaraju Raghavaiah|Kosaraju Raghavaiah]].
title: Bomma Borusa

abstract: Veerasamy () is a Tamil 2007 [[Tamil|Tamil cinema]] [[action film|action film]] written, produced and directed by [[T. Rajendar|T. Rajendar]] who also appeared as a lead in the title role with [[Mumtaj|Mumtaj]] and [[Meghana Naidu|Meghana Naidu]] starred in the movie alongside him. Apart from acting and directing, Rajender also composed and written the songs and handled cinematography.
title: Veerasamy

abstract: The Duchess of Langeais is a 2007 French-Italian [[drama film|drama film]] directed by [[Jacques Rivette|Jacques Rivette]]. Its original French title is Ne touchez pas la hache ("Don't touch the axe"). It is based on the [[1834 novel of the same name|La Duchesse de Langeais]] by [[Honoré de Balzac|Honoré de Balzac]]. The film stars [[Jeanne Balibar|Jeanne Balibar]] and [[Guillaume Depardieu|Guillaume Depardieu]] as lovers in early 1823 [[Majorca|Majorca]] who are involved in a tormented and frustrating relationship.
title: The Duchess of Langeais

abstract: Aur Ek Prem Kahani () is a [[1996|Bollywood films of 1996]] Indian Hindi film directed by [[Balu Mahendra|Balu Mahendra]]. The film became the debut of several Southern stars, [[Ramesh Aravind|Ramesh Aravind]], Sudhir Ahuja, and [[Heera Rajagopal|Heera Rajagopal]]. Co-starring in the film were [[Revathi Menon|Revathi Menon]] and [[Akshay Anand|Akshay Anand]]. The film is a remake of Balu Mahendra's [[Kannada|Kannada]] film [[Kokila|Kokila (1977 film)]].
title: Aur Ek Prem Kahani

abstract: Aanaval Mothiram ([[Malayalam|Malayalam]]: ആനവാല് മോതിരം) is a 1991 [[Malayalam film|Malayalam film]] directed by [[G. S. Vijayan|G. S. Vijayan]], written by [[T. Damodaran|T. Damodaran]], and starring [[Sreenivasan|Sreenivasan]], [[Suresh Gopi|Suresh Gopi]], [[Saranya Ponvannan|Saranya Ponvannan]], and [[Jagathy Sreekumar|Jagathy Sreekumar]].
title: Aanaval Mothiram

abstract: The Boat That Rocked (retitled Pirate Radio in North America, Good Morning England in France, Radio Rock Revolution in Germany and I Love Radio Rock in Italy) is a 2009 British [[comedy film|comedy film]] written and directed by [[Richard Curtis|Richard Curtis]] with [[pirate radio in the United Kingdom|pirate radio in the United Kingdom]] during the 1960s as its setting. The film has an [[ensemble cast|ensemble cast]] consisting of [[Philip Seymour Hoffman|Philip Seymour Hoffman]], [[Bill Nighy|Bill Nighy]], [[Rhys Ifans|Rhys Ifans]], [[Nick Frost|Nick Frost]] and [[Kenneth Branagh|Kenneth Branagh]]. Set in 1966, it tells the story of the fictional pirate radio station "Radio Rock" and its crew of eclectic [[disc jockey|disc jockeys]], who broadcast [[rock|rock music]] and [[pop music|pop music]] to the United Kingdom from a ship anchored in the [[North Sea|North Sea]] while the British government endeavors to shut them down. It was produced by [[Working Title Films|Working Title Films]] for [[Universal Pictures|Universal Pictures]] and was filmed on the [[Isle of Portland|Isle of Portland]] and at [[Shepperton Studios|Shepperton Studios]].
title: The Boat That Rocked

abstract: A Very Serious Person is a 2006 [[drama film|drama film]] directed by [[Charles Busch|Charles Busch]] and starring [[Polly Bergen|Polly Bergen]], [[Charles Busch|Charles Busch]], [[Dana Ivey|Dana Ivey]], [[Julie Halston|Julie Halston]], [[Carl Andress|Carl Andress]], and [[P.J. Verhoest|P.J. Verhoest]].
title: A Very Serious Person

abstract: Gopal ([[Sivaji Ganesan|Sivaji Ganesan]]) and Gowri ([[K. R. Vijaya|K. R. Vijaya]]) are salespeople in competing organisations. They are professional rivals and end up sharing rooms in the same house belonging to an English. Naidu ([[M. R. R. Vasu|M. R. R. Vasu]]) and his Kannada wife ([[Manorama|Manorama (Tamil actress)]]) are caretakers of the house where Mohan and Gowri stay. Gopal and Gowri get married and both quit their jobs on the same day. Naidu and his wife lend them some money to start a business. Gopal's business becomes successful and Gowri and Mohan have a son and are about to have another baby. A Punjabi family led by Baldev Singh ('Major' Sundararajan) move into one of the portions. A Malayalee Muslim led by Ibrahim (V K Ramasamy) family take up residence in other part of the same house. After some initial hiccups, the four families settle down and become close friends. Gopal's secretary Kamala tries to vamp him and her brother takes a photo of the two of them together and begins to blackmail Gopal. His neighbours help him fight off the blackmailer and this seals the bond between them even more strongly. When the house owner decides to sell the house and return to England, the families buy the house together with Gopal paying Naidu's share. They call the house Bharatha Vilas, since it houses people from all parts of the country. The movie catches up with the residents of Bharatha Vilas after many years. Gopal is now even more successful and slightly arrogant about his wealth. His daughter is very close to Ibrahim's family and considers his son Hamid as her brother. Someone sends an anonymous letter about their relationship and Gopal cuts off all contact with Ibrahim and fixes his daughter's wedding with one of his relatives.
title: Bharatha Vilas

abstract: Siva Manasula Sakthi () also known by the initialism SMS, is a 2009 Indian [[Tamil|Tamil cinema]] [[romantic comedy|romantic comedy]] film written and directed by debutant [[M. Rajesh|M. Rajesh (director)]], a former assistant of director [[S. A. Chandrasekhar|S. A. Chandrasekhar]]. It stars [[Jiiva|Jiiva]] and newcomer [[Anuya Bhagwat|Anuya Bhagwat]], a student of [[Pune Film Institute|Pune Film Institute]], in the lead roles, with [[Santhanam|Santhanam (actor)]], [[Urvashi|Urvashi]] and [[Sathyan|Sathyan (Tamil actor)]] appearing in supporting and [[Arya|Arya (actor)]] appearing in a [[cameo role|cameo role]]. Despite initially gaining mixed reviews,the film became a [[Super hit|Hit record]] and has since become a cult romantic comedy film in the Tamil film industry. The film was later remade in Telugu as [[Shiva Manasulo Shruti|Shiva Manasulo Shruti]] with [[Mahesh Babu|Mahesh Babu]]'s brother-in-law [[Sudheer Babu|Sudheer Babu]] and [[Regina Cassandra|Regina Cassandra]] and released in February 2012. The music by Yuvan Shankar Raja was hailed as a blockbuster and all time masterpiece.
title: Siva Manasula Sakthi

abstract: Alli Thandha Vaanam (Gift from Above(The sky gave me too much)) is a 2001 [[Tamil|Tamil language]] [[romantic|romance film]] [[drama film|drama film]] directed by Sridar Prasad. It stars [[Murali|Murali (Tamil actor)]], [[Prabhu Deva|Prabhu Deva]] and [[Laila|Laila Mehdin]] in the lead roles, [[Neha|Shabana Raza]], [[Prakash Raj|Prakash Raj]], [[Vivek|Vivek (actor)]], [[TSBK Moulee|T. S. B. K. Moulee]] and [[Rajeev|Rajeev (Tamil actor)]] with in supporting roles. The film was a commercial success at the box office and three songs have been shot in various locations in Malaysia. The song 'Vaadi Vaadi Naatu Kattai' was a chartbuster hit. The film's score and music was composed by [[Vidyasagar|Vidyasagar (music director) ]]. It was released on 5 September,2001.
title: Alli Thandha Vaanam

abstract: The Viking Watch of the Danish Seaman () is a 1948 [[Danish|Denmark]] war drama directed by [[Bodil Ipsen|Bodil Ipsen]] and [[Lau Lauritzen Jr.|Lau Lauritzen Jr.]] The film, known alternatively as Perilous Expedition or its literal title translation Steady stands the Danish sailor, written by [[Grete Frische|Grete Frische]] based upon the wartime diary of [[Kaj Frische|Kaj Frische]], tells the true story of Danish sailors who sailed with the Allied forces during the German occupation of Denmark in World War II. It stars [[Poul Reichhardt|Poul Reichhardt]] and [[Lisbeth Movin|Lisbeth Movin]]. The film received the [[Bodil Award|Bodil Award]] for [[Best Danish Film|Bodil Award for Best Danish Film]] in 1949.
title: The Viking Watch of the Danish Seaman

abstract: Vennila Kabadi Kuzhu (English: White Moon Kabadi Crew) is a 2009 [[Indian|Cinema of India]] [[Tamil|Tamil cinema]] [[drama film|drama film]] written and directed by newcomer [[Susindran|Susindran]], starring debutant [[Vishnu Vishal|Vishnu Vishal]], [[Kishore|Kishore (actor)]] and [[Saranya Mohan|Saranya Mohan]] along with numerous other newcomers in the lead roles.
title: Vennila Kabadi Kuzhu

abstract: I'm Through with White Girls (The Inevitable Undoing of Jay Brooks) is a 2007 [[independent|Independent film]] [[romantic comedy|romantic comedy]] film starring [[Anthony Montgomery|Anthony Montgomery]] and directed by Jennifer Sharp. The film was shot in Los Angeles over the course of twenty-four days.
title: I'm Through with White Girls

abstract: Naan Avanillai 2 () is a 2009 [[Tamil|Tamil cinema]] [[romantic|romance film]] [[mystery film|mystery film]] directed by [[Selva|Selva (director)]]. It is the sequel to the [[Naan Avanillai|Naan Avanillai (2007 film)]] (2007). [[Jeevan|Jeevan (Tamil actor)]] reprises the lead role, while the female roles are enacted by [[Sangeetha|Sangeetha Krish]], [[Lakshmi Rai|Lakshmi Rai]], [[Shweta Menon|Shweta Menon]] and [[Shruti Marathe|Shruti Marathe]] and [[Rachana Maurya|Rachana Maurya]]. [[D. Imman|D. Imman]], who did the [[film score|film score]] for the first part of the film, replaced [[Vijay Antony|Vijay Antony]] as the [[music director|music director]]. The film was released on 27 November 2009.
title: Naan Avanillai 2

abstract: Suvarna Sundari ([[English|English language]]: Golden Beauty) is a [[1957|Bollywood films of 1957]] [[Telugu|Telugu cinema]] [[swashbuckling|Swashbuckler film]] [[adventure|Adventure film]] [[fantasy film|fantasy film]], produced by [[P. Adinarayana Rao|P. Adinarayana Rao]] under the [[Anjali Pictures|Anjali Pictures]] banner and directed by [[Vedantam Raghavaiah|Vedantam Raghavaiah]]. It stars [[Akkineni Nageswara Rao|Akkineni Nageswara Rao]], [[Anjali Devi|Anjali Devi]] in the lead roles and music also composed by Adinarayana Rao. The film was simultaneously shot in [[Tamil|Tamil language]] as [[Manaalane Mangaiyin Baakkiyam|Manaalane Mangaiyin Baakkiyam]]. The Tamil version was released first. Lata Mangeshkar suggested that Manaalane Mangaiyin Baakkiyam be remade in Hindi instead of dubbing the film. It was then made in [[Hindi|Hindi language]] with the title same as the Telugu version. Akkineni Nageswara Rao and Anjali Devi did their roles in the Hindi version as well; it was the only Hindi movie in ANR's film career, while [[Gemini Ganesan|Gemini Ganesan]] played the male lead role in the Tamil version. The film was considered a "blockbuster" at the box office.
title: Suvarna Sundari

abstract: Zill-e-Shah is a [[Pakistani|Cinema of Pakistan]] [[Punjabi-language|Punjabi language]] film and is the sequel to another Punjabi film from 2006, [[Majajan|Majajan]].
title: Zill-e-Shah

abstract: Lajwanti is a 1958 Indian [[drama film|Drama (film and television)]] directed by [[Narendra Suri|Narendra Suri]]. It was entered into the [[1959 Cannes Film Festival|1959 Cannes Film Festival]], where it was nominated for the [[Palme d'Or|Palme d'Or]] for Best Film. The film was remade in [[Tamil|Tamil language]] as [[Engal Selvi|Engal Selvi]] (1960).
title: Lajwanti

abstract: Deaf Smith & Johnny Ears, also known as Los Amigos, is a 1973 [[Spaghetti Western|Spaghetti Western]] film starring [[Anthony Quinn|Anthony Quinn]] and [[Franco Nero|Franco Nero]] in 1973. The film is loosely based on the life of [[Deaf Smith|Deaf Smith]], with direction of [[Paolo Cavara|Paolo Cavara]].
title: Deaf Smith & Johnny Ears

abstract: Marketa Lazarová is a 1967 Czechoslovak [[historical film|Historical period drama]] directed by [[František Vláčil|František Vláčil]]. It is an adaptation of the novel [[Marketa Lazarová|Marketa Lazarová (novel)]] (1931) by [[Vladislav Vančura|Vladislav Vančura]]. The film takes place in an indeterminate time during the Middle Ages, and tells the story of a daughter of a feudal lord who is kidnapped by neighbouring robber knights and becomes a mistress of one of them.
title: Marketa Lazarová

abstract: Balettan is a 2003 Indian [[Malayalam|Malayalam]]-language [[family drama|family drama]] film directed by [[V. M. Vinu|V. M. Vinu]] and written by [[T. A. Shahid|T. A. Shahid]]. It stars [[Mohanlal|Mohanlal]], [[Devayani|Devayani (actress)]], [[Harisree Ashokan|Harisree Ashokan]], [[Innocent|Innocent (actor)]], [[Nedumudi Venu|Nedumudi Venu]], and [[Jagathy Sreekumar|Jagathy Sreekumar]]. The film was released on 28 August 2003. It won the [[Kerala Film Critics Association Awards|Kerala Film Critics Association Awards]] for the Best Popular Film of the year. Balettan was the highest-grossing Malayalam film of the year at the box office. The film was remade in Telugu as Rajababu with [[Rajasekhar|Rajasekhar (actor)]].
title: Balettan

abstract: Hypnotized and Hysterical (Hairstylist Wanted) (original title: Filles perdues, cheveux gras) is a 2002 French musical comedy-drama film about the crossing paths of three lost young women. It was directed by [[Claude Duty|Claude Duty]].
title: Hypnotized and Hysterical (Hairstylist Wanted)

abstract: Space Adventure Cobra: The Movie opens with the bounty hounter Jane Royal apparently killing a creature and taking its head out. As she boasts in a bar, the self-proclaimed "Cobra" is attracted to her, and starts to follow her. She doubts he is the real Cobra, as it is said that he died two years ago and had a special weapon called "Psychogun" in his left arm. When Cobra visits Jane in her home, the creature's head attack them, but it is ultimately killed by Jane. She suspects a criminal group called the "Pirate Guild" to be the responsible for the attack, as she is on their hit list and earlier left the head to the care of a bounty hunter organization. When the Guild's death squad chases them, Cobra reveals his signature weapon to stop their enemies. After this, the fact is reported to Crystal Bowie, Cobra's archenemy, and Jane reveals she has been looking for Cobra's help.
title: Space Adventure Cobra: The Movie

abstract: Muthal Vasantham is a [[1986|Tamil films of 1986]] [[Indian|Cinema of India]] [[Tamil|Tamil language]] film, directed by [[Manivannan|Manivannan]] and produced by [[P. Kalaimani|P. Kalaimani]], who also wrote the film's story. The film stars [[Sathyaraj|Sathyaraj]], [[Pandiyan|Pandiyan (actor)]], [[Malaysia Vasudevan|Malaysia Vasudevan]] and [[Ramya Krishnan|Ramya Krishnan]] in lead roles. The film had musical score by [[Ilaiyaraaja|Ilaiyaraaja]]. The film was remade in Telugu as [[Asthulu Anthasthulu|Asthulu Anthasthulu]] and in Hindi as [[Hum Bhi Insaan Hain|Hum Bhi Insaan Hain (1989 film)]].
title: Muthal Vasantham

abstract: A sequel to The Storm Riders was first announced in March 2008 after Universe gained rights to the Fung Wan franchise from former film distributor [[Golden Harvest|Orange Sky Golden Harvest]]. The Pangs aimed on creating a big-budgeted film involving visual effects and stated that The Storm Warriors would not be a direct sequel to its 1998 predecessor. Principal photography for The Storm Warriors began in April 2008 and ended in July; filming took place in three studios located in [[Bangkok|Bangkok]], [[Thailand|Thailand]]. The film is notable for being the first Chinese language film shot in [[bluescreen|Chroma key]]. During post-production, effects artists worked on scenes involving [[computer-generated imagery|computer-generated imagery]], focusing on the film's setting and backgrounds.
title: The Storm Warriors

abstract: Ramchand Pakistani () is an [[Urdu|Urdu]]-language [[Pakistani|Cinema of Pakistan]] [[drama|drama]] film directed by [[Mehreen Jabbar|Mehreen Jabbar]] and produced by [[Javed Jabbar|Javed Jabbar]]. The film features [[Nandita Das|Nandita Das]], Rashid Farooqi, Syed Fazel Hussain, [[Maria Wasti|Maria Wasti]] and [[Noman Ijaz|Noman Ijaz]] in lead roles. The film is based on a true story of a boy who inadvertently crosses the border between Pakistan and [[India|India]] and the following ordeal that his family has to go through. Ramchand Pakistani was also released in India.
title: Ramchand Pakistani

abstract: Xcuse Me is a 2003 [[Hindi|Hindi]] [[comedy-drama film|comedy-drama film]]. It is the sequel to [[N. Chandra|N. Chandra]]'s 2001 film [[Style|Style (2001 film)]] which was a box office success. Xcuse Me was released on 26 September 2003 and a moderate success at the box office.
title: Xcuse Me

abstract: Vi er allesammen tossede () is a [[1959|1959 in film]] [[Danish|Danish language]] comedy directed by [[Sven Methling|Sven Methling]] and starring [[Kjeld Petersen|Kjeld Petersen]], [[Buster Larsen|Buster Larsen]], [[Birgitte Reimer|Birgitte Reimer]] and [[Dirch Passer|Dirch Passer]]. The film relates the story of a confused driver who is mistakenly committed to an insane asylum after he insists to police that his car was damaged in an accident with an elephant. The film received the [[Bodil Award for Best Danish Film|Bodil Award for Best Danish Film]] in 1960 and is listed on the Danish Film Institute's Top 100 Danish Films.
title: Vi er allesammen tossede

abstract: The Baby Doll Night (, [[translit.|Transliteration]]   Leilet El-Baby Doll) is an Egyptian political [[comedy-drama|comedy-drama]] film released in June 2008.
title: The Baby Doll Night

abstract: Kutty Srank (translated as junior boat captain in Malayalam) is a film about a mariner who operates a cargo vessel near the sea port of [[Kodungalloor|Kodungalloor]], once a roaring port town in [[Kerala|Kerala]].
title: Kutty Srank

abstract: Gowariker had always aspired to make a romantic comedy and was inspired to adapt Rye's novel into a feature film after watching a play based on the same source material. Later, he bought the rights and co-wrote the screenplay with playwright Naushil Mehta. In the process, several plot changes were made for the cinematic adaptation, notably the similarity between the twelve girls, and the ending. Since Gowariker was against using prosthetics to create the twelve characters, Chopra worked on her body language and her voice to make them distinct. [[Principal photography|Principal photography]] was extensively done at sixty-seven locations across [[Mumbai|Mumbai]], and partly in [[Baroda|Baroda]] and [[Chicago|Chicago]]. The [[soundtrack, consisting of thirteen songs|What's Your Raashee? (soundtrack)]], each representing an astrological sign and one compilation, was composed by [[Sohail Sen|Sohail Sen]], with lyrics by [[Javed Akhtar|Javed Akhtar]].
title: What's Your Raashee?

abstract: Christmas in the Clouds is a 2001 [[comedy film|comedy film]] about a [[ski resort|ski resort]] owned and operated by a [[Native American|Native Americans in the United States]] tribe. Featured at the 2001 [[Sundance Film Festival|Sundance Film Festival]], the film went on to receive Best Competition Feature Film at the [[Austin Film Festival|Austin Film Festival]] and Best Native American-Theme Film at the [[Santa Fe Film Festival|Santa Fe Film Festival]]. The film was released in theaters and on DVD in 2005.
title: Christmas in the Clouds

abstract: Jeevante Jeevan is a 1985 Indian [[Malayalam|Malayalam]]-language film written and directed by [[J. Williams|J. Williams (cinematographer)]]. The film stars [[Mohanlal|Mohanlal]], [[Maniyanpilla Raju|Maniyanpilla Raju]], [[Prathapachandran|Prathapachandran]] and Arathi Gupta in lead roles. The film had musical score by [[Shyam|Shyam (composer)]].
title: Jeevante Jeevan

abstract: Champions of Faith: Baseball Edition is a [[documentary film|documentary film]] that showcases the intersection of [[sports|sports]] and [[faith|faith]] in [[Major League Baseball|Major League Baseball]] by profiling many of the most accomplished and devout figures in the game. Major League baseball's [[Mike Piazza|Mike Piazza]], [[David Eckstein|David Eckstein]], [[Jeff Suppan|Jeff Suppan]], [[Mike Sweeney|Mike Sweeney]], [[Jack McKeon|Jack McKeon]] and [[Rich Donnelly|Rich Donnelly]] lead the cast in this sports special that tells the story of how their faith plays a role not only on the field but at home.
title: Champions of Faith

abstract: The Darling of Paris is a 1917 American [[silent|silent film]] [[romantic drama film|romantic drama film]] directed by [[J. Gordon Edwards|J. Gordon Edwards]] and starring [[Theda Bara|Theda Bara]] and [[Glen White|Glen White (actor)]]. It was a very loose [[film adaptation|film adaptation]] of the 1831 novel [[The Hunchback of Notre-Dame|The Hunchback of Notre-Dame]] by [[Victor Hugo|Victor Hugo]]. It was produced by [[William Fox|William Fox (producer)]]. The Darling of Paris was later re-edited from six to five [[reels|Reel#Motion picture terminology]] and re-released by Fox on February 16, 1919. The film is now considered [[lost|Lost film]].
title: The Darling of Paris

abstract: Niram was a commercial success, and brought back in a genre of college campus based films in [[Malayalam cinema|Malayalam cinema]]. The film was remade in [[Telugu|Telugu language]] as [[Nuvve Kavali|Nuvve Kavali]] starring [[Tarun|Tarun Kumar]] and [[Richa Pallod|Richa Pallod]], in Tamil as [[Piriyadha Varam Vendum|Piriyadha Varam Vendum]] starring [[Prashanth|Prashanth (actor)]] and [[Shalini|Shalini]], in Kannada as [[Ninagagi|Ninagagi]] with [[Vijay Raghavendra|Vijay Raghavendra]] and in Hindi as [[Tujhe Meri Kasam|Tujhe Meri Kasam]] starring [[Ritesh Deshmukh|Ritesh Deshmukh]] and [[Genelia D'Souza|Genelia D'Souza]].
title: Niram

abstract: Summer 2007 is a [[2008|2008 in film]] [[India|Indian]] [[drama film|drama film]] directed by the debutant Suhail Tatari. The film deals with five medical students who undergo a rude awakening of sorts after visiting a [[Maharashtrian|Maharashtra]] village and witnessing the misfortune of villagers. The film stars [[Sikandar Kher|Sikandar Kher]], [[Gul Panag|Gul Panag]], [[Yuvika Chaudhary|Yuvika Chaudhary]], [[Arjan Bajwa|Arjan Bajwa]] and Alekh Sangal. [[Ashutosh Rana|Ashutosh Rana]] and [[Divya Dutta|Divya Dutta]] play the supporting roles.
title: Summer 2007

abstract: Devaraagam is a 1996 Indian Malayalam-language film directed by [[Bharathan|Bharathan]] and starring [[Arvind Swamy|Arvind Swamy]] and [[Sridevi|Sridevi]] in the lead roles. It also had [[KPAC Lalitha|KPAC Lalitha]], [[Kozhikode Narayanan Nair|Kozhikode Narayanan Nair]], [[Zeenath|Zeenath]] and [[Nedumudi Venu|Nedumudi Venu]] in supporting roles. The film music was composed by [[M. M. Keeravani|M. M. Keeravani]]. A Tamil dubbed version of the film was also released.
title: Devaraagam

abstract: The Plot to Kill Hitler is a 1990 [[television film|television film]] based on the [[July 20 plot|20 July plot]] by [[German High Command|Oberkommando der Wehrmacht]] to kill [[Adolf Hitler|Adolf Hitler]] in 1944. [[Brad Davis|Brad Davis (actor)]] stars as Colonel [[Claus Schenk Graf von Stauffenberg|Claus Schenk Graf von Stauffenberg]], who plants a bomb in the conference room of the [[Führer|Führer]]'s headquarters in East Prussia.
title: The Plot to Kill Hitler

abstract: Tipu Kanan Tipu Kiri (100 Lies to Hide a Wife) digital film from [[Malaysia|Malaysia]], directed by [[Chennai|Chennai]]-based journalist [[Sharad Sharan|Sharad Sharan]]. The film, about a group of friends at the crossroads of life, features a set of new actors including [[Natasha Hudson|Natasha Hudson]], [[Sazzy Falak|Sazzy Falak]] and [[Hans Isaac|Hans Isaac]] with noted [[Tamil|Tamil cinema]] actor, [[Madhavan|R. Madhavan]] in a guest appearance.
title: Tipu Kanan Tipu Kiri

abstract: Justice Viswanathan is a [[1971|1971 in film]] Indian [[Tamil language|Tamil language]] [[Drama film|Drama film]], directed by [[G. R. Nathan|G. R. Nathan]], starring [[Ravichandran|Ravichandran (Tamil actor)]] and [[Major Sundarrajan|Major Sundarrajan]]. The movie is a remake of the 1969 Hindi movie [[Do Bhai|Do Bhai (1969 film)]], starring [[Ashok Kumar|Ashok Kumar]] and [[Jeetendra|Jeetendra]], which was also remade in Telugu in 1971 as Nenu Manishine.
title: Justice Viswanathan

abstract: Raja Desingu () is a 1960 Indian [[Tamil language|Tamil language]] film starring [[M. G. Ramachandran|M. G. Ramachandran]], [[S. S. Rajendran|S. S. Rajendran]], [[Bhanumathi|Bhanumathi Ramakrishna]] and [[Padmini|Padmini (actress)]] in the lead roles. The film was directed by T. R. Raghunath, had musical score by [[G. Ramanathan|G. Ramanathan]] and was released on 2 September 1960. The movie flopped miserably at the box office and ran for 70 days.
title: Raja Desingu

abstract: Arasilangkumari () is a [[Tamil language|Tamil language]] film starring [[M. G. Ramachandran|M. G.
