Ramachandran]], [[Padmini|Padmini (actress)]] and [[Rajasulochana|Rajasulochana]] in the lead roles. The film, produced by M. Somasundaram under Jupiter Pictures banner, had a score written by [[G. Ramanathan|G. Ramanathan]] and was released on 1 January 1961. A. S. A. Sami, who directed the major portion, was replaced by editor-turned-director A. Kasilingam, who completed the film. The film is an adaptation of the 1952 Hollywood film, [[Scaramouche|Scaramouche (1952 film)]]. The film did not run well. It was under production for a long time and was released very much delayed and the result was poor run.
title: Arasilangkumari

abstract: Nallavan Vazhvan () is a 1961 [[Tamil-language|Tamil language]] [[drama film|Drama (film and television)]], directed by [[P. Neelakantan|P. Neelakantan]]. The film features [[M. G. Ramachandran|M. G. Ramachandran]] and [[Rajasulochana|Rajasulochana]] in lead roles. The film had musical score by [[T. R. Pappa|T. R. Pappa]] and was released on 31 August 1961. The film didn't do well at the box office and ran for 80 days. It was the 50th film for MGR.
title: Nallavan Vazhvan

abstract: Koduthu Vaithaval (The Blessed Woman) is a 1963 [[Tamil-language|Tamil language]] Indian [[drama film|Drama (film and television)]], directed by [[P. Neelakantan|P. Neelakantan]]. The film features [[M. G. Ramachandran|M. G. Ramachandran]], [[M. R. Radha|M. R. Radha]] and [[E. V. Saroja|E. V. Saroja]] in lead roles. The film, produced by E. V. Rajan, had musical score by [[K. V. Mahadevan|K. V. Mahadevan]] and was released on 9 February 1963. The film was a hit at the box office and ran for 90 days.
title: Koduthu Vaithaval

abstract: Thazhampoo (The [[Pandanus|Pandanus odorifer]] flower) is a [[Tamil language|Tamil language]] film, starring [[M. G. Ramachandran|M. G. Ramachandran]] in the lead role, with [[K. R. Vijaya|K. R. Vijaya]] and [[Nagesh|Nagesh]]. The film was released in 1965.
title: Thazhampoo

abstract: Avasara Police 100 is a 1990 [[India|Indian]] [[Tamil|Tamil language]]-language film starring and directed by [[K. Bhagyaraj|K. Bhagyaraj]] with [[M. G. Ramachandran|M. G. Ramachandran]] in the lead role.
title: Avasara Police 100

abstract: La Tratta delle bianche is a 1952 Italian [[melodrama film|melodrama film]]. It was also released in the United States in 1954 under the title Girls Marked Danger.
title: Girls Marked Danger

abstract: Gandharvam ([[Malayalam|Malayalam]]: ഗാന്ധര്‍വ്വം) (1993) is a [[Malayalam|Malayalam]] language [[romantic|romance film]] [[thriller|thriller (genre)]] directed by [[Sangeeth Sivan|Sangeeth Sivan]]. [[Mohanlal|Mohanlal]] and [[Kanchan|Kanchan (actress)]] appear in lead roles along with [[Jagathi Sreekumar|Jagathi Sreekumar]], [[Devan|Devan (actor)]], [[Vijayakumar|Vijayakumar (actor)]], [[Prem Kumar|Prem Kumar (Malayalam actor)]] and [[Kaviyoor Ponnamma|Kaviyoor Ponnamma]].
title: Gandharvam

abstract: Ashokavanam is a [[1978|Malayalam films of 1978]] [[Indian|Cinema of India]] [[Malayalam|Malayalam language]] film, directed by [[M. Krishnan Nair|M. Krishnan Nair (director)]] and produced by TE Vasudevan. The film stars [[Jagathy Sreekumar|Jagathy Sreekumar]], [[Adoor Bhasi|Adoor Bhasi]], [[Jose Prakash|Jose Prakash]] and [[Sukumaran|Sukumaran]] in lead roles. The film had musical score by [[V. Dakshinamoorthy|V. Dakshinamoorthy]].
title: Ashokavanam

abstract: The film begins with the death of the family of a young girl as a result of a character's [[drunken driving|drunken driving]]. The film sketches the path of the young girl growing up into a woman who lives her life independently and with self-esteem. How the male protagonist enters the woman's life and how they fall in love with each other forms the rest of the story. The film went on to win the [[Nandi Awards|Nandi Awards]] among several other [[prominent awards|Anand (2004 film)#Awards]]. If the award-winning [[Dollar Dreams|Dollar Dreams]] (2000) set the tone, then Anand introduced the legacy of successful films made with simple stories. A noteworthy mention is of the film's [[soundtrack|Anand (2004 film)#Soundtrack]] which was well appreciated for its soft melodies.
title: Anand (2004 film)

abstract: Pokémon: The Rise of Darkrai, originally released in Japan as , is a 2007 Japanese anime film directed by [[Kunihiko Yuyama|Kunihiko Yuyama]] as the tenth [[Pokémon anime|Pokémon (anime)]] film. It was released in Japanese theaters on July 14, 2007. It was later released in United States on February 24, 2008 on [[Cartoon Network|Cartoon Network]], on November 5, 2008 in Australia and September 29, 2008 in the United Kingdom. The Rise of Darkrai aired on [[Jetix UK|Disney XD (United Kingdom and Ireland)#Jetix]] in February 2009. As indicated by the film title, [[Darkrai|Darkrai]], as well as [[Dialga|Dialga]] and [[Palkia|Palkia]], are the featured Pokémon. The events of the take place during the tenth season of [[Pokémon: Diamond and Pearl|List of Pokémon: Diamond and Pearl episodes]].
title: Pokémon: The Rise of Darkrai

abstract: Dilli Ka Thug (The Trickster of Delhi) is a [[1958|Bollywood films of 1958]] [[Hindi|Hindi]]-language [[comedy film|comedy film]]. It stars [[Kishore Kumar|Kishore Kumar]], [[Nutan|Nutan]], [[Madan Puri|Madan Puri]] and [[Iftekhar|Iftekhar]]. The music was by [[Ravi|Ravi (music director)]] and the lyrics were by [[S.H. Bihari|S.H. Bihari]], [[Shailendra|Shailendra (lyricist)]] and [[Majrooh Sultanpuri|Majrooh Sultanpuri]]. The song "Hum to mohabbat karega" was Sultanpuri's contribution.
title: Dilli Ka Thug

abstract: My Little Girl is a 1986 American [[drama film|Drama (film and television)]] the directorial debut of Connie Kaiserman that was released in the U.S. in 1987. It is also [[Geraldine Page|Geraldine Page]]'s final role and [[Jennifer Lopez|Jennifer Lopez]]' film debut.
title: My Little Girl

abstract: Baharen Phir Bhi Aayengi () is a [[1966|Bollywood films of 1966]] Hindi-language film produced by [[Guru Dutt|Guru Dutt]] and directed by [[Shaheed Latif|Shaheed Latif]]. It stars [[Mala Sinha|Mala Sinha]], [[Dharmendra|Dharmendra]], [[Tanuja|Tanuja]], and [[Rehman|Rehman (actor)]]. The film is still remembered for its music is by [[O.P. Nayyar|O.P. Nayyar]] and lyrics by Sheven Rizvi, Aziz Kashmiri and for its expressionistic cinematography by K.G. Prabhakar.
title: Baharen Phir Bhi Aayengi

abstract: [[Alexander Fu|Alexander Fu]] died in a car accident before the filming of The Eight Diagram Pole Fighter was finished. The script was partly re-written after his death and Fu's character does not appear in the final showdown as originally written in the script.
title: The Eight Diagram Pole Fighter

abstract: Bedara Kannappa () is a 1954 Indian [[Kannada film|Cinema of Karnataka]] directed by [[H. L. N. Simha|H. L. N. Simha]] and written by [[G. V. Iyer|G. V. Iyer]]. It stars [[Rajkumar|Rajkumar (actor)]] and [[Pandari Bai|Pandari Bai]] in lead roles. Bedara Kannappa started as a play produced by the Gubbi Veeranna Nataka Company before it became a Kannada film. The release was a historic moment for the Kannada cinema industry causing its production of films to increase over the next ten years. The film was a launch pad to Rajkumar's career. It marked the debut of [[Narasimharaju|Narasimharaju (Kannada actor)]], who went on to be named among Kannada cinema's finest actors, alongside Rajkumar.
title: Bedara Kannappa

abstract: What Gets Me Hot! is the title of a 1984 [[pornographic|pornographic]] movie that featured [[Traci Lords|Traci Lords]], [[Bunny Bleu|Bunny Bleu]], [[Susan Hart|Susan Hart]], [[Dorothy Onan|Dorothy Onan]], [[Marc Wallice|Marc Wallice]], Sean Alexander, [[Tom Byron|Tom Byron]], [[Greg Rome|Greg Rome]], [[Herschel Savage|Herschel Savage]] (aka Hershel Savage), Maria Kay, [[Helga Sven|Helga Sven]], and [[Leslie Thane|Leslie Thane]]. It was written and directed by the [[Hungarian|Hungary]]-born Richard Mailer.
title: What Gets Me Hot!

abstract: Aces Go Places, (), also known in the United States as Diamondfinger or Mad Mission, is a 1982 Hong Kong [[action|Hong Kong action cinema]] [[comedy film|comedy film]] directed by [[Eric Tsang|Eric Tsang]], and starring [[Samuel Hui|Samuel Hui]] and [[Karl Maka|Karl Maka]].
title: Aces Go Places

abstract: The Masseur ([[Filipino|Filipino language]]: Masahista) is a 2005 Filipino film written and directed by [[Brillante Mendoza|Brillante Mendoza]]. This film is about a young man who gives massages to gay men in Manila and had a relationship.
title: The Masseur

abstract: Anmol is a [[1993|Bollywood films of 1993]] [[India|Indian]] film directed by [[Ketan Desai|Ketan Desai (director)]] and produced by his father [[Manmohan Desai|Manmohan Desai]] and starring [[Manisha Koirala|Manisha Koirala]] and [[Rishi Kapoor|Rishi Kapoor]]. This was the final film produced by Manmohan Desai before his death in 1994. The plot is loosely based on life of Mr. Anmol Khandelwal.
title: Anmol

abstract: Dil Ek Mandir () is a [[1963|List of Bollywood films of 1963]] Indian [[Hindi|Hindi]]-language [[romantic drama|romantic drama]] film directed by [[C. V. Sridhar|C. V. Sridhar]]. The film stars [[Rajendra Kumar|Rajendra Kumar]], [[Meena Kumari|Meena Kumari]], [[Raaj Kumar|Raaj Kumar]] and [[Mehmood|Mehmood Ali]]. The film's music is by [[Shankar Jaikishan|Shankar Jaikishan]]. All the songs of this film were hits and were loved by everyone. The film was a major hit at the box office. The film was a remake of the [[Tamil|Tamil language]] film [[Nenjil Or Aalayam|Nenjil Or Aalayam]] (1962), also directed by Sridhar.
title: Dil Ek Mandir

abstract: Meri Jung () is a [[1985|Bollywood films of 1985]] Indian Hindi movie produced by N N Sippy and directed by [[Subhash Ghai|Subhash Ghai]]. The film stars [[Anil Kapoor|Anil Kapoor]], [[Meenakshi Sheshadri|Meenakshi Sheshadri]], [[Nutan|Nutan]], [[Amrish Puri|Amrish Puri]], [[Javed Jaffrey|Javed Jaffrey]] (in his debut film), [[A. K. Hangal|A. K. Hangal]], [[Iftekhar|Iftekhar]], [[Kushboo|Kushboo]] and [[Parikshat Sahni|Parikshat Sahni]]. The film's music is by [[Laxmikant Pyarelal|Laxmikant Pyarelal]].
title: Meri Jung

abstract: Shakalaka Boom Boom is a 2007 Indian [[thriller|thriller film]] [[drama film|drama film]] directed and produced by [[Suneel Darshan|Suneel Darshan]] and written by [[Anurag Kashyap|Anurag Kashyap (director)]]. The film stars [[Bobby Deol|Bobby Deol]], [[Upen Patel|Upen Patel]], [[Celina Jaitly|Celina Jaitly]] and [[Kangana Ranaut|Kangana Ranaut]] in the lead. It released on 6 April 2007.
title: Shakalaka Boom Boom

abstract: As Young as You Feel (1951) is a comedy film starring [[Monty Woolley|Monty Woolley]], [[Thelma Ritter|Thelma Ritter]], and [[David Wayne|David Wayne]], with [[Marilyn Monroe|Marilyn Monroe]] in a small role.
title: As Young as You Feel

abstract: Neeya? () is a 1979 Indian [[Tamil-language|Tamil language]] [[horror film|horror film]], starring [[Kamal Haasan|Kamal Haasan]] in the lead role and directed by [[Durai|Durai (director)]]. It is a remake of the [[Hindi|Hindi]] film [[Nagin|Nagin (1976 film)]], itself inspired by François Truffaut's film [[The Bride Wore Black|The Bride Wore Black]], based on [[Cornell Woolrich|Cornell Woolrich]]'s novel of the same name.
title: Neeya?

abstract: Unarchigal is a 1976 [[Tamil|Tamil language]] language film directed by [[R. C. Sakthi|R. C. Sakthi]] starring [[Kamal Haasan|Kamal Haasan]] and [[Srividya|Srividya]] in the lead roles. It is a highly sensuous film which deals with [[sexually transmitted disease|sexually transmitted diseases]], and subsequently the film ran into trouble with the censor board prompting a delay in its release. additionally, [[Kamal Haasan|Kamal Haasan]] worked as assistant director also.
title: Unarchigal

abstract: Njan Ninne Premikkunnu is a [[1975|Malayalam films of 1975]] [[Indian|Cinema of India]] [[Malayalam|Malayalam language]] film, directed by [[K. S. Gopalakrishnan|K. S. Gopalakrishnan]]. The film stars [[Kamal Haasan|Kamal Haasan]], Girija, [[Janardhanan|Janardhanan (actor)]] and Murali Sr. in the lead roles. The film has musical score by [[M. S. Baburaj|M. S. Baburaj]].
title: Njan Ninne Premikkunnu

abstract: Per Sollum Pillai (English: The child who says the name) is a [[1987|1987 in film]] [[Tamil-language|Tamil language]] [[Indian|Cinema of India]] feature film directed by [[S. P. Muthuraman|S. P. Muthuraman]], starring [[Kamal Haasan|Kamal Haasan]], [[Radhika|Raadhika]], [[Manorama|Manorama (Tamil actress)]], [[K. R. Vijaya|K. R. Vijaya]] and [[Raveendran|Raveendran (actor)]]. The movie completed 100 days and was a hit at the box office. The movie is a remake of [[Padikkadha Medhai|Padikkadha Medhai]] of the same writer. The movie was dubbed into Telugu as Maa Inti Krishnudu
title: Per Sollum Pillai

abstract: Punnagai Mannan () is a 1986 Indian [[Tamil language|Tamil language]] [[romantic drama|romantic drama]] film written and directed by [[K. Balachander|K. Balachander]]. The film stars [[Kamal Haasan|Kamal Haasan]] and [[Revathi|Revathi]] in the lead roles. Punnagai Mannan was released on 1 November 1986, during [[Diwali|Diwali]], and ran for 25 weeks in theatres. It was later dubbed into [[Telugu|Telugu language]] as Dance Master, and into [[Hindi|Hindi]] as Chacha Charlie in 1996.
title: Punnagai Mannan

abstract: Maanavan (English: The Student) is a Tamil language [[Social|Social]] [[Satirical|Satirical]] film was directed by [[M. A. Thirumugam|M. A. Thirumugam]] and produced by [[Sandow M. M. A. Chinnappa Thevar|Sandow M. M. A. Chinnappa Thevar]] under his productions Dhandayudhapani Films. The script were written by Balamurugan. Music by [[Shankar - Ganesh|Shankar - Ganesh]] assets to the film. The film starring [[Jaishankar|Jaishankar]] and [[Muthuraman|R. Muthuraman]] lead with [[Sowcar Janaki|Sowcar Janaki]], [[Lakshmi|Lakshmi (actress)]], [[Nagesh|Nagesh]] and [[Sachu|Sachu]] played pivotal roles. [[Kamal Haasan|Kamal Haasan]] appears only for a dance sequence along with Kutty Padmini. This was [[Kamal Haasan|Kamal Haasan]]'s first adult role after a 7-year hiatus. The film also marks the debut of many character actors and comedians like Pandu, [[Kathadi Ramamurthy|Kathadi Ramamurthy]] among others.
title: Maanavan

abstract: Sollathaan Ninaikkiren () is a 1973 [[Tamil language|Tamil language]] film, written and directed by [[K. Balachander|K. Balachander]], starring [[Sivakumar|Sivakumar]], [[S. V. Subbaiah|S. V. Subbaiah]], [[Jayachitra|Jayachitra]], [[Srividya|Srividya]], [[Shubha|Shubha (actress)]], [[Kamal Haasan|Kamal Haasan]] and [[Jayasudha|Jayasudha]] in the lead roles. The film has [[Kamal Haasan|Kamal Haasan]] as a playboy and Jayasudha as a young girl married to an older man (Poornam Vishwanathan). The film is based on the novel Ilavu Kaatha Kili by Manian. Balachander remade the film in [[Kannada|Kannada]] as [[Sundara Swapnagalu|Sundara Swapnagalu]].
title: Sollathaan Ninaikkiren

abstract: Pattampoochi is a 1975 [[Tamil language|Tamil language]] [[drama film|drama film]] directed by A. S. Pragasam and starring [[Kamal Haasan|Kamal Haasan]] and [[Jayachitra|Jayachitra]]. The film was a box office success.
title: Pattampoochi

abstract: Oru Oodhappu Kan Simittugiradhu () is a [[Tamil language|Tamil language]] film starring [[Kamal Haasan|Kamal Haasan]] in the lead role of the protagonist, Ravi. This movie is based on a novel by the same name written by [[Pushpa Thangadorai|Pushpa Thangadorai]].
title: Oru Oodhappu Kan Simittugiradhu

abstract: Mogam Muppadhu Varusham () is a Tamil language film directed by [[S. P. Muthuraman|S. P. Muthuraman]], starring [[Kamal Haasan|Kamal Haasan]] in the lead role, with [[Vijayakumar|Vijayakumar (actor)]], [[Sumithra|Sumithra (actress)]], [[Fatafat Jayalaxmi|Fatafat Jayalaxmi]] and [[Sripriya|Sripriya]] in supporting roles. The film was based on the novel of the same name, written by Maniyan and published in the magazine [[Ananda Vikatan|Ananda Vikatan]].
title: Mogam Muppadhu Varusham

abstract: Sigaw (The Echo) is a 2004 [[Filipino|Philippines]] horror film directed by [[Yam Laranas|Yam Laranas]]. The film was a box office success in the [[Philippines|Philippines]] where the horror genre has become increasingly popular. The success of the film also owes much to the bankability of its two main stars. In 2005, the film received a release in both Singapore and Malaysia.
title: Sigaw

abstract: Papá Corazón se quiere casar is a [[1974|List of Argentine films of 1974]] [[Argentine|Argentina]] [[film|film]].
title: Papá Corazón se quiere casar

abstract: Thodisi Bewafaii () is a [[1980|Bollywood films of 1980]] Hindi movie written and directed by [[Esmayeel Shroff|Esmayeel Shroff]]. The film stars [[Rajesh Khanna|Rajesh Khanna]], [[Shabana Azmi|Shabana Azmi]] and [[Padmini Kohlapure|Padmini Kohlapure]]. The music is by [[Khayyam|Khayyam (composer)]].
title: Thodisi Bewafaii

abstract: Sawan Ko Aane Do (English: Let the Monsoon arrive) is a [[1979|Bollywood films of 1979]] [[Rajshri Productions|Rajshri Productions]] Hindi movie produced by [[Tarachand Barjatya|Tarachand Barjatya]] and directed by Kanak Mishra. The film was noted for its enchanting songs and charismatic performance by Arun Govil.
title: Sawan Ko Aane Do

abstract: Jeene Ki Raah () is a [[1969|Bollywood films of 1969]] [[Bollywood|Bollywood]], [[drama film|Drama (film and television)]] produced and directed by [[L. V. Prasad|L. V. Prasad]] under the Prasad Productions Pvt. Ltd. banner. The film stars [[Jeetendra|Jeetendra]], [[Tanuja|Tanuja]], [[Sanjeev Kumar|Sanjeev Kumar (actor)]] in the lead roles and music composed by [[Laxmikant Pyarelal|Laxmikant Pyarelal]]. The film is a remake of [[Telugu|Telugu language]] movie [[Bratuku Theruvu|Bratuku Theruvu]] (1953), starring [[Akkineni Nageswara Rao|Akkineni Nageswara Rao]], [[Savitri|Savitri (actress)]], which was dubbed in Tamil as Bale Raman and released in 1956. When the Hindi version became a success, there was another remake in [[Telugu|Telugu language]] as [[Bharya Biddalu|Bharya Biddalu]] (1971), starring Akkineni Nageswara Rao, [[Jayalalithaa|J. Jayalalithaa]]. Later in Tamil, the same film was remade as [[Naan Yen Pirandhen|Naan Yen Pirandhen]] with MGR, Kanchana, K.R. Vijaya in the pivotal roles.
title: Jeene Ki Raah

abstract: Prudence and the Pill is a 1968 British [[comedy film|comedy film]] made by [[Twentieth Century-Fox|Twentieth Century-Fox]]. It was directed by [[Fielder Cook|Fielder Cook]] and [[Ronald Neame|Ronald Neame]] and produced by Kenneth Harper and Ronald J. Kahn from a screenplay by Hugh Mills, based on his own novel. The music score was by Bernard Ebbinghouse and the cinematography by [[Ted Moore|Ted Moore]].
title: Prudence and the Pill

abstract: Sunghursh is a [[1968|Bollywood films of 1968]] Indian [[Hindi film|Bollywood]] directed and produced by [[Harnam Singh Rawail|H. S. Rawail]]. It is based on a short story Layli Asmaner Ayna in [[Bengali language|Bengali language]] by [[Jnanpith Award|Jnanpith Award]]-winning writer [[Mahasweta Devi|Mahasweta Devi]], which presents a fictionalised account of vendetta within a [[thuggee|thuggee]] cult in the holy Indian town of [[Varanasi|Varanasi]]. The film stars [[Dilip Kumar|Dilip Kumar]], [[Vyjayanthimala|Vyjayanthimala]], [[Sanjeev Kumar|Sanjeev Kumar]], [[Balraj Sahni|Balraj Sahni]], [[Jayant|Jayant (actor)]], [[Deven Verma|Deven Verma]], [[Durga Khote|Durga Khote]] and [[Iftekhar|Iftekhar]].
title: Sunghursh

abstract: [[Heath Ledger|Heath Ledger]], [[Christopher Plummer|Christopher Plummer]], [[Andrew Garfield|Andrew Garfield]], [[Lily Cole|Lily Cole]], [[Verne Troyer|Verne Troyer]], and [[Tom Waits|Tom Waits]] star in the film, though Ledger's death one-third of the way through filming caused production to be temporarily suspended. Ledger's role was recast with [[Johnny Depp|Johnny Depp]], [[Jude Law|Jude Law]], and [[Colin Farrell|Colin Farrell]] portraying transformations of Ledger's character as he travels through a dream world; the film marks Ledger's final film performance. The Imaginarium of Doctor Parnassus interweaves several plot lines in a nonlinear arrangement.
title: The Imaginarium of Doctor Parnassus

abstract: Raampur Ka Lakshman is a [[1972|List of Bollywood films of 1972]] Indian Hindi movie directed by [[Manmohan Desai|Manmohan Desai]]. The film was remade in 1978 in Tamil, titled as [[Mangudi Minor|Mangudi Minor]], where [[Rajinikanth|Rajinikanth]] essayed the similar role played by [[Shatrughan Sinha|Shatrughan Sinha]] in the Hindi original.
title: Raampur Ka Lakshman

abstract: The Best Bet () is a Singaporean comedy film written and directed by [[Jack Neo|Jack Neo]] and distributed by [[MediaCorp Raintree Pictures|MediaCorp Raintree Pictures]]. The film stars [[Richard Low|Richard Low]], [[Mark Lee|Mark Lee (Singaporean actor)]], [[Christopher Lee|Christopher Lee (Malaysian actor)]], [[Chen Liping|Chen Liping]] and [[Joanne Peh|Joanne Peh]].
title: The Best Bet

abstract: The project was created to experiment with a new type of 3D film technology pioneered by producer Steve Schklair. After considering shooting [[American football|American football]] games in 3D, Schklair's company [[3ality Digital|3ality Digital]] decided to create a concert film with U2. The band were hesitant to participate, but agreed to the project mainly as a technological experiment rather than a profit-making venture. Although set in Buenos Aires, U2 3D was shot at seven concerts across Latin America, and two in Australia. The film's complex setup involved shooting with up to 18   3D cameras simultaneously and capturing the footage digitally.
title: U2 3D

abstract: Origin: Spirits of the Past, known in Japan as , is a 2006 [[Japanese animated|anime]] [[science fiction film|science fiction film]] directed by Keiichi Sugiyama, written by Nana Shiina and Naoko Kakimoto, and produced by [[Gonzo|Gonzo (studio)]]. The film stars the voices of [[Ryo Katsuji|Ryo Katsuji]], [[Aoi Miyazaki|Aoi Miyazaki]], [[Yūko Kotegawa|Yūko Kotegawa]], [[Masaru Hamaguchi|Masaru Hamaguchi]], [[Toshikazu Fukawa|Toshikazu Fukawa]], [[Kenichi Endō|Kenichi Endō]] and [[Ren Osugi|Ren Osugi]]. It premiered in Japan on January 7, 2006, and premiered in the [[United States|United States]] on September 24, 2006 at the [[Fantastic Fest|Fantastic Fest]] [[film festival|film festival]] in [[Austin|Austin, Texas]], [[Texas|Texas]].
title: Origin: Spirits of the Past

abstract: The Burning Train is a [[1980|Bollywood films of 1980]] [[India|Indian]] [[Bollywood|Bollywood]] [[action thriller|action movie]] [[film|film]], produced by [[B. R. Chopra|B. R. Chopra]] under the B. R. Films banner and directed by [[Ravi Chopra|Ravi Chopra]]. The film featured a huge all-star cast, featuring [[Dharmendra|Dharmendra]], [[Hema Malini|Hema Malini]], [[Vinod Khanna|Vinod Khanna]], [[Parveen Babi|Parveen Babi]], [[Jeetendra|Jeetendra]], [[Neetu Singh|Neetu Singh]] in the pivotal roles and music composed by [[R. D. Burman|R. D. Burman]].
title: The Burning Train

abstract: Ram Balram () is a [[1980|Bollywood films of 1980]] [[Hindi|Bollywood]] [[action film|action film]] directed by [[Vijay Anand|Vijay Anand (Hindi film maker)]]. It starred [[Dharmendra|Dharmendra]] as "Ram" and [[Amitabh Bachchan|Amitabh Bachchan]] as "Balram". Supporting cast included [[Zeenat Aman|Zeenat Aman]] and [[Rekha|Rekha]]. [[Ajit|Ajit Khan]], [[Amjad Khan|Amjad Khan (actor)]] and [[Prem Chopra|Prem Chopra]] were the villains in the film. The film marked the third time in which Bollywood eternal superstars (Amitabh Bachchan and Dharmendra) came together after their previous successful ventures in Chupke Chupke and Sholay. The movie had an awesome initial opening, to thunderous responses all over India with cinema houses packed full. However, proceeds from the movie started to drop by the 4th week and it then went on to surface as the third highest-grossing film of the year earning a "Hit" at the box office. It was termed disappointing since at that time, films of Dharmendra and Amitabh were expected to earn more, who were already the most popular stars at the time. However, some box office analysts rate it as a "Superhit" when taking into consideration its net proceeds.
title: Ram Balram

abstract: Yahudi (, Jew), is a [[1958|Bollywood films of 1958]] [[Bollywood|Bollywood]] [[film|film]] directed by [[Bimal Roy|Bimal Roy]]. It starred [[Dilip Kumar|Dilip Kumar]], [[Meena Kumari|Meena Kumari]], [[Sohrab Modi|Sohrab Modi]], [[Nazir Hussain|Nazir Hussain]], [[Nigar Sultana|Nigar Sultana (actress)]] and others. It was based on the play [[Yahudi Ki Ladki|Yahudi Ki Ladki]] by [[Agha Hashar Kashmiri|Agha Hashar Kashmiri]], a classic in [[Parsi|Parsi theatre]]-Urdu theatre, about persecution of Jews in the Roman Empire.
title: Yahudi

abstract: Channelling Baby is a 1999 [[New Zealand|New Zealand]] film starring several of the country's well known actors as well as up and coming actress [[Amber Sainsbury|Amber Sainsbury]].
title: Channelling Baby

abstract: The movie is considered a [[cult classic|cult classic]] in Russia, it was included in various top list of animated films and science fiction films. A shortened [[novelisation|novelisation]] of the film was written by Bulychov himself, a [[diafilm|Reversal film]] and a number of video games were based on The Mystery of the Third Planet, and [[spiritual successor|spiritual successor]] film [[Alice's Birthday|Alice's Birthday]] was released in 2009.
title: The Mystery of the Third Planet

abstract: The Andromeda Nebula () is a [[1967|1967 in film]] [[Soviet|USSR]] [[Science fiction film|Science fiction film]] starring [[Sergei Stolyarov|Sergei Stolyarov]] and directed by [[Yevgeni Sherstobitov|Yevgeni Sherstobitov]] at the [[Dovzhenko Film Studios|Dovzhenko Film Studios]]. The film was originally intended to be the first episode of a series of films, alternatively titled as The Andromeda Nebula: Episode I. Prisoners of the Iron Star, but the remaining parts were never made due to Stolyarov's death.
title: The Andromeda Nebula

abstract: The Ape Man is a 1943 [[horror|Horror film]]-[[science fiction film|science fiction film]] starring [[Bela Lugosi|Bela Lugosi]] and directed by [[William Beaudine|William Beaudine]]. The film follows the tale of a part [[human|human]] part [[ape|ape]].An in-title-only [[sequel|sequel]] Return of the Ape Man followed in 1944 and starred Lugosi, [[John Carradine|John Carradine]] and [[George Zucco|George Zucco]].
title: The Ape Man

abstract: Desert Hearts is a 1985 American [[romantic|romance film]] [[drama film|Drama (film and television)]] directed by [[Donna Deitch|Donna Deitch]]. The screenplay written by Natalie Cooper is an adaptation of the 1964 [[lesbian|Lesbian literature]]-themed novel [[Desert of the Heart|Desert of the Heart]] by [[Jane Rule|Jane Rule]]. Set in [[Reno, Nevada|Reno, Nevada]] in 1959, it tells the story of a university professor awaiting a divorce who finds her true self when she meets a free-spirited younger woman confident in her romantic and [[sexual attraction|Homosexuality]]. The film stars [[Helen Shaver|Helen Shaver]] and [[Patricia Charbonneau|Patricia Charbonneau]] with a supporting performance by [[Audra Lindley|Audra Lindley]].
title: Desert Hearts

abstract: New Wave Hookers is a 1985 [[pornographic film|pornographic film]] that established the [[Alt porn|Alt porn]] genre. It featured a cast of established performers from the era and was followed by a number of sequels and a remake. The movie starred [[Ginger Lynn|Ginger Lynn]], [[Desiree Lane|Desiree Lane]], Kristara Barrington, [[Kimberly Carson|Kimberly Carson]], Brooke Fields, Gina Carrera, [[Jamie Gillis|Jamie Gillis]], [[Jack Baker|Jack Baker (actor)]], [[Tom Byron|Tom Byron]], Steve Powers, [[Peter North|Peter North (porn star)]], [[Rick Cassidy|Rick Cassidy]], Greg Rome, and [[Steve Drake|Steve Drake]]. [[Traci Lords|Traci Lords]] appeared in the original version dressed in all-red lingerie and portrayed "the Devil."
title: New Wave Hookers

abstract: Vallarasu ([[Vijayakanth|Vijayakanth]]) is the Deputy Commissioner of Police and a very honest police officer who has arrested Wasim Khan ([[Mukesh Rishi|Mukesh Rishi]]), a terrorist from Pakistan. He has a wife Anjali ([[Devayani|Devayani (actress)]]) and 2 children. Vallarasu kills his senior police officer ([[Raghuvaran|Raghuvaran]]), who is his father-in-law, on knowing he is hand-in-glove with terrorists and anti-national elements. Anjali leaves Vallarasu after she comes to know he had killed her father. Vallarasu takes the help of some youths (including [[Sriman|Sriman(actor)]]) who are disillusioned by their inability to join the police force to fight the terrorists and other criminal elements. Vallarasu fights R. Kandasamy ([[P. Vasu|P. Vasu]]), a rich man who is behind the attempts to destabilize the country. With the help of Seshadri ([[Karan|Karan (actor)]]), a software engineer, Vallarasu succeeds in killing Kandasamy's son. In retaliation, Kandaswamy attacks Raheem ([[Sriman|Sriman (actor)]]) and Seshadri, who both die. In the climax, Anjali unites with Vallarasu after knowing the truth, and he kills both Kandasamy and Wasim Khan.
title: Vallarasu

abstract: Betaab is a [[1983|Bollywood films of 1983]] [[India|Indian]] [[Hindi|Hindi]] [[romance film|romance film]] released and directed by Rahul Rawail and produced by Bikram Sing Dahal. The film stars [[Sunny Deol|Sunny Deol]] and [[Amrita Singh|Amrita Singh]] in their debut roles. The music was composed by [[Rahul Dev Burman|Rahul Dev Burman]]. The film went on to be one of the biggest hits of the year. The film was remade in [[Telugu|Telugu language]] as Samrat in 1987, with [[Ramesh Babu|Ramesh Babu]] and [[Sonam|Sonam (actress)]].
title: Betaab

abstract: Aan Milo Sajna () is a [[1970|Bollywood films of 1970]] Hindi film written by [[Sachin Bhowmick|Sachin Bhowmick]], produced by Jagdish Kumar and directed by Mukul Dutt. The film stars [[Rajesh Khanna|Rajesh Khanna]] and [[Asha Parekh|Asha Parekh]] in the lead roles and the supporting cast included [[Vinod Khanna|Vinod Khanna]], [[Rajendra Nath|Rajendra Nath]], [[Aruna Irani|Aruna Irani]] and [[Nirupa Roy|Nirupa Roy]]. The music is by [[Laxmikant Pyarelal|Laxmikant Pyarelal]] with lyrics by [[Anand Bakshi|Anand Bakshi]]. The film became a super hit at the box office and the song "Acha to Hum Chalte Hain" was a phenomenon. This film is counted among the 17 consecutive hit films of Rajesh Khanna between 1969 and 1971, by adding the two-hero films Marayada and Andaz to the 15 consecutive solo hits he gave from 1969 to 1971. During the interval of other films released in 1970, when the trailer for Aan Milo Sajna, used to be played, crowds would erupt as soon as Rajesh Khanna arrived on the screen.
title: Aan Milo Sajna

abstract: Dushman Duniya Ka ([[English|English language]]: Enemy of the World) is a [[1996|Bollywood films of 1996]] [[Bollywood|Bollywood]] [[drama film|drama film]], produced by [[Ashok Mishra|Ashok Mishra]], Babubhai, Masoom Ali under the Canmore Cinema banner and directed by [[Mehmood|Mehmood Ali]]. It stars [[Jeetendra|Jeetendra]], [[Sumalatha|Sumalatha]], Manzoor Ali, [[Laila Mehdin|Laila Mehdin]] in the lead roles while [[Shahrukh Khan|Shahrukh Khan]], [[Salman Khan|Salman Khan]] have given special appearances and the music was composed by [[Anu Malik|Anu Malik]]. The film is first debut to [[Laila Mehdin|Laila Mehdin]] and Manzoor Ali.
title: Dushman Duniya Ka

abstract: Apradh is a [[1972|List of Bollywood films of 1972]] action thriller romance [[Hindi film|Bollywood]] produced and directed by [[Feroz Khan|Feroz Khan (actor)]]. It was Feroz Khan's debut as a producer and a director. The film stars [[Feroz Khan|Feroz Khan (actor)]], [[Mumtaz|Mumtaz (actress)]], [[Prem Chopra|Prem Chopra]], [[Iftekhar|Iftekhar]], [[Helen|Helen Jairag Richardson]], [[Faryal|Faryal]] and [[Madan Puri|Madan Puri]]. The film's music is by [[Kalyanji Anandji|Kalyanji Anandji]].
title: Apradh

abstract: Uljhan is a 1975 Hindi film. Produced by Sudesh Kumar and directed by Raghunath Jhalani, it stars [[Ashok Kumar|Ashok Kumar]], [[Sanjeev Kumar|Sanjeev Kumar (actor)]], [[Asrani|Asrani]], [[Farida Jalal|Farida Jalal]], [[Aruna Irani|Aruna Irani]], [[Sulakshana Pandit|Sulakshana Pandit]], and [[Ranjeet|Ranjeet]]. The music is by [[Kalyanji Anandji|Kalyanji Anandji]]. It is a remake of 1959 murder mystery [[Kangan|Kangan (1959 film)]] starring [[Ashok Kumar|Ashok Kumar]] and [[Nirupa Roy|Nirupa Roy]] with a twist about the identity of the killer.
title: Uljhan

abstract: Aap Beati is a [[1976|Bollywood films of 1976]] Hindi film. Produced and directed by Mohan Kumar, the film stars [[Shashi Kapoor|Shashi Kapoor]], [[Hema Malini|Hema Malini]], [[Ashok Kumar|Ashok Kumar]], [[Nirupa Roy|Nirupa Roy]], [[Premnath|Premnath]], [[Aruna Irani|Aruna Irani]], [[Helen|Helen Jairag Richardson]], [[Asrani|Asrani]], Sujit Kumar and [[Madan Puri|Madan Puri]]. The film's music is by [[Laxmikant Pyarelal|Laxmikant Pyarelal]]
title: Aap Beati

abstract: Aayiram Jenmangal () is a 1978 Tamil-language [[horror film|horror film]] directed by [[Durai|Durai (director)]], starring [[Vijayakumar|Vijayakumar (actor)]], [[Latha|Latha (actress)]], [[Rajinikanth|Rajinikanth]] and [[Padmapriya|Padmapriya (actress)]] in the lead roles. It was the first horror film of Rajinikanth. The movie was a hit at the box office.
title: Aayiram Jenmangal

abstract: Naan Potta Savaal (The challenge I took) is 1980 a Tamil film, directed by Puratchidasan. The cowboy style movie did not fare well at the box office and was a failure. It was released into Telugu as Ethe Naasaval. The film is released on 7 August 1980 and the Telegu version on 15 June 1984.
title: Naan Potta Savaal

abstract: Ellam Un Kairasi is a Tamil-language film directed by [[M. A. Thirumugam|M. A. Thirumugam]] and featured Rajinikanth in the lead role.
title: Ellam Un Kairasi

abstract: Thudikkum Karangal () is a Tamil film directed by C. V. Sridhar. The movie was average at the box office. The film's soundtrack was composed by [[S. P. Balasubrahmanyam|S. P. Balasubrahmanyam]], who made his debut as composer with this film in [[Tamil|Tamil language]] language.
title: Thudikkum Karangal

abstract: The film idea was suggested by Manoj Kumar, who asked Khosla to accompany him for a show of [[Deedar|Deedar (1951 film)]] (1951), directed by [[Nitin Bose|Nitin Bose]], which was having a rerun in local theatres. Thereafter, the story of Do Badan was written after reworking its story line and the screenplay was written by G.R. Kamat.
title: Do Badan

abstract: Immaan Dharam (Honesty and Religion) is a [[1977|Bollywood films of 1977]] [[Bollywood|Bollywood]] film, written by [[Salim-Javed|Salim-Javed]] ([[Salim Khan|Salim Khan]] and [[Javed Akhtar|Javed Akhtar]]), directed by Desh Mukherjee and produced by Premji. The film stars [[Sanjeev Kumar|Sanjeev Kumar (actor)]], [[Amitabh Bachchan|Amitabh Bachchan]], [[Shashi Kapoor|Shashi Kapoor]] and [[Rekha|Rekha]]. The music is by [[Laxmikant Pyarelal|Laxmikant Pyarelal]].
title: Immaan Dharam

abstract: Raja Jani () is a [[1972|List of Bollywood films of 1972]] [[Bollywood|Bollywood]] film, produced by Madan Mohla, directed by Mohan Segal, and written by [[S. Ali Raza|S. Ali Raza]]. The film stars [[Dharmendra|Dharmendra]], [[Hema Malini|Hema Malini]], [[Premnath|Premnath]], [[Prem Chopra|Prem Chopra]], [[Johnny Walker|Johnny Walker (actor)]], Sajjan, [[Bindu|Bindu (actress)]] and [[Helen|Helen Jairag Richardson]]. The music is by [[Laxmikant–Pyarelal|Laxmikant–Pyarelal]]. It was the fourth highest-grossing film of the year, and was remade in [[Tamil|Tamil language]] as [[Adutha Varisu|Adutha Varisu]].
title: Raja Jani

abstract: Farishtay (English: Angels) is a [[1991|Bollywood films of 1991]] [[Hindi|Hindi]] film directed by [[Anil Sharma|Anil Sharma]]. The movie features [[Dharmendra|Dharmendra]], [[Vinod Khanna|Vinod Khanna]] and [[Rajinikanth|Rajinikanth]] in lead roles.
title: Farishtay

abstract: Asli Naqli is a [[1986|Bollywood films of 1986]] Hindi film directed by Sudarsan Nag. It stars [[Shatrughan Sinha|Shatrughan Sinha]] and [[Rajinikanth|Rajinikanth]] in the lead roles with [[Anita Raj|Anita Raj]] and [[Raadhika|Raadhika]] playing their female leads respectively. It was a box office hit. The movie was dubbed in Tamil as Thaayin Meedhu Sabatham.
title: Asli Naqli

abstract: Pop Gear (U.S. title: Go Go Mania) is a British music [[revue film|Revue#Film revues]], directed by Frederic Goode, which was released in 1965. It contains live concert footage of [[the Beatles|the Beatles]], and [[lip-synch|lip-synched]] films of some of the [[British Invasion|British Invasion]] bands, including [[the Animals|the Animals]], [[Herman's Hermits|Herman's Hermits]], [[the Nashville Teens|the Nashville Teens]], [[Peter and Gordon|Peter and Gordon]], [[Matt Monro|Matt Monro]], [[Billy J. Kramer and the Dakotas|Billy J. Kramer and the Dakotas]], [[the Honeycombs|the Honeycombs]], [[the Rockin' Berries|the Rockin' Berries]], and the [[Spencer Davis Group|Spencer Davis Group]]. Each segment is introduced by [[Jimmy Savile|Jimmy Savile]], who at the time was the host of [[Top of the Pops|Top of the Pops]] on the BBC. The material by the Beatles was lifted from a newsreel short The Beatles Come to Town (1963). The film was released sometime between January and April 1965, the footage having been filmed in December 1964.
title: Pop Gear

abstract: Super High Me documents Benson avoiding cannabis for a cleansing period and then smoking and otherwise consuming cannabis every day for 30 days in a row. Benson says that Super High Me is "Super Size Me with cannabis instead of [[McDonald's|McDonald's]]". The film also includes interviews with marijuana activists, [[dispensary|dispensary]] owners, politicians and patients who are part of the [[medical cannabis|medical cannabis]] movement. The DVD was released on April 20, 2008.
title: Super High Me

abstract: Khudgarz ([[English|English language]]: Selfish) is a [[1987|Bollywood films of 1987]] [[Bollywood|Bollywood]] [[drama film|drama film]], produced and directed by [[Rakesh Roshan|Rakesh Roshan]] under the Film Kraft banner. It stars [[Jeetendra|Jeetendra]], [[Shatrughan Sinha|Shatrughan Sinha]], [[Govinda|Govinda (actor)]], [[Bhanupriya|Bhanupriya]], [[Amrita Singh|Amrita Singh]], [[Neelam Kothari|Neelam Kothari]] in the lead roles and music composed by [[Rajesh Roshan|Rajesh Roshan]]. The film marks the directorial debut of actor [[Rakesh Roshan|Rakesh Roshan]]. The movie was based on [[Jeffrey Archer|Jeffrey Archer]]'s novel [[Kane and Abel|Kane and Abel (novel)]].
title: Khudgarz

abstract: Waah! Tera Kya Kehna ([[English|English language]]: Wow! You're Amazing) is a 2002 [[Bollywood|Bollywood]] [[comedy film|comedy film]] directed by [[Manoj Agrawal|Manoj Agrawal]] starring [[Govinda|Govinda (actor)]] and [[Raveena Tandon|Raveena Tandon]].
title: Waah! Tera Kya Kehna

abstract: Duyung (translation: Mermaid) is a [[Malaysia|Malaysian]] fantasy comedy film that was released on 6 March 2008. The film is directed by A. Razak Mohaideen and produced by [[KRU Films|KRU Films]] (now known as KRU Studios) in association with Grand Brilliance Sdn Bhd and Line Clear Motion Pictures. It stars [[Saiful Apek|Saiful Apek]] as a kind-hearted man who encounters a mermaid, portrayed by [[Maya Karin|Maya Karin]].
title: Duyung

abstract: Nirakkoottu ([[Malayalam|Malayalam]]: നിറക്കൂട്ട്‌) is a 1985 Indian [[Malayalam|Malayalam film]]-language film directed by [[Joshy|Joshy]], written by [[Dennis Joseph|Dennis Joseph]], and starring [[Mammootty|Mammootty]], [[Sumalatha|Sumalatha]], [[Urvashi|Urvashi (actress)]], [[Lizy|Lizy (actress)]], [[Babu Namboothiri|Babu Namboothiri]] and [[Jose Prakash|Jose Prakash]]. The music was composed by [[Shyam|Shyam (composer)]]. The story follows journalist Sasikala Varghese's (Urvashi) investigation with millionaire Ravi Varma (Mammootty), who is sentenced to death for the murder of his wife Mercy (Sumalatha). [[K. S. Chithra|K. S. Chithra]] won the [[Kerala State Film Award for Best Singer|Kerala State Film Award for Best Singer]] for the song "Poomaname" (along with songs in other films that year) and Mammootty won a [[Special Jury Award|Kerala State Film Award – Special Jury Award]] for his role. The film won the [[Filmfare Award for Best Film - Malayalam|Filmfare Award for Best Film - Malayalam]].
title: Nirakkoottu

abstract: Home Delivery: Aapko... Ghar Tak (English: Home Delivery: At your house) is a 2005 [[Bollywood|Bollywood]] film starring [[Vivek Oberoi|Vivek Oberoi]], [[Ayesha Takia|Ayesha Takia]], [[Mahima Chaudhry|Mahima Chaudhry]], and [[Boman Irani|Boman Irani]] in the lead roles. The film also stars [[Abhishek Bachchan|Abhishek Bachchan]] and [[Riteish Deshmukh|Riteish Deshmukh]] in cameos. It is written and directed by [[Sujoy Ghosh|Sujoy Ghosh]] and produced by Shabbir Boxwalla.
title: Home Delivery

abstract: Perils of the Royal Mounted (1942) was the 18th [[serial|Serial (film)]] released by [[Columbia Pictures|Columbia Pictures]]. It starred Robert Kellard (aka Robert Stevens) as the hero, Sgt. Mack MacLane of the Royal Mounties, and Kenneth MacDonald as Mort Ramsome, the head villain. It also co-starred Nell O'Day, Iron Eyes Cody, Kermit Maynard and I. Stanford Jolley.
title: Perils of the Royal Mounted

abstract: Sivagangai Seemai () is a 1959 [[Tamil-language|Tamil language]] [[historical drama|Historical period drama]] film directed by [[K. Shankar|K. Shankar]]. This was [[Kannadasan|Kannadasan]]’s second home production and he wrote the script and lyrics for the movie. It is based on the life of Maruthu Brothers. The movie's cast is [[S. S. Rajendran|S. S. Rajendran]], [[S. Varalakshmi|S. Varalakshmi]], [[Kamala Lakshmanan|Kumari Kamala]] and [[M. N. Rajam|M. N. Rajam]] in lead roles.
title: Sivagangai Seemai

abstract: Waltzing Regitze, also known as Memories of a Marriage, ([[Original title|Danish language]]: Dansen med Regitze) is a 1989 Danish [[drama film|drama film]] directed by [[Kaspar Rostrup|Kaspar Rostrup]]. Based upon a popular Danish novel by Martha Christensen, the film is an unsentimental portrait of the history and changes of a middle-aged couple's marriage, told through flashbacks during a summer party. The film stars [[Ghita Nørby|Ghita Nørby]] and [[Frits Helmuth|Frits Helmuth]]. Waltzing Regitze was nominated for the [[Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film|Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film]]. In 1990, it won the [[Robert Award|Robert Award]] for Film of the Year and swept the [[Bodil Awards|Bodil Awards]], winning [[Best Danish Film|Bodil Award for Best Danish Film]] as well as all four of acting categories.
title: Waltzing Regitze

abstract: Hum Aapke Dil Mein Rehte Hain () is a [[1999|Bollywood films of 1999]] Indian [[Hindi-language|Hindi-language]] [[romantic drama film|romantic drama film]] starring [[Anil Kapoor|Anil Kapoor]], [[Kajol|Kajol]], [[Anupam Kher|Anupam Kher]] and [[Shakti Kapoor|Shakti Kapoor]]. Kajol was nominated for a [[Filmfare Best Actress Award|Filmfare Best Actress Award]]. It is a remake of the [[Telugu|Telugu language]] film [[Pavithra Bandham|Pavithra Bandham]] starring [[Venkatesh|Daggubati Venkatesh]] and [[Soundarya|Soundarya]]. The film also was the 5th highest Indian grossing film of the year. It was declared Superhit by [[Box Office India|Box Office India]].
title: Hum Aapke Dil Mein Rehte Hain

abstract: On February 16, 2013, it was announced that the touring portion of Cinematic Titanic was going on an indefinite hiatus. According to an [[email|email]] sent out to members of the site, due to "5 people living in 5 different cities with different lives and projects, it has become increasingly difficult to coordinate our schedules and give Cinematic Titanic the attention it requires to keep growing as a creative enterprise and a business." The final tour began on September 23, 2013.
title: Cinematic Titanic

abstract: Silsila Hai Pyar Ka is a [[1999|Bollywood films of 1999]] [[Hindi|Hindi]] [[romantic|Romance film]] movie directed by [[Shrabani Deodhar|Shrabani Deodhar]] and starring [[Karisma Kapoor|Karisma Kapoor]], [[Chandrachur Singh|Chandrachur Singh]] and [[Danny Denzongpa|Danny Denzongpa]]. The cast includes [[Shakti Kapoor|Shakti Kapoor]], [[Alok Nath|Alok Nath]], [[Johnny Lever|Johnny Lever]], [[Aruna Irani|Aruna Irani]], [[Tiku Talsania|Tiku Talsania]], [[Dina Pathak|Dina Pathak]], Nilam Singh, Mishkaa Khanna and Ali Haider.
title: Silsila Hai Pyar Ka

abstract: Husband for Hire is a 2008 [[comedy|comedy]] [[television film|television film]] that premiered on [[Oxygen Network|Oxygen (TV network)]] on January 24, 2008. Husband for Hire was written and directed by Kris Isacsson, and it starred [[Nadine Velazquez|Nadine Velazquez]], [[Tempestt Bledsoe|Tempestt Bledsoe]], [[Mark Consuelos|Mark Consuelos]], [[Erik Estrada|Erik Estrada]] and [[Mario López|Mario López]].
title: Husband for Hire

abstract: Khuddar is a [[1994|Bollywood films of 1994]] [[Hindi|Hindi]] [[movie|movie]] directed by Iqbal Durrani and starring [[Govinda|Govinda (actor)]], [[Karishma Kapoor|Karishma Kapoor]] and [[Kader Khan|Kader Khan]]. Other cast includes [[Shakti Kapoor|Shakti Kapoor]], [[Shreeram Lagoo|Shreeram Lagoo]], Anjana Mumtaz, Raju Shrestha, Mahesh Anand, Vikas Anand, Navneet Nishaan and Anil Dhawan. It includes the controversial number "Sexy Sexy Mujhe Log Bole", which was censored to "Baby Baby Mujhe Log Bole". It is a remake of the Tamil film [[Walter Vetrivel|Walter Vetrivel]], starring [[Sathyaraj|Sathyaraj]]. Dialogues of this movie became very popular and therefore audio cassettes of dialogues were released.
title: Khuddar

abstract: Baaz: A Bird in Danger is 2003 [[Hindi|Hindi]] psychological [[thriller film|thriller film]] directed by Tinnu Verma and starring [[Sunil Shetty|Sunil Shetty]] in negative role as a psycho cop, [[Karisma Kapoor|Karisma Kapoor]], [[Jackie Shroff|Jackie Shroff]]. Other cast members include [[Dino Morea|Dino Morea]], [[Preeti Jhangiani|Preeti Jhangiani]] [[Aditi Gowitrikar|Aditi Gowitrikar]] and [[Suhasini Mulay|Suhasini Mulay]].
title: Baaz: A Bird in Danger

abstract: Gopi Kishan is [[1994|Bollywood films of 1994]] Indian [[Hindi|Hindi]] action comedy movie directed by Mukesh Duggal starring [[Sunil Shetty|Sunil Shetty]] in a double role, supported by [[Shilpa Shirodkar|Shilpa Shirodkar]] and [[Karishma Kapoor|Karishma Kapoor]]. Other cast includes [[Suresh Oberoi|Suresh Oberoi]], [[Aruna Irani|Aruna Irani]], Mohan Joshi, [[Shammi|Shammi (actress)]], Satyendra Kagoor and Mushtaq Khan. The film is a remake of [[K. Bhagyaraj|K. Bhagyaraj]]'s hit Tamil film [[Avasara Police 100|Avasara Police 100]].
title: Gopi Kishan

abstract: The Ex-Mrs. Bradford is a 1936 American [[comedy-mystery|List of comedy-mystery films]] film. [[William Powell|William Powell]] and [[Jean Arthur|Jean Arthur]] star as a divorced couple who investigate a murder at a racetrack. This was the last film directed by [[Stephen Roberts|Stephen Roberts (director)]] before his untimely death from a heart attack.
title: The Ex-Mrs. Bradford

abstract: When Willie Comes Marching Home is a 1950 [[World War II|World War II]] [[comedy film|comedy film]] directed by [[John Ford|John Ford]] and starring [[Dan Dailey|Dan Dailey]] and [[Corinne Calvet|Corinne Calvet]]. It is based on the 1945 [[short story|short story]] When Leo Comes Marching Home by [[Sy Gomberg|Sy Gomberg]]. The film won the [[Golden Leopard|Golden Leopard]] at the [[Locarno International Film Festival|Locarno International Film Festival]].[[Sy Gomberg|Sy Gomberg]] also received an Oscar nomination for [[Best Motion Picture Story|Best Motion Picture Story]] at the [[23rd Academy Awards|23rd Academy Awards]] in 1951 but was edged out for the award by [[Edna Anhalt|Edna Anhalt]] and [[Edward Anhalt|Edward Anhalt]] for [[Panic in the Streets|Panic in the Streets (1950 film)]].
title: When Willie Comes Marching Home

abstract: is a 2006 Japanese-American [[war film|war film]] directed and co-produced by [[Clint Eastwood|Clint Eastwood]], starring [[Ken Watanabe|Ken Watanabe]] and [[Kazunari Ninomiya|Kazunari Ninomiya]]. The film portrays the [[Battle of Iwo Jima|Battle of Iwo Jima]] from the perspective of the [[Japanese|Empire of Japan]] [[soldiers|Imperial Japanese Army]] and is a companion piece to Eastwood's [[Flags of Our Fathers|Flags of Our Fathers (film)]], which depicts the same battle from the American viewpoint; the two films were shot back to back. Letters from Iwo Jima is almost entirely in [[Japanese|Japanese language]], although it was produced by American companies [[DreamWorks|DreamWorks]], [[Malpaso Productions|Malpaso Productions]], and [[Amblin Entertainment|Amblin Entertainment]]. After Flags of Our Fathers underperformed at the box office, [[Paramount Pictures|Paramount Pictures]] swapped the United States distribution rights to Warner Bros., who had the international rights.The film was released in [[Japan|Japan]] on December 9, 2006 and received a limited release in the [[United States|United States]] on December 20, 2006 in order to be eligible for consideration for the [[79th Academy Awards|79th Academy Awards]]. It was subsequently released in more areas of the U.S. on January 12, 2007, and was released in most states on January 19. An English-dubbed version of the film premiered on April 7, 2008. Upon release, the film received critical acclaim and did slightly better at the box office than its companion.
title: Letters from Iwo Jima

abstract: Mio in the Land of Faraway was co-produced by companies from [[Sweden|Sweden]], [[Norway|Norway]] and the [[Soviet Union|Soviet Union]] with a budget of about fifty million [[Swedish kronor|Swedish krona]], making it the most expensive film adaptation of an Astrid Lindgren book during her lifetime. It featured an international cast consisting largely of [[British|United Kingdom]], [[Russia|Russian]] and [[Scandinavia|Scandinavian]] actors, while its filming locations included Stockholm, [[Moscow|Moscow]], [[Crimea|Crimea]], and [[Scotland|Scotland]]. The film was shot in [[English|English language]] and subsequently dubbed in Swedish and Russian. Its special effects were created by [[Derek Meddings|Derek Meddings]]. The film's theme song, "[[Mio My Mio|Mio My Mio (song)]]", was composed by two former [[ABBA|ABBA]] members, [[Benny Andersson|Benny Andersson]] and [[Björn Ulvaeus|Björn Ulvaeus]], and performed by the Swedish band [[Gemini|Gemini (Swedish band)]].
title: Mio in the Land of Faraway

abstract: The music of the film Saranga is by musician Zulfiqar Ali. Film song lyrics are penned by Saeed Gillani, and the singers are [[Noor Jehan|Noor Jehan]] and [[Masood Rana|Masood Rana]]
title: Saranga

abstract: Totally Spies! The Movie (known as Totally Spies! Le film in France) is a 2009 French/Canadian [[animated|Traditional animation]] [[spy|Spy film]] [[action film|action film]]. The film is an adaptation of the [[Totally Spies!|Totally Spies!]] television series, about a trio of teenagers from Beverly Hills who become spies. The film covers [[how the girls first met|Origin story]]. In 2010, the film was broadcast in the United States and Canada on Cartoon Network and Teletoon respectively.
title: Totally Spies! The Movie

abstract: Papa Kehte Hain is a [[1996|Bollywood films of 1996]] Indian [[Hindi|Hindi]] [[romance film|romance film]] directed by [[Mahesh Bhatt|Mahesh Bhatt]]. The film starred [[Jugal Hansraj|Jugal Hansraj]] and [[Mayuri Kango|Mayuri Kango]] in lead roles, with [[Tiku Talsania|Tiku Talsania]], [[Anupam Kher|Anupam Kher]], [[Alok Nath|Alok Nath]], Suhasini Mule and Reema Lagoo in supporting roles.
title: Papa Kehte Hai

abstract: Dirty Pair: Project Eden, known in Japan as , is a feature-length anime film based on the [[Dirty Pair|Dirty Pair]] anime series, originally released in Japan on November 28, 1986. The movie was originally licensed in [[North America|North America]] in 1994 by [[Streamline Pictures|Streamline Pictures]], but was later redubbed and released on DVD on November 9, 2003 by [[ADV Films|ADV Films]]. The Streamline version was directed by [[Carl Macek|Carl Macek]].
title: Dirty Pair: Project Eden

abstract: Thanthonni () is a 2010 [[Malayalam|Malayalam language]]-language film released on 19 March 2010. The film was directed by [[George Varghese|George Varghese (director)]], a former assistant to [[Joshy|Joshy]]. Thanthonni stars [[Prithviraj|Prithviraj Sukumaran]] and [[Sheela|Sheela (Tamil actress)]] in the lead roles.
title: Thanthonni

abstract: Vasanthiyum Lakshmiyum Pinne Njaanum was later remade to [[Tamil|Tamil language]] as [[Kasi|Kasi (film)]] and in [[Telugu|Telugu language]] as [[Seenu Vasanthi Lakshmi|Seenu Vasanthi Lakshmi]] and in Kannada as [[Namma Preethiya Ramu|Namma Preethiya Ramu]].
title: Vasanthiyum Lakshmiyum Pinne Njaanum

abstract: Hello Madras Girl is a [[1983|1983 in film]] [[Malayalam-language|Cinema of Kerala]] [[Indian|Cinema of India]] [[feature film|feature film]] [[directed|Film director]] by J. Williams, starring [[Shankar|Shankar (actor)]], [[Rajkumar Sethupathi|Rajkumar Sethupathi]], [[Madhavi|Madhavi (actress)]] and [[Poornima Jayaram|Poornima Jayaram]]. The film also stars [[Mohanlal|Mohanlal]] in an important role.
title: Hello Madras Girl

abstract: Sawan Ki Ghata () is a [[1966|Bollywood films of 1966]] [[Bollywood|Bollywood]] film produced and directed by [[Shakti Samanta|Shakti Samanta]]. [[Manoj Kumar|Manoj Kumar]], [[Sharmila Tagore|Sharmila Tagore]], [[Mumtaz|Mumtaz (actress)]], [[Pran|Pran (actor)]] and [[Madan Puri|Madan Puri]] are the film's main cast.
title: Sawan Ki Ghata

abstract: Johnny English Reborn is a 2011 [[action comedy|action comedy]] film directed by [[Oliver Parker|Oliver Parker]]. It is the sequel to [[Johnny English|Johnny English]] (2003) and the second instalment in the [[Johnny English series|Johnny English (film series)]]. The film stars [[Rowan Atkinson|Rowan Atkinson]], reprising his role as the title character.
title: Johnny English Reborn

abstract: Marakkillorikkalum (English: Will remember always) is a 1983 Malayalam film co-written and directed by [[Fazil|Fazil (director)]] starring [[Prem Nazir|Prem Nazir]], [[Shankar|Shankar (actor)]] and [[Mohanlal|Mohanlal]] in lead roles. [[Mammootty|Mammootty]] makes a cameo appearance in the film.The film had musical score by [[Zero Babu|Zero Babu]].
title: Marakkillorikkalum

abstract: Lupo! is a 1970 film directed by [[Menahem Golan|Menahem Golan]]. The script was co-written by Golan and Ken Globus.
title: Lupo!

abstract: Mazha tells the love story of Bhadra ([[Samyuktha Varma|Samyuktha Varma]]) and her music teacher Sastrigal ([[Biju Menon|Biju Menon]]). The film begins with teenager Bhadra coming to learn music under Sastrigal and getting infatuated with him and his singing in Sivapuram. The story describes the teenager Bhadra's characters and behavior in a nice mood. At her teenage time the madhura is a beautiful village having a lot of Tamil Brahmins, the shasthrikal is also one of them. Bhadhra falls in love with her music teacher (shasthrikal) because of her teenage nature and curiosity towards his music.
title: Mazha

abstract: The film won the most major awards in the film-awarding bodies, including 12 awards in the 28th Manila Film Festival in 2002. It was named Best Picture, Best Actor (for [[Eddie Garcia|Eddie Garcia]]), Best Actress (for [[Ara Mina|Ara Mina]]), Best Supporting Actress (for [[Kris Aquino|Kris Aquino]]) and Best Director (for [[Joel Lamangan|Joel Lamangan]]). Mano Po was among the top-grossing films in time for the Metro Manila Filmfest.
title: Mano Po

abstract: Biutiful is a 2010 [[drama film|drama film]] directed, produced and co-written by [[Alejandro González Iñárritu|Alejandro González Iñárritu]] and starring [[Javier Bardem|Javier Bardem]]. This film was González Iñárritu's first feature since [[Babel|Babel (film)]] (2006) and fourth overall, and his first film in his native [[Spanish language|Spanish language]] since his debut feature [[Amores perros|Amores perros]] (2000).
title: Biutiful

abstract: Kerala Cafe is a 2009 [[Malayalam|Malayalam film]] [[anthology film|anthology film]] produced by [[Ranjith|Ranjith (director)]] and directed by a team of ten directors including [[Lal Jose|Lal Jose]], [[Shaji Kailas|Shaji Kailas]], [[Anwar Rasheed|Anwar Rasheed]], [[Shyamaprasad|Shyamaprasad]], [[B. Unnikrishnan|B. Unnikrishnan]], [[Revathy|Revathy]], [[Anjali Menon|Anjali Menon]], [[M. Padmakumar|M. Padmakumar]], Shankar Ramakrishnan, and [[Uday Ananthan|Uday Ananthan]]. For the first time in Malayalam cinema, one film was conceived by a team of ten directors. Ten cinematographers, musicians, editors, art directors and almost all the top Malayalam film actors joined this unique venture. The cast includes [[Mammootty|Mammootty]], [[Rahman|Rahman (actor)]], [[Prithviraj|Prithviraj Sukumaran]], [[Suresh Gopi|Suresh Gopi]], [[Dileep|Dileep]], [[Jayasurya|Jayasurya]], [[Fahadh Faasil|Fahadh Faasil]], [[Navya Nair|Navya Nair]], [[Nithya Menon|Nithya Menon]], and others.
title: Kerala Cafe

abstract: Dalaal is the story of the illiterate Bhola Nath, who escorts young women to meet with their brothers. Bhola is enthusiastic and works diligently to earn the respect of everyone around him; but one day, during the course of his duties, he meets a beautiful woman named Roopali, who makes him understand the true nature of his job: that of a pimp. Whether Bhola will realize his mistake and redeem himself forms the climax.
title: Dalaal

abstract: After producing [[The Girl Who Leapt Through Time|The Girl Who Leapt Through Time (2006 film)]], Madhouse was asked to produce something new. Hosoda and writer [[Satoko Okudera|Satoko Okudera]], created a story about a social network and a stranger's connection with strange family. The real-life city of Ueda, was chosen as the setting for Summer Wars, as part of the territory was once governed by the [[Sanada clan|Sanada clan]] and was close to Hosoda's birthplace in Toyama. Hosoda used the clan as the basis for the Jinnouchi family after visiting his then-fiancé's home in Ueda.
title: Summer Wars

abstract: Desatanakkili Karayarilla () is a 1986 [[Malayalam film|Malayalam film]] written and directed by [[Padmarajan|Padmarajan]]. It stars [[Mohanlal|Mohanlal]], [[Karthika|Karthika (actress)]], [[Shari|Shari (actress)]] and [[Urvashi|Urvashi (actress)]] in pivotal roles. The film tells the story of two school girls who eloped while on a school trip. It was critically well acclaimed, being one of the first Indian films that talked about [[womance|womance]].
title: Desatanakkili Karayarilla

abstract: Nirmalyam (, meaning "Remains" or "Yesterday's Offerings") is a 1973 [[Malayalam film|Malayalam film]] written and directed by [[M. T. Vasudevan Nair|M. T. Vasudevan Nair]], and starring [[P. J. Antony|P. J. Antony]] and Shanta Devi. Malayalam actor [[P. J. Antony|P. J. Antony]] won the [[National Film Award for Best Actor|National Film Award for Best Actor]] in 1974 for his performance as a velichappadu (an [[oracle|oracle]] or a medium between the Goddess and the worshipper in a [[Hindu|Hindu]] temple) in this movie. The film received the [[National Film Award for Best Feature Film|National Film Award for Best Feature Film]] and [[Kerala State Film Award for Best Film|Kerala State Film Award for Best Film]] in 1974. It is one of the classics in Malayalam cinema.
title: Nirmalyam

abstract: Veerathirumagan is a 1962 Tamil-language [[Ruritanian romance|Ruritanian romance]] film, produced by [[AVM Productions|AVM Productions]], and directed by [[A. C. Tirulokchandar|A. C. Tirulokchandar]]. This was the debut film for A. C. Thirulokachandar.
title: Veerathirumagan

abstract: Vennira Aadai () is a 1965 [[Tamil-language|Tamil language]] [[romance film|romance film]], directed by [[C. V. Sridhar|C. V. Sridhar]]. The film features [[Jayalalithaa|Jayalalithaa]], [[Sreekanth|Sreekanth]], [[Nirmala|Vennira Aadai Nirmala]] and [[Major Sundarrajan|Major Sundarrajan]] in lead roles. The film, produced by Chithralaya Pictures had musical score by [[Viswanathan–Ramamoorthy|Viswanathan–Ramamoorthy]]. The film was remade in Telugu as [[Sharada|Sharada (1973 film)]] (1973), in Hindi as [[Dulhan|Dulhan (1975 film)]] (1975) and in Kannada as Deepa (1977).
title: Vennira Aadai

abstract: Vartha () is a [[1986|Malayalam films of 1986]] [[Indian|Cinema of India]] [[Malayalam language|Malayalam language]] film, directed by [[IV Sasi|IV Sasi]] and produced by PV Gangadharan. The film stars [[Mammootty|Mammootty]], [[Mohanlal|Mohanlal]], [[Venu Nagavally|Venu Nagavally]] and [[Prathapachandran|Prathapachandran]] in lead roles. The film had musical score by [[A. T. Ummer|A. T. Ummer]]. The film was remade in Tamil as [[Palaivana Rojakkal|Palaivana Rojakkal]] with [[Sathyaraj|Sathyaraj]] and in Hindi as [[Jai Shiv Shankar|Jai Shiv Shankar]] with [[Rajesh Khanna|Rajesh Khanna]].
title: Vartha

abstract: Kiladi Jodi () is 1978 Indian [[Kannada language|Kannada language]] film directed by [[S. V. Rajendra Singh Babu|Rajendra Singh Babu]] that stars [[Vishnuvardhan|Vishnuvardhan (actor)]], [[Srinath|Srinath]] and [[Lakshmi|Lakshmi (actress)]] in lead roles.
title: Kiladi Jodi

abstract: The Girl Who Had Everything is a 1953 American [[romantic drama film|romance film]] directed by [[Richard Thorpe|Richard Thorpe]] and produced by Armande Deutsch for [[Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer|Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer]]. The film features [[William Powell|William Powell]] in his last MGM feature and one of his last film roles before retirement.
title: The Girl Who Had Everything

abstract: Jaali Note (English: Fake Currency) is a [[1960|Bollywood films of 1960]] [[Hindi film|Hindi film]] directed by [[Shakti Samanta|Shakti Samanta]], based on the theme of [[counterfeit money|counterfeit money]]. It stars [[Dev Anand|Dev Anand]] along with [[Madhubala|Madhubala]], [[Om Prakash|Om Prakash]], [[Madan Puri|Madan Puri]], and [[Helen|Helen Jairag Richardson]].
title: Jaali Note

abstract: Bhartrahari is a [[Bollywood|Bollywood]] [[film|film]]. It was released in [[1944|Bollywood films of 1944]]. The film was directed by [[Chaturbhuj Doshi|Chaturbhuj Doshi]] for Navin Pictures and produced by P. B. Zaveri. The music was composed by [[Khemchand Prakash|Khemchand Prakash]] and the lyricist was Pandit Indra Chandra. The cast included [[Surendra|Surendra (actor)]], [[Mumtaz Shanti|Mumtaz Shanti]], [[Jehanara Kajjan|Jehanara Kajjan]], [[Aroon|Arun Kumar Ahuja]], [[Sulochana Chatterji|Sulochana Chatterji]] and [[Yashwant Dave|Yashwant Dave]].
title: Bhartrahari

abstract: Mr. and Mrs. Gambler is a 2012 Hong Kong [[romantic comedy|romantic comedy]] film written, produced and directed by [[Wong Jing|Wong Jing]] and starring [[Chapman To|Chapman To]] and [[Fiona Sit|Fiona Sit]].
title: Mr. and Mrs. Gambler

abstract: Five Dances is a 2013 film written and directed by [[Alan Brown|Alan Brown (filmmaker)]] and starring [[Ryan Steele|Ryan Steele (actor)]], Reed Luplau, Catherine Miller, Kimiye Corwin, and Luke Murphy.
title: Five Dances

abstract: Young & Beautiful () is a 2013 French [[erotic|Erotic film]] [[drama film|drama film]] directed by [[François Ozon|François Ozon]] and produced by Eric and [[Nicolas Altmayer|Nicolas Altmayer]]. The film stars [[Marine Vacth|Marine Vacth]] in the leading role of Isabelle, a [[teenage prostitute|Prostitution of children]], and features supporting performances by [[Johan Leysen|Johan Leysen]], [[Géraldine Pailhas|Géraldine Pailhas]], [[Frédéric Pierrot|Frédéric Pierrot]], and [[Charlotte Rampling|Charlotte Rampling]]. The film was nominated for the [[Palme d'Or|Palme d'Or]] at the [[2013 Cannes Film Festival|2013 Cannes Film Festival]], and received praise from the film critics. It was shown at the [[2013 Toronto International Film Festival|2013 Toronto International Film Festival]].
title: Young & Beautiful

abstract: Prathyartha is a 1999 [[Kannada|Kannada cinema]] suspense-thriller film directed by [[Sunil Kumar Desai|Sunil Kumar Desai]] featuring [[Ramesh Aravind|Ramesh Aravind]], [[Raghuvaran|Raghuvaran]], [[Girish Karnad|Girish Karnad]] and [[Sudeep|Sudeep]] in the lead roles. The film features background score and soundtrack composed by [[Ilaiyaraaja|Ilaiyaraaja]]. The concept of this movie is based on the 1995 movie [[Nick of Time|Nick of Time (film)]].
title: Prathyartha

abstract: Biyer Phool is a 1996 Indian Bengali romantic comedy film, directed by [[Ram Mukherjee|Ram Mukherjee]], starring [[Prosenjit Chatterjee|Prosenjit Chatterjee]], [[Rani Mukerji|Rani Mukerji]], [[Indrani Haldar|Indrani Haldar]] and [[Sabyasachi Chakraborty|Sabyasachi Chakraborty]] in the lead roles. It marks the debut of Rani Mukerji, daughter of director, who went to become a leading Bollywood actress.
title: Biyer Phool

abstract: The Story of Luke is a 2012 American [[comedy-drama|comedy-drama]] film written and directed by [[Alonso Mayo|Alonso Mayo]]. It is Mayo's [[first feature-length film|List of directorial debuts]] and tells the story of Luke, a young man with [[autism|autism]] who embarks on a quest for a job and a girlfriend. It stars [[Lou Taylor Pucci|Lou Taylor Pucci]], [[Seth Green|Seth Green]], [[Cary Elwes|Cary Elwes]] and [[Kristin Bauer|Kristin Bauer]].
title: The Story of Luke

abstract: The Lunchbox is a 2013 Indian [[epistolary|wiktionary:epistolary]] romantic film written and directed by [[Ritesh Batra|Ritesh Batra]], and produced by [[Guneet Monga|Guneet Monga]], [[Anurag Kashyap|Anurag Kashyap]], and Arun Rangachari. The film was jointly produced by various studios including [[DAR motion pictures|DAR motion pictures]], [[UTV Motion Pictures|UTV Motion Pictures]], [[Dharma Productions|Dharma Productions]], [[Sikhya Entertainment|Sikhya Entertainment]], [[NFDC|National Film Development Corporation of India]] (India), ROH Films (Germany), ASAP Films (France), and the Cine Mosaic (United States). It stars [[Irrfan Khan|Irrfan Khan]], [[Nimrat Kaur|Nimrat Kaur]] and [[Nawazuddin Siddiqui|Nawazuddin Siddiqui]] in lead roles. The film was screened at [[International Critics' Week|2013 Cannes Film Festival#International Critics' Week]] at the [[2013 Cannes Film Festival|2013 Cannes Film Festival]], and later won the Critics Week Viewers Choice Award also known as Grand Rail d'Or. It was shown at the [[2013 Toronto International Film Festival|2013 Toronto International Film Festival]]. The film was released in India on 20 September 2013.
title: The Lunchbox

abstract: Monsoon Shootout is a 2017 [[Bollywood|Bollywood]] [[neo-noir|neo-noir]] [[action thriller|action thriller]] film written and directed by [[Amit Kumar|Amit Kumar]] and produced by [[Guneet Monga|Guneet Monga]], Trevor Ingma, Martijn de Grunt, and co-produced by [[Anurag Kashyap|Anurag Kashyap]], and Vivek Rangachari, starring [[Vijay Varma|Vijay Varma]], [[Geetanjali Thapa|Geetanjali Thapa]], [[Sreejita De|Sreejita De]], [[Nawazuddin Siddiqui|Nawazuddin Siddiqui]] and [[Tannishtha Chatterjee|Tannishtha Chatterjee]] in the lead roles. The film received positive reviews at the [[2013 Cannes Film Festival|2013 Cannes Film Festival]] in the Official Midnight Screenings section. Belonging to the school of [[Parallel cinema|Parallel cinema]], Monsoon Shooting was released worldwide four years later on December, 15, 2017 to positive reviews.
title: Monsoon Shootout

abstract: Us Paar is a Hindi film released in 1974, starring [[Vinod Mehra|Vinod Mehra]] and [[Moushumi Chatterjee|Moushumi Chatterjee]]. Directed by [[Basu Chatterjee|Basu Chatterjee]] and music by [[Sachin Dev Burman|Sachin Dev Burman]].
title: Us Paar

abstract: Batanes: Sa Dulo Ng Walang Hanggan or more popularly known as Batanes is a 2007 drama film directed by [[Adolfo Alix, Jr.|Adolfo Alix, Jr.]] and John David Hukom. The film is a joint project by Ignite Media, Inc. and [[GMA Films|GMA Films]]. It stars [[Iza Calzado|Iza Calzado]] and Taiwanese superstar [[Ken Chu|Ken Chu]] of [[F4|F4 (band)]] (which is also from [[Meteor Garden|Meteor Garden]], playing the role of Xi Men). Batanes is the first Filipino film of Ken Chu and this is where [[Joem Bascon|Joem Bascon]] got his first award as Breakthrough Performance by an Actor given by the Golden Screen Awards.
title: Batanes: Sa Dulo Ng Walang Hanggan

abstract: A Perfect Candidate is a 1996 documentary about the [[1994 U.S. Senate race in Virginia|1994 U.S. Senate race in Virginia]] between Democrat [[Chuck Robb|Chuck Robb]] and Republican [[Oliver North|Oliver North]]. The film aired on television as part of the [[PBS|PBS]] series [[P.O.V.|POV (TV series)]] in 1997, earning the network an Emmy Award nomination.
title: A Perfect Candidate

abstract: Hooked: Muscle Women was a 2008 [[MSNBC documentary|MSNBC Documentaries]] focused on professional [[female bodybuilding|female bodybuilding]]. The primary focuses of the documentary is on two [[International Federation of BodyBuilders|International Federation of BodyBuilders]] (IFBB) pro bodybuilders, [[Colette Nelson|Colette Nelson]] and [[Kristy Hawkins|Kristy Hawkins]] and their competing in the 2008 [[Ms. International|Ms. International]]. The documentary also features [[Teresita Morales|Teresita Morales]] a World Natural Bodybuilding Federation (WNBF) pro [[natural female bodybuilder|natural bodybuilder]] who competes in the 2008 World Championships.
title: Hooked: Muscle Women

abstract: Infinitely Polar Bear is a 2014 American [[comedy-drama|comedy-drama]] film written and directed by [[Maya Forbes|Maya Forbes]], and starring [[Mark Ruffalo|Mark Ruffalo]], [[Zoe Saldana|Zoe Saldana]], Imogene Wolodarsky, and Ashley Aufderheide. The film premiered in competition at the [[30th Sundance Film Festival|2014 Sundance Film Festival]] on January 18, 2014. The film was released on June 19, 2015, by [[Sony Pictures Classics|Sony Pictures Classics]].
title: Infinitely Polar Bear

abstract: The German Doctor () is a 2013 Argentine historical drama film directed, produced, and written by [[Lucía Puenzo|Lucía Puenzo]], based on her own novel Wakolda (2011). The film stars [[Àlex Brendemühl|Àlex Brendemühl]] as Nazi [[SS|Schutzstaffel]] officer and physician [[Josef Mengele|Josef Mengele]], infamous for performing [[human experiments|Nazi human experimentation]] in the [[Auschwitz concentration camp|Auschwitz concentration camp]]. It also stars Florencia Bado, [[Natalia Oreiro|Natalia Oreiro]], [[Diego Peretti|Diego Peretti]], [[Elena Roger|Elena Roger]], and Guillermo Pfening.
title: The German Doctor

abstract: Duniyadari (Marathi: दुनियादारी) is a 2013 Marathi film directed by [[Sanjay Jadhav|Sanjay Jadhav]]. The film is about the journey of every one which eventually makes them realize the true face of life. It has been acclaimed by Marathi audience. Critical reception was positive. The film is a remake of 2005 bollywood movie [[Dosti: Friends Forever|Dosti: Friends Forever]]
title: Duniyadari

abstract: Daivathinte Swantham Cleetus tells the story of a "thug" named Cleetus (Mammootty) who is asked by a parish priest (Siddique), who does not know about his background, to play the role of Jesus Christ in a play. During the film, events in the life of Cleetus start to mirror events portrayed about Jesus' life in the Bible.
title: Daivathinte Swantham Cleetus

abstract: Spirit Warriors: The Shortcut sometimes referred to as Spirit Warriors 2 is a 2002 [[Filipino|Cinema of the Philippines]] [[fantasy|fantasy film]], [[adventure|adventure film]]-[[horror film|horror film]] and a sequel to the 2000 film [[Spirit Warriors|Spirit Warriors (film)]]. The film was written and directed by [[Chito S. Roño|Chito S. Roño]] with a screenplay by Roy Iglesias. It was distributed by [[Regal Films|Regal Films]].
title: Spirit Warriors: The Shortcut

abstract: Neerum Neruppum () is a 1971 Indian [[Tamil language|Tamil language]] [[swashbuckler film|swashbuckler film]] directed by [[Pa.Neelakandhan|P. Neelakantan]], starring [[M. G. Ramachandran|M. G. Ramachandran]] in the lead role and [[J. Jayalalitha|J. Jayalalitha]], [[R. S. Manohar|R. S. Manohar]], [[Cho Ramaswamy|Cho Ramaswamy]] among others. The storyline is based on the French novel [[The Corsican Brothers|The Corsican Brothers]] by [[Alexandre Dumas|Alexandre Dumas]]. The film was remade in Hindi as [[Gora Aur Kala|Gora Aur Kala]].
title: Neerum Neruppum

abstract: Ek Se Bhale Do is a [[1985|Bollywood films of 1985]] [[Indian|Cinema of India]] [[Bollywood|Bollywood]] film directed by [[Rajendra Singh Babu|Rajendra Singh Babu]]. It stars [[Kumar Gaurav|Kumar Gaurav]] and [[Rati Agnihotri|Rati Agnihotri]] in pivotal roles. The title "Ek Se Bhale Do" is a [[Hindi|Hindi]] phrase that translates as "two is better than one".
title: Ek Se Bhale Do

abstract: Mar Mitenge ([[English|English language]]: Bear The Death; [[Hindi|Hindi]]: मॉर मिटेंगे) is a [[1988|Bollywood films of 1988]] [[Bollywood|Bollywood]] [[Action film|Action film]], produced by Pradeep Sharma under the TUTU Films banner and directed by Kawal Sharma. It stars [[Jeetendra|Jeetendra]], [[Mithun Chakraborty|Mithun Chakraborty]], [[Madhavi|Madhavi (actress)]], [[Bhanupriya|Bhanupriya]] in the pivotal roles and music composed by [[Laxmikant-Pyarelal|Laxmikant-Pyarelal]].
title: Mar Mitenge

abstract: Sange Muzhangu () is a 1972 [[Indian|Cinema of India]] [[Tamil|Tamil cinema]] [[thriller film|thriller film]], directed by [[P. Neelakantan|P. Neelakantan]], starring [[M. G. Ramachandran|M. G. Ramachandran]] in the lead role, with [[S. A. Ashokan|S. A. Ashokan]], [[Lakshmi|Lakshmi (actress)]], [[Cho Ramaswamy|Cho Ramaswamy]], among others enacting supporting roles.
title: Sange Muzhangu

abstract: Dharam Sankat is a [[1991|Bollywood films of 1991]] [[Indian|Cinema of India]] [[Bollywood|Bollywood]] film directed by N.D. Kothari and produced by Umesh N. Kothari. It stars [[Vinod Khanna|Vinod Khanna]] and [[Amrita Singh|Amrita Singh]] in pivotal roles.
title: Dharam Sankat

abstract: Jeena Marna Tere Sang is a [[1992|Bollywood films of 1992]] [[Indian|Cinema of India]] [[Bollywood|Bollywood]] film directed by Vijay Reddy. It stars [[Sanjay Dutt|Sanjay Dutt]] and [[Raveena Tandon|Raveena Tandon]] in pivotal roles. It is a remake of the Kannada film [[Prema Parva|Prema Parva]], starring [[Murali|Murali (Tamil actor)]] and Bhavya.
title: Jeena Marna Tere Sang

abstract: Chor Aur Chaand is a [[1993|Bollywood films of 1993]] [[Indian|Cinema of India]] [[Bollywood|Bollywood]] film directed by Pavan Kaul and produced by [[Aditya Pancholi|Aditya Pancholi]]. It stars Aditya Pancholi and [[Pooja Bhatt|Pooja Bhatt]] in pivotal roles.
title: Chor Aur Chaand

abstract: Thirumbi Paar (; English: Look Back!) is a 1953 [[Tamil language|Tamil language]] film starring [[Sivaji Ganesan|Sivaji Ganesan]], [[P. V. Narasimha Bharathi|P. V. Narasimha Bharathi]], [[Pandari Bai|Pandari Bai]], [[Krishna Kumari|Krishna Kumari (actress)]] and [[Girija|Girija (actress)]] in the lead roles. Produced and directed by [[T. R. Sundaram|T. R. Sundaram]] of [[Modern Theatres|Modern Theatres]], the film was written by [[M. Karunanidhi|M. Karunanidhi]], who would later become the chief minister of Tamil Nadu. Thirumbi Paar was one of the earliest Tamil films whose dialogues were known to be a political satire on the [[Indian National Congress|Indian National Congress]], the ruling party then. Sivaji Ganesan played a negative role in the film and received wide acclaim.
title: Thirumbi Paar

abstract: Log Kya Kahenge (What Will People Think) is a 1983 [[Indian|Cinema of India]] [[Bollywood|Bollywood]] film produced and directed by [[B. R. Ishara|B. R. Ishara]]. It stars [[Shabana Azmi|Shabana Azmi]], [[Shatrughan Sinha|Shatrughan Sinha]] and [[Sanjeev Kumar|Sanjeev Kumar]] in pivotal roles and also features [[Navin Nischol|Navin Nischol]]. The title of the film, "Log Kya Kahenge", is documented as a common stigma facing women in Indian society who challenge pre-arranged marriages and are expected to behave in a certain manner. The film deals with themes of murder and adultery.
title: Log Kya Kahenge

abstract: Pop Class is a DVD album by teen heartthrob [[Sam Concepcion|Sam Concepcion]] released under [[Universal Records|Universal Records (Philippines)]]. The concept of the album is a mini-movie-musical following the tradition of [[Glee|Glee (TV series)]], [[Camp Rock|Camp Rock]] and [[High School Musical|High School Musical]].
title: Pop Class

abstract: Vivasayee ( ), is a 1967 [[Indian|Cinema of India]] [[Tamil|Tamil cinema]] film, directed by [[M. A. Thirumugam|M. A. Thirumugam]], starring [[M. G. Ramachandran|M. G. Ramachandran]] in the lead role, with [[K. R. Vijaya|K. R. Vijaya]], [[M. N. Nambiar|M. N. Nambiar]], [[S. A. Asokan|S. A. Asokan]], [[Nagesh|Nagesh]] and [[Manorama|Manorama (Tamil actress)]], among others, enacting supporting roles.
title: Vivasayee

abstract: Oru Thaai Makkal (; Sons of a Mother), is a 1971 [[Indian|Cinema of India]] [[Tamil|Tamil cinema]] [[romantic|romantic comedy]] [[comedy-drama|comedy-drama]] film, directed by [[P. Neelakantan|P. Neelakantan]], starring [[M. G. Ramachandran|M. G. Ramachandran]] in the lead role, with [[M. N. Nambiar|M. N. Nambiar]], [[Jayalalithaa|Jayalalithaa]] and [[R. Muthuraman|R. Muthuraman]], among others enacting supporting roles. The film was a remake of the Hindi film [[Ayee Milan Ki Bela|Ayee Milan Ki Bela]].
title: Oru Thaai Makkal

abstract: Do Lachhian () is a 1960 (sometimes written 1959) Punjabi film directed by Jugal Kishore, starring Gopal Sehgal, Daljeet, Indra Billi and Krishna Kumari in lead roles.
title: Do Lachhian

abstract: Naam O Nishan is a [[1987|Bollywood films of 1987]] [[Indian|Cinema of India]] [[Bollywood|Bollywood]] film directed by [[Ajay Kashyap|Ajay Kashyap]] and produced by B.P. Verma. It stars [[Sanjay Dutt|Sanjay Dutt]] and [[Amrita Singh|Amrita Singh]] in pivotal roles.
title: Naam O Nishan

abstract: Asmaan Se Ooncha ([[English|English language]]: Higher than the Sky; [[Hindi|Hindi]]: आसमान से ऊंचा) is a [[1989|Bollywood films of 1989]] [[Bollywood|Bollywood]] [[Action film|Action film]], produced by [[Sujit Kumar|Sujit Kumar]] under the Shiv Bhakti Films banner and directed by [[Mehul Kumar|Mehul Kumar]]. It stars [[Jeetendra|Jeetendra]], [[Govinda|Govinda (actor)]], [[Raj Babbar|Raj Babbar]], [[Anita Raj|Anita Raj]], [[Sonam|Sonam (actress)]] in the lead roles and music composed by [[Rajesh Roshan|Rajesh Roshan]].
title: Asmaan Se Ooncha

abstract: Bhaaga Pirivinai () is a [[Tamil language|Tamil language]] film starring [[Sivaji Ganesan|Sivaji Ganesan]], [[M. R. Radha|M. R. Radha]] and [[B. Saroja Devi|B. Saroja Devi]] in the lead roles. The film was directed by [[A. Bhimsingh|A. Bhimsingh]], produced by G. N. Velumani under Saravana Films and had musical score by [[Viswanathan–Ramamoorthy|Viswanathan–Ramamoorthy]]. Bhaaga Pirivinai celebrated 100 days in many centers of its release, ran more than 25 weeks and became one of the blockbusters of Ganesan in the year 1959.
title: Bhaaga Pirivinai

abstract: Apricot Island () is a 2011 [[Slovak|Slovakia]] [[drama|drama]]-[[romance|romance film]], starring [[Szidi Tobias|Szidi Tobias]].
title: Apricot Island

abstract: Postman Pat: The Movie is a 2014 American-British [[3D|3D film]] [[computer animated|computer animated]] [[comedy film|comedy film]] based on the television series [[Postman Pat|Postman Pat]] by [[John Cunliffe|John Cunliffe (author)]] and [[Ivor Wood|Ivor Wood]]. It was directed by [[Mike Disa|Mike Disa]], produced by Robert Anich Cole, written and screenplay by [[Nicole Dubuc|Nicole Dubuc]], with music by [[Rupert Gregson-Williams|Rupert Gregson-Williams]].
