It was co-produced by [[Classic Media|DreamWorks Classics]], [[RGH Pictures|Rubicon Group Holding]] and Timeless Films.
title: Postman Pat: The Movie

abstract: Sollamale () is a [[1998|Tamil films of 1998]] [[Tamil|Tamil language]] [[romantic|Romance film]] [[drama|drama]] film directed by [[Sasi|Sasi (director)]], who made his directorial debut with the film. The film featured [[Livingston|Livingston (actor)]] and [[Kausalya|Kausalya (actress)]] in lead roles whilst Anand, [[Prakash Raj|Prakash Raj]] and [[Karan|Karan (actor)]] play supporting roles. The film opened in July 1998 to positive reviews and became a box office success.
title: Sollamale

abstract: Naalai Namadhe () is a 1975 Indian [[Tamil-language|Tamil language]] film directed by [[K. S. Sethumadhavan|K. S. Sethumadhavan]], starring [[M. G. Ramachandran|M. G. Ramachandran]] and [[Latha|Latha (actress)]] in the lead roles with [[M. N. Nambiar|M. N. Nambiar]], [[Nagesh|Nagesh (actor)]], [[Chandramohan|Chandra Mohan (Telugu actor)]] and [[Vennira Aadai Nirmala|Vennira Aadai Nirmala]]. It is a remake of the 1973 [[Hindi|Hindi]] film [[Yaadon Ki Baaraat|Yaadon Ki Baaraat]], directed by [[Nasir Hussain|Nasir Hussain]] and written by [[Salim-Javed|Salim-Javed]]. The film was a blockbuster and ran for 150 days.
title: Naalai Namadhe

abstract: Gadibidi Ganda is a Kannada film released in 1993, directed by V. S. Reddy. This film stars [[Ravichandran|V. Ravichandran]], [[Ramya Krishnan|Ramya Krishnan]] and [[Roja|Roja Selvamani]] amongst others. Music and lyrics was composed by [[Hamsalekha|Hamsalekha]]. The film was produced by K. Krishna Mohana Rao. It was a remake of Telugu movie [[Allari Mogudu|Allari Mogudu]], starring [[Mohan Babu|Mohan Babu]].
title: Gadibidi Ganda

abstract: Bad Cat is a Turkish adult animated action-comedy film directed by Mehmet Kurtuluş and Ayşe Ünal. The film is based on the comic strip Kötu Kedi Şerafettin by Bülent Üstün.
title: Bad Cat

abstract: Christmas Tango (, [[translit.|Transliteration]]   To tango ton Hristougennon) is a 2011 Greek [[drama film|drama film]] directed by [[Nikos Koutelidakis|Nikos Koutelidakis]].
title: Christmas Tango

abstract: Jigarwala is a [[1991|Bollywood films of 1991]] [[Indian|Cinema of India]] [[Bollywood|Bollywood]] film directed by Swaroop Kumar and produced by Surinder Kaur Jerath. It stars [[Anil Kapoor|Anil Kapoor]] and [[Tina Munim|Tina Munim]] in pivotal roles. This movie marked the last film appearance of Tina Munim.
title: Jigarwala

abstract: Development of The Amazing Spider-Man 2 began after the success of The Amazing Spider-Man. DeHaan, Giamatti, Jones, and Cooper were cast between December 2012 and February 2013. Filming took place in [[New York City|New York City]] from February to June 2013. The film was released in 2D, [[3D|3D film]], and [[IMAX 3D|IMAX]] on May 2, 2014, in the United States with two international premieres being held between March 31 and April 10, 2014. It received mixed reviews from critics and audiences and grossed $709 million worldwide, making it the [[ninth-highest-grossing film of 2014|2014 in film#Highest-grossing films]] but the lowest-grossing Spider-Man film.
title: The Amazing Spider-Man 2

abstract: Sathyathinte Nizhalil is 1975 [[Malayalam|Malayalam]] [[black and white|black and white]] movie directed by [[Babu Nandancode|Babu Nanthankode]]. The story was written by [[P. Shanmugham|P. Shanmugham]] with dialogue and screenplay by [[Sreekumaran Thampi|Sreekumaran Thampi]]. Playback singers were [[Ambili|Ambili (singer)]], [[K. J. Yesudas|K. J. Yesudas]] and [[P. Susheela|P. Susheela]], and actors were [[Sudheer|Sudheer (Malayalam actor)]], [[K. P. Ummer|K. P. Ummer]], [[Ushanandini|Ushanandini]], [[Bahadoor|Bahadoor]], [[Pappu|Kuthiravattam Pappu]], [[Thikkurisi Sukumaran Nair|Thikkurisi Sukumaran Nair]], [[Philomina|Philomina]], [[Janardanan|Janardanan]] and [[Kunchan|Kunchan (actor)]].
title: Sathyathinte Nizhalil

abstract: Enakkaga Kaathiru is a 1981 Tamil-language film directed by [[P. S. Nivas|P. S. Nivas]], starring [[Suman|Suman (actor)]], [[Sumalatha|Sumalatha]] and [[Bhanuchander|Bhanuchander]].
title: Enakkaga Kaathiru

abstract: Naan Petra Selvam is a [[Tamil language|Tamil language]] film starring [[Sivaji Ganesan|Sivaji Ganesan]] and [[G. Varalakshmi|G. Varalakshmi]] in the lead roles. The film was released in the year 1956.
title: Naan Petra Selvam

abstract: Pennin Perumai (English: Woman's Pride) is a 1956 [[Tamil language|Tamil language]] film starring [[Sivaji Ganesan|Sivaji Ganesan]], [[Gemini Ganesan|Gemini Ganesan]], [[Savithri|Savitri (actress)]] and [[M. N. Rajam|M. N. Rajam]] in the lead roles.
title: Pennin Perumai

abstract: Sooryakanthi is a [[1977|Malayalam films of 1977]] [[Indian|Cinema of India]] [[Malayalam|Malayalam language]] film, directed by [[Baby|Baby (director)]]. Screenplay and story are by Surasu. The film stars [[Sukumaran|Sukumaran]], [[Kuthiravattam Pappu|Kuthiravattam Pappu]], [[M. G. Soman|M. G. Soman]] and [[Mallika Sukumaran|Mallika Sukumaran]] in the lead roles. The film has musical score by Jaya Vijaya.
title: Sooryakanthi

abstract: Preyasi Raave is a 1999 [[Telugu film|Telugu film]] directed by [[Chandra Mahesh|Chandra Mahesh]] and produced by [[D. Ramanaidu|D. Ramanaidu]]. The film stars [[Srikanth|Srikanth (Telugu actor)]], [[Raasi|Raasi (actress)]], [[Babloo Prithiveeraj|Babloo Prithiveeraj]] and [[Sanghavi|Sanghavi]] in the lead roles..
title: Preyasi Raave

abstract: Bunohan (also under the international title of Bunohan: Return to Murder) is a Malaysian drama thriller film, written and directed by [[Dain Iskandar Said|Dain Iskandar Said]] and released in Malaysia on 8 March 2012. The film features actors Faizal Hussein, Zahiril Adzim and Pekin Ibrahim in leading roles. Bunohan is the second film to be directed by Dain Said. Bunohan had its world premiere at the [[2011 Toronto International Film Festival|2011 Toronto International Film Festival]] where it was praised for its solid, visceral storytelling and arresting photography.
title: Bunohan

abstract: Dhoon (Tune or Passion) is a [[1953|Bollywood films of 1953]] [[Bollywood|Bollywood]] film directed by [[M. Kumar|M. Kumar]]. The film was produced by Silver Kings, a production company formed by Kumar and his then wife, actress Pramila. The film stars [[Raj Kapoor|Raj Kapoor]], [[Nargis|Nargis]], [[Motilal|Motilal (actor)]], Kumar, [[Pramila|Pramila (Esther Victoria Abraham)]], E. Bilmoria, [[Leela Mishra|Leela Mishra]] and Kamal Mehra. Mehra was a lesser known comedian who started his career in 1951 with Naujawan. He went on to act in several films before starting his own production company Pride Of India under which he made films like [[Kismat|Kismat (1968 film)]] (1968), [[Mahal|Mahal (1969 film)]] (1969) and [[Naami Chor|Naami Chor]] (1977). The music was by [[Madan Mohan|Madan Mohan]].
title: Dhoon

abstract: Adhey Kangal (English: Same Eyes) is a 1967 [[Tamil-language|Tamil language]] Indian [[thriller film|Thriller (genre)]] written and directed by [[A. C. Tirulokchandar|A. C. Tirulokchandar]], starring [[Ravichandran|Ravichandran (actor)]] and [[Kanchana|Kanchana (actress)]] in the lead roles. The film was remade in Telugu Simultaneously as [[Ave Kallu|Ave Kallu]].
title: Adhey Kangal

abstract: The Face Reader became one of the highest-grossing films in South Korea in 2013, with 9.1 million admissions. It won six awards at the 50th [[Grand Bell Awards|Grand Bell Awards]], including Best Film, Best Director for [[Han Jae-rim|Han Jae-rim]], and Best Actor for [[Song Kang-ho|Song Kang-ho]].
title: The Face Reader

abstract: Madadgaar ([[English|English language]]: Friend; Hindi: मददगार) is a [[1987|Bollywood films of 1987]] [[Bollywood|Bollywood]] [[Action film|Action film]], produced by Nirmal Anand under the BNT Films banner and directed by Ramesh Puri. It stars [[Jeetendra|Jeetendra]], [[Sulakshana Pandit|Sulakshana Pandit]] in the pivotal roles and music composed by [[Laxmikant-Pyarelal|Laxmikant-Pyarelal]].
title: Madadgaar

abstract: Mera Saathi ([[English|English language]]: My Companion; [[Hindi|Hindi]]: मेरा साथी) is a [[1985|Bollywood films of 1985]] [[Bollywood|Bollywood]] [[Action|Action film]] [[drama film|drama film]], produced by K. Kesava Rao under the Sree Brahmarambika Films banner and directed by [[K. Raghavendra Rao|Kovelamudi Raghavendra Rao]]. It stars [[Jeetendra|Jeetendra]], [[Rajiv Kapoor|Rajiv Kapoor]], [[Jaya Prada|Jaya Prada]] in the pivotal roles and music composed by [[Bappi Lahiri|Bappi Lahiri]]. The film is a remake of the [[Telugu|Telugu language]] movie [[Dharmaatmudu|Dharmaatmudu]] (1983), starring [[Krishnam Raju|Krishnam Raju]], [[Jayasudha|Jayasudha]] in the lead roles.
title: Mera Saathi

abstract: Des Hoyaa Pardes () is a 2004 [[National Award|National Film Awards]] winning Punjabi film, directed by Manoj Punj, starring Gurdas Maan, Juhi Chawla and Divya Dutta in lead roles.
title: Des Hoyaa Pardes

abstract: Ghar Parivar is a [[1991|Bollywood films of 1991]] Indian [[Bollywood|Bollywood]] film directed by Mohanji Prasad and produced by B. K. Parivar. It stars [[Rajesh Khanna|Rajesh Khanna]], [[Rishi Kapoor|Rishi Kapoor]], [[Moushumi Chatterjee|Moushumi Chatterjee]] and [[Meenakshi Seshadri|Meenakshi Seshadri]].
title: Ghar Parivar

abstract: Paavai Vilakku (Lady With A Lamp) is a 1960 [[Tamil|Tamil language]] film directed by K. Somu. The film features [[Sivaji Ganesan|Sivaji Ganesan]], [[Sowcar Janaki|Sowcar Janaki]], [[Pandari Bai|Pandari Bai]], [[M. N. Rajam|M. N. Rajam]] and [[Kumari Kamala|Kumari Kamala]] in the lead roles. The film had musical score by [[K. V. Mahadevan|K. V. Mahadevan]] and was released on 19 October 1960. The film was based on the very popular Tamil author Akilan's novel Paavai Vilakku, serialised in a weekly magazine. It had many twists and turns, and the movie is also not easy to narrate in detail. Despite the popularity of the novel, brilliant writing for the screen by A.P. Nagarajan and fine performances, Sivaji came up with an excellent portrayal, well supported by Sowcar Janaki, Rajam, and Kumari Kamala., the film did not do well at the box office.
title: Paavai Vilakku

abstract: Blackfellas is a 1993 [[Australian|Cinema of Australia]] [[drama film|drama film]] directed by [[James Ricketson|James Ricketson]]. It is an adaptation of [[Archie Weller|Archie Weller]]'s 1981 novel The Day of the Dog. Blackfellas stars John Moore, [[David Ngoombujarra|David Ngoombujarra]], [[Jack Charles|Jack Charles (actor)]], [[John Hargreaves|John Hargreaves (actor)]] and [[Ernie Dingo|Ernie Dingo]]. The film won two [[AFI Awards|Australian Film Institute Awards]] and had its premier at the [[Valhalla Cinema|Valhalla Cinema, Melbourne]] in [[Melbourne|Melbourne]] on 26 August 1993.
title: Blackfellas

abstract: Fred 3: Camp Fred is a 2012 [[television|television film]] [[comedy film|comedy film]] directed by [[Jonathan Judge|Jonathan Judge]]. It is the third film in the Fred film series, following [[Fred 2: Night of the Living Fred|Fred 2: Night of the Living Fred]]. Released on July 28, 2012, the film stars [[Lucas Cruikshank|Lucas Cruikshank]], [[Tom Arnold|Tom Arnold (actor)]], [[Jake Weary|Jake Weary]], and [[John Cena|John Cena]]. The film received negative reviews.
title: Fred 3: Camp Fred

abstract: My Life and Times with Antonin Artaud () is a 1993 French film, directed by [[Gérard Mordillat|Gérard Mordillat]]. It is based on [[Jacques Prevel|Jacques Prevel]]'s 1974 novel of the same name. It follows Prevel's journal of a two-year friendship with [[Antonin Artaud|Antonin Artaud]] until his death in 1948
title: My Life and Times with Antonin Artaud

abstract: Rahgir (The Traveler) is a [[Bollywood|Bollywood]] romantic social drama [[film|film]]. It was released in [[1969|Bollywood films of 1969]] and directed by [[Tarun Majumdar|Tarun Majumdar]]. The film was produced by Geetanjali Pictures and had music by [[Hemant Kumar|Hemant Kumar]]. The film had [[Biswajeet|Biswajeet]] playing the central role of Rahgir where his acting "attracted attention". Costarring with Biswajeet were [[Sandhya Roy|Sandhya Roy]], [[Shashikala|Shashikala]], [[Kanhaiyalal|Kanhaiyalal (actor)]], [[Iftekhar|Iftekhar]], [[Nirupa Roy|Nirupa Roy]] and [[Asit Sen|Asit Sen (actor)]].
title: Rahgir

abstract: Kutumba ran for 50 days in more than 17 centres across [[Karnataka|Karnataka]] and recorded 100 days in many centres across the state like [[Bangalore|Bangalore]], [[Mysore|Mysore]], [[Davanagere|Davanagere]], [[Shimoga|Shimoga]], [[Mangalore|Mangalore]], [[Hubli|Hubli]]. It also completed 125 days of run at its main center in [[Bangalore|Bangalore]].
title: Kutumba

abstract: Sisterakas is a 2012 Filipino [[comedy|comedy]] [[parody film|parody film]] produced by [[Star Cinema|Star Cinema]] and [[Viva Films|Viva Films]] and selected as one of the eight official entries to the [[2012 Metro Manila Film Festival|2012 Metro Manila Film Festival]]. The film was released nationwide in theaters on December 25, 2012. The film was directed by [[Wenn V. Deramas|Wenn V. Deramas]] and stars an ensemble cast including [[Ai-Ai Delas Alas|Ai-Ai Delas Alas]], [[Vice Ganda|Vice Ganda]], [[Kris Aquino|Kris Aquino]], [[Kathryn Bernardo|Kathryn Bernardo]], [[Daniel Padilla|Daniel Padilla]], and [[Xyriel Manabat|Xyriel Manabat]]. This is Aquino's first collaboration with [[VIVA Films|VIVA Films]].
title: Sisterakas

abstract: Cela s'appelle l'aurore (English: This is Called Dawn) is a 1956 Franco-Italian film, directed by [[Luis Buñuel|Luis Buñuel]]. It was written by Buñuel and [[Jean Ferry|Jean Ferry]], based on a novel by [[Emmanuel Roblès|Emmanuel Roblès]].
title: Cela s'appelle l'aurore

abstract: Makkal Aatchi (English: People's rule) is a [[1995|Tamil films of 1995]] [[Tamil language|Tamil language]] [[Indian|Cinema of India]] film directed by [[R. K. Selvamani|R. K. Selvamani]]. The film features [[Mammootty|Mammootty]] in the lead role and [[Roja|Roja (actress)]], [[Aishwarya|Aishwarya (actress)]], [[Anandaraj|Anandaraj]] and [[Livingston|Livingston (actor)]] in supporting roles. The movie was dubbed in [[Malayalam|Malayalam]] as Ente Naadu. The film became a major success among 1995 Deepavali releases, along with [[Muthu|Muthu (1995 film)]].
title: Makkal Aatchi

abstract: Main Tere Liye is a 1989 [[Indian|India]] [[Bollywood|Bollywood]] film directed by [[Vijay Anand|Vijay Anand (Hindi film maker)]]. It stars [[Rajendra Kumar|Rajendra Kumar]], [[Asha Parekh|Asha Parekh]], [[Suneil Anand|Suneil Anand]] and [[Meenakshi Seshadri|Meenakshi Seshadri]] in pivotal roles.
title: Main Tere Liye

abstract: Police Aur Mujrim is a [[1992|Bollywood films of 1992]] [[India|Indian]] [[Bollywood|Bollywood]] film produced and directed by [[K.C. Bokadia|K.C. Bokadia]]. It stars [[Raaj Kumar|Raaj Kumar]], [[Vinod Khanna|Vinod Khanna]], [[Meenakshi Seshadri|Meenakshi Seshadri]] and [[Nagma|Nagma]] in pivotal roles.
title: Police Aur Mujrim

abstract: Amiri Garibi ([[English|English language]]: [[Rich|wikt:rich]] - [[Poor|wikt:Special:Search/poor]]; [[Hindi|Hindi]]: अमीरी गरीबी) is a [[1990|Bollywood films of 1990]] [[Bollywood|Bollywood]] [[drama film|drama film]], produced by Pradeep Sharma under the TUTU Films banner and directed by [[Harmesh Malhotra|Harmesh Malhotra]]. It stars Jeetendra, Rekha, Rishi Kapoor, Poonam Dhillon, Raj Babbar, Neelam Kothari in the lead roles and music composed by [[Laxmikant-Pyarelal|Laxmikant-Pyarelal]]. The film is a remake of the [[Telugu|Telugu language]] movie [[Makutamleni Maharaju|Makutamleni Maharaju]] (1987), starring [[Krishna|Krishna (Telugu actor)]], [[Sridevi|Sridevi]], [[Rajendra Prasad|Rajendra Prasad (actor)]] in the pivotal roles.
title: Amiri Garibi

abstract: Kakabakaba Ka Ba? (lit. Does Your Heart Beat Faster?) is a 1980 [[musical|musical film]]-[[romantic comedy|romantic comedy]] film produced by [[LVN Pictures|LVN Pictures]] (in its last offering) in 1980, with [[Mike De Leon|Mike De Leon]] as director.
title: Kakabakaba Ka Ba?

abstract: Sarhad Paar is a [[2006|List of Bollywood films of 2006]] Indian [[Hindi|Hindi]] [[drama film|drama film]] directed by Raman Kumar and produced by Goldie Tucker. The film stars [[Sanjay Dutt|Sanjay Dutt]], [[Tabu|Tabu (actress)]], and [[Mahima Chaudhry|Mahima Chaudhry]] as main characters, with [[Rahul Dev|Rahul Dev]] portraying the main villain. The script was co-written by veteran actor [[Akash Khurana|Akash Khurana]], who also plays a pivotal supporting character in the film.
title: Sarhad Paar

abstract: Rio 2096: A Story of Love and Fury (Portuguese: Uma História de Amor e Fúria) is a 2013 Brazilian [[animated|Animation]] drama film written and directed by [[Luiz Bolognesi|Luiz Bolognesi]].
title: Rio 2096: A Story of Love and Fury

abstract: 10:30 am Local Call is a 2013 Malayalam mystery film directed by Manu Sudhakaran and starring [[Nishan K. P. Nanaiah|Nishan K. P. Nanaiah]], [[Shritha Sivadas|Shritha Sivadas]], [[Kailash|Kailash (actor)]], [[Lal|Lal (actor)]], Mrudula Murali and [[Jennifer Antony|Jennifer Antony]] playing a prominent role.
title: 10:30 am Local Call

abstract: Zinda Bhaag unravels the theme of illegal immigration highlighting the issue and the epicentre of this trend within Punjab. The story of Zinda Bhaag unravels the theme of illegal immigration, called ‘dunky’. This involves inhuman and dangerous methods of crossing borders into foreign lands. It is a film about three young men trying to escape the reality of their everyday lives and succeeding in ways they had least expected. In a nondescript neighbourhood of a city (most probably Gujranwala, Wazirabad or Gujrat) within [[Punjab|Punjab, Pakistan]] , three friends are desperate to get onto the fast track to success. Khaldi, Taambi and Chitta, all in their early twenties, believe that the only way out is to the West. The journey that unfolds through the story of this film gives us insight into what constitutes the everyday lives of many young men and women in [[Pakistan|Pakistan]] - a sense of entitlement that cannot be fulfilled, desperation to somehow prove themselves in the face of all legitimate doors being locked and an ennui from which they feel there is no getaway.
title: Zinda Bhaag

abstract: Poonam Ki Raat (Full moon Night) is a [[1965|Bollywood films of 1965]] horror thriller film starring [[Manoj Kumar|Manoj Kumar]], [[Nandini|Nandini]], Shiv Kumar, and Kumud Chhugani. It was produced and directed by [[Kishore Sahu|Kishore Sahu]]. The music was given by [[Salil Chowdhury|Salil Chowdhury]], with lyrics by [[Shailendra|Shailendra (lyricist)]].
title: Poonam Ki Raat

abstract: Bhale Huchcha () is a 1972 [[India|Indian]] [[Kannada|Cinema of Karnataka]] film directed by [[Y. R. Swamy|Y. R. Swamy]] and produced by Gopal Lakshman. It stars [[Rajkumar|Rajkumar (actor)]] and [[Aarathi|Aarathi]] in lead roles.
title: Bhale Huchcha

abstract: Humsey Hai Jahaan is a 2008 romance comedy [[Indian|Cinema of India]] [[Bollywood|Bollywood]] film directed by Mashhoor Amrohi and produced by Tajdar Amrohi. It stars Mashhoor Amrohi, [[Vishakha Singh|Vishakha Singh]], [[Jackie Shroff|Jackie Shroff]] in lead roles.
title: Humsey Hai Jahaan

abstract: Abhayam Thedi is a [[1986|Malayalam films of 1986]] [[Indian|Cinema of India]] [[Malayalam|Malayalam language]] film, directed by [[IV Sasi|IV Sasi]]. The film stars [[Mohanlal|Mohanlal]], [[Shobhana|Shobhana]], [[Sukumari|Sukumari]], and [[Thilakan|Thilakan]] in lead roles. The film had musical score by [[Shyam|Shyam (composer)]].
title: Abhayam Thedi

abstract: Main Nashe Mein Hoon () is a [[1959|Bollywood films of 1959]] Hindi film directed by Naresh Saigal with [[Raj Kapoor|Raj Kapoor]] and [[Mala Sinha|Mala Sinha]] in the lead roles.
title: Main Nashe Mein Hoon

abstract: Life! Camera Action... is a [[family-drama film|Drama film]] directed, written, edited, produced by [[Rohit Gupta|Rohit Gupta]] in his directorial debut. Starring [[Dipti Mehta|Dipti Mehta]], [[Shaheed Woods|Shaheed Woods]], Noor Naghmi, Swati Kapila, John Crann, this ninety minutes quasi-autobiographical film follows a girl in pursuit of her dreams of becoming a filmmaker against all odds. The film received several awards and nominations. Its theatrical release was limited to [[film festivals|film festivals]]. The film received [[direct-to-DVD|direct-to-video]] release and subsequently on other [[video on demand|video on demand]] (VOD) platforms.
title: Life! Camera Action...

abstract: Fandry (English: Pig) is a 2013 [[Indian|Indian Cinema]] [[Marathi|Marathi cinema]]-language film, written and directed by [[Nagraj Manjule|Nagraj Manjule]] in a directorial debut. It stars Somnath Avghade and [[Rajeshwari Kharat|Rajeshwari Kharat]]. The story focuses on a young boy's infatuation amidst [[caste-based|Caste system in India]] discrimination. The film—set in [[Akolner|Akolner]], a village near [[Ahmednagar|Ahmednagar]]—is about a teenager from a [[Dalit|Dalit]] (Oppressed caste) family, who lives at the village fringe, and falls in love with an upper caste girl.
title: Fandry

abstract: Night in London is a [[1967|Bollywood films of 1967]] Hindi film directed by [[Brij|Brij Sadanah]]. The film stars [[Biswajeet|Biswajeet]], [[Mala Sinha|Mala Sinha]], [[Johnny Walker|Johnny Walker (actor)]] and [[Helen|Helen (actress)]].
title: Night in London

abstract: Of the Flesh () is a 1983 Philippine [[drama film|drama film]] directed by [[Marilou Diaz-Abaya|Marilou Diaz-Abaya]]. The film was selected as the Philippine entry for the [[Best Foreign Language Film|Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film]] at the [[57th Academy Awards|57th Academy Awards]], but was not accepted as a nominee.
title: Of the Flesh

abstract: Kanwarlal is a [[1988|Bollywood films of 1988]] [[Bollywood|Bollywood]] [[Action film|Action film]], produced by G. Hanumantha Rao under the [[Padmalaya Studios|Padmalaya Studios]] banner, presented by [[Krishna|Krishna (Telugu actor)]] and directed by S.S. Ravichandra. It stars [[Jeetendra|Jeetendra]], [[Raj Babbar|Raj Babbar]], Sujata Mehta in lead roles and music composed by [[Bappi Lahiri|Bappi Lahiri]]. The film is a remake of the [[Malayalam|Malayalam language]] film [[Rajavinte Makan|Rajavinte Makan]] (1986), starring [[Mohanlal|Mohanlal]], [[Ambika|Ambika (actress)]]. It also remade in [[Tamil|Tamil language]] as [[Makkal En Pakkam|Makkal En Pakkam]] (1987), starring [[Sathyaraj|Sathyaraj]], in [[Kannada|Kannada language]] as [[Athiratha Maharatha|Athiratha Maharatha]] (1987), with [[Anant Nag|Anant Nag]], [[Tiger Prabhakar|Tiger Prabhakar]], with Ambika reprising her role in both versions and in [[Telugu|Telugu language]] as Aahuthi (1987), starring [[Dr.Rajasekhar|Rajasekhar (actor)]] and [[Jeevitha Rajasekhar|Jeevitha]] in the pivotal roles.
title: Kanwarlal

abstract: Big Momma's House is a 2000 [[action|Action film]] [[comedy film|comedy film]] directed by [[Raja Gosnell|Raja Gosnell]], written by Darryl Quarles and [[Don Rhymer|Don Rhymer]], and starring [[Martin Lawrence|Martin Lawrence]] as [[FBI|Federal Bureau of Investigation]] agent Malcolm Turner. The majority of the film took place in [[Cartersville, Georgia|Cartersville, Georgia]], but the film was shot on location in [[California|California]]. The prime shooting spots were [[Los Angeles|Los Angeles]] and [[Orange County|Orange County, California]]. The film is also notable for being one of only four titles to be released on the [[EVD|Enhanced Versatile Disc]] video format. It is the first installment in a trilogy series called Big Momma, which includes two sequels, [[Big Momma's House 2|Big Momma's House 2]] and [[Big Mommas: Like Father, Like Son|Big Mommas: Like Father, Like Son]].
title: Big Momma's House

abstract: Pitaah (Father) is a 2002 [[Indian|Cinema of India]] [[Bollywood|Bollywood]] film directed by [[Mahesh Manjrekar|Mahesh Manjrekar]] and produced by Avinash Adik. It stars [[Sanjay Dutt|Sanjay Dutt]], [[Jackie Shroff|Jackie Shroff]], [[Nandita Das|Nandita Das]] and [[Anupama Verma|Anupama Verma]] in pivotal roles. The plot of the film similar to the 1996 film [[A Time to Kill|A Time to Kill (1996 film)]]. The film was well received by critics as well as audience.
title: Pitaah

abstract: 2001: Do Hazaar Ek is a [[Bollywood|Bollywood]] [[film|film]]. It was released in [[1998|List of Bollywood films of 1998]] and stars [[Dimple Kapadia|Dimple Kapadia]], [[Jackie Shroff|Jackie Shroff]], [[Rajat Bedi|Rajat Bedi]] And [[Tabu|Tabu (actress)]].
title: 2001: Do Hazaar Ek

abstract: Mangaiyar Thilakam (Crown Among Women) is a 1955 Indian [[Tamil-language|Tamil language]] [[drama film|Drama (film and television)]] directed by L. V. Prasad. The film was produced by Sripadhashankar under Vaidya films and stars Sivaji Ganesan and Padmini in the lead roles, while M. N. Rajam, S. V. Subbiah, K. A. Thangavelu and K. Sarangapani play pivotal roles. The film's soundtrack and background score were composed by S. Dakshinamurthi, while the lyrics for the songs were written by [[Kannadasan|Kannadasan]], Puratchidasan and Maruthakasi.
title: Mangaiyar Thilakam

abstract: Attarintiki Daredi () is a 2013 Indian [[Telugu-language|Telugu language]] [[comedy-drama|comedy-drama]] film written and directed by [[Trivikram Srinivas|Trivikram Srinivas]]. It stars [[Pawan Kalyan|Pawan Kalyan]], [[Samantha Akkineni|Samantha Akkineni]] and [[Pranitha Subhash|Pranitha Subhash]] in the lead roles with [[Nadhiya|Nadhiya]], [[Boman Irani|Boman Irani]] and [[Brahmanandam|Brahmanandam]] in supporting roles.
title: Attarintiki Daredi

abstract: The Conjuring is a 2013 American [[supernatural horror film|supernatural horror film]] directed by [[James Wan|James Wan]] and written by [[Chad Hayes|Chad Hayes (writer)]] and [[Carey W. Hayes|Carey W. Hayes]]. It is the inaugural film in [[The Conjuring Universe|The Conjuring Universe]] franchise. [[Patrick Wilson|Patrick Wilson (American actor)]] and [[Vera Farmiga|Vera Farmiga]] star as [[Ed and Lorraine Warren|Ed and Lorraine Warren]], [[paranormal investigators|Ghost hunting]] and authors associated with prominent cases of [[haunting|haunting]]. Their purportedly real-life reports inspired [[The Amityville Horror|The Amityville Horror]] story and [[film franchise|The Amityville Horror (film series)]]. The Warrens come to the assistance of the Perron family, who experienced increasingly disturbing events in their farmhouse in [[Rhode Island|Rhode Island]] in 1971.
title: The Conjuring

abstract: Gunasagari is a 1953 [[India|Indian]] [[Kannada|Cinema of Karnataka]] film directed by [[H. L. N. Simha|H. L. N. Simha]] and produced by [[AVM Productions|AVM Productions]]. It stars [[Gubbi Veeranna|Gubbi Veeranna]], [[Honnappa Bhagavathar|Honnappa Bhagavathar]] and [[Pandari Bai|Pandari Bai]] in lead roles. The music is composed by R. Sudarshanam. The film was released in Tamil as Sathya Sodhanai.
title: Gunasagari

abstract: Magic Temple is a 1996 [[Filipino|Cinema of the Philippines]] [[family|family film]]-[[fantasy|fantasy film]]-[[adventure film|adventure film]] directed by the acclaimed director [[Peque Gallaga|Peque Gallaga]] and released by [[Star Cinema|Star Cinema]]. It was written by Peque Gallaga, Lore Reyes and [[Erik Matti|Erik Matti]]. It is notable for winning all of the 14 nominations including the Best Film at the [[1996 Metro Manila Film Festival|1996 Metro Manila Film Festival]].
title: Magic Temple

abstract: Simhadriya Simha () is a 2002 blockbuster Indian Kannada [[action|action film]] [[family|family]] [[drama|drama]] directed by [[S. Narayan|S. Narayan]]. The film starred [[Vishnuvardhan|Vishnuvardhan (actor)]], [[Meena|Meena (actress)]] and [[Bhanupriya|Bhanupriya]] in lead roles. The music of the film was composed by [[Deva|Deva (music director)]]. The film was a remake of the 1994 [[Tamil|Tamil language]] film [[Nattamai|Nattamai]] which starred [[Sarath Kumar|Sarath Kumar]] and [[Kushboo|Kushboo]] in lead roles.
title: Simhadriya Simha

abstract: Diggajaru is a 2001 Indian [[Kannada film|Cinema of Karnataka]] directed by [[D. Rajendra Babu|D. Rajendra Babu]]. The film stars [[Vishnuvardhan|Vishnuvardhan (actor)]] and [[Ambareesh|Ambareesh]] in lead roles. The music of the film was composed by [[Hamsalekha|Hamsalekha]]. It was a remake of [[K. S. Ravikumar|K. S. Ravikumar]]'s 1998 Tamil [[Natpukkaga|Natpukkaga]], which starred [[Sarath Kumar|Sarath Kumar]] and [[Simran Bagga|Simran Bagga]] in the lead roles. The film became a blockbuster hit all over the state.
title: Diggajaru

abstract: Thotti Gang is a 2002 Telugu comedy film produced and directed by [[E. V. V. Satyanarayana|E. V. V. Satyanarayana]] starring [[Prabhu Deva|Prabhu Deva]], [[Allari Naresh|Allari Naresh]], [[Sunil|Sunil (actor)]], [[Gajala|Gajala]] and [[Anita Hassanandani|Anita Hassanandani]] in the lead roles. The movie was released on 6 December 2002 to positive reviews and was declared a super hit at the box office. The film was based on 2001 American film [[Saving Silverman|Saving Silverman]]. The film was dubbed and released in Tamil as Love Game with a separate comedy track featuring [[Livingston|Livingston (actor)]] and [[Venniradai Moorthy|Venniradai Moorthy]].
title: Thotti Gang

abstract: Dead Europe is a 2012 Australian [[drama film|drama film]] directed by [[Tony Krawitz|Tony Krawitz]]. It is an adaptation of the 2005 novel by [[Christos Tsiolkas|Christos Tsiolkas]] with the same name.
title: Dead Europe

abstract: Shake, Rattle & Roll V is the fifth installment of the Shake Rattle & Roll franchise. It was distributed by Regal Films. It is directed by Manny Castañeda, Don Escudero & Jose Javier Reyes. This film is an entry of the [[1994 Metro Manila Film Festival|1994 Metro Manila Film Festival]].
title: Shake, Rattle & Roll V

abstract: Jab Tak Hai Jaan (English: As Long As There is Life/As Long As I Live) is a 2012 Indian [[romantic|romance film]] [[drama film|drama film]] directed by [[Yash Chopra|Yash Chopra]]; written and produced by [[Aditya Chopra|Aditya Chopra]] under their production banner, [[Yash Raj Films|Yash Raj Films]]. It stars [[Shah Rukh Khan|Shah Rukh Khan]] as Samar Anand, a bomb disposal expert whose diary falls into the hands of an intern played by [[Anushka Sharma|Anushka Sharma]]. The diary recounts his time as a struggling immigrant in London, and later details his whirlwind romance with Meera Thapar, played by [[Katrina Kaif|Katrina Kaif]].
title: Jab Tak Hai Jaan

abstract: Foxcatcher received critical acclaim for the three lead actors' performances, Miller's direction, and the film's visual style and tone. It was nominated for the [[Palme d'Or|Palme d'Or]] in the main competition section at the [[2014 Cannes Film Festival|2014 Cannes Film Festival]], where Miller won the [[Best Director Award|Best Director Award (Cannes Film Festival)]]. The film had three [[Golden Globe Award|Golden Globe Award]] nominations, including [[Best Picture|Golden Globe Award for Best Motion Picture – Drama]]. The film was nominated for five Oscars at the [[2015 Academy Awards|87th Academy Awards]], including a [[Best Actor|Academy Award for Best Actor]] nomination for Carell, [[Best Supporting Actor|Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor]] for Ruffalo and [[Best Director|Academy Award for Best Director]] for Miller. It became the first film to be nominated for [[Best Director|Academy Award for Best Director]] but not [[Best Picture|Academy Award for Best Picture]] since 2008, when [[Julian Schnabel|Julian Schnabel]] was nominated for [[The Diving Bell and the Butterfly|The Diving Bell and the Butterfly (film)]], two years before the Academy extended its maximum number of Best Picture nominees to 10 films.
title: Foxcatcher

abstract: Anubhoothi is a [[1997|Malayalam films of 1997]] [[Indian|Cinema of India]] [[Malayalam|Malayalam language]] film, directed by [[IV Sasi|IV Sasi]]. The film stars [[Jagathy Sreekumar|Jagathy Sreekumar]], [[Suresh Gopi|Suresh Gopi]], [[Kalpana|Kalpana (Malayalam actress)]] and [[Jagadish|Jagadish]] in lead roles. The film had musical score by [[Shyam|Shyam (composer)]].
title: Anubhoothi

abstract: Friend: The Great Legacy begins 17 years after where the previous film left off. Lee Joon-seok, who claimed responsibility for ordering his friend Dong-soo's murder (despite having nothing to do with it), has spent a lot of time behind bars and now he is released to a world that is as unfamiliar to him as the criminal organization he used to lead. With his subordinate Eun-ki now practically parading as the boss, Joon-seok, a leader by nature, secretly embarks on a mission to subvert his current position. He invites Choi Sung-hoon, whom he'd met in prison, and Sung-hoon's gang to join in his plan. Sung-hoon is the twenty-something son of one of Joon-seok's female friends in high school who now works as a bar hostess, and he had been serving a one-year sentence for beating his mother's abusive husband. Having developed a respect for the charismatic Joon-seok in prison, Sung-hoon willingly takes his side. But when he discovers the truth behind his background, this creates great tension between the two. Interspersed are scenes of Joon-seok's own father, Lee Chul-joo as a [[gangster|kkangpae]] who founded the criminal organization in 1963 [[Busan|Busan]].
title: Friend: The Great Legacy

abstract: The Terror Live () is a 2013 South Korean [[action|action film]] [[thriller|thriller (genre)]] film written and directed by [[Kim Byung-woo|Kim Byung-woo]]. It stars [[Ha Jung-woo|Ha Jung-woo]] as an ambitious news anchorman who monopolizes the live broadcast of a terrorist attack following the explosion of [[Mapo Bridge|Mapo Bridge]] on the [[Han River|Han River (Korea)]], as the story unfolds within the narrow confines of a radio booth.
title: The Terror Live

abstract: Eastern Boys is a 2013 French [[drama film|drama film]] written and directed by [[Robin Campillo|Robin Campillo]]. It premiered at the [[70th Venice International Film Festival|70th Venice International Film Festival]] in the [[Orizzonti|Orizzonti]] section and was later screened in the Contemporary World Cinema section at the [[2013 Toronto International Film Festival|2013 Toronto International Film Festival]].
title: Eastern Boys

abstract: Bhama Rukmani is a [[1980|Tamil films of 1980]] [[Tamil language|Tamil language]] [[drama film|drama film]] directed by R. Bhaskaran. The film features [[K. Bhagyaraj|K. Bhagyaraj]], [[Raadhika|Raadhika]] and Praveena in lead roles. The film, had musical score by [[M. S. Viswanathan|M. S. Viswanathan]] and was released on 12 June 1980.
title: Bhama Rukmani

abstract: Kaanal Neer () is a 1961 Indian [[Tamil-language|Tamil language]] [[drama film|Drama (film and television)]] written and directed by [[P. S. Ramakrishna Rao|P. S. Ramakrishna Rao]]. The film stars [[A. Nageswara Rao|A. Nageswara Rao]] and [[P. Bhanumathi|P. Bhanumathi]] in the lead. An adaptation of the novel Badi Didi by [[Sarat Chandra Chattopadhyay|Sarat Chandra Chattopadhyay]], it was simultaneously filmed in [[Telugu|Telugu language]] as [[Batasari|Batasari]].
title: Kaanal Neer

abstract: Mayor Muthanna () is a [[1969|Kannada films of 1969]] Indian [[Kannada-language|Kannada-language]] film directed by [[Siddalingaiah|Siddalingaiah]]. The film stars [[Rajkumar|Rajkumar (actor)]] and [[Bharathi|Bharathi Vishnuvardhan]]. The film was Siddalingaiah's first as a director and actor [[Dwarkish|Dwarkish]]'s first productional venture.
title: Mayor Muthanna

abstract: Ponnagaram is a [[1980|1980 in film]] [[Tamil-language|Cinema of Tamil Nadu]] [[Indian|Cinema of India]] [[feature film|feature film]] [[directed|Film director]] by K.S.Madhangan, starring [[Sarath Babu|Sarath Babu]] and [[Shoba|Shoba]]
title: Ponnagaram

abstract: Govindudu Andarivadele (), also known by the [[acronym|acronym]] GAV, is a 2014 Indian [[Telugu-language|Telugu language]] [[drama film|Drama (film and television)]] written and directed by [[Krishna Vamsi|Krishna Vamsi]] and produced by [[Bandla Ganesh|Bandla Ganesh]] for [[Parameswara Art Productions|Parameswara Art Productions]]. The film features [[Ram Charan|Ram Charan]], [[Srikanth|Meka Srikanth]], [[Kajal Aggarwal|Kajal Aggarwal]] and [[Kamalinee Mukherjee|Kamalinee Mukherjee]] in the lead roles, while [[Prakash Raj|Prakash Raj]], [[Jayasudha|Jayasudha]], [[Rahman|Rahman (actor)]] and [[Adarsh Balakrishna|Adarsh Balakrishna]] play supporting roles. [[Yuvan Shankar Raja|Yuvan Shankar Raja]] composed the film's [[soundtrack|Govindudu Andarivadele (soundtrack)]] and score while [[Sameer Reddy|Sameer Reddy]] worked as the cinematographer.
title: Govindudu Andarivadele

abstract: Facing Fear was a nominee for the 86th [[Academy Awards|Academy Awards]] in the Best Documentary Short Subject category.
title: Facing Fear

abstract: Tevar (English: Attitude) is a 2015 [[Indian|Cinema of India]] [[action film|action film]] directed by [[Amit Sharma|Amit Sharma (director)]] and written by [[Gunasekhar|Gunasekhar]]. The film stars [[Arjun Kapoor|Arjun Kapoor]] and [[Sonakshi Sinha|Sonakshi Sinha]] and in lead roles while [[Manoj Bajpayee|Manoj Bajpayee]] also plays a crucial role. It is an official remake of Telugu film [[Okkadu|Okkadu]] (2003). [[Shruti Haasan|Shruti Haasan]] made a [[special appearance|Item number]] in the song "Madamiyan".
title: Tevar

abstract: Baa Nalle Madhuchandrake (; ) is a 1993 Indian Kannada-language romantic thriller film starring [[K. Shivram|K. Shivram]] and Nandini Singh in the lead roles. The film is directed and written by [[Nagathihalli Chandrashekar|Nagathihalli Chandrashekar]] and based on the novel of same name written by him. It is produced by Urmila Babu for Drishya Kavya Films banner. The film features a soundtrack by [[Hamsalekha|Hamsalekha]].
title: Baa Nalle Madhuchandrake

abstract: Kaamyab ([[English|English language]]: Successful; [[Hindi|Hindi]]: कामयाब) is a [[Bollywood|Bollywood]] [[Action film|Action film]], produced by G. Hanumantha Rao by [[Padmalaya Studios|Padmalaya Studios]] banner, presented by [[Krishna|Krishna (Telugu actor)]] and directed by [[K. Raghavendra Rao|K. Raghavendra Rao]]. Starring [[Jeetendra|Jeetendra]], [[Shabana Azmi|Shabana Azmi]], [[Radha|Radha (actress)]] in the lead roles and music composed by [[Bappi Lahari|Bappi Lahari]]. The film is remake of [[Telugu|Telugu language]] Movie Shakti (1983), starring Krishna, [[Jaya Sudha|Jaya Sudha]], Radha in pivotal roles.
title: Kaamyab

abstract: Earth to Echo is a 2014 American [[found footage|found footage (film technique)]] [[science fiction|science fiction]] film directed by [[Dave Green|Dave Green (director)]], and produced by Ryan Kavanaugh and Andrew Panay. The film was originally developed and produced by [[Walt Disney Pictures|Walt Disney Pictures]], which later sold the distribution rights to [[Relativity Media|Relativity Media]], which released the film in theaters on July 2, 2014.
title: Earth to Echo

abstract: 2 Seconds () is a [[Canadian|Canada]] drama film, released in 1998. This film premiered in 1999 at the [[Sundance Film Festival|Sundance Film Festival]]. Written and directed by [[Manon Briand|Manon Briand]], 2 Seconds stars [[Charlotte Laurier|Charlotte Laurier]] as Laurie, a [[bisexual|bisexual]] woman who takes a job as a [[bike courier|bike courier]] in [[Montreal|Montreal]] after being fired from her previous job as a professional [[downhill racer|downhill mountain biking]]. Laurie is forcefully retired as a downhill racer when her concerns about her signs of aging cause her to lose her last race by 2 seconds (hence the name of the movie). Laurie and the one bike she was allowed to keep then move in with her geeky, physics-loving brother who is trying very hard to find a girlfriend. While putting her bike together, Laurie discovers that she is missing a gear on her bicyclette so she makes do with what she has. Because of this, she breaks the chain on her bike one day, leading to her meeting with her soon-to-be best friend Lorenzo . Lorenzo is an ex Italian professional racer who currently works as a bike mechanic in his own bike shop. offered her a job at the bicycle company, but one of her co workers, Willie, tries to make her life miserable. After talking to Lorenzo, Laurie figures out what she needs to do to help herself and try to resolve things.
title: 2 Seconds

abstract: Looney Tunes Showcase: Volume 1 is a [[Blu-ray|Blu-ray]] disc announced by [[Warner Home Video|Warner Home Video]]. It was released on January 10, 2012. It contains 25 [[Looney Tunes|Looney Tunes]] and [[Merrie Melodies|Merrie Melodies]] shorts and numerous supplements. It is a separate release of Disc 1 of the [[Looney Tunes Platinum Collection: Volume 1|Looney Tunes Platinum Collection: Volume 1]]. This will be the series for Looney Tunes and Merrie Melodies cartoons in standard Blu-ray cases. But due to low budgets in remastering the shorts, The Looney Tunes Showcase was discontinued.
title: Looney Tunes Showcase: Volume 1

abstract: Anokha Pyar is a [[1948|Bollywood films of 1948]] Indian [[Bollywood|Bollywood]] film starring [[Dilip Kumar|Dilip Kumar]], [[Nargis|Nargis]] and [[Nalini Jaywant|Nalini Jaywant]]. The black and white film was directed by M. I. Dharamsey under the Ambika Films banner. The music was composed by Anil Biswas, who made use of a fairly unknown [[Lata Mangeshkar|Lata Mangeshkar]] for the popular songs in the film. The rest of the cast included Sankatha Prasad, Mukri, Ved, Kesarbai, Habib and Sheikh.
title: Anokha Pyar

abstract: Aiye is an Indian [[Bollywood|Bollywood]] social family film. It was released in [[1949|Bollywood films of 1949]]. Produced and directed by [[Yakub|Yakub (actor)]] under Indian Productions banner, it had music by [[Nashad|Nashad]]. The film had Sulochana Chatterjee, [[Noor Mohammed Charlie|Noor Mohammed Charlie]], Masud, [[Jankidas|Jankidas]], Sheela Naik, Ashraf Khan and Yakub starring in it. The film was commercially unsuccessful and Yakub called it the "big mistake" of his life.
title: Aiye

abstract: Main Intequam Loonga is a [[1982|Bollywood films of 1982]] Bollywood [[sports film|sports film]] starring [[Dharmendra|Dharmendra]], [[Reena Roy|Reena Roy]], [[Amrish Puri|Amrish Puri]] and [[Nirupa Roy|Nirupa Roy]]. Dharmendra plays the role of a [[boxer|boxer]] in the film. Footage from this film was used in the 2007 film [[Apne|Apne]], also starring Dharmendra as a retired boxer. It is a remake of the 1978 Kannada film [[Thayige Thakka Maga|Thayige Thakka Maga]], starring Dr. Rajkumar and Padmapriya.
title: Main Intequam Loonga

abstract: Ghazab is a [[1982|Bollywood films of 1982]] Bollywood film starring [[Dharmendra|Dharmendra]] and [[Rekha|Rekha]]. The film was a remake of the Tamil film [[Kalyanaraman|Kalyanaraman (1979 film)]]. The movie was a 'Hit' and the performance of [[Dharmendra|Dharmendra]] was critically acclaimed.
title: Ghazab

abstract: Jaani Dost ([[English|English language]]: Best Friends; [[Hindi|Hindi]]: जानी दोस्त) is a [[1983|Bollywood films of 1983]] [[Bollywood|Bollywood]] [[Action film|Action film]], produced by C. Ashwini Dutt and M.Arjuna Raju under the [[Vyjayanthi|Vyjayanthi Movies]] & Roja Movies Combines banner and directed by [[K. Raghavendra Rao|K. Raghavendra Rao]]. It stars [[Dharmendra|Dharmendra]], [[Jeetendra|Jeetendra]], [[Parveen Babi|Parveen Babi]], [[Sridevi|Sridevi]] in the lead roles and music composed by [[Bappi Lahari|Bappi Lahari]]. The film is a remake of the [[Telugu|Telugu language]] movie [[Adavi Simhalu|Adavi Simhalu]], starring [[Krishna|Krishna (Telugu actor)]], [[Krishnam Raju|Krishnam Raju]], Sridevi, [[Jaya Prada|Jaya Prada]] in the pivotal roles. Both the movies were made simultaneously by the same banner and director, some of the scenes and actors are identical in both the versions.
title: Jaani Dost

abstract: Mera Karam Mera Dharam is a [[1987|Bollywood films of 1987]] Bollywood film, starring [[Dharmendra|Dharmendra]] and [[Moushumi Chatterjee|Moushumi Chatterjee]].
title: Mera Karam Mera Dharam

abstract: Jaan Hatheli Pe ([[English|English language]]: Life on Palm) is a [[1987|Bollywood films of 1987]] [[Bollywood|Bollywood]] [[Action film|Action film]] produced by Sudesh Kumar under the Vijaya Shree Pictures banner and directed by Raghunath Jhalani. It stars [[Dharmendra|Dharmendra]], [[Jeetendra|Jeetendra]], [[Raj Babbar|Raj Babbar]], [[Hema Malini|Hema Malini]], [[Rekha|Rekha]] in the lead roles and music composed by [[Laxmikant-Pyarelal|Laxmikant-Pyarelal]].
title: Jaan Hatheli Pe

abstract: Sone Pe Suhaaga ([[English|English language]]: Borax on Gold; [[Hindi|Hindi]]: सोने पे सुहागा) is a [[1988|Bollywood films of 1988]] [[Indian|India]] [[masala film|masala film]], produced by Abdul Hafiz Nadiadwala on A. G. Films Pvt Ltd banner and directed by K.Bapaiah. Starring [[Dharmendra|Dharmendra]], [[Jeetendra|Jeetendra]], [[Anil Kapoor|Anil Kapoor]], [[Sridevi|Sridevi]], [[Poonam Dhillon|Poonam Dhillon]], [[Kimi Katkar|Kimi Katkar]] in lead roles and music composed by [[Bappi Lahiri|Bappi Lahiri]].
title: Sone Pe Suhaaga

abstract: Nafrat Ki Aandhi ([[English|English language]]: Storm Of Hatred) is a 1989 [[Bollywood|Bollywood]] [[Action film|Action film]], Produced by Ratan Irani on Shree Jagdamba Movies Combines banner and directed by [[Mehul Kumar|Mehul Kumar]]. Starring [[Dharmendra|Dharmendra]], [[Jeetendra|Jeetendra]] [[Anita Raj|Anita Raj]], [[Madhavi|Madhavi (actress)]] in the lead roles and music composed by [[Bappi Lahari|Bappi Lahari]].
title: Nafrat Ki Aandhi

abstract: Humlaa is a [[1992|Bollywood films of 1992]] Bollywood film directed by N. Chandra, starring [[Dharmendra|Dharmendra]], [[Anil Kapoor|Anil Kapoor]], [[Meenakshi Sheshadri|Meenakshi Sheshadri]] and [[Kimi Katkar|Kimi Katkar]].
title: Humlaa

abstract: Maha Shaktishaali is a [[1994|Bollywood films of 1994]] Bollywood film.
title: Maha Shaktishaali

abstract: Gundagardi (English: Hooliganism or rowdism) is a 1997 [[India|Indian]] [[Hindi|Hindi]]-language film directed by V. Sai Prasad and produced by M.C. Bokadia, starring [[Vijayashanti|Vijayashanti]], [[Raj Babbar|Raj Babbar]] and [[Gulshan Grover|Gulshan Grover]] with [[Dharmendra|Dharmendra]] in a supporting role. It did very bad at the box office and was a major flop suffering extremely huge and heavy losses, but its songs, especially "Bahar Baras Raha Hai Pani", composed by [[Jatin Lalit|Jatin Lalit]] were huge hits. The film was dubbed in Telugu as Gunda Darbar and in Tamil as Thalaivi.
title: Gundagardi

abstract: Action Man: Robot Atak is a 2004 [[direct-to-DVD|direct-to-DVD]] [[CGI|Computer-generated imagery]] animated film based on the [[Hasbro|Hasbro]] toy line, [[Action Man|Action Man (1993-2006 toyline)]]. The film was made by Arcana Digital and directed by John Moffett, Steven Burch and Chris Woods. Produced to tie-in with the line of Action Man toys released in 2004, Robot Atak was the first in a trilogy of direct-to-video films and was followed by a sequel in 2005, Action Man: X Missions - The Movie.
title: Action Man: Robot Atak

abstract: Pédale douce is a 1996 French [[comedy film|comedy film]] directed by [[Gabriel Aghion|Gabriel Aghion]]. [[Fanny Ardant|Fanny Ardant]] won the 1997 [[César Award for Best Actress|César Award for Best Actress]] for her performance as Eva.
title: Pédale douce

abstract: For Marjory Stoneman Douglas's 1947 non-fiction book about the Florida Everglades, see [[The Everglades: River of Grass|The Everglades: River of Grass]]River of Grass (1994) is the debut film of American director [[Kelly Reichardt|Kelly Reichardt]], who also wrote the screenplay. It was selected for the [[Sundance Film Festival|Sundance Film Festival]] and the [[Berlin International Film Festival|Berlin International Film Festival]], and was nominated for the Sundance Grand Jury Prize in 1994, and for three [[Independent Spirit Awards|Independent Spirit Awards]] in 1996.
title: River of Grass

abstract: Fast & Furious 6 was in development by February 2010 as the first film in the series to move away from the underground car-racing theme of the series' previous films which was considered to have placed a barrier on audience numbers. Pre-production had begun by April 2011, and [[principal photography|principal photography]] began in London, England in July 2012. Filming locations also included the [[Canary Islands|Canary Islands]], Glasgow, and Los Angeles. The film was first released in the United Kingdom, on May 17, 2013, followed by an international release on May 24, 2013. A [[sequel|Furious 7]] was released on April 3, 2015.
title: Fast & Furious 6

abstract: Shasti (; ''Punishment'') is a [[Bangladesh|Bangladeshi]] [[Bengali-language|Bengali-language]] film. It is the film presented by [[HSBC Bank Bangladesh|HSBC Bank Bangladesh]]. It was released in 2004 all over Bangladesh.
title: Shasti

abstract: The Essential Daffy Duck is a DVD set featuring cartoons focusing on [[Daffy Duck|Daffy Duck]]. It was released on November 1, 2011.
title: The Essential Daffy Duck

abstract: Or Iravu () is a 1951 [[Tamil language|Tamil language]] film produced by [[AVM Productions|AVM Productions]]. It was based on the play of the same name written by [[C. N. Annadurai|C. N. Annadurai]] (later chief minister of [[Tamil Nadu|Tamil Nadu]]).
title: Or Iravu

abstract: Blessings of the Land () is a 1959 Filipino [[drama film|drama film]] directed by [[Manuel Silos|Manuel Silos]]. It was entered into the [[10th Berlin International Film Festival|10th Berlin International Film Festival]]. The film won Best Picture and Best Story from the [[Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences|Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences]]. In 1960, it was shown at the [[Asian Film Festival|Asian Film Festival]] held in Tokyo. The story was written by [[Celso Al. Carunungan|Celso Al. Carunungan]], while the screenplay was written by Carunungan together with [[Pablo Naval|Pablo Naval]]. The movie was produced by [[LVN Pictures|LVN Pictures]].
title: Blessings of the Land

abstract: Meleparambil Anveedu (English:The All-Male House of Meleparambil) is a 1993 Indian [[Malayalam|Malayalam]]-language [[romantic|Romance film]] [[comedy film|comedy film]] directed by [[Rajasenan|Rajasenan]] and scripted by [[Raghunath Paleri|Raghunath Paleri]] from a story by [[Gireesh Puthenchery|Gireesh Puthenchery]]. The film stars [[Jayaram|Jayaram]] and [[Shobana|Shobana]], along with [[Narendra Prasad|Narendra Prasad]], [[Meena|Meena (Malayalam actress)]], [[Jagathy Sreekumar|Jagathy Sreekumar]], [[Janardanan|Janardanan (actor)]], [[Vijayaraghavan|Vijayaraghavan (actor)]], [[Oduvil Unnikrishnan|Oduvil Unnikrishnan]], and [[Vinu Chakravarthy|Vinu Chakravarthy]]. The film was produced and distributed by [[Mani C. Kappan|Mani C. Kappan]].
title: Meleparambil Anveedu

abstract: Kurukkante Kalyanam (English: The Fox's Marriage) is a 1982 [[Malayalam film|Malayalam film]]. The film dwells on love that transcends age barriers. It is about a shy, timid, and introverted Sivasubrahmania Hariramachandran ([[Sukumaran|Sukumaran]]) who falls head over heels for the petite and spunky Saritha ([[Madhavi|Madhavi (actress)]]), regardless of an age difference of 14 years. The film was the directional debut of [[Sathyan Anthikad|Sathyan Anthikad]]. It was written by Dr. P. Balakrishnan.
title: Kurukkante Kalyanam

abstract: Weekend Pass is a [[1984|1984 in film]] [[comedy film|comedy film]] written and directed by Lawrence Bassoff, based on a story by Mark Tenser.
title: Weekend Pass

abstract: Farsighted for Two Diopters ( / Dva Dioptara Dalekogledstvo) is a 1976 Bulgarian comedy film directed by [[Petar B. Vasilev|Petar B. Vasilev]] and written by [[Mormarevi Brothers|Mormarevi Brothers]]. The film stars [[Georgi Partsalev|Georgi Partsalev]], [[Dimitar Panov|Dimitar Panov]], [[Sashka Bratanova|Sashka Bratanova]], [[Ivan Obretenov|Ivan Obretenov]] and [[Valentin Gadzhokov|Valentin Gadzhokov]].
title: Farsighted for Two Diopters

abstract: Aadhaaram is a 1992 [[Malayalam film|Malayalam film]] directed by George Kithu, written by [[Lohithadas|Lohithadas]], and starring [[Murali|Murali (Malayalam actor)]], [[Suresh Gopi|Suresh Gopi]], [[Geetha|Geetha (actress)]], and Sudheesh. The film was well received in the box office. Murali received a [[Kerala State Film Award for Best Actor|Kerala State Film Award for Best Actor]] for this film, and after this success he was offered more lead roles in films.
title: Aadhaaram

abstract: Certain Chapters is a short independent Tamil-Language film released in [[Singapore|Singapore]].
title: Certain Chapters

abstract: Vasantha Maligai () is a 1972 [[Tamil-language|Tamil language]] [[romance film|romance film]], directed by [[K. S. Prakash Rao|Kovelamudi Surya Prakash Rao]] and produced by [[D. Ramanaidu|D. Ramanaidu]]. The film stars [[Sivaji Ganesan|Sivaji Ganesan]] and [[Vanisri|Vanisri]], and is a remake of the 1971 [[Telugu|Telugu language]] film [[Prema Nagar|Prema Nagar]].
title: Vasantha Maligai

abstract: Tata Manavadu is a 1973 Telugu film, directed by [[Dasari Narayana Rao|Dasari Narayana Rao]] (debut). This is the first film as a hero for comedian [[Raja Babu|Raja Babu (actor)]], who was paired with actress [[Vijaya Nirmala|Vijaya Nirmala]]. The film won the [[Nandi Award for Best Feature Film|Nandi Award for Best Feature Film]] and ran for 25 weeks in theaters. This film was later remade in Kannada as [[Maga Mommaga|Maga Mommaga]] with [[Dwarakish|Dwarakish]] and in Hindi as [[Suntan|Suntan (1976 film)]].
title: Tata Manavadu

abstract: Ammayane Sathyam ([[English|English language]]: I Swear on my Mother) is a 1993 [[Malayalam film|Malayalam film]] written and directed by [[Balachandra Menon|Balachandra Menon]]. The film stars [[Mukesh|Mukesh (actor)]], [[Annie|Annie (actress)]], [[Balachandra Menon|Balachandra Menon]], [[Narendra Prasad|Narendra Prasad]], [[Jagathy Sreekumar|Jagathy Sreekumar]], [[Ganesh Kumar|K. B. Ganesh Kumar]], [[Thilakan|Thilakan]], [[K. P. A. C. Lalitha|K. P. A. C. Lalitha]], Paravoor Bharathan, Prem Kumar, and Mammukoya. Balachendra Menon remade the film in Tamil as [[Kandaen Seethayae|Kandaen Seethayae]], however the project was later shelved. He also introduced actress Annie through this film.
title: Ammayane Sathyam

abstract: MLA Fatakeshto is a [[2006|2006 in film]] [[Bengali-language|Cinema of West Bengal]] [[Indian|Cinema of India]] [[political drama|political drama]] [[film|feature film]] [[directed|Film director]] by [[Swapan Saha|Swapan Saha]] for [[Shree Venkatesh Films|Shree Venkatesh Films]], starring [[Mithun Chakraborty|Mithun Chakraborty]], [[Debashree Roy|Debashree Roy]], [[Koel Mallick|Koel Mallick]], [[Rajatava Dutta|Rajatava Dutta]] and [[Soumitra Chatterjee|Soumitra Chatterjee]].
title: MLA Fatakeshto

abstract: Submarino premiered in the main competition of the [[60th Berlin International Film Festival|60th Berlin International Film Festival]]. The film won the 2010 [[Nordic Council Film Prize|Nordic Council Film Prize]]. It was met by positive reviews in Denmark and has been nominated for 15 [[Robert Award|Robert Awards]].
title: Submarino

abstract: Safari 3000 is a 1982 film directed by [[Harry Hurwitz|Harry Hurwitz]] and starring [[David Carradine|David Carradine]], [[Stockard Channing|Stockard Channing]], and [[Christopher Lee|Christopher Lee]]. The film was shot on location in Africa.
title: Safari 3000

abstract: The Masked Gang: Iraq () is a 2007 Turkish [[comedy film|comedy film]], directed by [[Murat Aslan|Murat Aslan (filmmaker)]], about an incompetent gang of criminals attempting to capture an oil installation in northern Iraq in order divert the oil to Turkey. The film, which went on general release across Turkey on , was the third highest-grossing [[Turkish film of 2007|Turkish films of 2007]]. It is a sequel to [[The Masked Gang|The Masked Gang]] (2005) and was followed by [[The Masked Gang: Cyprus|The Masked Gang: Cyprus]] (2008).
title: The Masked Gang: Iraq

abstract: Source Code is a 2011 [[science fiction|science fiction film]] [[thriller film|thriller film]] directed by [[Duncan Jones|Duncan Jones]] and written by [[Ben Ripley|Ben Ripley]]. It stars [[Jake Gyllenhaal|Jake Gyllenhaal]] as a [[U.S. Army|U.S. Army]] captain who is sent into a computed reality to find a bomber. [[Michelle Monaghan|Michelle Monaghan]], [[Vera Farmiga|Vera Farmiga]], and [[Jeffrey Wright|Jeffrey Wright (actor)]] play supporting roles. The film had its world premiere on March 11, 2011 at [[South by Southwest|South by Southwest]], and was released by [[Summit Entertainment|Summit Entertainment]] on April 1, 2011 in North America and Europe.
title: Source Code

abstract: January Oru Orma is a [[1987|Malayalam films of 1987]] [[Indian|Cinema of India]] [[Malayalam|Malayalam language]] film, directed by [[Joshiy|Joshiy]]. The film stars [[Mohanlal|Mohanlal]], [[Suresh Gopi|Suresh Gopi]], [[Karthika|Karthika (actress)]] and [[Jayabharathi|Jayabharathi]] in lead roles. The film had musical score by [[Ouseppachan|Ouseppachan]].
title: January Oru Orma

abstract: Daayraa ([[translation|translation]]: The Square Circle) is a 1996 [[Bollywood|Bollywood]] film, directed by [[Amol Palekar|Amol Palekar]], starring [[Nirmal Pandey|Nirmal Pandey]] and [[Sonali Kulkarni|Sonali Kulkarni]]. The screenplay was by award-winning journalist and novelist, [[Timeri N. Murari|Timeri N. Murari]]. Exploring themes such as male-female relationships, preconceived notions of love, and social attitudes toward them, the plot involves a romantic relationship between a [[transvestite|Transvestism]] dancer and a [[gang raped|gang raped]] woman who begins to dress up like a man. Due to its sensitive themes, the film was not released theatrically in India. The film was the first in Palekar's trilogy on sexuality; [[Anahat|Anahat (film)]] (2003) and [[Thaang|Quest (2006 film)]] (2006) followed it.
title: Daayraa

abstract: Rise of the Planet of the Apes was released on August 5, 2011, to critical and commercial success. The film was nominated for an [[Academy Award|Academy Award]] for [[Best Visual Effects|Academy Award for Best Visual Effects]]. It was also nominated for five [[Saturn Awards|Saturn Awards]] including [[Best Director|Saturn Award for Best Director]] for Wyatt and [[Best Writing|Saturn Award for Best Writing]] for Jaffa and Silver, winning [[Best Science Fiction Film|Saturn Award for Best Science Fiction Film]], [[Best Supporting Actor|Saturn Award for Best Supporting Actor]] for Serkis and [[Best Special Effects|Saturn Award for Best Special Effects]]. Serkis's performance as [[Caesar|Caesar (Planet of the Apes)]] was widely acclaimed, earning him many nominations from associations which do not usually recognize [[performance capture|Motion capture]] as traditional acting.
title: Rise of the Planet of the Apes

abstract: Griff the Invisible is a 2010 Australian romantic [[comedy-drama film|comedy-drama film]] written and directed by [[Leon Ford|Leon Ford]].
title: Griff the Invisible

abstract: Nilaavinte Naattil is a 1986 [[Malayalam film|Malayalam film]] directed by [[Vijay Menon|Vijay Menon]] starring [[Prem Nazir|Prem Nazir]], [[Seema|Seema (actress)]], [[Bharath Gopi|Bharath Gopi]], [[Lalu Alex|Lalu Alex]] and [[M. G. Soman|M. G. Soman]]. The movie deals with the feelings of a young girl who is alone in a big lonely house at night and left with no other options than being seduced into [[sex|Sexual intercourse]] by a stranger.
title: Nilaavinte Naattil

abstract: The film received critical praise and good reviews. M. T. Vasudevan Nair's script, which made use of [[Valluvanadan|Valluvanad (southern Malabar)]] dialect, was well appreciated and is accepted to be one of the finest ever. Later, M. T. and A. Vincent went on to create some of the memorable films in Malayalam film history. The film is also known for the powerful performance of Prem Nazir as Balan, the lead character of the film. [[The Hindu|The Hindu]] described Murappennu as "a well-made film with a compelling plot" and as "one of the most significant films in the history of Malayalam cinema". It was a box office superhit. It received a certificate of merit at the [[National Film Awards|National Film Awards]].
title: Murappennu

abstract: Dabangg 2 is a 2012 Indian [[action comedy|action film]] film directed and produced by [[Arbaaz Khan|Arbaaz Khan]] under the banner of Arbaaz Khan Productions. It is a sequel to the 2010 film [[Dabangg|Dabangg]] and the second installment of [[Dabangg film series|Dabangg (film series)]]. It is written by Dilip Shukla. The story is set in the city of [[Kanpur|Kanpur]]. The film features [[Salman Khan|Salman Khan]] and [[Sonakshi Sinha|Sonakshi Sinha]] reprising their roles from the previous film, while [[Prakash Raj|Prakash Raj]] plays the antagonist.
title: Dabangg 2

abstract: Palangal is a 1981 [[Malayalam|Malayalam]] film written by [[John Paul Puthusery|John Paul Puthusery]] story by Manih Mohamed and directed by [[Bharathan|Bharathan]] starring [[Nedumudi Venu|Nedumudi Venu]], [[Zarina Wahab|Zarina Wahab]], [[Bharath Gopi|Bharath Gopi]] and [[Shankar|Shankar (actor)]]. Film's plot is a love story of a man who works in railway lines and a woman who lost his lover in railway lines. Majority of the film was shot in Shornur due to the persistence of Bharathan as he always wants to hear the siren of the trains in the whole film. Coal engine was used in those periods in train and engines were brought from Madras for shooting this film.
title: Palangal

abstract: Manonmani () is a 1942 [[Tamil-language|Tamil-language]] film directed by [[T. R. Sundaram|T. R. Sundaram]]. It starred [[P. U. Chinnappa|P. U. Chinnappa]], [[T. R. Rajakumari|T. R. Rajakumari]], Serukalathur Sama, [[T. S. Balaiah|T. S. Balaiah]], [[T. R. Mahalingam|T. R. Mahalingam (actor)]], K. K. Perumal, A. Sakunthala, [[N. S. Krishnan|N. S. Krishnan]], [[T. A. Madhuram|T. A. Madhuram]], Kali N. Ratnam, L. Narayana Rao, S. S. Kokko, C. T. Rajakantham, P. R. Mangalam, P. G. Venkatesan, T. R. B. Rao, M. E. Madhavan, "Buffoon" Shanmugham, J. M. G. Sarada and G. Saraswathi.
title: Manonmani

abstract: Christmas in Paradise is a 2007 [[Lifetime|Lifetime (TV network)]] television [[Christmas|Christmas]] movie which originally aired on December 15, 2007. Starring [[Charlotte Ross|Charlotte Ross]], [[Colin Ferguson|Colin Ferguson (actor)]], [[Devon Werkheiser|Devon Werkheiser]], [[Josie Loren|Josie Loren]], [[Kenton Duty|Kenton Duty]] and [[Aria Wallace|Aria Wallace]], the film tells the story of two families who find companionship during a [[Caribbean|Caribbean]] Christmas holiday, only to have their idyllic vacation disrupted by an unexpected visitor from the past. The movie was filmed entirely on location on the island of [[Puerto Rico|Puerto Rico]] in 2007, and has subsequently been rebroadcast on Lifetime every year during the holiday season as an annual [[Christmas film|Christmas films]].
title: Christmas in Paradise

abstract: Sri Naga Shakthi is a 2011 released [[Kannada film|Kannada film]] starring [[Shruthi|Shruti (actress)]] and [[Ramkumar|Ramkumar]] in the lead roles. The film has been directed and written by Om Sai Prakash. Actress Chandrika has produced the film under her home banner. The film has been in the cans for many years and has finally released on 7 January 2011.
title: Sri Naga Shakthi

abstract: Jhoothi Shaan is a 1991 [[India|Indian]] film starring [[Mithun Chakraborty|Mithun Chakraborty]] and [[Poonam Dhillon|Poonam Dhillon]] along with [[Shabana Azmi|Shabana Azmi]].
title: Jhoothi Shaan

abstract: Olympiyan Anthony Adam is a 1999 Indian [[Malayalam|Malayalam]] [[action|Action film]] [[thriller|Thriller (genre)]] film written and directed by [[Bhadran|Bhadran (director)]], starring [[Mohanlal|Mohanlal]], [[Meena|Meena Durairaj]], and [[Nassar|Nassar]]. It was produced by Mohanlal for [[Pranavam Arts|Pranavam Arts International]], and was one of the costliest films made in Malayalam up to that point. It had a large opening at the box office.
title: Olympiyan Anthony Adam

abstract: Once Upon a Time in Anatolia () is a 2011 internationally co-produced drama film, co-written and directed by [[Nuri Bilge Ceylan|Nuri Bilge Ceylan]] based on the true experience of one of the film's writers, telling the story of a group of men who search for a dead body on the [[Anatolia|Anatolian]] steppe. The film, which went on nationwide general release across Turkey on , premiered at the [[2011 Cannes Film Festival|2011 Cannes Film Festival]] where it was a co-winner of the [[Grand Prix|Grand Prix (Cannes Film Festival)]].
title: Once Upon a Time in Anatolia

abstract: Mr. Marumakan () is a 2012 [[Malayalam|Malayalam]]-language [[comedy-drama|comedy-drama]] film written by the duo [[Udayakrishna-Siby K. Thomas|Udayakrishna-Siby K. Thomas]] and directed by Sandhya Mohan. The movie stars [[Dileep|Dileep]] and [[Sanusha|Sanusha]] in the lead roles and [[Bhagyaraj|Bhagyaraj]], [[Khushboo|Kushboo Sundar]], [[Sheela|Sheela]], [[Biju Menon|Biju Menon]], [[Nedumudi Venu|Nedumudi Venu]] and [[Riyaz Khan|Riyaz Khan]] in supporting roles.
title: Mr. Marumakan

abstract: Rhythm Is It! is a [[2004|2004 in film]] German [[documentary film|documentary film]] directed by [[Thomas Grube|Thomas Grube]] and [[Enrique Sánchez Lansch|Enrique Sánchez Lansch]]. The film documents a project undertaken by the [[Berlin Philharmonic|Berlin Philharmonic]] principal conductor [[Simon Rattle|Simon Rattle]] and choreographer [[Royston Maldoom|Royston Maldoom]] who decided to popularize classical music by staging a performance of [[Igor Stravinsky|Igor Stravinsky]]'s ballet [[The Rite of Spring|The Rite of Spring]] with a cast of 250 children recruited from Berlin's public schools.
title: Rhythm Is It!

abstract: Manal Kayiru (English: Sand Rope) is a 1982 Tamil movie directed by Visu. It was remade in Kannada as [[Savira Sullu|Savira Sullu]] and in Malayalam as [[Thiruthalvaadi|Thiruthalvaadi]].
title: Manal Kayiru

abstract: Akkare Ninnoru Maran (മലയാളം:അക്കരെ നിന്നൊരു മാരന്‍) is a [[1985|Malayalam films of 1985]] [[Indian|Cinema of India]] [[Malayalam|Malayalam language]] film, directed by Girish and produced by Sanal Kumar and G Suresh Kumar. The film stars [[Maniyanpilla Raju|Maniyanpilla Raju]], [[Menaka|Menaka (actress)]], [[Sukumari|Sukumari]] and [[Innocent|Innocent (actor)]] in lead roles. The film had musical score by Rajamani and songs by [[Kannur Rajan|Kannur Rajan]].
title: Akkare Ninnoru Maran

abstract: Dui Duari the film special honored is [[Riaz|Riaz (Actor)]] and most popular singer Sabina Yasmin by National Film Awards of Bangladesh as there won best actor award and best female singer award 2000. [[Riaz|Riaz (Actor)]] acting a different character as Rahossa Manob.
title: Dui Duari

abstract: Jamai Shashur also ( or meaning of ) is a [[Bangladesh|Bangladeshi]] [[Bengali-language|Bengali-language]] [[film|film]]. Released in Bangladesh on 2003 Directed by Shahdat Khan. It was a comedy plot based on the relationship of a father in law with son in law. The story written by Abdullah Zahir Babu and Shah Rashidul Hossain Farhad. The film was a super-hit in the box office. The film is a remake of the 1998 [[Telugu|Telugu language]] movie [[Bavagaru Bagunnara|Bavagaru Bagunnara?]] which starred [[Chiranjeevi|Chiranjeevi]] & [[Rambha|Rambha (actress)]].
title: Jamai Shashur

abstract: Sandhyakku Virinja Poovu () is a 1983 [[Malayalam film|Malayalam film]] written by [[Thoppil Bhasi|Thoppil Bhasi]] and directed by [[P. G. Viswambharan|P. G. Viswambharan]]. [[Seema|Seema (actress)]], [[Mammootty|Mammootty]], [[Adoor Bhasi|Adoor Bhasi]], [[Shankar|Shankar (actor)]] and [[Mohanlal|Mohanlal]] play the major roles.
title: Sandhyakku Virinja Poovu

abstract: Badle Ki Aag ([[English|English language]]: Flames of Revenge, ;) is a [[1982|Bollywood films of 1982]] [[Indian|Bollywood]] [[action|Action film]] [[thriller|Thriller film]] film, produced and directed by [[Rajkumar Kohli|Rajkumar Kohli]] under the Shankar Movies banner. It stars [[Sunil Dutt|Sunil Dutt]], [[Dharmendra|Dharmendra]], [[Jeetendra|Jeetendra]], [[Reena Roy|Reena Roy]] and [[Smita Patil|Smita Patil]] in lead roles and music was composed by [[Laxmikant-Pyarelal|Laxmikant-Pyarelal]]. Badle Ki Aag was a box-office success.
title: Badle Ki Aag

abstract: Sadaa Suhagan is a 1986 [[Bollywood|Bollywood]] [[drama film|drama film]], produced by Vijay Soorma, Rajeev Kumar on Vidya Shree Films banner and directed by [[Tatineni Rama Rao|Tatineni Rama Rao]]. The film is remake of [[Tamil|Tamil language]] Movie [[Dheerga Sumangali|Dheerga Sumangali]] (1974).

abstract: Nithyakanyaka is a 1963 Indian [[Malayalam|Malayalam]]-language film, directed by [[K. S. Sethumadhavan|K. S. Sethumadhavan]] and produced by A. K. Balasubrahmaniam. The film stars [[Sathyan|Sathyan (actor)]], [[Ragini|Ragini (actress)]], [[Thikkurissi Sukumaran Nair|Thikkurissi Sukumaran Nair]] and [[Ambika|Ambika Sukumaran]] in the lead roles. The film had musical score by [[G. Devarajan|G. Devarajan]]. This film is based on [[Edhir Paradhathu|Edhir Paradhathu]] (1954), directed by [[Chitrapu Narayana Rao|Chitrapu Narayana Rao]].
title: Nithyakanyaka

abstract: Ninamaninja Kalpadukal (Bloodstained Footprints) is a 1963 [[Malayalam language|Malayalam language]] film, directed by [[N. N. Pisharody|N. N. Pisharody]] and produced by Shobhana Parameswaran Nair. The lead role is played by [[Prem Nazir|Prem Nazir]], with [[Ambika|Ambika Sukumaran]], [[Sheela|Sheela]] and [[Madhu|Madhu (actor)]], who debuted with this film. The film is based on a novel by [[Parappurath|Parappurath]] and portrays the trials the Indo-China war. It won the [[National Film Award for Best Feature Film in Malayalam|National Film Award for Best Feature Film in Malayalam]]. It was a super hit movie. The movie shattered all box office records, becoming the first Malayalam movie to gross 60 lakhs at the box office.[1]
title: Ninamaninja Kalpadukal

abstract: Mooladhanam (, translation: [[Capital|Capital (economics)]]) is a [[1969|Malayalam films of 1969]] [[Indian|Cinema of India]] [[Malayalam|Malayalam language]] film, directed by [[P. Bhaskaran|P. Bhaskaran]] and produced by M. Azim. The film stars [[Prem Nazir|Prem Nazir]], [[Sathyan|Sathyan (actor)]], [[Sharada|Sharada (actress)]] and [[Jayabharathi|Jayabharathi]] in the lead roles. The film had musical score by [[G. Devarajan|G. Devarajan]]. The film is set amidst the Communist movement in Kerala during the 1960s.

Shekhar]].

The film stars [[Madhu|Madhu (actor)]], [[Sharada|Sharada (actress)]], [[Sukumari|Sukumari]] and [[KPAC Lalitha|KPAC Lalitha]] in the lead roles. The film had musical score by [[A. T. Ummer|A. T. Ummer]].
