The film stars [[Adeel Hussain|Adeel Hussain]], [[Mahira Khan|Mahira Khan]], [[Sheheryar Munawar|Sheheryar Munawar]] and [[Sonya Jehan|Sonya Jehan]], along with veterans [[Bushra Ansari|Bushra Ansari]], [[Kainat Saleem|Kainat Saleem]], [[Arshad Mahmud|Arshad Mehmood (composer)]], [[Jamal Shah|Jamal Shah]] and Munawar Siddiqui. It is produced in Urdu.
title: Ho Mann Jahaan

abstract: Chauraha (English:Crossroads) is a [[1994|Bollywood films of 1994]] [[Bollywood|Bollywood]] [[Action film|Action film]], produced by Pradeep Shirodkar under the Revathi Films banner and directed by Sadaqat Hussain. It stars [[Jeetendra|Jeetendra]], [[Jaya Prada|Jaya Prada]], [[Jackie Shroff|Jackie Shroff]], [[Ashwini Bhave|Ashwini Bhave]] in pivotal roles and music composed by [[Laxmikant Pyarelal|Laxmikant Pyarelal]].
title: Chauraha

abstract: Crossroads Guitar Festival 2013 is a music [[DVD|DVD]], [[concert film|concert film]] and eleventh [[live album|live album]] by the [[British|United Kingdom]] [[rock musician|rock musician]] [[Eric Clapton|Eric Clapton]] and was released on November 18, 2013 through [[Warner Bros. Records|Warner Bros. Records]]. It features recordings by various artists that performed during the [[Crossroads Guitar Festival 2013|Crossroads Guitar Festival]]. The release reached international album, DVD and Blu-ray charts and was certified by various organisations with gold and platinum awards.
title: Crossroads Guitar Festival 2013

abstract: The Long Falling () is a 2011 French-Belgian [[drama film|drama film]] written and directed by [[Martin Provost|Martin Provost]].
title: The Long Falling

abstract: Bad Moms is a 2016 American [[comedy film|comedy film]] directed and written by [[Jon Lucas|Jon Lucas]] and [[Scott Moore|Scott Moore (screenwriter)]]. The film stars an [[ensemble cast|ensemble cast]] that includes [[Mila Kunis|Mila Kunis]], [[Christina Applegate|Christina Applegate]], [[Kristen Bell|Kristen Bell]], [[Kathryn Hahn|Kathryn Hahn]], [[Jay Hernandez|Jay Hernandez]], [[Annie Mumolo|Annie Mumolo]], and [[Jada Pinkett Smith|Jada Pinkett Smith]].
title: Bad Moms

abstract: The Greatest Showman is a 2017 American [[musical film|musical film]] directed by [[Michael Gracey|Michael Gracey]] in his directorial debut, written by [[Jenny Bicks|Jenny Bicks]] and [[Bill Condon|Bill Condon]] and starring [[Hugh Jackman|Hugh Jackman]], [[Zac Efron|Zac Efron]], [[Michelle Williams|Michelle Williams (actress)]], [[Rebecca Ferguson|Rebecca Ferguson]], and [[Zendaya|Zendaya]]. The film is inspired by the story of [[P. T. Barnum|P. T. Barnum]]'s creation of the [[Barnum & Bailey Circus|Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey Circus]] and the lives of its star attractions.
title: The Greatest Showman

abstract: Les Yeux jaunes des crocodiles () is a 2014 French [[drama film|drama film]] directed by Cécile Telerman and based on the best-selling novel Les Yeux jaunes des crocodiles by [[Katherine Pancol|Katherine Pancol]]. The film stars [[Julie Depardieu|Julie Depardieu]], [[Emmanuelle Béart|Emmanuelle Béart]], [[Alice Isaaz|Alice Isaaz]] and [[Jacques Weber|Jacques Weber]].
title: Les Yeux jaunes des crocodiles

abstract: Chhoti Bahoo [English: Youngest Daughter-in-law] is a [[1994|Bollywood films of 1994]] Hindi family drama film directed by M. M. Baig. The film stars [[Deepak Tijori|Deepak Tijori]] and [[Shilpa Shirodkar|Shilpa Shirodkar]] in the lead roles.
title: Chhoti Bahoo

abstract: Shoot Me in the Heart () is a 2015 South Korean [[drama film|drama film]] directed by [[Mun Che-yong|Mun Che-yong]], and starring [[Lee Min-ki|Lee Min-ki]] and [[Yeo Jin-goo|Yeo Jin-goo]]. It is [[based|film adaptation]] on the bestselling novel of the same name by Jeong Yu-jeong, which won the Segye Literature Award in 2009.
title: Shoot Me in the Heart

abstract: Gowri Kalyanam (English: The Marriage of Gowri) is a 1966 Indian [[Tamil language|Tamil language]] film, directed by [[K. Shankar|K. Shankar]] and produced by G. V. Saravanan. The film stars [[Jaishankar|Jaishankar]], [[Jayalalithaa|Jayalalithaa]], [[Ravichandran|Ravichandran (actor)]], [[Sheela|Sheela]] and [[Nagesh|Nagesh]] in lead roles. The film had musical score by [[M. S. Viswanathan|M. S. Viswanathan]].
title: Gowri Kalyanam

abstract: My Blind Heart is a film about Kurt ([[Christos Haas|Christos Haas]]), a 29-year-old marine biologist who suffers from the rare disease [[Marfan syndrome|Marfan syndrome]], which makes him almost blind as well as giving him a very peculiar appearance. After his dream of working at a Shark School is shattered, Kurt kills his mother ([[Susanne Lothar|Susanne Lothar]]), with whom he has a suffocating relationship and sets out on a journey to rebel against his body and the limits society tries to set for him. A short stay at a care home results in chaos and him getting kicked out, and he ends up on the streets where he befriends 13-year-old runaway Conny ([[Jana McKinnon|Jana McKinnon]]). Conny becomes his partner in crime during his protesting actions, not knowing what Kurt's motives are. Finally, Kurt manages to use a former friend from the care home, Roberto ([[Robert Schmiedt|Robert Schmiedt]]), to help him achieve his ultimate goal.
title: My Blind Heart

abstract: Khoon Ka Khoon was a "filmed version of a stage performance of the play" with Sohrab Modi as Hamlet and Naseem Banu as Ophelia. The film has been cited by [[National Film Archive of India|National Film Archive of India]] founder P K. Nair, as one of "21 most wanted missing Indian cinema treasures".
title: Khoon Ka Khoon

abstract: Anbu Karangal is a [[1965|Tamil films of 1965]] [[Indian|Cinema of India]] [[Tamil|Tamil language]] film, directed by [[K. Shankar|K. Shankar]] and produced by N. Periannana. The film stars [[Sivaji Ganesan|Sivaji Ganesan]], [[Devika|Devika]], [[K. Balaji|K. Balaji]] and [[Nagesh|Nagesh]] in lead roles. The film had musical score by R. Sudarsanam.
title: Anbu Karangal

abstract: Ulagam Pirandhadhu Enakkaga () is a 1990 Indian [[Tamil|Tamil language]] film, directed by [[S. P. Muthuraman|S. P. Muthuraman]] and produced by AVM. Saravanan and AVM. Balasubramanian. The film stars [[Sathyaraj|Sathyaraj]], [[Gautami|Gautami]], [[Rupini|Rupini]] and [[Saranya|Saranya Ponvannan]] in lead roles. The film had musical score by [[R. D. Burman|R. D. Burman]].
title: Ulagam Pirandhadhu Enakkaga

abstract: Scammerhead is a 2015 Canadian [[comedy film|comedy film]] directed by Dan Zukovic, in which a scam-artist attempts to successfully execute his most elaborate scam to date. The film stars Alex Rocco, Bruce Glover and Dan Zukovic.
title: Scammerhead

abstract: Parched is a 2015 Indian [[drama film|drama film]] written and directed by [[Leena Yadav|Leena Yadav]] and produced by [[Ajay Devgan|Ajay Devgan]] under his banner [[Ajay Devgn FFilms|Ajay Devgn FFilms]]. It premiered at the Special Presentations section of the [[2015 Toronto International Film Festival|2015 Toronto International Film Festival]]. In India, the film released on 23 September 2016.
title: Parched

abstract: MLB Showdown simulates [[baseball|baseball]] through a card game, with heavy randomness. It involves a 20-sided die and cards made specifically for the game. These cards were available in booster packs, a staple of collectible card games, as well as starter games and draft packs. There are two types of cards: player cards (current and former Major League players) and strategy cards (actions that can add to or subtract from die rolls, change results, draw extra cards, etc.)The outcome of an at-bat largely depends on the player cards. The player whose pitcher is pitching that turn rolls a die to determine whether the batting player rolls on the pitcher's chart or the batter's chart. Each of the two charts has a list of possible results from the at-bat.
title: MLB Showdown

abstract: The Lord of the Rings Strategy Battle Game (abbreviated to LotR SBG), previously marketed as The Hobbit: An Unexpected Journey Strategy Battle Game and The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug Strategy Battle Game and now as The Hobbit: The Battle of Five Armies Strategy Battle Game, is a [[tabletop miniature wargame|miniature wargaming]] produced by [[Games Workshop|Games Workshop]]. It is based on [[The Lord of the Rings film trilogy|The Lord of the Rings (film series)]] directed by [[Peter Jackson|Peter Jackson]], and [[the book that inspired it|The Lord of the Rings]], written by [[J. R. R. Tolkien|J. R. R. Tolkien]].
title: The Lord of the Rings Strategy Battle Game

abstract: Dark Millennium is an out-of-print [[collectible card game|collectible card game]]. It's the successor to the [[Horus Heresy|Horus Heresy (card game)]] and set in the fictional [[Warhammer 40,000|Warhammer 40,000]] universe. The base card set was launched in October 2005 by [[Sabertooth Games|Sabertooth Games]].
title: Dark Millennium

abstract: Dark Sun is an original [[Dungeons & Dragons|Dungeons & Dragons]] (D&D) [[campaign setting|campaign setting]] set in the fictional, post-apocalyptic [[desert world|fictional planet]] of Athas. Dark Sun featured an innovative [[metaplot|metaplot]], influential art work, dark themes, and a genre-bending take on traditional fantasy role-playing. The product line began with the original [[Dark Sun Boxed Set|Dark Sun Boxed Set]] released for D&D's [[2nd edition|AD&D 2nd Edition]] in 1991, originally ran until 1996, and was one of [[TSR|TSR (company)]]'s most successful releases.
title: Dark Sun

abstract: A major tenet of EuroShogi is simplification without radical changes, while maintaining good gameplay. The variant [[Heian shogi|Heian shogi]] with playing board 8×8 or 9×8 is the only shogi variant somewhat similar to EuroShogi; other variants are larger or smaller, have new units, or lack [[drops|Shogi#Drops]].
title: EuroShogi

abstract: Evolution: Random Mutations is a [[card game|card game]] created by Dmitriy Knorre and Sergey Machin in 2010. The game is inspired by the [[evolutionary biology|evolutionary biology]]. It was published by SIA Rightgames RBG. Publishing of the game was financed in Boomstarter. English, French and German game editions were published in 2014.
title: Evolution: Random Mutations

abstract: Boggle is a [[word game|word game]] designed by Bill Cooke, invented by Allan Turoff and originally distributed by [[Parker Brothers|Parker Brothers]]. The game is played using a plastic grid of lettered [[dice|dice]], in which players attempt to find words in sequences of adjacent letters.
title: Boggle

abstract: Axis & Allies is a series of [[World War II|World War II]] [[strategy|strategy game]] [[board game|board games]]. Originally designed by [[Larry Harris|Larry Harris (game designer)]] and published by Nova Game Designs in 1981, the game was republished by the [[Milton Bradley Company|Milton Bradley Company]] in 1984 as part of the [[Gamemaster Series|Gamemaster (board game series)]] of board games. This edition has been retroactively named Axis & Allies: Classic to differentiate it from later revisions. In 1996, Axis & Allies: Classic was inducted into the Academy of Adventure Gaming Arts & Design Adventure Gaming Hall of Fame. [[Games|GAMES Magazine]] magazine also has inducted Axis & Allies into their buyers' guide [[Hall of Fame|GAMES 100#Hall of Fame]], an honor the magazine extends to "games that have met or exceeded the highest standards of quality and play value and have been continuously in production for at least 10 years; i.e., classics."
title: Axis & Allies

abstract: Rail Baron is a [[railroad|railroad]] [[board game|board game]] for 3 to 6 players.
title: Rail Baron

abstract: The Lord of the Rings Trading Card Game (a.k.a. LOTR TCG) is an out-of-print [[collectible card game|collectible card game]] produced by [[Decipher, Inc.|Decipher, Inc.]] Released November [[2001|2001 in games]], it is based on [[Peter Jackson|Peter Jackson]]'s [[The Lord of the Rings|The Lord of the Rings (film series)]] film trilogy and the [[J. R. R. Tolkien|J. R. R. Tolkien]] novel on which the films were based. Decipher also had the rights to [[The Hobbit|The Hobbit]] novel but did not release any cards based on it. In addition to images taken from the films, in 2004 [[Weta Workshop|Weta Workshop]] produced artwork depicting characters and items from the novel absent from the films for use on cards.
title: The Lord of the Rings Trading Card Game

abstract: The Awful Green Things from Outer Space (AGTFOS) is a two-player board game developed and illustrated by [[Tom Wham|Tom Wham]]. It originally appeared as an insert in [[Dragon magazine|Dragon (magazine)]] #28 (1979), and subsequently as a boxed game published by [[TSR|TSR, Inc.]] in 1980. The rights to the game were subsequently acquired by [[Steve Jackson Games|Steve Jackson Games]], which resumed publication after the game had been out of print for some years. The game has gone through a number of revisions over the years, and both full-sized and smaller [[Pocket Box|Pocket Box]] editions exist.
title: The Awful Green Things from Outer Space

abstract: Monopoly Junior is a simplified version of the board game [[Monopoly|Monopoly (game)]], designed for young children. It has a rectangular board that is smaller than the standard game and rather than using street names it is based on a city's amusements (a zoo, a video game arcade, a pizzeria, etc.) to make the game more child-friendly.
title: Monopoly Junior

abstract: Daldøs [dal'd[[ø|ø]]] is a [[running-fight|Running-fight game]] [[board game|board game]] only known from a few coastal locations in southern [[Scandinavia|Scandinavia]], where its history can be traced back to around 1800. The game is notable for its unusual four-sided [[dice|dice]] (stick or [[long dice|long dice]]). In [[Denmark|Denmark]] it is known as daldøs in Northern and Western [[Jutland|Jutland]] ([[Mors|Mors (island)]], [[Thisted|Thisted]] and [[Fanø|Fanø]]), and possibly as daldos on [[Bornholm|Bornholm]]. In [[Norway|Norway]] it is known under the name of daldøsa from [[Jæren|Jæren]], where, unlike in Denmark, a continuous tradition of the daldøs game exists. Daldøs has much in common with some games in the [[sáhkku|sáhkku]] family of [[Sámi|Sámi]] board games. Sáhkku is known to have been played among Sámi on the northern coast and eastern-central inland of [[Sápmi|Sápmi]], far away from Jæren and Denmark. Otherwise, the closest relatives of this game appear to be the [[tâb|tâb]] games from Northern Africa and South-western Asia, possibly apart from one unlabelled diagram in a codex from Southern England.
title: Daldøs

abstract: The Ninth Age: Fantasy Battles (commonly abbreviated to The 9th Age or T9A) is a [[tabletop miniature wargame|Miniature wargaming]] created and updated since 2015 by the non-profit association The Ninth Age. It is designed for armies of 28 mm scale [[models|Miniature model (gaming)]] on square bases.
title: The Ninth Age: Fantasy Battles

abstract: WordCrex is a [[mobile app|mobile app]] similar to the famous word game [[Scrabble|Scrabble]] and Wordfeud. The [[iOS|iOS]]-version was released June 2, 2016 and the [[Android|Android (operating system)]]-version 8 september 2016. The game was presented as the first free fair word game challenge. WordCrex was developed by two Dutch creative friends [[Jelle Verwaijen|Jelle Verwaijen]] and [[Dimitri Dirkzwager|Dimitri Dirkzwager]]. It is different than most word games because the players use the same set of seven letters to form words. This way the luck factor of getting the right letters is not a decisive factor anymore. WordCrex is a [[multiplayer|Multiplayer game]] game. Games can be played with 2, 3 or 4 players per game.
title: WordCrex

abstract: Candy Land (also Candyland) is a simple [[racing|Race game]] [[board game|board game]] currently published by [[Hasbro|Hasbro]]. The game requires no reading and minimal counting skills, making it suitable for young children. Due to the design of the game, there is no strategy involved: players are never required to make choices, just follow directions. The winner is predetermined by the shuffle of the cards. A perennial favorite, the game sells about one million copies per year.
title: Candy Land

abstract: Reversi is a [[strategy|Abstract strategy game]] [[board game|board game]] for two players, played on an 8×8 uncheckered board. There are sixty-four identical game pieces called disks (often spelled "discs"), which are light on one side and dark on the other. Players take turns placing disks on the board with their assigned color facing up. During a play, any disks of the opponent's color that are in a straight line and bounded by the disk just placed and another disk of the current player's color are turned over to the current player's color.
title: Reversi

abstract: Arimaa was invented in 2003 by Omar Syed, an Indian-American computer engineer trained in [[artificial intelligence|artificial intelligence]]. Syed was inspired by [[Garry Kasparov's defeat at the hands of the chess computer Deep Blue|Deep Blue versus Garry Kasparov]] to design a new game which could be played with a standard chess set, would be difficult for computers to play well, but would have rules simple enough for his then four-year-old son Aamir to understand. ("Arimaa" is "Aamir" spelled backwards plus an initial "a".)
title: Arimaa

abstract: Terakh is a [[board game|board game]] produced by Stoneplay and originally released in 2005. The game is named after its Canadian inventors Terence Wong and Akhil Patel.
title: Terakh

abstract: Marvel Superstars is an out-of-print [[collectible card game|collectible card game]] published by [[Upper Deck|Upper Deck]] that released in North America in March 2010. The cards and game play are inspired by films based on [[Marvel Comics|Marvel Comics]] characters. It is the first collectible card game to use characters from Marvel films produced by different studios. The card art features scenes from the films.
title: Marvel Superstars

abstract: The My Little Pony Collectible Card Game (abbreviated as MLPCCG) is a two-player [[collectible card game|collectible card game]] based on the television show [[My Little Pony: Friendship Is Magic|My Little Pony: Friendship Is Magic]]. The game is produced by Enterplay LLC under license from [[Hasbro|Hasbro]], and follows from Enterplay's previous work to produce a trading card series based on the same show.
title: My Little Pony Collectible Card Game

abstract: Mansions of Madness is a tabletop strategy game designed by Corey Konieczka and published by [[Fantasy Flight Games|Fantasy Flight Games]] in 2011. Players explore a locale filled with [[Lovecraftian|H. P. Lovecraft]] horrors and solve a mystery.
title: Mansions of Madness

abstract: Circular chess is a [[chess variant|chess variant]] played using the standard set of pieces on a [[circular|Circle]] board consisting of four rings, each of sixteen squares. This is topologically equivalent to playing on the surface of a cylinder.
title: Circular chess

abstract: Tantrix is a hexagonal [[tile-based|Tile-based game]] [[abstract game|abstract game]] invented by Mike McManaway from [[New Zealand|New Zealand]]. Each of the 56 different tiles in the set contains three lines, going from one edge of the tile to another. No two lines on a tile have the same colour. There are four colours in the set: red, yellow, blue, and green. No two tiles are identical, and each is individually numbered from 1 through 56.
title: Tantrix

abstract: Dance Dance Revolution DVD Game is a 2006 [[DVD|DVD]]-based game in the [[Dance Dance Revolution series|Dance Dance Revolution]] (or DDR series) hosted by Roxee, a member of the [[Australian|Australian]] children's entertainment property, The Funkees. It is unique from other DDR games for a number of reasons. It was the first DDR game not to be developed by the creators of the original series, [[Konami|Konami]]. The only other non-Konami-developed DDR game is the [[Disney Channel Edition|Dance Dance Revolution Disney Channel Edition]]. To date it remains the only game neither developed nor published by Konami and, perhaps more significantly, it is the only game in the series which lacks input.
title: Dance Dance Revolution DVD Game

abstract: The Dungeons & Dragons Miniatures Game is a [[collectible miniatures game|collectible miniatures game]] played with pre-painted, plastic [[miniature figures|miniature figure (gaming)]] based on characters and monsters from the [[Dungeons & Dragons|Dungeons & Dragons]] game. The figures are 30mm in scale. Produced by [[Wizards of the Coast|Wizards of the Coast]], the Dungeons & Dragons Miniatures line is composed of 20 loosely themed sets that were released roughly every four months since the line was launched in 2003 until its cancellation in 2011.
title: Dungeons & Dragons Miniatures Game

abstract: The Song of Blades and Heroes core rules (currently Revised Fifth Edition 2012) was originally written and illustrated by Andrea Sfiligoi of [[Ganesha Games|Ganesha Games]] in 2007.
title: Song of Blades and Heroes

abstract: The Strange is set in modern-day Earth but allows a GM to take their stories through many different "recursions", worlds based frequently on literary creations.
title: The Strange

abstract: The Lord of the Rings: The Card Game is produced by [[Fantasy Flight Games|Fantasy Flight Games]]. It is a cooperative game set in the [[fantasy world|Middle-earth]] of [[JRR Tolkien|JRR Tolkien]]'s books. The initial time-frame for the game is the 17 years between Bilbo leaving the Shire and Frodo following him.
title: The Lord of the Rings: The Card Game

abstract: Earthdawn is a [[fantasy|fantasy]] [[role-playing game|role-playing game]], originally produced by [[FASA|FASA Corporation]] in 1993. In 1999 it was licensed to [[Living Room Games|Living Room Games]], which produced the Second Edition. It was licensed to [[RedBrick|RedBrick Limited]] in 2003, who released the Classic Edition in 2005 and the game's Third Edition in 2009 (the latter through [[Mongoose Publishing|Mongoose Publishing]]'s Flaming Cobra imprint). The license is now held (again) by FASA Corporation through FASA Games, Inc., who have released the Fourth Edition, with updated mechanics and an advanced metaplot timeline.The game is similar to fantasy games like [[Dungeons & Dragons|Dungeons & Dragons]], but draws more inspiration from games like [[RuneQuest|RuneQuest]]. The rules of the game are tightly bound to the underlying [[magical|magic (gaming)]] [[metaphysics|metaphysics]], with the goal of creating a rich, logical fantasy world. Like many role-playing games from the nineties, Earthdawn focuses much of its detail on its [[setting|Fantasy world]], a province called Barsaive.
title: Earthdawn

abstract: Cluedo (), known as Clue in [[North America|North America]], is a [[murder mystery game|murder mystery game]] for three to six players that was devised by [[Anthony E. Pratt|Anthony E. Pratt]] from [[Birmingham|Birmingham]], [[England|England]]. The game was first manufactured by [[Waddingtons|Waddingtons]] in the [[UK|UK]] in 1949. Since then, it has been relaunched and updated several times, and it is currently owned and published by the American game and toy company [[Hasbro|Hasbro]]. The object of the game is to determine who murdered the game's victim ("[[Dr. Black|Cluedo characters#Dr. Black/Mr. Boddy]]" in the UK version and "Mr. Boddy" in North American versions), where the crime took place, and which weapon was used. Each player assumes the role of one of the six suspects, and attempts to deduce the correct answer by strategically moving around a game board representing the rooms of a mansion and collecting clues about the circumstances of the murder from the other players.
title: Cluedo

abstract: After the successful launch of [[Wizards of the Coast|Wizards of the Coast]]'s Magic: The Gathering card game in 1993, [[TSR|TSR, Inc.]] entered the fledgling CCG market with their take on a fantasy-themed card game in June 1994. Spellfire was designed by [[Steve Winter|Steve Winter]], [[Jim Ward|Jim Ward (game designer)]], [[Dave Cook|David Cook (game designer)]], and [[Tim Brown|Timothy Brown (game designer)]].
title: Spellfire

abstract: Paul Bettany (born 27 May 1971) is an English actor. He is known for his voice role as [[J.A.R.V.I.S.|Edwin Jarvis#J.A.R.V.I.S.]] and as the [[Vision|Vision (Marvel Comics)]] in the [[Marvel Cinematic Universe|Marvel Cinematic Universe]], specifically the films [[Iron Man|Iron Man (2008 film)]] (2008), [[Iron Man 2|Iron Man 2]] (2010), [[The Avengers|The Avengers (2012 film)]] (2012), [[Iron Man 3|Iron Man 3]] (2013), [[Avengers: Age of Ultron|Avengers: Age of Ultron]] (2015), [[Captain America: Civil War|Captain America: Civil War]] (2016), [[Avengers: Infinity War|Avengers: Infinity War]] (2018), and [[Avengers: Endgame|Avengers: Endgame]] (2019). He first came to the attention of mainstream audiences when he appeared in the British film [[Gangster No. 1|Gangster No. 1]] (2000), and director [[Brian Helgeland|Brian Helgeland]]'s film [[A Knight's Tale|A Knight's Tale]] (2001). He has gone on to appear in a wide variety of films, including [[A Beautiful Mind|A Beautiful Mind (film)]] (2001), [[Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World|Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World]] (2003), [[Dogville|Dogville]] (2003), [[Wimbledon|Wimbledon (film)]] (2004), the adaptation of the novel [[The Da Vinci Code|The Da Vinci Code (film)]] (2006) and [[Margin Call|Margin Call (film)]] (2011). He also portrayed Dryden Vos in [[Solo: A Star Wars Story|Solo: A Star Wars Story]] (2018).
title: Paul Bettany

abstract: Adrien Brody (born April 14, 1973) is an American [[actor|actor]] and [[producer|film producer]]. He received widespread recognition and acclaim after starring in [[Roman Polanski|Roman Polanski]]'s [[The Pianist|The Pianist (2002 film)]] (2002), for which he won the [[Academy Award for Best Actor|Academy Award for Best Actor]] at age twenty-nine, making him the youngest actor to win in that category. Brody is also the only male American actor to receive the [[César Award for Best Actor|César Award for Best Actor]].
title: Adrien Brody

abstract: Annette Crosbie, (born 12 February 1934) is a Scottish actress. She is known for her role as Margaret Meldrew in the [[BBC|BBC]] sitcom [[One Foot in the Grave|One Foot in the Grave]] (1990–2000). She twice won the [[BAFTA TV Award for Best Actress|British Academy Television Award for Best Actress]], for [[The Six Wives of Henry VIII|The Six Wives of Henry VIII (BBC TV series)]] in 1971 and [[Edward the Seventh|Edward the Seventh]] in 1976, and was nominated for the [[BAFTA Award for Best Actress in a Supporting Role|BAFTA Award for Best Actress in a Supporting Role]] for the 1976 film [[The Slipper and the Rose|The Slipper and the Rose]]. Her other film appearances include [[The Pope Must Die|The Pope Must Die]] (1991), [[Shooting Fish|Shooting Fish]] (1997), [[Calendar Girls|Calendar Girls]] (2003) and [[Into the Woods|Into the Woods (film)]] (2014).
title: Annette Crosbie

abstract: Diane Keaton ([[née|Given name]] Hall; born January 5, 1946) is an [[American|United States]] film actress, director, and producer. She is the recipient of [[various accolades|Diane Keaton#Awards and nominations]] including an [[Academy Award|Academy Award]], a [[BAFTA Award|BAFTA Award]], two [[Golden Globe Awards|Golden Globe Awards]], and the [[AFI Life Achievement Award|AFI Life Achievement Award]].
title: Diane Keaton

abstract: Capucine (6 January 192817 March 1990) was a French fashion model and actress known for her comedic roles in [[The Pink Panther|The Pink Panther (1963 film)]] (1963) and [[What's New Pussycat?|What's New Pussycat?]] (1965). She appeared in 36 films and 17 television productions between 1948 and 1990.
title: Capucine

abstract: Malcolm McDowell (born Malcolm John Taylor; 13 June 1943) is an English actor, known for his boisterous and sometimes villainous roles. He trained as an actor at the [[London Academy of Music and Dramatic Art|London Academy of Music and Dramatic Art]].
title: Malcolm McDowell

abstract: Bernadette Peters (born Bernadette Lazzara; February 28, 1948) is an American actress, singer and children's book author. Over the course of a career that has spanned five decades, she has starred in [[musical theatre|musical theatre]], television and film, performing in solo concerts and recordings. She is one of the most critically acclaimed [[Broadway|Broadway theatre]] performers, having received nominations for seven [[Tony Awards|Tony Awards]], winning two (plus an honorary award), and nine [[Drama Desk Awards|Drama Desk Awards]], winning three. Four of the Broadway [[cast albums|cast albums]] on which she has starred have won [[Grammy Awards|Grammy Awards]].
title: Bernadette Peters

abstract: Nichelle Nichols (born Grace Dell Nichols; December 28, 1932) is an American [[actress|actor]], [[singer|singing]], and [[voice artist|voice acting]]. She sang with [[Duke Ellington|Duke Ellington]] and [[Lionel Hampton|Lionel Hampton]] before turning to acting. Nichols played communications officer Lieutenant (later, Commander) [[Uhura|Uhura]] aboard the [[USS Enterprise|USS Enterprise (NCC-1701)]] in the [[Star Trek|Star Trek: The Original Series]] television series (1966–1969), as well as the succeeding motion pictures. Nichols's role was groundbreaking as one of the first [[African American|African Americans]] female characters on American television not portrayed as a servant. She also worked to recruit diverse astronauts to NASA, including women and ethnic minorities.
title: Nichelle Nichols

abstract: Rolf Peter Ingvar Storm (born 27 August 1953), known professionally as Peter Stormare (), is a [[Swedish American|Swedish American]] actor, voice actor, theatre director, playwright and musician. He is best known for playing the roles of Gaear Grimsrud in [[Fargo|Fargo (film)]] (1996), Dieter Stark in [[The Lost World: Jurassic Park|The Lost World: Jurassic Park]] (1997), Vladimir in [[Playing God|Playing God (1997 film)]] (1997) Uli Kunkel/Karl Hungus in [[The Big Lebowski|The Big Lebowski]] (1998), Lev Andropov in [[Armageddon|Armageddon (1998 film)]] (1998), Jeff in [[Dancer in the Dark|Dancer in the Dark]] (2000), Dr. Solomon P. Eddie in [[Minority Report|Minority Report (film)]] (2001), Alexi in [[Bad Boys II|Bad Boys II]] (2003), [[Lucifer|Lucifer (DC Comics)]] in [[Constantine|Constantine (film)]] (2005), [[John Abruzzi|John Abruzzi]] in the [[Fox|Fox Network]] series [[Prison Break|Prison Break (TV series)]] (2005–2007), Ghost in [[22 Jump Street|22 Jump Street]] (2014) and Dr. Hill in the video game [[Until Dawn|Until Dawn]] (2015).
title: Peter Stormare

abstract: Raquel Welch (born Jo Raquel Tejada; September 5, 1940) is an American actress and singer.
title: Raquel Welch

abstract: Stevland Hardaway Morris (né Judkins; born May 13, 1950), better known by his stage name Stevie Wonder, is an American singer, songwriter, musician, record producer, and multi-instrumentalist.
title: Stevie Wonder

abstract: Carole King (born Carol Joan Klein, February 9, 1942) is an American [[composer|composer]] and [[singer-songwriter|singer-songwriter]]. She is the most successful female songwriter of the latter half of the 20th century in the US, having written or co-written 118 pop hits on the [[Billboard Hot 100|Billboard Hot 100]] between 1955 and 1999. King also wrote 61 hits that charted in the UK, making her the most successful female songwriter on the UK singles charts between 1952 and 2005.
title: Carole King

abstract: John Herbert Gleason (February 26, 1916June 24, 1987) was an American comedian, actor, writer, composer and conductor. Developing a style and characters from growing up in [[Brooklyn|Brooklyn]], New York, he was known for his brash visual and verbal comedy, exemplified by his bus driver [[Ralph Kramden|Ralph Kramden]] character in the television series [[The Honeymooners|The Honeymooners]]. By filming the episodes with [[Electronicam|Electronicams]], Gleason was later able to release the series in syndication, which increased its popularity over the years with new audiences. He also developed [[The Jackie Gleason Show|The Jackie Gleason Show]], which maintained high ratings from the mid-1950s through 1970. After originating in [[New York City|New York City]], filming moved to [[Miami|Miami]], Florida, in 1964 after Gleason took up permanent residence there.
title: Jackie Gleason

abstract: Tress MacNeille (born Teressa Claire Payne; June 20, 1951) is an [[American|United States]] voice actress, and singer who has voiced various characters in shows like [[The Simpsons|The Simpsons]], [[Futurama|Futurama]], [[Hey Arnold!|Hey Arnold!]], [[Tiny Toon Adventures|Tiny Toon Adventures]], [[Rugrats|Rugrats]], [[Animaniacs|Animaniacs]] and [[Disney's House of Mouse|Disney's House of Mouse]].
title: Tress MacNeille

abstract: Pamela Hayden (born November 28, 1953) is an [[American|United States]] [[actress|actress]] and [[voice actress|voice actress]], known for providing various voices for the animated television show [[The Simpsons|The Simpsons]], most notably [[Milhouse Van Houten|Milhouse Van Houten]].
title: Pamela Hayden

abstract: Bob Crowley (born 1952) is a theatre designer (scenic and costume), and theatre director.
title: Bob Crowley

abstract: Laurence Harvey (born Laruschka Mischa Skikne; 1 October 192825 November 1973) was a [[Lithuania|Lithuanian]]-born [[British Jewish|British Jewish]] actor. In a career that spanned a quarter of a century, Harvey appeared in stage, film and television productions primarily in the United Kingdom and the United States. His performance in [[Room at the Top|Room at the Top (1959 film)]] (1959) resulted in an Academy Award nomination. That success was followed by the role of [[William Barret Travis|William Barret Travis]] in [[The Alamo|The Alamo (1960 film)]] (1960), and as the brainwashed Raymond Shaw in [[The Manchurian Candidate|The Manchurian Candidate (1962 film)]] (1962).
title: Laurence Harvey

abstract: Charles Patrick Ryan O'Neal (born April 20, 1942) is an American actor and former boxer. O'Neal trained as an amateur boxer before beginning his career in acting in 1960. In 1964, he landed the role of [[Rodney Harrington|Rodney Harrington]] on the [[ABC|American Broadcasting Company]] nighttime soap opera [[Peyton Place|Peyton Place (TV series)]]. The series was an instant hit and boosted O'Neal's career. He later found success in films, most notably [[Love Story|Love Story (1970 film)]] (1970), for which he received [[Academy Award|Academy Award]] and [[Golden Globe|Golden Globe]] nominations as Best Actor, [[Peter Bogdanovich|Peter Bogdanovich]]'s [[What's Up, Doc?|What's Up, Doc? (1972 film)]] (1972) and [[Paper Moon|Paper Moon (film)]] (1973), [[Stanley Kubrick|Stanley Kubrick]]'s [[Barry Lyndon|Barry Lyndon]] (1975), and [[Richard Attenborough|Richard Attenborough]]'s [[A Bridge Too Far|A Bridge Too Far (film)]] (1977). He had a recurring role in the TV series [[Bones|Bones (TV series)]] as Max, the father of [[the series' protagonist|Temperance "Bones" Brennan]].
title: Ryan O'Neal

abstract: George Roy Hill (December 20, 1921 – December 27, 2002) was an American [[film director|film director]]. He is most noted for directing such films as [[Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid|Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid]] (1969) and [[The Sting|The Sting]] (1973), both starring the acting duo [[Paul Newman|Paul Newman]] and [[Robert Redford|Robert Redford]].
title: George Roy Hill

abstract: F. Murray Abraham (born Murray Abraham; October 24, 1939) is an [[American|Americans]] actor. He became widely known during the 1980s after winning an [[Oscar|Academy Award for Best Actor]] for his leading role as [[Antonio Salieri|Antonio Salieri]] in the drama film [[Amadeus|Amadeus (film)]] (1984). Abraham also won a [[Golden Globe|Golden Globe Award for Best Actor – Motion Picture Drama]] and received a [[BAFTA Award|BAFTA Award for Best Actor in a Leading Role]] nomination for the role.
title: F. Murray Abraham

abstract: Lil Wayne's solo debut album [[Tha Block Is Hot|Tha Block Is Hot]] (1999) was [[certified platinum|Music recording sales certification]] by the [[Recording Industry Association of America|Recording Industry Association of America]] (RIAA). His subsequent albums, [[Lights Out|Lights Out (Lil Wayne album)]] (2000) and [[500 Degreez|500 Degreez]] (2002), went on to be [[certified gold|Music recording sales certification]]. Wayne reached higher popularity with his fourth album [[Tha Carter|Tha Carter]] (2004), which was led by the single "[[Go D.J.|Go D.J.]]" and his appearance on [[Destiny's Child|Destiny's Child]]'s [[Top 10|Top 40]] single "[[Soldier|Soldier (Destiny's Child song)]]", that same year. The album was followed by [[Tha Carter II|Tha Carter II]] (2005), as well as several [[mixtape|mixtapes]] and collaborations throughout 2006 and 2007. Wayne gained more prominence with his sixth album [[Tha Carter III|Tha Carter III]] (2008), which became his most successful album to date, with first-week sales of over one million copies in the United States. The album won the [[Grammy Award|Grammy Award]] for [[Best Rap Album|Best Rap Album]] and includes the singles "[[Lollipop|Lollipop (Lil Wayne song)]]", "[[A Milli|A Milli]]" and "[[Got Money|Got Money]]".
title: Lil Wayne

abstract: Cornell Iral Haynes Jr. (born November 2, 1974), known professionally as Nelly, is an American rapper, singer, songwriter, entrepreneur, investor, and occasional actor from [[St. Louis, Missouri|St. Louis, Missouri]]. Nelly embarked on his music career with [[Midwest hip hop|Midwest hip hop]] group [[St. Lunatics|St. Lunatics]], in 1993 and signed to [[Universal Records|Universal Records]] in 1999. Under Universal, Nelly began his solo career in the year 2000, with his debut album [[Country Grammar|Country Grammar]], of which the [[title-track|Country Grammar (Hot Shit)]] was a top ten hit. The album debuted at number three on the [[Billboard 200|Billboard 200]] and went on to peak at number one. Country Grammar is Nelly's best-selling album to date, selling over 8.4 million copies in the United States. His following album [[Nellyville|Nellyville]], produced the [[number-one hits|Hot 100 number-one hits of 2002 (USA)]] "[[Hot in Herre|Hot in Herre]]" and "[[Dilemma|Dilemma (song)]]" (featuring [[Kelly Rowland|Kelly Rowland]]). Other singles included "[[Work It|Work It (Nelly song)]]" (featuring [[Justin Timberlake|Justin Timberlake]]), "[[Air Force Ones|Air Force Ones (song)]]" (featuring [[Murphy Lee|Murphy Lee]] and [[St. Lunatics|St. Lunatics]]), "[[Pimp Juice|Pimp Juice]]" and "[[#1|Number 1 (Nelly song)]]".
title: Nelly

abstract: Michael Patrick Smith, (born 19 January 1942), known by the professional [[stage name|stage name]] of Michael Crawford, is an [[English|English people]] [[actor|actor]], [[comedian|comedian]], [[singer|singer]], [[voice artist|voice artist]] and [[philanthropist|philanthropist]].
title: Michael Crawford

abstract: Bernard Herrmann (born Max Herman; June 29, 1911December 24, 1975) was an American composer best known for his work in composing for [[motion pictures|motion pictures]]. As a conductor, he championed the music of lesser-known composers.
title: Bernard Herrmann

abstract: Colin Baker (born 8 June 1943) is an English actor. He became known for playing Paul Merroney in the BBC drama series [[The Brothers|The Brothers (1972 TV series)]] from 1974 to 1976. He later played the [[sixth incarnation|Sixth Doctor]] of [[the Doctor|The Doctor (Doctor Who)]] in the long-running [[science fiction television|science fiction on television]] series [[Doctor Who|Doctor Who]] from 1984 to 1986. Baker's tenure as the Doctor proved to be a controversial era for the series, which included a hiatus in production and his subsequent replacement on the orders of BBC executive [[Michael Grade|Michael Grade]].
title: Colin Baker

abstract: Iggy Pop's music has encompassed a number of styles over the course of his career, including [[garage rock|garage rock]], [[punk rock|punk rock]], [[hard rock|hard rock]], [[art rock|art rock]], [[new wave|New wave music]], [[jazz|jazz]], [[blues|blues]], and [[electronic|Electronic music]]. Though his popularity has fluctuated through the years, many of Iggy Pop's songs have become well-known, including "[[Search and Destroy|Search and Destroy (The Stooges song)]]" and "[[I Wanna Be Your Dog|I Wanna Be Your Dog]]" by the Stooges, and his solo hits "[[Lust for Life|Lust for Life (Iggy Pop song)]]", "[[The Passenger|The Passenger (song)]]", and "[[Real Wild Child (Wild One)|Wild One (Johnny O'Keefe song)#Iggy Pop]]".
title: Iggy Pop

abstract: Adrian Paul Hewett (born 29 May 1959) is an English actor known for his titular role as [[Duncan MacLeod|Duncan MacLeod]] on the television series [[Highlander: The Series|Highlander: The Series]]. In 1997, he founded the [[Peace Fund|Peace Fund]] charitable organisation.
title: Adrian Paul

abstract: David Boreanaz (; born May 16, 1969) is an [[American|Americans]] [[actor|actor]], television [[producer|television producer]], and director, known for playing the roles of vampire-turned-private investigator [[Angel|Angel (Buffy the Vampire Slayer)]] on [[Buffy the Vampire Slayer|Buffy the Vampire Slayer]] (1997–2003) and its spinoff [[Angel|Angel (1999 TV series)]] (1999–2004); [[FBI|Federal Bureau of Investigation]] Special Agent [[Seeley Booth|Seeley Booth]] on the television [[crime procedural|crime procedural]] comedy-drama series [[Bones|Bones (TV series)]] (2005–2017); and Jason Hayes in the military drama series [[SEAL Team|SEAL Team (TV series)]].
title: David Boreanaz

abstract: Milica Bogdanovna Jovovich ( ; born December 17, 1975), known professionally as Milla Jovovich, is an American actress, model and musician. She has appeared in numerous [[science fiction|science fiction film]] and [[action film|action films]], leading the music channel [[VH1|VH1]] to deem her the "reigning queen of kick-butt" in 2006. In 2004, [[Forbes|Forbes]] determined that she was the highest-paid model in the world.
title: Milla Jovovich

abstract: William Broderick Crawford (December 9, 1911 – April 26, 1986) was an American stage, film, radio, and television actor, often cast in tough-guy roles and best known for his [[Oscar|Academy Award for Best Actor]] and [[Golden Globe|Golden Globe Award for Best Actor – Motion Picture Drama]]-winning portrayal of Willie Stark in [[All the King's Men|All the King's Men (1949 film)]] and for his starring role as Dan Mathews in the television series [[Highway Patrol|Highway Patrol (U.S. TV series)]] (1955–1959).
title: Broderick Crawford

abstract: Christy Carlson Romano (born March 20, 1984) is an American actress, comedian, voice actress and singer. She is known for her role as [[Ren Stevens|Ren Stevens]] in the [[Disney Channel|Disney Channel]] sitcom [[Even Stevens|Even Stevens]], and as the voice of the titular character in the Disney Channel animated series [[Kim Possible|Kim Possible]].
title: Christy Carlson Romano

abstract: Lalaine Vergara-Paras (born June 3, 1987), known [[mononymously|mononymously]] as Lalaine, is an American actress, singer, and songwriter. She is best known for her role as Miranda Sanchez on the [[Disney Channel|Disney Channel]] teen sitcom [[Lizzie McGuire|Lizzie McGuire]], which ran from 2001 to 2004. Her other most notable appearances include the television film [[Annie|Annie (1999 film)]] (1999) and as Abby Ramirez in the [[Disney Channel Original Movie|Disney Channel Original Movie]] [[You Wish!|You Wish! (film)]] (2003).
title: Lalaine

abstract: Brittany Murphy-Monjack (born Brittany Anne Bertolotti; November 10, 1977   – December 20, 2009), was an American actress and singer. A native of Atlanta, Murphy moved to Los Angeles as a teenager and pursued a career in acting. Her breakthrough role was as Tai Frasier in [[Clueless|Clueless (film)]] (1995), followed by supporting roles in [[independent films|independent films]] such as [[Freeway|Freeway (1996 film)]] (1996) and [[Bongwater|Bongwater (film)]] (1998). She made her stage debut in a [[Broadway|Broadway theatre]] production of [[Arthur Miller|Arthur Miller]]'s [[A View from the Bridge|A View from the Bridge]] in 1997, before appearing as Daisy Randone in [[Girl, Interrupted|Girl, Interrupted (film)]] (1999) and as Lisa Swenson in [[Drop Dead Gorgeous|Drop Dead Gorgeous (film)]] (1999).
title: Brittany Murphy

abstract: Dean Martin (born Dino Paul Crocetti; June 7, 1917 – December 25, 1995), was an American singer, actor, comedian, and producer.
title: Dean Martin

abstract: Deryck Guyler (29 April 1914 – 7 October 1999) was an [[English|England]] [[actor|actor]], best known for his portrayal of officious, short-tempered middle-aged men in [[sitcom|sitcoms]] such as [[Please Sir!|Please Sir!]] and [[Sykes|Sykes]].
title: Deryck Guyler

abstract: Baz Luhrmann (born Mark Anthony Luhrmann, 17 September 1962) is an Australian writer, director, and producer with projects spanning film, television, opera, theatre, music, and recording industries. He is regarded by many as a contemporary example of an [[auteur|auteur]] for his distinctly recognizable style and deep involvement in the writing, directing, design, and musical components of all his work. He is the most commercially successful Australian director, with four of his films in the top ten highest worldwide grossing [[Australian films|Australian films]] of all time.
title: Baz Luhrmann

abstract: Zsa Zsa Gabor ( ; ; born Sári Gábor ; February 6, 1917   – December 18, 2016) was a [[Hungarian-American|Hungarian Americans]] actress and socialite. Her sisters were actresses [[Eva|Eva Gabor]] and [[Magda Gabor|Magda Gabor]].Gabor began her stage career in [[Vienna|Vienna]] and was crowned [[Miss Hungary|Miss Hungary]] in 1936. She emigrated from [[Hungary|Hungary]] to the United States in 1941. Becoming a sought-after actress with "European flair and style", she was considered to have a personality that "exuded charm and grace". Her first film role was a supporting role in [[Lovely to Look At|Lovely to Look At]]. She later acted in [[We're Not Married!|We're Not Married!]] and played one of her few leading roles in the [[John Huston|John Huston]]-directed film, [[Moulin Rouge|Moulin Rouge (1952 film)]] (1952). Huston would later describe her as a "creditable" actress.
title: Zsa Zsa Gabor

abstract: Eva Gabor (; February 11, 1919 – July 4, 1995) was a [[Hungarian|Hungary]]-American actress, comedian, singer and [[socialite|socialite]]. She was widely known for her role on the 1965–71 television [[sitcom|sitcom]] [[Green Acres|Green Acres]] as [[Lisa Douglas|Lisa Douglas]], the wife of [[Eddie Albert|Eddie Albert]]'s character, [[Oliver Wendell Douglas|Oliver Wendell Douglas]]. She voiced "Duchess" in the 1970 Disney film [[The Aristocats|The Aristocats]], and Miss Bianca in [[Disney|The Walt Disney Company]]’s [[The Rescuers|The Rescuers]] and [[The Rescuers Down Under|The Rescuers Down Under]]. Gabor was successful as an actress in film, on Broadway and on television. She was also a successful businessperson, marketing wigs, clothing and beauty products. Her elder sisters, [[Zsa Zsa|Zsa Zsa Gabor]] and [[Magda Gabor|Magda Gabor]], were also actresses and socialites.
title: Eva Gabor

abstract: John Mills was born in Norfolk, the son of Edith (Baker), a theatre box office manager, and Lewis Mills, a mathematics teacher. Mills was born at Watts Naval School, where his father was a master. He spent his early years in the village of [[Belton|Belton with Browston]] where his father was the headmaster of the village school. He first felt the thrill of performing at a concert in the school hall when six years old. He lived in a modest house in Gainsborough Road Felixstowe until 1929. His older sister was [[Annette Mills|Annette Mills]], remembered as presenter of BBC Television's [[Muffin the Mule|Muffin the Mule]] (1946–55).
title: John Mills

abstract: Robert Powell (; born 1 June 1944) is an English television and film actor, best known for the title role in [[Jesus of Nazareth|Jesus of Nazareth (miniseries)]] (1977) and as the fictional [[secret agent|secret agent]] [[Richard Hannay|Richard Hannay]]. He is also known for his roles as [[Mark Williams|Mark Williams (Holby City)]] in the [[BBC One|BBC One]] medical drama [[Holby City|Holby City]], as David Briggs in the sitcom [[The Detectives|The Detectives]] alongside [[Jasper Carrott|Jasper Carrott]], and as Tobias 'Toby' Wren in the "science-fact" drama [[Doomwatch|Doomwatch]].
title: Robert Powell

abstract: Kim Hunter (born Janet Cole; November 12, 1922 – September 11, 2002) was an American film, theatre, and television actress. She won both an [[Academy Award|Academy Awards]] and a [[Golden Globe Award|Golden Globe Award]], each as Best Supporting Actress, for her performance as [[Stella Kowalski|Stella Kowalski]] in the [[1951|1951 in film]] film [[A Streetcar Named Desire|A Streetcar Named Desire (1951 film)]]. Decades later, she was nominated for a [[Daytime Emmy Award|Daytime Emmy Award]] for her work on the long-running [[soap opera|soap opera]] [[The Edge of Night|The Edge of Night]]. She also portrayed the character of [[chimpanzee|chimpanzee]] [[Zira|Zira (Planet of the Apes)]] in the first three installments of the original film adaptation [[Planet of the Apes|Planet of the Apes]].
title: Kim Hunter

abstract: Paul Le Mat (born September 22, 1945) is an American actor. He first came to prominence with his role in [[American Graffiti|American Graffiti]] (1973); his performance was met with critical acclaim and earned him the [[Golden Globe Award for New Star of the Year - Actor|Golden Globe Award for New Star of the Year - Actor]].
title: Paul Le Mat

abstract: In 1969, Fawcett began her career when she appeared in commercials and guest roles on television. During the 1970s, she appeared in numerous television series, including recurring roles on [[Harry O|Harry O]] (1974–1976), and [[The Six Million Dollar Man|The Six Million Dollar Man]] (1974–1978) with her first husband, film and television star [[Lee Majors|Lee Majors]]. Her breakthrough role came in 1976, when she was cast as Jill Munroe in the [[ABC|American Broadcasting Company]] series Charlie's Angels, alongside [[Kate Jackson|Kate Jackson]] and [[Jaclyn Smith|Jaclyn Smith]]. The show propelled all three to stardom, but especially Fawcett (then billed as "Farrah Fawcett-Majors"). After appearing in only the first season, Fawcett decided to leave the show, which led to legal disputes. She eventually signed a contract that required her to make six guest appearances in the show's third and fourth seasons (1978–1980). For her role in Charlie's Angels she received her first Golden Globe nomination.
title: Farrah Fawcett

abstract: Pamela Sue Martin (born January 5, 1953) is an American actress. She is best known for her portrayal of teenage detective [[Nancy Drew|Nancy Drew]] on the television series [[The Hardy Boys/Nancy Drew Mysteries|The Hardy Boys/Nancy Drew Mysteries]] and for originating the role of socialite [[Fallon Carrington Colby|Fallon Carrington Colby]] on the [[ABC|American Broadcasting Company]] nighttime soap opera [[Dynasty|Dynasty (1981 TV series)]].
title: Pamela Sue Martin

abstract: Lara Flynn Boyle (born March 24, 1970) is an American actress and producer. She is best known for her role as [[Donna Hayward|Donna Hayward]] in the [[ABC|American Broadcasting Company]] [[cult|cult television]] [[television series|Television show]] [[Twin Peaks|Twin Peaks]] (1990–1991). After portraying Stacy in [[Penelope Spheeris|Penelope Spheeris]]'s comedy [[Wayne's World|Wayne's World (film)]] (1992), Boyle had a lead role in [[John Dahl|John Dahl]]'s critically acclaimed [[neo-noir film|Neo-noir]] [[Red Rock West|Red Rock West]] (1993), followed by roles in [[Threesome|Threesome (1994 film)]] (1994), [[Cafe Society|Cafe Society (1995 film)]] (1995), and [[Happiness|Happiness (1998 film)]] (1998). From 1997 to 2003, Boyle portrayed Assistant District Attorney Helen Gamble in the [[ABC|American Broadcasting Company]] television series [[The Practice|The Practice]] for which she was nominated a [[Primetime Emmy Award|Primetime Emmy Award]] for [[Outstanding Supporting Actress in a Drama Series|Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Supporting Actress in a Drama Series]].
title: Lara Flynn Boyle

abstract: Carrie-Anne Moss was born in [[Burnaby|Burnaby]], British Columbia, the daughter of Barbara and Melvyn Moss. She has an older brother, Brooke. Moss's mother reportedly named her after [[The Hollies|The Hollies]]' 1967 hit song, "[[Carrie Anne|Carrie Anne]]", which had been released in May that year. Moss lived with her mother in Vancouver as a child. At the age of 11, she joined the Vancouver children's musical theatre and later went on to tour Europe with the [[Magee Secondary School|Magee Secondary School]] Choir in her senior year.
title: Carrie-Anne Moss

abstract: Polly Bergen (born Nellie Paulina Burgin; July 14, 1930   – September 20, 2014) was an [[American|Americans]] actress, singer, television host, writer and entrepreneur.
title: Polly Bergen

abstract: Michael Anthony Hall (born April 14, 1968), known professionally as Anthony Michael Hall, is an American actor who starred in several teen-oriented films of the 1980s. Hall began his career in commercials and on stage as a child, and made his screen debut in 1980. His films with director-screenwriter [[John Hughes|John Hughes (filmmaker)]], beginning with the popular 1983 comedy [[National Lampoon's Vacation|National Lampoon's Vacation]] and the [[coming-of-age|coming of age]] comedy [[Sixteen Candles|Sixteen Candles]], shaped his early career. Hall's next movies with Hughes were the teen classics [[The Breakfast Club|The Breakfast Club]] and [[Weird Science|Weird Science (film)]], both in 1985.
title: Anthony Michael Hall

abstract: Sally Margaret Field (born November 6, 1946) is an American actress and director. She is the recipient of [[various accolades|Sally Field#Awards and nominations]], including two [[Academy Awards|Academy Awards]], three [[Primetime Emmy Awards|Primetime Emmy Awards]], two [[Golden Globe Awards|Golden Globe Awards]], a [[Screen Actors Guild Award|Screen Actors Guild Award]] and has been nominated for a [[Tony Award|Tony Award]] and two [[BAFTA Awards|BAFTA Awards]].
title: Sally Field

abstract: James Gilmore Backus (February 25, 1913 – July 3, 1989) was an American radio, television, film, and [[voice actor|Voice acting]]. Among his most famous roles were the voice of nearsighted cartoon character [[Mr. Magoo|Mr. Magoo]], the rich Hubert Updike III on the radio version of [[The Alan Young Show|The Alan Young Show]], [[Joan Davis|Joan Davis]]' character's husband (a domestic court judge) on TV's [[I Married Joan|I Married Joan]], [[James Dean|James Dean]]'s character's father in [[Rebel Without a Cause|Rebel Without a Cause]], and [[Thurston Howell III|Thurston Howell III]], on the 1960s sitcom [[Gilligan's Island|Gilligan's Island]]. He also starred in his own show of one season, [[The Jim Backus Show|The Jim Backus Show]], also known as Hot Off the Wire.
title: Jim Backus

abstract: Janet Leigh (born Jeanette Helen Morrison; July 6, 1927 – October 3, 2004) was an American actress, singer, dancer, and author. Raised in [[Stockton, California|Stockton, California]], by working-class parents, Leigh was discovered at age eighteen by actress [[Norma Shearer|Norma Shearer]], who helped her secure a contract with [[Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer|Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer]]. Leigh had her first formal foray into acting appearing in radio programs before making her film debut in [[The Romance of Rosy Ridge|The Romance of Rosy Ridge]] (1947).
title: Janet Leigh

abstract: Natacha Rambova (born Winifred Kimball Shaughnessy; January 19, 1897 – June 5, 1966) was an American film costume designer and set designer, and occasional actress who was active in Hollywood in the 1920s. In her later life, she abandoned design to pursue other interests, specifically [[Egyptology|Egyptology]], a subject on which she became a published scholar in the 1950s.
title: Natacha Rambova

abstract: Sir Michael Terence Wogan (; 3 August 1938 – 31 January 2016), better known as Terry Wogan, was a British and Irish radio and television broadcaster who worked for the [[BBC|BBC]] in the UK for most of his career. Before he retired in 2009, his [[BBC Radio 2|BBC Radio 2]] weekday breakfast programme [[Wake Up to Wogan|Wake Up to Wogan]] had eight million regular listeners, making him the most listened-to radio broadcaster in Europe.
title: Terry Wogan

abstract: Michael Ciaran Parker (born 4 May 1952), better known by his [[stage name|stage name]] Michael Barrymore, is an English [[comedian|comedian]] and [[television presenter|television presenter]] of [[game show|game shows]] and [[light entertainment|light entertainment]] programmes on [[British television|British television]] in the 1980s, 1990s and 2000s. These included [[Strike It Lucky|Strike It Lucky]], [[My Kind of People|My Kind of People]], [[My Kind of Music|My Kind of Music]] and [[Kids Say the Funniest Things|Kids Say the Funniest Things]].
title: Michael Barrymore

abstract: Christina Ricci (; born February 12, 1980) is an American actress and producer. She is known for playing unconventional characters with a dark edge. Ricci is the recipient of several accolades, including a [[National Board of Review Award for Best Actress|National Board of Review Award for Best Actress]] and a [[Satellite Award for Best Actress|Satellite Award for Best Actress – Motion Picture]], as well as [[Golden Globe|Golden Globe Award for Best Actor – Motion Picture Musical or Comedy]], [[Primetime Emmy|Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Guest Actress in a Drama Series]], [[Screen Actors Guild|Screen Actors Guild Award for Outstanding Performance by a Female Actor in a Miniseries or Television Movie]] and [[Independent Spirit|Independent Spirit Award for Best Female Lead]] nominations.
title: Christina Ricci

abstract: Marisa Tomei (; born December 4, 1964) is an American actress. She is the recipient of [[various accolades|Marisa Tomei#Awards and nominations]] including an [[Academy Award|Academy Award]] and nominations for a [[BAFTA Award|BAFTA Award]], two [[Golden Globe Awards|Golden Globe Awards]], and three [[Screen Actors Guild Awards|Screen Actors Guild Awards]].
title: Marisa Tomei

abstract: Diane Ladd (born November 29, 1935) is an American actress, film director, producer and author. She has appeared in over 120 film and television roles. For the 1974 film [[Alice Doesn't Live Here Anymore|Alice Doesn't Live Here Anymore]], she won the [[BAFTA Award for Best Actress in a Supporting Role|BAFTA Award for Best Actress in a Supporting Role]] and was nominated for the [[Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress|Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress]]. She went on to win the [[Golden Globe Award for Best Supporting Actress on Television|Golden Globe Award for Best Supporting Actress - Series, Miniseries or Television Film]] for [[Alice|Alice (TV series)]] (1980–81), and to receive Academy Award nominations for [[Wild at Heart|Wild at Heart (film)]] (1990) and [[Rambling Rose|Rambling Rose (film)]] (1991). Her other film appearances include [[Chinatown|Chinatown (1974 film)]] (1974), [[Ghosts of Mississippi|Ghosts of Mississippi]] (1996), [[Primary Colors|Primary Colors (film)]] (1998), [[28 Days|28 Days (film)]] (2000), and [[American Cowslip|American Cowslip]] (2008). Ladd is the mother of actress [[Laura Dern|Laura Dern]], with her ex-husband, actor [[Bruce Dern|Bruce Dern]].
title: Diane Ladd

abstract: Bonnie Blair Brown (born April 23, 1946) is an [[American|United States]] theater, film and television [[actress|actress]]. She has had a number of high-profile roles, including in the play [[Copenhagen|Copenhagen (play)]] on Broadway, the leading actress in the films [[Altered States|Altered States]] (1980), [[Continental Divide|Continental Divide (film)]] (1981) and [[Strapless|Strapless]] (1989), as well as a run as the title character in the [[comedy-drama|comedy-drama]] television series [[The Days and Nights of Molly Dodd|The Days and Nights of Molly Dodd]], which ran from 1987 to 1991. Her later roles include Nina Sharp on the [[Fox|Fox Broadcasting Company]] television series [[Fringe|Fringe (TV series)]] and Judy King on the [[Netflix|Netflix]] series [[Orange Is the New Black|Orange Is the New Black]].
title: Blair Brown

abstract: Eddi-Rue McClanahan (February 21, 1934 – June 3, 2010) was an American actress best known for her roles on television as [[Vivian Harmon|Maude (TV series)#Characters]] on [[Maude|Maude (TV series)]] (1972–78), [[Aunt Fran Crowley|List of Mama's Family characters#Aunt Fran Crowley]] on [[Mama's Family|Mama's Family]] (1983–84), and [[Blanche Devereaux|Blanche Devereaux]] on [[The Golden Girls|The Golden Girls]] (1985–92), for which she won an [[Emmy Award|Emmy Award]] for [[Outstanding Lead Actress in a Comedy Series|Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Lead Actress in a Comedy Series]] in 1987.
title: Rue McClanahan

abstract: Marlene Warfield (born June 19, 1941 in [[Queens|Queens]], [[New York|New York (state)]]) is an [[American|United States]] actress.
title: Marlene Warfield

abstract: Tony Danza (born Antonio Salvatore Iadanza; April 21, 1951) is an American [[actor|actor]] and former professional [[boxer|Boxing]]. He is best known for starring on the TV series [[Taxi|Taxi (TV series)]] and [[Who's the Boss?|Who's the Boss?]], for which he was nominated for an [[Emmy Award|Emmy Award]] and four [[Golden Globe Awards|Golden Globe Awards]]. In 1998, Danza won the [[People's Choice Award|People's Choice Award]] for Favorite Male Performer in a New Television Series for his work on the 1997 sitcom [[The Tony Danza Show|The Tony Danza Show (1997 TV series)]] (not to be confused with his 2004–2006 daytime variety talk show [[of the same name|The Tony Danza Show (2004 talk show)]]).
title: Tony Danza

abstract: Apart from Hindi, he sang in many Indian languages including [[Bengali|Bengali language]], [[Marathi|Marathi language]], [[Assamese|Assamese language]], [[Gujarati|Gujarati language]], [[Kannada|Kannada]], [[Bhojpuri|Bhojpuri]], [[Malayalam|Malayalam]] and [[Urdu|Urdu]]. He has also sung in private albums in several languages especially in Bengali. He won 8 Film fare Awards for Best Male Playback Singer and holds the record for winning the most [[Filmfare Awards|Filmfare Awards]] in that category. He was awarded the "[[Lata Mangeshkar Award|Lata Mangeshkar Award]]" by the [[Madhya Pradesh|Madhya Pradesh]] government in the year 1985–86. In the year 1997, the Madhya Pradesh Government initiated an award called the "Kishore Kumar Award" as a contribution to [[Hindi cinema|Bollywood]]. Recently, Kishore Kumar's unreleased last song was sold for Rs 15.6 lakh (1.56 million) at the Osian's Cinefan Auction, New Delhi in 2012.
title: Kishore Kumar

abstract: Anne Archer (born August 24, 1947) is an American actress. She was nominated for the [[Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress|Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress]] for the 1987 film [[Fatal Attraction|Fatal Attraction]]. Her other film appearances include [[Paradise Alley|Paradise Alley]] (1978), [[Patriot Games|Patriot Games (film)]] (1992), [[Short Cuts|Short Cuts]] (1993), [[Clear and Present Danger|Clear and Present Danger (film)]] (1994), and [[Lullaby|Lullaby (2014 film)]] (2014). On stage, she starred as Mrs. Robinson in the [[West End|West End (theatre)]] production of [[The Graduate|The Graduate]] in 2001, and in the title role of The Trial of Jane Fonda at the 2014 [[Edinburgh Festival Fringe|Edinburgh Festival Fringe]].
title: Anne Archer

abstract: Paul Reiser (born March 30, 1956) is an [[American|Americans]] comedian, actor, writer, and musician. He is best known for his roles as Michael Taylor in the 1980s sitcom [[My Two Dads|My Two Dads]], Paul Buchman in the 1990s TV sitcom [[Mad About You|Mad About You]], Carter Burke in the 1986 film [[Aliens|Aliens (film)]], and more recently as Doug Getty in the Amazon TV series [[Red Oaks|Red Oaks]].
title: Paul Reiser

abstract: Karl Malden (born Mladen George Sekulovich; March 22, 1912 – July 1, 2009) was an American actor. He was primarily a character actor who "for more than 60 years brought an intelligent intensity and a homespun authenticity to roles in theater, film and television", especially in such classic films as [[A Streetcar Named Desire|A Streetcar Named Desire (1951 film)]] (1951) — for which he won the [[Academy Award|Academy Awards]] for [[Best Supporting Actor|Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor]] — [[On the Waterfront|On the Waterfront]] (1954), [[Pollyanna|Pollyanna (1960 film)]] (1960), and [[One-Eyed Jacks|One-Eyed Jacks]] (1961). Malden also played in high-profile Hollywood films such as [[Baby Doll|Baby Doll]] (1956), [[The Hanging Tree|The Hanging Tree]] (1959), [[How the West Was Won|How the West Was Won (film)]] (1962), and [[Patton|Patton (film)]] (1970). From 1972 to 1977, he portrayed Lt. Mike Stone in the television [[crime drama|crime drama]] [[The Streets of San Francisco|The Streets of San Francisco]]. He was later the spokesman for [[American Express|American Express]]. Film and culture critic [[Charles Champlin|Charles Champlin]] described Malden as "an Everyman, but one whose range moved easily up and down the levels of society and the IQ scale, from heroes to heavies and ordinary, decent guys just trying to get along", and at the time of his death, Malden was described as "one of the great character actors of his time" who created a number of "powerhouse performances on screen". Malden was also President of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences from 1989 to 1992.
title: Karl Malden

abstract: William James Te Wehi Taitoko (17 January 1948 – 7 August 1991) better known by his stage name Billy T. James, was a [[New Zealand|New Zealand]] entertainer, comedian, musician and actor. He became a key figure in the development of New Zealand comedy, and a household name during his lifetime.
title: Billy T. James

abstract: Lorna Luft (born November 21, 1952) is an American television, stage, and film actress and singer. She is the daughter of singer and actress [[Judy Garland|Judy Garland]] and producer [[Sidney Luft|Sidney Luft]], and half-sister to singer and actress [[Liza Minnelli|Liza Minnelli]].
title: Lorna Luft

abstract: Ralf Schumacher (born 30 June 1975) is a German former racing driver. He is the younger brother of seven-time Formula One World Champion [[Michael Schumacher|Michael Schumacher]] and the pair are the only siblings to win Formula One races.
title: Ralf Schumacher

abstract: Agnès Varda (; born 30 May 1928) is a Belgian-born French film director. Her films, photographs, and art installations focus on documentary realism, feminist issues, and social commentary with a distinctive experimental style. She has spent most of her working life in France.
title: Agnès Varda

abstract: Alexander Gordon Jump (April 1, 1932 – September 22, 2003) was an American [[actor|actor]] best known as the clueless [[radio station|radio station]] manager [[Arthur "Big Guy" Carlson|Arthur Carlson]] in the [[TV series|television series]] [[WKRP in Cincinnati|WKRP in Cincinnati]] and the incompetent "Chief of Police Tinkler" in the sitcom [[Soap|Soap (TV series)]]. Jump's most memorable guest starring role was on a two-part episode of the 1980s sitcom [[Diff'rent Strokes|Diff'rent Strokes]], where he portrayed a [[pedophile|pedophile]] who attempts to [[molest|child molestation]] main characters Arnold and his friend, Dudley. He also played the "Maytag Repairman" in commercials for [[Maytag|Maytag Corporation]] brand appliances, from 1989 until his retirement from the role in July 2003.
title: Gordon Jump

abstract: Margaret Colin (born May 26, 1958) is an American actress. She is known for her roles as [[Margo Hughes|Margo Hughes]] on [[As the World Turns|As the World Turns]] and as [[Eleanor Waldorf-Rose|Eleanor Waldorf]] on [[Gossip Girl|Gossip Girl]].
title: Margaret Colin

abstract: Jennifer O'Neill (born February 20, 1948) is a [[Brazilian American|Brazilian Americans]] actress, model, author and speaker, known for her role in the 1971 film [[Summer of '42|Summer of '42]] and modelling for [[CoverGirl|CoverGirl]] cosmetics starting in the 1970s.
title: Jennifer O'Neill

abstract: Adolf Anton Wilhelm Wohlbrück (19 November 18969 August 1967) was an Austrian actor who settled in the United Kingdom under the name Anton Walbrook.
title: Anton Walbrook

abstract: Werner Klemperer (March 22, 1920 – December 6, 2000) was a German-American stage, film, and television actor and singer/musician.
title: Werner Klemperer

abstract: Mýa Marie Harrison (born October 10, 1979) is an American recording artist, songwriter, producer, and actress. Born into a musical family, she signed with [[Interscope Records|Interscope Records]] in 1998 and released her [[eponymous debut album|Mýa (album)]] the same year. The album was a critical and commercial success and produced her first top ten single "[[It's All About Me|It's All About Me]]." Subsequent singles, "[[Ghetto Supastar (That Is What You Are)|Ghetto Supastar (That Is What You Are)]]" and "[[Take Me There|Take Me There (Blackstreet & Mýa song)]]" attained chart success worldwide, with the former garnering her first [[Grammy|Grammy]] nomination. [[Fear of Flying|Fear of Flying (album)]], her sophomore album, was released in 2000 and became a worldwide success, boosted by the success of its singles "[[Case of the Ex|Case of the Ex]]" and "[[Free|Free (Mýa song)]]." In [[2002|44th Grammy Awards]], Harrison won a [[Grammy Award|Grammy Award]] in the category for [[Best Pop Collaboration with Vocals|Best Pop Collaboration with Vocals]] for her rendition of [[Labelle|Labelle]]'s 1975 hit "[[Lady Marmalade|Lady Marmalade#Moulin Rouge! version]]" alongside with [[Pink|Pink (singer)]], [[Christina Aguilera|Christina Aguilera]] and [[Lil' Kim|Lil' Kim]].
title: Mýa

abstract: Barry Levinson (born April 6, 1942) is an American [[filmmaker|filmmaker]], [[screenwriter|screenwriter]], and [[actor|actor]]. Levinson's best-known works are mid-budget [[comedy-drama|comedy-drama]] and [[drama film|Drama (film and television)s]] such as [[Diner|Diner (film)]] (1982); [[The Natural|The Natural (film)]] (1984); [[Good Morning, Vietnam|Good Morning, Vietnam]] (1987); [[Bugsy|Bugsy]] (1991); and [[Wag the Dog|Wag the Dog]] (1997). He won the [[Academy Award for Best Director|Academy Award for Best Director]] for [[Rain Man|Rain Man]] (1988) which also won the [[Academy Award for Best Picture|Academy Award for Best Picture]].
title: Barry Levinson

abstract: Lotte Lenya (18 October 1898 – 27 November 1981) was an Austrian and American singer, [[diseuse|Monologist#Diseuse]], and actress, long based in the United States. In the German-speaking and classical music world she is best remembered for her performances of the songs of her husband, [[Kurt Weill|Kurt Weill]]. In English-language cinema, she was nominated for an [[Academy Award|Academy Awards]] for her role as a jaded aristocrat in [[The Roman Spring of Mrs. Stone|The Roman Spring of Mrs. Stone]] (1961). She also played the murderous and sadistic [[Rosa Klebb|Rosa Klebb]] in the [[James Bond|James Bond]] movie [[From Russia with Love|From Russia with Love (film)]] (1963).
title: Lotte Lenya

abstract: Robert Carlyle (born 14 April 1961) is a Scottish actor. His film work includes [[Trainspotting|Trainspotting (film)]] (1996) and its [[sequel|T2 Trainspotting]] (2017), [[The Full Monty|The Full Monty]] (1997), [[The World Is Not Enough|The World Is Not Enough]] (1999), and [[Angela's Ashes|Angela's Ashes (film)]] (1999). He has been in the television shows [[Hamish Macbeth|Hamish Macbeth (TV series)]], [[Stargate Universe|Stargate Universe]], and [[Once Upon a Time|Once Upon a Time (TV series)]]. He won the [[BAFTA Award for Best Actor in a Leading Role|BAFTA Award for Best Actor in a Leading Role]] for The Full Monty and a [[Gemini Award|Gemini Award]] for Stargate Universe, and was [[Emmy Award|Emmy Award]]-nominated for his work in [[Human Trafficking|Human Trafficking (miniseries)]] (2005).
title: Robert Carlyle

abstract: Marko Matvere (born 4 February 1968) is an [[Estonia|Estonian]] actor and singer. He was the front actor of the [[Tallinn|Tallinn]] City Theatre, but was to go freelance in 2004. Matvere is one of the most famous and expensive Estonian actor. He made his first movie appearance in Suflöör (1993). So far, Matvere has played or voiced in seven films and television series including foreign TV- series.
title: Marko Matvere

abstract: Marco Antonio Muñiz, known by his stage name Marc Anthony, was born in [[New York City|New York City]] to parents from [[Guayama, Puerto Rico|Guayama, Puerto Rico]]. His mother Guillermina was a housewife, his father, Felipe Muñiz, a musician and hospital lunchroom worker. Anthony's parents named him after Mexican singer [[Marco Antonio Muñiz|Marco Antonio Muñiz]]. Anthony grew up in East Harlem, also known as [[Spanish Harlem|Spanish Harlem]] and El Barrio, and is the youngest of eight children. He was raised [[Roman Catholic|Roman Catholic]].
title: Marc Anthony

abstract: Otto Lilienthal (23 May 1848 – 10 August 1896) was a [[German|Germany]] pioneer of [[aviation|aviation]] who became known as the "flying man". He was the first person to make well-documented, repeated, successful flights with [[glider|Glider (aircraft)s]]. Newspapers and magazines published photographs of Lilienthal gliding, favorably influencing public and scientific opinion about the possibility of flying machines becoming practical. On 9 August 1896, his glider stalled and he was unable to regain control. Falling from about 15   m (50   ft), he broke his neck and died the next day, 10 August 1896.
title: Otto Lilienthal

abstract: Stephanie Zimbalist was born in New York City, the daughter of Loranda Stephanie (née Spalding, 1933–2007) and actor [[Efrem Zimbalist Jr.|Efrem Zimbalist Jr.]] (1918–2014). The family soon moved to Los Angeles, where Stephanie grew up. She was educated at the [[Marlborough School (Los Angeles)|Marlborough School (Los Angeles)]] and graduated from [[Foxcroft School|Foxcroft School]] in [[Middleburg, Virginia|Middleburg, Virginia]]. She attended the [[Juilliard School|Juilliard School]] before commencing her acting career.
title: Stephanie Zimbalist

abstract: Doris Roberts (born Doris May Green; November 4, 1925 – April 17, 2016) was an American actress, author, and [[philanthropist|philanthropist]] whose career spanned six decades of television and film. She received five [[Emmy Awards|Emmy Awards]] and a [[Screen Actors Guild|Screen Actors Guild]] award during her acting career, which began in 1951.
title: Doris Roberts

abstract: Dorothy Ruth Hoogstraten (February 28, 1960 – August 14, 1980), who took the professional name Dorothy Stratten, was a Canadian [[Playboy Playmate|Playboy Playmate]], model, and actress. Stratten was the [[Playboy|Playboy]] Playmate of the Month for August 1979 and [[Playmate of the Year|List of Playmates of the Year]] in 1980. Stratten appeared in three comedy films and in at least two episodes of shows broadcast on US network television. She was murdered at the age of 20 by her estranged husband/manager [[Paul Snider|Paul Snider]], who committed [[suicide|suicide]] on the same day. Her death inspired two motion pictures, the 1981 [[TV movie|TV movie]] [[Death of a Centerfold|Death of a Centerfold: The Dorothy Stratten Story]] and the 1983 theatrical release [[Star 80|Star 80]], as well as the book [[The Killing of the Unicorn|The Killing of the Unicorn]] and the songs "[[Californication|Californication (song)]]" by the [[Red Hot Chili Peppers|Red Hot Chili Peppers]] and "The Best Was Yet to Come" by [[Bryan Adams|Bryan Adams]].
title: Dorothy Stratten

abstract: Ariadna Thalía Sodi Miranda (; born 26 August 1971), known [[mononymous|mononymously]] as Thalía, is a Mexican singer, songwriter, producer, actress and entrepreneur. She is considered one of the most successful and influential Mexican artists worldwide. Apart from her native [[Spanish|Spanish language]], Thalía has also sung in [[English|English language]], [[Tagalog|Tagalog language]], [[French|French language]], and [[Portuguese|Portuguese language]].
title: Thalía

abstract: Elizabeth Ann Guttman (born September 11, 1961), credited as E. G. Daily and sometimes Elizabeth Daily, is an American actress, voice artist, and singer, best known for voicing [[Tommy Pickles|Tommy Pickles]] in the [[Nicktoon|Nicktoons]] [[Rugrats|Rugrats]] and [[All Grown Up!|All Grown Up!]] and [[Buttercup|Blossom, Bubbles, and Buttercup#Buttercup]] in [[Cartoon Network|Cartoon Network]]'s [[The Powerpuff Girls|The Powerpuff Girls]]. She also voiced the title-character from the live-action film [[Babe: Pig in the City|Babe: Pig in the City]] replacing [[Christine Cavanaugh|Christine Cavanaugh]].
title: E. G. Daily

abstract: Jolene Blalock (born March 5, 1975) is an American actress and model, best known for playing the [[Vulcan|Vulcan (Star Trek)]] first officer and science officer [[T'Pol|T'Pol]] on the [[UPN|UPN]] science-fiction series [[Star Trek: Enterprise|Star Trek: Enterprise]]. She has also guest-starred on television series and films.
title: Jolene Blalock

abstract: John Forsythe (born Jacob Lincoln Freund; January 29, 1918 – April 1, 2010) was an American [[stage|stage (theatre)]], film/television [[actor|actor]], [[producer|Television producer]], [[narrator|narrator]], [[drama|drama]] [[teacher|teacher]] and [[philanthropist|philanthropist]] whose career spanned six decades. He also appeared as a guest on several talk and variety shows and as a panelist on numerous game shows.
title: John Forsythe

abstract: Olympia Dukakis (born June 20, 1931) is a [[Greek American|Greek Americans]] actress. She started her career in theater, and won an [[Obie Award|Obie Award]] for [[Best Actress|Obie Award for Distinguished Performance by an Actress]] in 1963 for her [[Off-Broadway|Off-Broadway]] performance in [[Bertolt Brecht|Bertolt Brecht]]'s [[Man Equals Man|Man Equals Man]]. She later transitioned to film acting, and in 1987, she won an [[Academy Award|Academy Awards]], a [[Golden Globe|Golden Globe Award]], and a [[BAFTA|British Academy of Film and Television Arts]] nomination for her performance in [[Moonstruck|Moonstruck]]. She received another Golden Globe nomination for Sinatra, and [[Emmy Award|Emmy Award]] nominations for Lucky Day, [[More Tales of the City|More Tales of the City (miniseries)]], and [[Joan of Arc|Joan of Arc (miniseries)]].
title: Olympia Dukakis

abstract: Iron Eyes Cody (born Espera Oscar de Corti, April 3, 1904 – January 4, 1999) was an Italian-American [[actor|actor]]. He portrayed [[Native Americans|Indigenous peoples of the Americas]] in [[Hollywood|Hollywood]] films, famously as Chief Iron Eyes in [[Bob Hope|Bob Hope]]'s [[The Paleface|The Paleface (1948 film)]] (1948). He also played a Native American shedding a tear about litter in one of the country's most well-known television [[public service announcement|public service announcements]], "[[Keep America Beautiful|Keep America Beautiful]]".
