abstract: Great Bend High School is a [[public|Public school (government funded)]] high school located in [[Great Bend, Kansas|Great Bend, Kansas]], serving students in [[grades|Educational stages#United States and Canada]] 9-12. The school is in the Unified School District 428. The athletic teams are known as the Panthers and all athletic programs compete in the 5A division according to the [[KSHSAA|Kansas State High School Activities Association]].
title: Great Bend High School

abstract: Central Westmoreland Career and Technology Center, or CWCTC, is located in [[New Stanton|New Stanton, Pennsylvania]], [[Pennsylvania|Pennsylvania]]. CWCTC is a [[part-time|part-time]] Career and Technical Educational School with 10 sending school districts. Students also receive their Physical And Health Educations at the center and are also assigned a student-services counselor, according to their last name
title: Central Westmoreland Career and Technology Center

abstract: Smith Center High School is a fully accredited public high school located in [[Smith Center, Kansas|Smith Center, Kansas]], serving students in grades 7-12. Smith Center High School is the only high school located within the city limits of Smith Center. The school colors are red and green and the mascot is the Redmen. Recently, Smith Center has gained national attention due to the success of its football team which held the longest winning streak in the nation at 79 games.
title: Smith Center High School

abstract: Kumasi Academy also known as KUMACA is a public, [[senior high school|senior high school]] located in Asokore-Mampong, a suburb of [[Kumasi|Kumasi]], in the [[Ashanti Region|Ashanti Region]] of [[Ghana|Ghana]]. Asokore-Mampong is about from the central business district of Kumasi off the Kumasi Airport-Aboabo Road.
title: Kumasi Academy

abstract: Lahore College of Arts and Sciences (abbreviated as LACAS), founded in 1987, is a [[private fee-paying|private school]] academic institution with most of its campuses located primarily in [[Lahore|Lahore]], [[Punjab|Punjab (Pakistan)]], [[Pakistan|Pakistan]]. LACAS provides [[preschool|Nursery school]], [[primary|primary education]] and [[secondary|secondary education]] education and preparation for international [[General Certificate of Education|General Certificate of Education]] (GCE) examinations.
title: Lahore College of Arts and Sciences

abstract: Jumeirah English Speaking School is a British [[private school|private school]] located in [[Dubai|Dubai]], [[UAE|United Arab Emirates]]. Its original campus on [[Sheikh Zayed Road|Sheikh Zayed Road]] is a primary school; A second campus at [[Arabian Ranches|Emaar Properties#UAE projects]] has students from primary, secondary and high school. As of December 2016, JESS has 2000 students enrolled.
title: Jumeirah English Speaking School

abstract: Wichita West High School, known locally as West, is a fully accredited [[high school|high school]] located in [[Wichita, Kansas|Wichita, Kansas]], serving students in grades 9-12. The high school is located close to downtown Wichita, and is near [[U.S. Route 54|U.S. Route 54]]. The current principal is Joel Hudson.
title: Wichita West High School

abstract: Lena-Winslow High School Dedicated December 7, 1958, Lena-Winslow High School, affectionately known as "Le-Win", is located in the town of [[Lena, Illinois|Lena, Illinois]]. Part of the Lena-Winslow Community Unit School District, Le-Win became the second largest school district in [[Stephenson County|Stephenson County]], when, in 1949, the State of [[Illinois|Illinois]] mandated that larger school districts be created. Only the district of [[Freeport|Freeport High School (Illinois)]] is larger.
title: Lena-Winslow High School

abstract: David Posnack Jewish Day School (formerly David Posnack Hebrew Day School) is a private [[Jewish day school|Jewish day school]] located in [[Davie, Florida|Davie, Florida]].
title: David Posnack Jewish Day School

abstract: Our Own English High School, Al Ain(مدرستنا الثانوية الإنجليزية، العين) is a [[K-12|K-12]] [[education|education]] establishment,and a GEMS GROUP of schools founded in 1992, located in the Manasir Area of [[Al Ain|Al Ain]] in the [[United Arab Emirates|United Arab Emirates]]. It has been recognized by the Ministry Of Education in [[Abu Dhabi|Abu Dhabi]], [[United Arab Emirates|United Arab Emirates]]. It is part of [[GEMS Education|GEMS Education]], an organization operating in the field of education through its various educational establishments across the globe.
title: Our Own English High School, Al Ain

abstract: Taweethapisek School was established on July 19, 1895 by [[King Rama V|King Rama V]] who ruled the Kingdom twice as long as his grandfather, [[King Rama II|King Rama II]]. To celebrate this special occasion, King Rama V wanted to establish a school in honor of his grandfather. He donated 2,000,000 baht and persuaded the royal members to donate to build the school at Wat Arunrajawararam, the royal temple of King Rama II. King Rama V named the school “Taweethapisek”. “Tawee” means twice or double and “pisek” means coronation. When the school started, there were 162 students and 6 teachers. The first school building was 4 stories high and the first director was Khun Uparakansilapaset.In 1951, the school started to move some students to study at a new location “Wat Nakklang” because the school building at [[Wat Arun|Wat Arun]] was too small for an excessive number of students. In 1960, the school building at Wat Nakklang was finished, and all the students from 7th – 12th grade were moved to the new school that year. Since that time, the school at Nakklang has been the place to study for new students until today.
title: Taweethapisek School

abstract: Education is free at the Uzbek Gymnasium. Classes are offered for grades five through eleven. The school usually accepts more academically-inclined students. Some of the students, who mainly come from villages located in Leilek District, live in the school boarding house during the academic year.
title: Uzbek Gymnasium

abstract: Maynooth Post Primary School is a [[coeducational|Mixed-sex education]] [[multidenominational|Multidenominational school]] [[secondary school|Secondary school#Republic of Ireland]] in [[Maynooth|Maynooth]], Ireland.
title: Maynooth Post Primary School

abstract: St. Joseph's College, Wattala is a Catholic College which is a branch school of [[St. Joseph's College, Colombo|St. Joseph's College, Colombo]]..
title: St. Joseph's College, Wattala

abstract: The Army Public School Nahan (informally APS Nahan or Army School Nahan or ASN) is a co-educational day boarding school in [[Nahan|Nahan]], [[Himachal Pradesh|Himachal Pradesh]], India. It was started in the month of May 1982 in old re-appropriated barracks of [[1 PARA (SF)|1 PARA (SF)]] by the [[Army Welfare Education Society|Army Welfare Education Society]]. The school's first principal was Mrs S Samadhar. The present principal is Mr R A Prabhakar, who has occupied the post since 2011 and is the ninth principal of the school.
title: Army Public School Nahan

abstract: Anuban Ratchaburi School () was established on as a [[mixed|Mixed-sex education]] [[school|school]] for pupils aged 4 to 13. It is located in [[Ratchaburi|Ratchaburi]] [[Thailand|Thailand]]. School is government's school under the supervision of the Office of Private Education Commission (OPEC) and the Ministry of Education (MOE). The school admits boys and girls over the age of 4-13. In accordance with English Program regulations,and Native Thai Program.
title: Anuban Ratchaburi School

abstract: White Rose School System, founded in 1991, is a private [[high school|high school]] located in [[Faisalabad|Faisalabad]], [[Pakistan|Pakistan]]. It provides education to boys and girls until [[matriculation|matriculation]]. It provides [[preschool education|Nursery school]], [[primary education|primary education]], [[secondary education|secondary education]]. Its central campus is located in [[Gulistan Colony|Faisalabad]], and eight other satellite campuses are located in different towns of the city. It ranka among one of the [[most-popular educational institutes|List of educational institutions in Faisalabad]] of Faisalabad.
title: White Rose School System

abstract: Lung Kong World Federation School Limited Lau Wong Fat Secondary School (, abbr. [[LWFSS|LWFSS]]) is a [[co-educational|co-educational]] secondary school aided by the [[Education Bureau|Education Bureau]]. It was established in [[1977|1977]] by the Lung Kong Clans, named after [[Lau Wong-fat|Lau Wong-fat]].
title: Lung Kong World Federation School Limited Lau Wong Fat Secondary School

abstract: Denair High School is a [[public|State school]] [[high school|Secondary school]] located in [[Denair|Denair, California]], [[California|California]] founded in 1912.
title: Denair High School

abstract: Wah Yan College, Kowloon (WYK; [[Traditional Chinese|Traditional Chinese]]: 九龍華仁書院; [[Jyutping|Jyutping]]: gau2 lung4 wa4 jan2 syu1 jyun2, [[demonym|demonym]]: Wahyanite, pl.: Wahyanites) is a [[Roman Catholic|Roman Catholic]] secondary school for boys run by the Chinese Province of the [[Society of Jesus|Society of Jesus]]. Located at 56 [[Waterloo Road|Waterloo Road, Hong Kong]], [[Yau Ma Tei|Yau Ma Tei]], [[Kowloon|Kowloon]], it is a grant-in-aid secondary school using [[English|English Language]] as the primary medium of instruction.
title: Wah Yan College, Kowloon

abstract: The Illinois Mathematics and Science Academy, or IMSA, is a three-year residential public high school in [[Aurora, Illinois|Aurora, Illinois]], United States, with an enrollment of approximately 650 students.
title: Illinois Mathematics and Science Academy

abstract: Omaha South High School is an information technology and visual/performing arts [[magnet school|magnet school]] which educates students in grades 9–12. It is located in [[Omaha|Omaha, Nebraska]], [[Nebraska|Nebraska]], United States. Built in the 1930s, it is one of the largest high school buildings in the state.
title: Omaha South High School

abstract: Wichita East High School, known locally as "East", is a [[public|Public high school]], [[co-educational|Coeducation]] [[secondary school|secondary school]] located near the center of [[Wichita|Wichita, Kansas]], [[Kansas|Kansas]], United States. The school's campus and the building's [[Collegiate Gothic|Collegiate Gothic]] styling make it an urban landmark. With a student population of 2,348, it is the largest high school in the state.
title: Wichita East High School

abstract: PACE at Peterborough Collegiate, formerly Peterborough Collegiate Vocational School, is a [[public|Public school (government funded)]] secondary school located in [[Peterborough|Peterborough, Ontario]], [[Ontario|Ontario]], Canada and is a member of the [[Kawartha Pine Ridge District School Board|Kawartha Pine Ridge District School Board]]. It is one of the oldest public schools in the country and was the only public high school in the city of Peterborough until the opening of [[Kenner Collegiate Vocational Institute|Kenner Collegiate Vocational Institute]] in 1952. Regular student programming ended at Peterborough Collegiate Vocational School in June 2012. The building was renamed Peterborough Collegiate and in August 2012 opened as a re-purposed facility offering alternative and continuing education (ACE).
title: Peterborough Collegiate

abstract: William G. Enloe GT/IB Center for the Humanities, Sciences, and the Arts, also called William G. Enloe High School, Enloe Magnet High School and Enloe High School, is a [[public|Public school (government funded)]] [[magnet|magnet school]] high school offering [[Gifted & Talented|Gifted education]] and [[International Baccalaureate|International Baccalaureate]] programs located in eastern [[Raleigh, North Carolina|Raleigh, North Carolina]]. It is operated under the [[Wake County Public School System|Wake County Public School System]]. The school is named after [[William Gilmore Enloe|William G. Enloe]], the [[Mayor of Raleigh|Mayor of Raleigh, North Carolina]] at the time the school was opened. It was the first [[integrated|Racial integration]] public high school in the city of Raleigh.
title: William G. Enloe High School

abstract: The Académie Colarossi was an [[art school|art school]] in Paris founded in the 19th century by the [[Italian|Italy]] sculptor [[Filippo Colarossi|Filippo Colarossi]]. First located on the [[Île de la Cité|Île de la Cité]], it moved in the 1870s to 10 rue de la Grande-Chaumière in the [[6th arrondissement|6th arrondissement of Paris]]. It closed in the 1930s.The Académie was established in the 19th century as an alternative to the government-sanctioned [[École des Beaux Arts|École des Beaux Arts]] that had, in the eyes of many promising young artists at the time, become far too conservative. Along with its equivalent [[Académie Julian|Académie Julian]], and unlike the official École, the Colarossi school accepted female students and allowed them to draw from the nude male model. Among the female attendees were [[Jeanne Hébuterne|Jeanne Hébuterne]], [[Modigliani|Amedeo Modigliani]]'s muse; Scottish Impressionist [[Bessie MacNicol|Bessie MacNicol]]; Canadian Impressionist [[Emily Carr|Emily Carr]]; and French sculptor [[Camille Claudel|Camille Claudel]], who was also a student of [[Rodin|Auguste Rodin]]'s. Noted also for its classes in life sculpting, the school attracted many foreign students, including a large number from the United States.
title: Académie Colarossi

abstract: North Toronto Collegiate Institute (North Toronto CI, NTCI. or North Toronto) is a [[non-semestered|Academic term]], public [[high school|high school]] institution for over 1,200 [[students|students]] located in [[Toronto|Toronto]], [[Ontario|Ontario]], [[Canada|Canada]]. The School is operated and governed by the [[Toronto District School Board|Toronto District School Board]]. From its founding until 1998, it was overseen by the [[Toronto Board of Education|Toronto Board of Education]].
title: North Toronto Collegiate Institute

abstract: Abraham Moss Community School is a [[mixed|Mixed-sex education]] [[all-through school|all-through school]] located on a 19 hectare site situated on Crescent Road in the [[Crumpsall|Crumpsall]]/[[Cheetham Hill|Cheetham Hill]] district of [[North Manchester|North Manchester]] adjacent to the [[Abraham Moss Metrolink station|Abraham Moss Metrolink station]]. The complex also includes a leisure centre, the district library and a 230-person theatre complex. The centre also hosts other tenants mainly in the public, voluntary and community sectors. It is named after Abraham Moss, [[Lord Mayor of Manchester|Lord Mayor of Manchester]] (1953–54).
title: Abraham Moss Community School

abstract: Bloor Collegiate Institute (Bloor CI, BCI , or Bloor, originally Davenport High School and Bloor High School) is a [[public secondary school|Secondary school]] located at the intersection of [[Bloor Street|Bloor Street]] and [[Dufferin Street|Dufferin Street]] in [[Toronto|Toronto]], [[Ontario|Ontario]]. The school is located in the [[Dufferin Grove|Dufferin Grove]] neighbourhood and part of the [[Toronto Board of Education|Toronto Board of Education]] that was merged into the [[Toronto District School Board|Toronto District School Board]]. Attached to the school is [[Alpha II Alternative School|Alpha II Alternative School]].
title: Bloor Collegiate Institute

abstract: Glenbard North High School, or GBN, and locally referred to as "Glenbard" or "North", is a public closed campus four-year [[high school|high school]] located at the corner of Kuhn Road and Lies Road in [[Carol Stream, Illinois|Carol Stream, Illinois]], a western suburb of [[Chicago, Illinois|Chicago, Illinois]], in the United States. It is part of [[Glenbard Township High School District 87|Glenbard Township High School District 87]], which also includes [[Glenbard South High School|Glenbard South High School]], [[Glenbard East High School|Glenbard East High School]], and [[Glenbard West High School|Glenbard West High School]]. The North campus is the largest among the four high schools in Glenbard Township District 87, currently serving approximately 2,416 students many who reside in Carol Stream as well as portions of [[Glendale Heights|Glendale Heights, Illinois]], [[Hanover Park|Hanover Park, Illinois]], and [[Bloomingdale|Bloomingdale, Illinois]].
title: Glenbard North High School

abstract: Shawnee Mission South High School is a high school located in [[Overland Park, Kansas|Overland Park, Kansas]], United States, serving students in grades 9-12. The school is one of several public high schools located within Shawnee Mission. The school colors are green and gold and the school mascot is the Raider. The average annual enrollment is approximately 1,600 students. The school newspaper is called The Patriot.
title: Shawnee Mission South High School

abstract: Shawnee Mission West High School is a fully accredited public high school located in [[Overland Park, Kansas|Overland Park, Kansas]], United States, serving students in grades 9-12. Shawnee Mission West is one of several public high schools located within Shawnee Mission, KS. The official school colors are black and gold and the school mascot is the [[Viking|Viking]].
title: Shawnee Mission West High School

abstract: East Hills Boys High School, (frequently abbreviated to EHBHS) known until 2011 as East Hills Boys Technology High School, is a boys school in [[Panania|Panania, New South Wales]], a suburb in south-western Sydney, [[New South Wales|New South Wales]], Australia, on Lucas Road. It is a single-sex boys [[high school|high school]] operated by the [[New South Wales Department of Education|New South Wales Department of Education]] with students from years 7 to 12. The school was established in 1955.
title: East Hills Boys High School

abstract: Olathe East High School is a public high school located in [[Olathe, Kansas|Olathe, Kansas]], [[United States|United States]], serving students in grades 9-12. Olathe East is a member of the [[Kansas State High School Activities Association|Kansas State High School Activities Association]] and offers a variety of sports programs. Athletic teams compete in the 6A division and are known as the "Hawks". Extracurricular activities are also offered in the form of performing arts, school publications, and clubs. The school colors are orange and navy blue, and the school's mascot is the Hawk. Olathe East was recognized as a [[National School of Excellence|National School of Excellence]] in 1998 by the [[U.S. Department of Education|U.S. Department of Education]].
title: Olathe East High School

abstract: Cadet College Palandri, is a [[military high school|military high school]], located in [[Palandri|Palandri]], [[Azad Kashmir|Azad Kashmir]], [[Pakistan|Pakistan]]. It is located in the valley of Palandri [[Azad Kashmir|Azad Kashmir]] where students are given special training for [[National security|National security]] and defense.
title: Cadet College Palandri

abstract: Lumberton High School is a [[high school|high school]] in [[Lumberton, Texas|Lumberton, Texas]]. It is operated by the [[Lumberton Independent School District|Lumberton Independent School District]].
title: Lumberton High School

abstract: George Bush High School is a public high school located in [[Mission Bend|Mission Bend, Texas]] and in [[unincorporated|unincorporated area]] [[Fort Bend County, Texas|Fort Bend County, Texas]], serving students in grades 9-12. The school is part of the [[Fort Bend Independent School District|Fort Bend Independent School District]] and serves several areas of unincorporated Fort Bend County, including Mission Bend. The high school is named after the forty-first president of the United States, [[George Herbert Walker Bush|George Herbert Walker Bush]], who attended the school's inauguration. The school colors are orange, white, and navy blue. The average annual enrollment is approximately 2,200 students.
title: George Bush High School

abstract: [[Northside Independent School District|Northside Independent School District]] and the business community combined their resources in 1991 to create Business Careers High School.
title: Business Careers High School

abstract: Olathe Northwest High School is a fully accredited public high school located in [[Olathe, Kansas|Olathe, Kansas]], [[United States|United States]], serving students in grades 9–12. The school is one of five high schools in the Olathe School District and also one of the twelve in the Sunflower League. The school colors are blue, black, and white, and the school mascot is the Raven. Olathe Northwest was established in 2003 to help educate the rapidly increasing population of Olathe. Olathe Northwest is a member of the Kansas State High School Activities Association and offers a variety of sports programs. Athletic teams compete in the 6A division and are known as the "Ravens". Extracurricular activities are also offered in the form of performing arts, school publications, and clubs.
title: Olathe Northwest High School

abstract: Jockey Club Ti-I College (TIC or JCTIC, ) is a secondary school in [[Sha Tin|Sha Tin]], [[Hong Kong|Hong Kong]].
title: Jockey Club Ti-I College

abstract: Lasalle Secondary School is located in the [[New Sudbury|New Sudbury, Ontario]] neighbourhood of [[Greater Sudbury|Greater Sudbury]], [[Ontario|Ontario]]. It offers both the English and French Immersion programs. There are three different Specialist High Skills Majors (SHSMs) available to students at Lasalle, in Energy, Business and Sports. As well, the school offers a specialized program called The Sport and Healthy, Active Living (SHAL) program. The school is part of the[[Rainbow District School Board|Rainbow District School Board]]. As of 2007, 1104 full-time equivalent students are enrolled at the school. The students and its mascot are referred to as Lancers.
title: Lasalle Secondary School

abstract: Kwun Tong Maryknoll College is one of the limited number of schools in Hong Kong which uses English as the medium of instruction. The school curriculum uses English as medium of instruction in all subjects with the exception of Chinese-related subjects.
title: Kwun Tong Maryknoll College

abstract: Palmview High School is a public senior high school in the [[La Homa|La Homa, Texas]] [[census-designated place|census-designated place]] in [[unincorporated|unincorporated area]] [[Hidalgo County, Texas|Hidalgo County, Texas]], with a [[Mission|Mission, Texas]] postal address, and a part of the [[La Joya Independent School District|La Joya Independent School District]].
title: Palmview High School

abstract: Dodge City High School is a fully accredited high school located in the northwest area of [[Dodge City|Dodge City, Kansas]], [[Kansas|Kansas]], United States, serving students in grades 9-12. The school is operated by [[Dodge City Public Schools|Dodge City Public Schools]]. The current principal is Jacque Feist. Dodge City High School is the only high school located within the city limits of Dodge City.
title: Dodge City High School

abstract: Iola High School is a fully accredited high school located in [[Iola, Kansas|Iola, Kansas]], United States, serving students in grades 9-12. The current principal is Stacey Fager. There are two different school mascots for the high school. The boys mascot is Marv the Mustang and the girls mascot is the Fillies. The school colors are blue and gold.
title: Iola High School

abstract: The medium-size, [[co-educational|co-educational]], [[Christian school|Christian school]] has approximately 1390 students enrolled in each semester with students ranging from Pre-Prep to [[Year 12|Year 12]]. There is also an on-campus Kindy and Outside School Hours Care. Hillcrest Christian College is a member of the CSA (Christian Schools Organisation), which defines the school as a locally governed and not-for-profit organisation.
title: Hillcrest Christian College

abstract: Hunter Huss High School (abbreviated HHHS) is a public [[high school|high school]] in the [[Gaston County Schools|Gaston County Schools]] school district located in [[Gastonia, NC|Gastonia, North Carolina]]. It is the oldest existing high school building still used as a high school in [[Gaston County|Gaston County, North Carolina]]. Its attendance range covers southwestern Gaston County and includes the western portions of the City of Gastonia as well as the communities of [[South Gastonia|South Gastonia, North Carolina]] and [[Crowders Mountain|Crowders, North Carolina]], and the surrounding rural area. The current principal is Bryan Denton. Assistant principals include James Hilburn, Tammy Mims, Tonnell Oliphant, and Page Willis. Steve Gardner serves as athletic director. Feeder [[Middle Schools|Middle Schools]] are York Chester and Southwest.
title: Hunter Huss High School

abstract: Parkside High School (PHS) is a four-year public [[high school|high school]] in [[Salisbury|Salisbury, MD]], [[Wicomico County|Wicomico County, Maryland]], [[Maryland|Maryland]], [[United States|United States]]. It is one of four public high schools in Wicomico County along with [[James Bennett High School|James M. Bennett High School]], [[Wicomico High School|Wicomico High School]], and [[Mardela Middle and High School|Mardela Middle and High School]].
title: Parkside High School

abstract: On 15 February 2008, demonstrations took place surrounding the quality of education in Colegio Arubano and other schools on the island of Aruba; a 2007 study in the Colegio Arubano student body indicated that about 70% of students graduate from lower grade feeder schools and are eligible to enter Colegio Arubano. 60% of students participating in VWO pass final exams, while 50% of all HAVO students pass the HAVO final exam.
title: Colegio Arubano

abstract: Dr. Frank J. Hayden Secondary School , is located in the northern area of [[Burlington|Burlington, Ontario]], [[Ontario|Ontario]], [[Canada|Canada]], at 3040 Tim Dobbie Drive. It is an English and [[French immersion|French immersion]] school in the [[Halton District School Board|Halton District School Board]] that serves approximately 1600 grade 9-12 students. In its first year, Dr. Frank J. Hayden Secondary School served approximately 600 students in grades 9–10. The school is named for [[Special Olympics|Special Olympics]] pioneer [[Frank Hayden|Frank Hayden]].
title: Dr. Frank J. Hayden Secondary School

abstract: Address of Madhuban Goenka Vidyalaya at a glance .
title: Madhuban Goenka Vidyalaya

abstract: Sewanee Elementary School is a [[public|State school#United States]], [[coeducational|Mixed-sex education]] [[Elementary School|Elementary School]] in [[Sewanee, Tennessee|Sewanee, Tennessee]] that played a significant role during the [[integration|Racial integration]] of Tennessee Public Schools in the 1960s.
title: Sewanee Elementary School

abstract: Coláiste Pobail Acla is a secondary school located in [[Currane Peninsula|Currane Peninsula]], [[in the West of Ireland (Connacht)|West of Ireland]], near [[Achill Island|Achill Island]]. The school was formed when Scoil Damhnait (founded by Padraig Sweeney in the 1940s), a secondary school on the [[Currane Peninsula|Currane Peninsula]] in the village of Pollranny, was amalgamated with [[McHale College|McHale College]] in 2011, forming Coláiste Pobail Acla.
title: Coláiste Pobail Acla

abstract: Peabody-Burns Junior/Senior High School is a [[public high school|Secondary education in the United States]] in [[Peabody|Peabody, Kansas]], [[Kansas|Kansas]], United States, operated by [[Unified School District 398|Peabody-Burns USD 398]], and serves students of grades [[7|Seventh grade]] to [[12|Twelfth grade]]. It is the sole high school in the district for [[Peabody|Peabody, Kansas]], [[Burns|Burns, Kansas]], [[Wonsevu|Wonsevu, Kansas]], and nearby rural areas of [[Marion|Marion County, Kansas]] / [[Chase|Chase County, Kansas]] / [[Harvey|Harvey County, Kansas]] / [[Butler|Butler County, Kansas]] Counties.
title: Peabody-Burns Junior/Senior High School

abstract: Somerset Area High School is a public high school in [[Somerset, Pennsylvania|Somerset, Pennsylvania]], United States, the county seat of [[Somerset County|Somerset County, Pennsylvania]]. The school serves about 700 Students in grades 9-12 and is attached to the Somerset Area Middle School.
title: Somerset Area High School

abstract: Somerset County Technology Center (previously named Somerset County Technical Institute, or "SCTI,") is a Public Vocational-Technical School, located just outside the county seat in Somerset Township. SCTC has eight sending High Schools, in which students attend the center for one-half of the day and their home school for the other one half. A plethora of adult education opportunities, both on and off site are available to county residents.
title: Somerset County Technology Center

abstract: Gulf Indian High School or GIHS is a [[CBSE|Central Board of Secondary Education]] affiliated school located in the [[Al Garhoud|Al Garhoud]] Area of Dubai . It is a senior secondary school with students from 3-17 where it is KG - 12. Students in 12th prepare for their All India Senior School Certificate Examination (AISSCE) as it is their senior and final year. The school is affiliated to the [[CBSE|Central Board of Secondary Education]], [[New Delhi|New Delhi]]. Dominated by discipline and well knit community, assessed by the [[KHDA|KHDA]] it came out with an 'Acceptable'.
title: Gulf Indian High School

abstract: St. Joseph's Anglo-Indian Higher Secondary School is an all-girls day school at [[Perambur|Perambur]] in the city of [[Chennai|Chennai]] that was founded in 1883 by Fr. J. Allen, initially as an attachment to Our Lady of Lourdes Shrine. It is now managed by the [[Presentation Sisters|Presentation Sisters]].
title: St. Joseph's Anglo-Indian Higher Secondary School

abstract: Chowchilla High School is a [[public|State school]] [[high school|Secondary school]] located in [[Chowchilla|Chowchilla, California]], [[California|California]].
title: Chowchilla High School

abstract: Suksanari School is a school that provides education in both lower secondary school and high school education. The school is a part of the Thai government education system. The founder, Somdejputthajarn (Nuam Putthasaramahatera), opened the school inside Anongkaram Temple in order to provide education for females, who had historically had not been emphasized in the Thai education system. Therefore, he opened the school and employed Mr. Toop to be a teacher.
title: Suksanari School

abstract: Ahamansu Islamic Senior High School started as private high School in 2006 by the Zongo Community with funds from donor organisations. In support of the idea, the Ahamansu Traditional Council offered large parcels of land to be used as campus for the establishment of the school.
title: Ahamansu Islamic Senior High School

abstract: Wirt County High School (WCHS) is a secondary school located in [[Elizabeth, West Virginia|Elizabeth, West Virginia]], [[United States|United States]], that serves grades nine through twelve. It is in [[Wirt County|Wirt County]], West Virginia.
title: Wirt County High School

abstract: Actor [[Shah Rukh Khan|Shah Rukh Khan]] shared multiple teasers of he song "Zaalima" on [[Twitter|Twitter]] along with some [[lyrics|lyrics]] before the full release of the song.
title: Zaalima

abstract: "All Dressed in Love" is a song written by [[Gnarls Barkley|Gnarls Barkley]]'s [[Cee-Lo|Cee Lo Green]], Matt Kahane (known as MC Jack Splash from the group Plantlife) and [[Salaam Remi|Salaam Remi]] and recorded by [[Jennifer Hudson|Jennifer Hudson]] for [[Sex and the City: The Movie|Sex and the City: The Movie]]. Despite not being released as a single, the song debuted at number 72 on the [[UK Singles Chart|UK Singles Chart]] on the strength of [[paid download|paid downloads]] alone.
title: All Dressed in Love

abstract: "Our Goodman" ([[Child|Child ballad]] 274, [[Roud|Roud Folk Song Index]] 114) is a Scottish and English humorous [[folk song|Folk music]]. It describes the efforts of an unfaithful wife to explain away the evidence of her infidelity. A version of the song, "[[Seven Drunken Nights|Seven Drunken Nights]]", was a hit record for [[The Dubliners|The Dubliners]] in the 1960s.
title: Our Goodman

abstract: "Loves Me Not" was a planned fourth single for the album [[Dangerous and Moving|Dangerous and Moving]] by [[t.A.T.u.|t.A.T.u.]] However, due to the group leaving Universal Records, the song's release was postponed, then later cancelled in all countries, except for a limited release in France. Even though it was cancelled, it is available on some countries' iTunes Music Store with only the original song. A video of the group performing the song at "Glam As You" in Paris was aired on a few television stations worldwide. Music and lyrics by Andy Kubiszewski and Ed Buller. Cover photo taken by [[Bryan Adams|Bryan Adams]].
title: Loves Me Not

abstract: "I See You (Theme from Avatar)" (also referred to as "I See You") is the official theme song recorded by British singer [[Leona Lewis|Leona Lewis]] for the 2009 film [[Avatar|Avatar (2009 film)]], directed by [[James Cameron|James Cameron]], and [[its accompanying soundtrack|Avatar: Music from the Motion Picture]] (2009). It was written by [[James Horner|James Horner]] and [[Kuk Harrell|Kuk Harrell]], with production done by Simon Franglen. A [[pop|Pop music]] inspired [[ballad|ballad]], the lyrics, which reflect the story line of the film, are about love, emotion and power. The song received multiple comparisons to [[Celine Dion|Celine Dion]]'s "[[My Heart Will Go On|My Heart Will Go On]]", which is the official theme song written by Horner for another film directed by Cameron, [[Titanic|Titanic (1997 film)]] (1997). Lewis has performed the song on [[So You Think You Can Dance|So You Think You Can Dance (United States)]] and [[Today|Today (U.S. TV program)]], and it was included on the set list of her debut concert tour, [[The Labyrinth|The Labyrinth (tour)]] (2010). It peaked at number 47 on the [[Irish Singles Chart|Irish Singles Chart]] and number 24 on the US [[Adult Contemporary|Adult Contemporary (chart)]] chart.
title: I See You (Theme from Avatar)

abstract: "Lies Greed Misery" is a song by American [[rock|rock music]] band [[Linkin Park|Linkin Park]]. It is the fourth track from their fifth studio album, [[Living Things|Living Things (Linkin Park album)]]. It has entered the UK Rock Singles Charts at number 26, although it hasn't been released as a single. The song was written by the band and produced by co-lead vocalist [[Mike Shinoda|Mike Shinoda]] and [[Rick Rubin|Rick Rubin]]. "Lies Greed Misery" was used as a promotional single and was the reward for a scavenger hunt contest run by Linkin Park. It was used in the promotion of [[Medal of Honor: Warfighter|Medal of Honor: Warfighter]] and got its premier in the multiplayer trailer for the game. Its working title was "Piledriver" and later "Breaking Point".
title: Lies Greed Misery

abstract: "Until It Beats No More" is a song recorded by American entertainer [[Jennifer Lopez|Jennifer Lopez]] for her seventh studio album, [[Love?|Love?]] (2011). It was written by [[Evan Bogart|E. Kidd Bogart]] and [[Jörgen Elofsson|Jörgen Elofsson]], with its producer Troy "Radio" Johnson. The song is a [[soft rock|soft rock]] song that speaks of a love that never dies. [[Music critics|Music journalism]] made note of "Until It Beats No More" being an ode to Lopez's then-husband [[Marc Anthony|Marc Anthony]]. The song received universal acclaim from [[music critics|Music journalism]], who cited it as a stand-out track on Love?. Upon the release of Love?, the song debuted at number nine on the [[South Korea Gaon International Chart|Gaon Chart]].
title: Until It Beats No More

abstract: "Pani Da Rang" () () is a song written and composed by [[Ayushmann Khurrana|Ayushmann Khurrana]] and [[Rochak Kohli|Rochak Kohli]] for the Indian film [[Vicky Donor|Vicky Donor]]. Picturised on [[Ayushmann Khurrana|Ayushmann Khurrana]] and [[Yami Gautam|Yami Gautam]] along with other co-actors from the Vicky Donor ensemble the song features vocals by [[Ayushmann Khurrana|Ayushmann Khurrana]] and Sukanya Purkayastha. The song primarily consists of [[Punjabi|Punjabi language]] lyrics with some [[Hindi|Hindi]] words included as well.
title: Pani Da Rang

abstract: "SMS (Bangerz)" was written by Miley Cyrus, [[Mike Will Made It|Mike Will Made It]], [[Sean Garrett|Sean Garrett]], and Marz, while production was handled by Mike Will Made It and Marz. Stephen Hybicki and Tim Roberts recorded the track with help from Mike Gaydusek, and Jaycen Joshua mixed it with assistants of Ryan Kaul. [[Chris "Tek" O'Ryan|Chris O'Ryan]] handled engineering the song, and it was further mastered by Dave Kutch at the Mastering Palace. The track is the third on Cyrus's fourth album [[Bangerz|Bangerz]], which was released in 2013.
title: SMS (Bangerz)

abstract: "Villikins and his Dinah" is based on "William and Dinah", a [[folk|folk music]] ballad extant from at least the early 19th century which was still being sung and collected in the early 20th. The theme of the ballad is the traditional one of lovers parted by parental interference who then commit suicide and are buried in one grave.
title: Villikins and his Dinah

abstract: "Sadda Haq" has a powerful set of lyrics with a rebellious tone. The [[hook|hook (music)]], "sadda haq aithe rakh" is [[Punjabi|Punjabi language]] for "give me what's mine, right here (and right now)".
title: Sadda Haq

abstract: Still Loving It is an [[English language|English language]] song performed by Swedish singer [[Eric Saade|Eric Saade]]. It taken from Saade's second album, [[Saade Vol. 1|Saade Vol. 1]], and was first released on 14 January 2011 in Sweden.
title: Still Loving It

abstract: "Heart Beats Again" was solely written by [[Dami Im|Dami Im]] and produced by Carl Dimitaga. It was the last song written for her third studio album [[Heart Beats|Heart Beats (Dami Im album)]]. Im said that "Heart Beats Again" has a [[double meaning|double meaning]], with one being that it is about the two loves in her life—husband Noah Kim and [[Jesus|Jesus]]. She spoke about the song in an interview with [[BuzzFeed|BuzzFeed]], saying: "It's the last song that I wrote for this album. [The album] was kind of finished, and I just thought 'Mmm, I still need one more song to kind of summarise the album and make it really, truly my own'. I wrote 'Heart Beats [Again]' at home, by myself, and it might not be a perfect song, but I just felt like it really expressed, like, the essence of why I’m doing this. It's the song that represents who I am, in an unpolluted way."
title: Heart Beats Again

abstract: "Ultralight Beam" is a song by American hip hop artist [[Kanye West|Kanye West]], from his seventh [[studio album|studio album]] [[The Life of Pablo|The Life of Pablo]] (2016). The song features singer [[The-Dream|The-Dream]], [[R&B|Contemporary R&B]] singer [[Kelly Price|Kelly Price]], rapper [[Chance the Rapper|Chance the Rapper]], [[gospel|Gospel music]] singer [[Kirk Franklin|Kirk Franklin]], and a ten-piece [[choir|choir]], with additional vocals by Natalie Green and Samoria Green. The song was first performed live on [[Saturday Night Live|Saturday Night Live]] on February 13, 2016, with the acts on the song. The song charted in the [[United States|United States]], [[United Kingdom|United Kingdom]], [[Ireland|Ireland]], and [[Canada|Canada]] in 2016.
title: Ultralight Beam

abstract: "I'm Not Gonna Miss You" is a song recorded by American [[country music|country music]] artist [[Glen Campbell|Glen Campbell]] and [[The Wrecking Crew|The Wrecking Crew (music)]]. Co-written by Campbell and producer [[Julian Raymond|Julian Raymond]], the song was released on September 30, 2014 for the soundtrack to the documentary [[Glen Campbell: I'll Be Me|Glen Campbell: I'll Be Me]], which focuses on the singer's diagnosis of [[Alzheimer's disease|Alzheimer's disease]] and his final tour.
title: I'm Not Gonna Miss You

abstract: "Try to Follow Me" (; also known as "Follow Me") is a song by South Korean girl group [[2NE1|2NE1]]. It was originally released on February 9, 2010 to promote [[Samsung|Samsung]]'s "Corby CF" mobile phone. It later was released with the album "[[To Anyone|To Anyone]]" in September, 2010.
title: Try to Follow Me

abstract: "El Son de la Negra" is a Mexican [[folk song|folk song]], originally from [[Tepic, Nayarit|Tepic, Nayarit]], best known from an adaptation by [[Jaliscian|Jalisco]] musical composer [[Blas Galindo|Blas Galindo]] in 1940 for his suite Sones de mariachi.
title: El Son de la Negra

abstract: Despite not being released as a single, "Out from Under" managed to peak at number nineteen on [[Billboard|Billboard (magazine)]] [[Bubbling Under Hot 100 Singles|Bubbling Under Hot 100 Singles]], following the release of Circus, and at number thirty-two in Sweden in June 2009. The song was featured on the fifth season of [[MTV|MTV]]'s [[The Hills|The Hills (TV series)]]. It was included on The Essential Britney Spears compilation album.
title: Out from Under

abstract: ‘Little Robin Redbreast’ is an [[English language|English language]] [[nursery rhyme|nursery rhyme]], chiefly notable as evidence of the way traditional rhymes are changed and edited. It has a [[Roud Folk Song Index|Roud Folk Song Index]] number of 20612.
title: Little Robin Redbreast

abstract: "Sexy to Me" is a song recorded by American singer [[JoJo|JoJo (singer)]]. It was written by JoJo, [[James Washington|Jim Beanz]], [[Marcella Araica|Marcella Araica]], [[Kenna|Kenna]] and [[Nathaniel "Danja" Hills|Danja (record producer)]], who also produced the song.
title: Sexy to Me

abstract: "BTD (Before the Dawn)" is a song released by the [[South Korea|South Korean]] boy band [[Infinite|Infinite (band)]]. The song is the second track of the group's second EP [[Evolution|Evolution (Infinite EP)]], released on January 6, 2011. A Japanese version of the song served as their debut single in Japan. It was released on November 19, 2011 in 3 different editions.
title: BTD (Before the Dawn)

abstract: A later version, Vi är på gång - VM 2006, was appointed [[fight song|fight song]] of [[Team Sweden|Sweden national football team]] for the [[2006 FIFA World Cup|2006 FIFA World Cup]] in [[Germany|Germany]].
title: Vi är på gång

abstract: "Lionsong" is the second song by Icelandic singer and musician [[Björk|Björk]] from her eighth studio album, [[Vulnicura|Vulnicura]]. It was written and composed by Björk and features beats by Venezuelan musician [[Arca|Arca (producer)]], who co-produced the track with her.
title: Lionsong

abstract: "4 Carats" is a song by American recording artist [[Kelly Clarkson|Kelly Clarkson]], from her sixth studio album, [[Wrapped in Red|Wrapped in Red]] (2013). Written by Clarkson, [[Cathy Dennis|Cathy Dennis]], [[Livvi Franc|Livvi Franc]], with [[Greg Kurstin|Greg Kurstin]], who helmed the song's production. A Christmas pop song, "4 Carats" was originally written for Clarkson's seventh studio album that would have followed-up Wrapped in Red. Lyrically, the song explores the themes of [[holiday gift giving|Christmas#Christmas gift giving]] and [[materialism|materialism]], with the singer asking [[Santa Claus|Santa Claus]] for a [[four carat|carat (mass)]] [[gemstone|gemstone]] [[ring|ring (jewellery)]] for [[Christmas day|Christmas day]]. Clarkson took inspirations from the songs "[[Santa Baby|Santa Baby]]" (1953) and "[[Material Girl|Material Girl]]" (1984), sung by [[Eartha Kitt|Eartha Kitt]] and [[Madonna|Madonna (entertainer)]], respectively, and described it as a crossover between the two.
title: 4 Carats

abstract: "Dans la place pour être" is a song by French hip hop duo [[Casseurs Flowters|Casseurs Flowters]] and produced by [[Skread|Skread]]. It is the 9th track from their debut [[studio album|studio album]], [[Orelsan et Gringe sont les Casseurs Flowters|Orelsan et Gringe sont les Casseurs Flowters]], where its title is "20h08 – Dans la place pour être". Despite not being officially released as a [[single|Single (music)]], the song entered the French Singles Chart at number 34 on 23 November 2013, and has since peaked at that same position.
title: Dans la place pour être

abstract: "Kick Your Game" is a song recorded by the American group [[TLC|TLC (group)]] for their second studio album, [[CrazySexyCool|CrazySexyCool]] (1994). The "[[funk|funky]]" [[R&B|Contemporary R&B]]-[[dance|Dance music]] track was written by frequent group collaborator [[Jermaine Dupri|Jermaine Dupri]], [[Manuel Seal|Manuel Seal]] and member [[Lisa "Left Eye" Lopes|Lisa Lopes]]. In August 1995, it was picked by [[LaFace|LaFace Records]] and [[Arista Records|Arista Records]] for release as a [[promotional|Promotional recording]] [[airplay|airplay]] single from the album. In the song's lyrics, TLC teaches boys who flirt in a [[club|Nightclub]] "the proper way to approach a lady"; Lopes' rap verses reportedly referred to then-boyfriend [[Andre Rison|Andre Rison]], whose house she [[burned down|arson]] during the making of CrazySexyCool.
title: Kick Your Game

abstract: "9th Inning" is a [[song|song]] by American rapper, producer, singer-songwriter [[Missy Elliott|Missy Elliott]] featuring guest appearance by childhood friend and longtime collaborator [[Timbaland|Timbaland]]. Originally, a snippet was released on Elliott's official website on September 10, 2012. This song, along with the accompanying "[[Triple Threat|Triple Threat (Missy Elliott song)]]", made its full debut via [[Ustream|Ustream]] on September 17, 2012 and were both released as promotional singles on September 18, 2012.
title: 9th Inning

abstract: The origins of "Little Wing" have been traced back to the 1966 recording of "(My Girl) She's a Fox", an R&B song which features Hendrix playing [[Curtis Mayfield|Curtis Mayfield]]-influenced guitar accompaniment. He developed the song while performing in New York City's Greenwich Village prior to his involvement with producer [[Chas Chandler|Chas Chandler]]. After being inspired by events at the 1967 [[Monterey Pop Festival|Monterey Pop Festival]], Hendrix completed the song in October 1967, when it was recorded by the Experience during the sessions for their second album [[Axis: Bold as Love|Axis: Bold as Love]].
title: Little Wing

abstract: "Since I've Been Loving You" is a song by the English [[rock|Rock music]] band [[Led Zeppelin|Led Zeppelin]], released in 1970 on the album [[Led Zeppelin III|Led Zeppelin III]].
title: Since I've Been Loving You

abstract: "Stairway to Heaven" is a song by the English [[rock|Rock music]] band [[Led Zeppelin|Led Zeppelin]], released in late 1971. It was composed by guitarist [[Jimmy Page|Jimmy Page]] and vocalist [[Robert Plant|Robert Plant]] for the band's [[untitled fourth studio album|Led Zeppelin IV]] (often called Led Zeppelin IV). It is often referred to as one of the greatest rock songs of all time.
title: Stairway to Heaven

abstract: "Dance With Me Now!" (stylized as "DANCE WITH ME NOW!" in digital formats) is a song recorded and performed by Japanese musical unit [[E-girls|E-girls]]. It was released by [[Rhythm Zone|Rhythm Zone]] and Avex Music Creative Inc. on February 10, 2016 as a promotional single to their first [[greatest hits|greatest hits]] album, E.G. Smile: E-girls Best (2016). The concept for the single was to emphasize a cooler, sexier and edgier image than their previous singles, which was then later developed and included onto the bands fourth studio and [[concept album|concept album]], E.G. Crazy (2017).
title: Dance With Me Now!

abstract: "Jeena Jeena" is a romantic [[Hindi song|Music of Bollywood]] from the [[2015 Bollywood|List of Bollywood films of 2015]] film [[Badlapur|Badlapur (film)]]. Composed by [[Sachin-Jigar|Sachin-Jigar]], the song is sung by popular [[Bollywood|Bollywood]] singer from Pakistan [[Atif Aslam|Atif Aslam]] , with lyrics penned by [[Dinesh Vijan|Dinesh Vijan]] and Priya Saraiya. The music video of the track features actors [[Varun Dhawan|Varun Dhawan]], [[Yami Gautam|Yami Gautam]] and [[Atif Aslam|Atif Aslam]]. Jeena Jeena is one of the biggest hits of 2015.
title: Jeena Jeena

abstract: "Not a Criminal" is a track that was slated for [[Chamillionaire|Chamillionaire]]'s second album, [[Ultimate Victory|Ultimate Victory]] (2007). The song, which features [[Kelis|Kelis]] on the chorus, was originally going to be released as the album's [[lead single|lead single]], but was replaced by "[[Hip Hop Police|Hip Hop Police]]". It was produced by [[Australia|Australian]] producer [[Styalz Fuego|Styalz Fuego]] of the Affinity Music Group. The song has another version, "Not a Criminal Part II", which features [[Busta Rhymes|Busta Rhymes]] and [[Snoop Dogg|Snoop Dogg]]. The single debuted and peaked at number three on the [[Bubbling Under Hot 100 Singles|Bubbling Under Hot 100 Singles]] chart, but soon dropped off the charts.
title: Not a Criminal

abstract: "Music Flyer" is a song recorded and performed by Japanese collective unit [[E-girls|E-girls]], taken as a [[promotional single|Promotional recording]] of their third studio album [[E.G. Time|E.G. Time]] (2015). It was released on December 17, 2014 for streaming, and December 24 as a limited pre-order track to the record through digital outlets such as [[iTunes Store|iTunes Store]] and [[Amazon.com|Amazon.com]]; the song was made available for worldwide digital consumption on January 1, 2015, the same date as the parent record's release. It was written, composed, arranged and produced by Japanese musician and [[Capsule|Capsule (band)]] member [[Yasutaka Nakata|Yasutaka Nakata]], marking the bands first collaboration with him, and was co-produced by Exile Hiro.
title: Music Flyer

abstract: "Cudi Montage" is a song by American [[hip hop|Hip hop music]] duo [[Kids See Ghosts|Kids See Ghosts]], composed of [[Kanye West|Kanye West]] and [[Kid Cudi|Kid Cudi]], released as the seventh track off their eponymous debut album [[Kids See Ghosts|Kids See Ghosts (album)]] (2018). The song is also notable for its sample of "Burn the Rain" by [[Kurt Cobain|Kurt Cobain]].
title: Cudi Montage

abstract: "The Games We Play" is a song by American rapper [[Pusha T|Pusha T]], from his third studio album, [[Daytona|Daytona (album)]] (2018).
title: The Games We Play

abstract: According to Chuck Crisafulli, the song "Been a Son" was one of the early indications that frontman [[Kurt Cobain|Kurt Cobain]] was capable of popcraft. Cobain had kept his poppier influences to himself in the band's early days, but once Nirvana's debut album [[Bleach|Bleach (Nirvana album)]] was done, he made no secret of his love of songs by [[John Lennon|John Lennon]] and [[The Beatles|The Beatles]] during interviews. The song represents one of the earliest statements from Cobain on the issues of sex and gender.
title: Been a Son

abstract: "Take the Skinheads Bowling" is the [[signature song|signature song]] of [[Santa Cruz, California|Santa Cruz, California]] [[alternative rock|alternative rock]] band [[Camper Van Beethoven|Camper Van Beethoven]], written by [[David Lowery|David Lowery (musician)]] and released on their 1985 album [[Telephone Free Landslide Victory|Telephone Free Landslide Victory]]. The song (as covered by the band [[Teenage Fanclub|Teenage Fanclub]]) was notably featured in the [[Michael Moore|Michael Moore]] documentary [[Bowling for Columbine|Bowling for Columbine]], and received substantial airplay on [[KROQ|KROQ]], and [[BBC Radio 2|BBC Radio 2]], (this is unlikely as the station only played middle-of-the-road music at that time, and certainly no 'cutting edge' new music) as well as The [[Dr. Demento|Dr. Demento]] Show. The song was also recorded by Welsh rock band [[Manic Street Preachers|Manic Street Preachers]] as a B-side to their 1996 single "[[Australia|Australia (Manic Street Preachers song)]]" and subsequently included on their B-side compilation album [[Lipstick Traces (A Secret History of Manic Street Preachers)|Lipstick Traces (A Secret History of Manic Street Preachers)]].
title: Take the Skinheads Bowling

abstract: The song was originally written by Fahrat, an Armenian [[ashugh|Ashik]] from Mush. The song's hero is Arabo, the famed [[fedayi|Armenian fedayi]], who is now presented as a symbol of the [[Armenian liberation movement|Armenian national movement]]. He mainly operated in [[Mush Plain|Muş]] and [[Sasun|Sason]]. In 1893, while returning from Caucasus, his group was surrounded in a gorge near [[Bulanikh|Bulanık]]. Everyone in his group was killed, including Arabo himself.Over time its connection to Arabo's death was forgotten. This was traced in the evolution of the song's title: "Arabo's song" («Արաբոյի երգ»), "Brave Arabo's song" («Քաջ Արաբոյի երգ»), "Msheti's song" («Մշեցու երգ»), "Zartir lao" («Զարթիր լաօ»), etc.
title: Zartir lao

abstract: "Día Especial" () is a [[Latin pop|Latin pop]] ballad performed by Colombian singer [[Shakira|Shakira]] from her album [[Fijación Oral Vol. 1|Fijación Oral Vol. 1]]. The song is about how a day is made special from [[forgiveness|forgiveness]]. "Día Especial" is not an official single to Fijación Oral Vol. 1, but was popular around the time of the album's release, peaking at number 26 on the US [[Billboard Latin Pop Songs|Latin Pop Airplay]]. [[Gustavo Cerati|Gustavo Cerati]] was the lyricist for the track with Shakira and [[Luis Fernando Ochoa|Luis Fernando Ochoa]] as co-writers for the music. The English version is entitled "The Day and the Time" and features on the album [[Oral Fixation Vol. 2|Oral Fixation Vol. 2]].
title: Día Especial

abstract: Woh Humsafar Tha (, lit. He was [my] co-journeyer) is a [[ghazal|ghazal]] written in 1971 by [[Naseer Turabi|Naseer Turabi]] and made famous as the title song of the [[Pakistani|Pakistan]] drama serial [[Humsafar|Humsafar]] which aired on [[Hum TV|Hum TV]]. The ghazal was originally sung by [[Abida Parveen|Abida Parveen]] and later by [[Qurat-ul-Ain Balouch|Qurat-ul-Ain Balouch]].
title: Woh Humsafar Tha

abstract: Music was written by [[Slavko Avsenik|Slavko Avsenik]], lyrics written by Marjan Stare and arranged by Slavko's brother Vilko Ovsenik. Original voice was contributed by three vocals in the band at that time: Ema Prodnik, Jožica Svete and Alfi Nipič. Song world premiered at opening of [[5th FIS Ski Flying World Championships|FIS Ski Flying World Championships 1979]] on 15 March 1979 when band performed in the rain on the stage under RTV dom next to famous flying hill [[Letalnica bratov Gorišek|Letalnica bratov Gorišek]]. The main chorus »Planica, Planica, snežena kraljica« (Planica, Planica, snow queen) is played every time someone jumps further than 220 meters. In 1979 it was first time released on »Frochloche stunden mit music« in [[Germany|Germany]]. A year later song was first released in Slovenia on »Vesele urice«.
title: Planica, Planica

abstract: The Girl and the Crow (in [[Swedish|Swedish language]]: Flickan och kråkan) is a song composed by [[Mikael Wiehe|Mikael Wiehe]], originally published on his album "Kråksånger" in 1981.
title: Flickan och kråkan

abstract: "Gimme What I Don't Know (I Want)" is a song recorded by American singer-songwriter [[Justin Timberlake|Justin Timberlake]] for his fourth [[studio album|studio album]], [[The 20/20 Experience – 2 of 2|The 20/20 Experience – 2 of 2]] (2013). It was written and produced by Timberlake, [[Timothy "Timbaland" Mosley|Timbaland]] and [[Jerome "J-Roc" Harmon|Jerome "J-Roc" Harmon]], with additional writing from [[James Fauntleroy|James Fauntleroy]].
title: Gimme What I Don't Know (I Want)

abstract: Upon its release, "Buzzcut Season" was met with positive reviews from [[music critics|music journalism]], who praised its production and Lorde's vocal delivery on the track. The song reached number twenty-nine on the US [[Billboard|Billboard (magazine)]] [[Hot Rock Songs|Hot Rock Songs]] and number thirty-eight on the [[ARIA Streaming Tracks|ARIA Charts]]. Lorde performed "Buzzcut Season" during a number of shows, including the [[Late Show with David Letterman|Late Show with David Letterman]].
title: Buzzcut Season

abstract: "Regarde comme il fait beau (dehors)" is a song by French hip hop duo [[Casseurs Flowters|Casseurs Flowters]] and produced by [[Skread|Skread]]. It is the second track from their debut [[studio album|studio album]], [[Orelsan et Gringe sont les Casseurs Flowters|Orelsan et Gringe sont les Casseurs Flowters]], where its title is "15h02 – Regarde comme il fait beau (dehors)". The song has not been officially released as a [[single|Single (music)]], but nevertheless entered the French Singles Chart at number 136 on 30 November 2013, and has since peaked at number 58. The song also features uncredited vocals from French [[rock|Rock music]] artist [[Izïa|Izïa]].
title: Regarde comme il fait beau (dehors)

abstract: "Best, Best" is a song by American rapper-songwriter [[Missy Elliott|Missy Elliott]]. It was originally supposed to appear on the 2008 recorded version of Elliott's seventh studio album, and was even released as promotional single on June 13, 2008, but since that version of the album was abandoned in the spring of 2009, it was thereby scrapped.
title: Best, Best

abstract: Hoy Gano Yo ([[en:|English language]] "Today I Win") is the tenth track from [[WarCry|WarCry (band)]]'s [[self titled debut album|WarCry (album)]]. It's one of the band's best-known songs, played nearly in every concert often as closing track, due to its lyrics about the way [[heavy metal|heavy metal music]] is seen in the society. "Hoy Gano Yo" is featured on live album [[Directo A La Luz|Directo A La Luz]] on both [[DVD|DVD]] and [[CD|Compact Disc]] versions. The song also appears on [[Finnish|Finland]] [[music video game|music video game]] [[Frets on Fire|Frets on Fire]].
title: Hoy Gano Yo

abstract: "Duncan and Brady", also known as "Been on the Job Too Long", "Twinkle, Twinkle, Little Star", or simply "Brady", is a [[traditional|Traditional music]] [[murder|Murder ballad]] [[ballad|ballad]] about the shooting of a policeman, Brady, by a bartender, Duncan. The song's lyrics stemmed from actual events, involving the shooting of James Brady in the Charles Starkes Saloon in [[St. Louis, Missouri|St. Louis, Missouri]]. Harry Duncan was convicted of the murder, and later executed. Originally recorded by [[Wilmer Watts|Wilmer Watts]] & his Lonely Eagles in 1929, it has been recorded numerous times, most famously by [[Lead Belly|Lead Belly]], also by [[Judy Henske|Judy Henske]], [[Dave Van Ronk|Dave Van Ronk]], [[The Johnson Mountain Boys|Johnson Mountain Boys]], [[New Riders of the Purple Sage|New Riders of the Purple Sage]], and [[Bob Dylan|Bob Dylan]].
title: Duncan and Brady

abstract: "Not Like the Movies" is a song by American singer [[Katy Perry|Katy Perry]] from her third studio album, [[Teenage Dream|Teenage Dream (Katy Perry album)]] (2010). She co-wrote the song with its producer [[Greg Wells|Greg Wells]]. [[Capitol Records|Capitol Records]] released it on August 3, 2010, as the album's first [[promotional single|Promotional recording]]. The song is a power ballad from the point of view of a teenage girl. Lyrically, the girl contemplates her first time and how "it wasn't right". She realizes through that experience that her "prince" is still "out there" waiting for her. It was written when Perry first started dating her then-husband, [[Russell Brand|Russell Brand]].
title: Not Like the Movies

abstract: "Booty Bounce" is a song by American recording artist [[Dev|Dev (singer)]]. It was produced by [[The Cataracs|The Cataracs]]. Although it was released after, "Booty Bounce" was sampled in [[Far East Movement|Far East Movement]]'s hit single "[[Like a G6|Like a G6]]" which reached number one on the US [[Billboard Hot 100|Billboard Hot 100]] chart, and sold over three million downloads in the country. It was also featured on Dev's 2011 mixtape Is Hot: The Mixtape.
title: Booty Bounce

abstract: Iragai Pole ([[English|English language]]:Like a feather...) is a song from the 2010 [[Tamil feature film|Tamil cinema]] [[Naan Mahaan Alla|Naan Mahaan Alla (2010 film)]], composed and performed by [[Yuvan Shankar Raja|Yuvan Shankar Raja]]. The song, with lyrics by Yugabharathy, was released as part of the soundtrack album of the film on 16 July 2010. The song became one of the most popular songs in 2010.
title: Iragai Pole

abstract: The song was written as the follow-up to "[[Uptown Funk|Uptown Funk]]" from [[Uptown Special|Uptown Special]]. "I Can't Lose" was written mostly by [[Jeff Bhasker|Jeff Bhasker]] and samples [[Snoop Dogg|Snoop Dogg]]'s "Ain't No Fun (If the Homies Can't Have None)" from [[Doggystyle|Doggystyle]] and "Hot Music" by [[Soho|Soho (band)]]; in an interview with [[The Guardian|The Guardian]], Ronson described how Bhaskar had decided that the most appropriate way of discovering an appropriate vocalist for the song was to "drive through the deep south to find someone to sing it", an idea which Ronson loved. This trawling process led to Ronson and Bhaskar sifting through "a few hundred amazing singers" in assorted churches, nightclubs, bars and community centres. However they "had a very specific vocalist in mind", who turned out to be Keyone as both of them realised as she started singing in [[Mississippi State University|Mississippi State University]].
title: I Can't Lose

abstract: "I Thought About Killing You" is a song by American hip-hop artist [[Kanye West|Kanye West]] from his eighth studio album, [[Ye|Ye (album)]] (2018). Within the song, West sampled "Fr3sh" by Kareem Lofty without licensing the sample and removed it in the end. The song was met with mixed critical reception.
title: I Thought About Killing You

abstract: "Cops Shot the Kid" is a song by American rapper [[Nas|Nas]], featuring fellow rap artist [[Kanye West|Kanye West]], from his eleventh studio album, [[Nasir|Nasir (album)]] (2018).
title: Cops Shot the Kid

abstract: The Carny is a song by [[Nick Cave and the Bad Seeds|Nick Cave and the Bad Seeds]] appearing on their fourth studio album [[Your Funeral... My Trial|Your Funeral... My Trial]]. It was written by [[Nick Cave|Nick Cave]] and was recorded in August 1986 at Hansa Tonstudio and Strongroom.
title: The Carny

abstract: "Kabhi Kabhie Mere Dil Mein" ([[Urdu|Urdu]]: کبھی کبھی میرے دل میں, [[Hindi|Hindi]]: कभी कभी मेरे दिल में खयाल आता है, [[English|English language]]: 'Sometimes..in My Heart') is a song from 1976 [[Bollywood|Bollywood]] movie [[Kabhi Kabhie|Kabhie Kabhie (1976 film)]] (English title: Sometimes...) directed by [[Yash Chopra|Yash Chopra]]. The title song of the film written by [[Sahir Ludhianvi|Sahir Ludhianvi]] was performed by [[Mukesh|Mukesh (singer)]].
title: Kabhi Kabhie Mere Dil Mein

abstract: "I Wanna Make You Feel Good" is a [[dance-pop|dance-pop]] song released in [[1984|1984 in music]] by [[The System|The System (band)]]. The song appears on the album [[X-Periment|X-Periment]]. B-side of the single is "Promises Can Break", another song from the album. The single version was a moderate hit in the [[United Kingdom|United Kingdom]], reaching number 73 on [[UK Singles Chart|UK Singles Chart]]. It was also a minor radio hit.
title: I Wanna Make You Feel Good

abstract: Bhaag D.K. Bose, Aandhi Aayi (English: Run D.K. Bose, The Storm's Here) is a [[Hindi|Hindi]] song composed and sung by [[Ram Sampath|Ram Sampath]], with lyrics penned by [[Amitabh Bhattacharya|Amitabh Bhattacharya]] for [[soundtrack album|soundtrack album]] of the film [[Delhi Belly|Delhi Belly (film)]]. The promotional video of the song, featuring [[Imran Khan|Imran Khan (Bollywood actor)]], [[Vir Das|Vir Das]] and [[Kunaal Roy Kapur|Kunaal Roy Kapur]], has been directed by Sajid Shaikh.
title: Bhaag D.K. Bose

abstract: "Watch n' Learn" is a song recorded by [[Barbadian|Barbadian people]] recording artist [[Rihanna|Rihanna]], for her sixth studio album [[Talk That Talk|Talk That Talk (Rihanna album)]] (2011). It was written by [[Priscilla Renea|Priscilla Renea]], [[Chauncey Hollis|Hit-Boy]], Rihanna and Alja Jackson. The production was done by Hollis under his stage-name [[Hit-Boy|Hit-Boy]]. When Renea came with an idea and concept for the song, Hollis had already started working on the composition, without having in mind any particular artist. With the work on the track being finished, it was forwarded to Rihanna and her label, which eagerly accepted it.
title: Watch n' Learn

abstract: "Missing My Baby" is a mid-tempo [[R&B|contemporary R&B]] [[ballad|ballad]] influenced by [[urban|urban music]] and [[soul music|soul music]]. The lyrics describe the love felt by the narrator, who reminisces of rhapsodic events she has shared with her lover. In some parts of the song, the narrator experiences loneliness and anguish because of the absence of her boyfriend. Although never intended to be released as a single, the track peaked at number 22 on the US [[Rhythmic Top 40|Rhythmic Top 40]] chart in 1995 after Selena's death.
title: Missing My Baby

abstract: "À la claire fontaine" ("By the clear fountain") is a traditional French song, which has also become very popular in Canada - especially the French-speaking areas such as Québec.
title: À la claire fontaine

abstract: "Winter Dreams (Brandon's Song)" is a song by American recording artist [[Kelly Clarkson|Kelly Clarkson]], from her sixth studio album, [[Wrapped in Red|Wrapped in Red]] (2013). Produced by [[Greg Kurstin|Greg Kurstin]], Clarkson co-wrote the song with [[Ashley Arrison|Ashley Arrison]] and Aben Eubanks for her husband (then-fiancé) Brandon Blackstock, stepson of American recording artist [[Reba McEntire|Reba McEntire]]. A slow-tempo [[Christmas|Christmas song]] [[neo-jazz|nu jazz]] [[pop|pop music]] song, "Winter Dreams" features a 50-piece chamber orchestra conducted and arranged by film composer [[Joseph Trapanese|Joseph Trapanese]]. Its lyrical theme mainly depicts love and escapism during the holidays, in which Clarkson sings about spending her first holiday with Blackstock, whom the song is also dedicated. Unlike the deep lyrical themes of "Every Christmas", in which she refers to her life before meeting Blackstock, Clarkson had described "Winter Dreams" with a lighter fare, referring to it as her holiday life after meeting him.
title: Winter Dreams (Brandon's Song)

abstract: "Let the Groove Get In" is a song recorded by American singer-songwriter [[Justin Timberlake|Justin Timberlake]] for his third [[studio album|studio album]], [[The 20/20 Experience|The 20/20 Experience]] (2013). It was written and produced by Timberlake, [[Timothy "Timbaland" Mosley|Timbaland]] and [[Jerome "J-Roc" Harmon|Jerome "J-Roc" Harmon]], with additional writing from [[James Fauntleroy|James Fauntleroy]]. A [[latin|latin music (genre)]] song, "Let the Groove Get In" contains sample from the recording "Alhamdulillaahi" part of the release Explore Series: Africa-Burkina Faso: Rhythms of the Grasslands (2002). [[Music critics|Music journalism]] received the song well and noticed a similarity between it and the works of [[Michael Jackson|Michael Jackson]] in particular his 1983 single "[[Wanna Be Startin' Somethin'|Wanna Be Startin' Somethin']]". Following the release of The 20/20 Experience, it debuted at number 31 on the [[South Korea International Chart|Gaon Chart]] and at number nine on the US [[Bubbling Under Hot 100 Singles|Bubbling Under Hot 100 Singles]] chart.
title: Let the Groove Get In

abstract: "Sunn Raha Hai" (English: Are you listening?) is a song from the 2013 [[Bollywood|Bollywood]] film, [[Aashiqui 2|Aashiqui 2]]. Composed by [[Ankit Tiwari|Ankit Tiwari]], the song is sung by [[Ankit Tiwari|Ankit Tiwari]], with lyrics penned by [[Sandeep Nath|Sandeep Nath]]. This song along with "[[Tum Hi Ho|Tum Hi Ho]]" became very popular and was a chartbuster all over India. The song is picturised on Rahul Jaykar ([[Aditya Roy Kapoor|Aditya Roy Kapoor]]) performing at a music concert, while the female version of the song is picturised on Arohi Keshav Shirke ([[Shraddha Kapoor|Shraddha Kapoor]]) performing at a local bar.
title: Sunn Raha Hai

abstract: "Raat Bhar" (English: "Whole night") is a [[pop|Pop music]] song from the 2014 Hit [[Bollywood|Bollywood]] film, [[Heropanti|Heropanti]]. Composed by [[Sajid-Wajid|Sajid-Wajid]], the song is sung by [[Arijit Singh|Arijit Singh]] and [[Shreya Ghoshal|Shreya Ghoshal]], with lyrics penned by Kausar Munir. The lively, peppy track, features [[Tiger Shroff|Tiger Shroff]] and [[Kriti Sanon|Kriti Sanon]] in the video.
title: Raat Bhar

abstract: "#GetItRight" (stylized as "#GETITRIGHT") is a song by American singer [[Miley Cyrus|Miley Cyrus]] for her fourth [[studio album|studio album]] [[Bangerz|Bangerz]] (2013). Written and produced by [[Pharrell Williams|Pharrell Williams]], "#GetItRight" is a [[pop|pop music]]-[[funk|funk]] song that lyrically discusses sexual desire. Originally considered for release as the album's lead single, "[[We Can't Stop|We Can't Stop]]" was ultimately chosen over it. Upon its release, it received generally favorable reviews from [[music critics|Music journalism]], who appreciated its overall production. Cyrus performed "#GetItRight" at the 2013 [[KIIS-FM Jingle Ball|KIIS-FM Jingle Ball]], [[Dick Clark's New Year's Rockin' Eve with Ryan Seacrest|Dick Clark's New Year's Rockin' Eve]] and on her [[Bangerz Tour|Bangerz Tour]].
title: GetItRight

abstract: "New National Anthem" is a [[political rap|political rap]] song by American rapper [[T.I.|T.I.]], released on September 23, 2014, through [[Grand Hustle|Grand Hustle]] and [[Columbia Records|Columbia Records]], as a pre-order track from [[Paperwork|Paperwork (T.I. album)]] (2014). The song, [[produced|hip hop production]] by [[Tommy "TBHITS" Brown|Tommy Brown (record producer)]], features a [[guest appearance|guest appearance]] from American singer-songwriter [[Skylar Grey|Skylar Grey]].
title: New National Anthem

abstract: "Tell Me When Did Things Go So Wrong" is a song by the American [[alternative rock|alternative rock]] group [[The Smithereens|The Smithereens]], appearing on their fourth album [[Blow Up|Blow Up (The Smithereens album)]]. Despite not being released as a single, the song charted in the United States.
title: Tell Me When Did Things Go So Wrong

abstract: "Let's Go Blue" is a short song most often associated with the [[University of Michigan|University of Michigan]], but widely performed during high school and professional sports as well. It was composed by Joe Carl and first arranged by Al Ahronheim in the 1970s. The song consists of 32 bars and is 40 seconds long.
title: Let's Go Blue

abstract: "Words I Couldn't Say" is a song written by [[Steve Robson|Steve Robson]], Tammi Kidd, and Gregory Becker and recorded by American [[country music|country music]] group [[Rascal Flatts|Rascal Flatts]] for their fourth studio album, [[Me and My Gang|Me and My Gang]] (2006). The song found renewed popularity in 2010 after it was featured in the [[drama film|drama film]] [[Country Strong|Country Strong]] as performed by American actress and singer [[Leighton Meester|Leighton Meester]]. Her cover, from the [[soundtrack album|Country Strong (soundtrack)]] released by [[RCA Records Nashville|RCA Records Nashville]], appeared on multiple [[Billboard|Billboard (magazine)]] sales charts in 2011.
title: Words I Couldn't Say

abstract: "Freeee (Ghost Town, Pt. 2)" is a song by American [[hip hop|Hip hop music]] duo [[Kids See Ghosts|Kids See Ghosts]], composed of [[Kanye West|Kanye West]] and [[Kid Cudi|Kid Cudi]], released as the fourth track off their eponymous debut album [[Kids See Ghosts|Kids See Ghosts (album)]] (2018). The song features a guest appearance from American rapper [[Ty Dolla Sign|Ty Dolla Sign]], and is the sequel to West's song "[[Ghost Town|Ghost Town (Kanye West song)]]", from his album [[Ye|Ye (album)]] (2018).
title: Freeee (Ghost Town, Pt. 2)

abstract: "Wouldn't Leave" is a song by American hip-hop artist [[Kanye West|Kanye West]] from his eighth studio album, [[Ye|Ye (album)]] (2018). The track includes vocals from [[PartyNextDoor|PartyNextDoor]], [[Ty Dolla Sign|Ty Dolla Sign]] and [[Jeremih|Jeremih]]. It was covered by [[August Alsina|August Alsina]] in October 2018. For the most part, the track received critical acclaim. It references West's controversies linked to slavery and [[Sway Calloway|Sway Calloway]].
title: Wouldn't Leave

abstract: "Why Did You Do That?" contains influences of the work of [[The Neptunes|The Neptunes]] intercepted with instrumentation from a xylophone and a repetitive chorus. Following its release, the track received much attention due to its lyrics, which critics and fans relegated as an argument against [[pop music|pop music]], but still enjoyed it as a guilty pleasure. The songwriters defended the track, saying that it was specifically written for emphasizing that Ally's career was on the rise as Jackson's went downhill. It charted at number 17 on the Slovakia Digital Top 100 chart.
title: Why Did You Do That?

abstract: North Sydney Oval is a multi-use sporting facility in [[North Sydney, New South Wales|North Sydney, New South Wales]], Australia, owned and operated by [[North Sydney Council|North Sydney Council]]. First used as a [[cricket|cricket]] ground in 1867, it is also used for [[rugby league|rugby league]] and [[rugby union|rugby union]], and previously for [[soccer|Association football]].
title: North Sydney Oval

abstract: Harry A. Gampel Pavilion is a 10,167-seat multi-purpose [[arena|arena]] in [[Storrs, Connecticut|Storrs, Connecticut]], United States, on the campus of the [[University of Connecticut|University of Connecticut]]. The arena opened on January 21, 1990, and is the largest on-campus arena in New England. It was named after industrialist and 1943 UConn graduate Harry A. Gampel, a philanthropist who walked with Martin Luther King Jr., and who donated one million dollars for the construction of the arena. It is about . Gampel Pavilion is the primary home to the [[Connecticut Huskies men's basketball|Connecticut Huskies men's basketball]], [[women's basketball|Connecticut Huskies women's basketball]], and [[women's volleyball|Connecticut Huskies#Women's volleyball]] teams.
title: Harry A. Gampel Pavilion

abstract: Hawks Field at Haymarket Park is a [[baseball|baseball]] complex in [[Lincoln, Nebraska|Lincoln, Nebraska]]. It is half a mile west of the campus of the [[University of Nebraska|University of Nebraska]] in downtown Lincoln. It is named for its location in Lincoln's historic [[Haymarket District|Haymarket District (Lincoln, Nebraska)]]. Adjacent to the ballpark is its smaller sister stadium, [[Bowlin Stadium|Bowlin Stadium]], a [[softball|softball]] complex.
title: Haymarket Park

abstract: October 9, 1926 saw first steps taken towards creating the Limerick Gaelic Grounds as a GAA stadium of note. A farm containing was purchased at Coolraine on the Ennis Road for development as a sporting grounds. Two years later the new grounds officially opened with two junior [[hurling|hurling]] games. The first big effort to raise funds for the development of the grounds was in 1932, with the establishment of a development committee, whose remit was to level the pitch, providing sideline seating and erect a boundary wall. The 1950s saw crowds of up to 50,000 attending games in the grounds. 1958 saw a new stand being built at Páirc na nGael - it was the Old Hogan Stand from [[Croke Park|Croke Park]]. A record paid attendance of 61,174 witnessed the [[Munster|Munster]] hurling final between [[Cork|Cork (city)]] and [[Tipperary|Tipperary (town)]] at the stadium in 1961 and it is estimated that another 10,000 spectators piled in without paying after the gates were broken down.
title: Gaelic Grounds

abstract: The Newlands Stadium, currently referred to as [[DHL|DHL Express]] Newlands for sponsorship reasons, is located in [[Cape Town|Cape Town]], [[South Africa|South Africa]]. The stadium currently has a capacity of 51,900 people, but is not an all-seater venue. It is the oldest rugby stadium in South Africa and the second-oldest rugby stadium in the world.Various sports teams currently use the stadium as their home base, including:
title: Newlands Stadium

abstract: Estadio Neza 86 is a football stadium in [[Ciudad Nezahualcóyotl|Ciudad Nezahualcóyotl]], a [[commuter town|commuter town]] located east of Mexico City in the [[State of Mexico|State of Mexico]]. The stadium is located on the grounds of the main campus of the Universidad Tecnológica de Nezahualcóyotl. The stadium will be renovated soon, which will decrease the capacity.
title: Estadio Neza 86

abstract: United Supermarkets Arena (previously the United Spirit Arena) is a multipurpose [[arena|arena]] on the [[campus|Campus of Texas Tech University]] of [[Texas Tech University|Texas Tech University]] in [[Lubbock, Texas|Lubbock, Texas]]. The 15,098-seat arena opened in 1999 and is home to the [[Texas Tech Red Raiders basketball|Texas Tech Red Raiders basketball]], [[Texas Tech Lady Raiders basketball|Texas Tech Lady Raiders basketball]], and [[Texas Tech Red Raiders women's volleyball|Texas Tech Red Raiders women's volleyball]] teams.
title: United Supermarkets Arena

abstract: LECOM Park is a [[baseball|baseball]] field located in [[Bradenton, Florida|Bradenton, Florida]]. It is the [[spring training|spring training]] home of the [[Pittsburgh Pirates|Pittsburgh Pirates]] and is named after 15-year naming rights deal was signed with the [[Lake Erie College of Osteopathic Medicine|Lake Erie College of Osteopathic Medicine]], which has its main campus in [[Erie, Pennsylvania|Erie, Pennsylvania]] and also a campus in Bradenton. It was formerly known as McKechnie Field, named for Bradenton resident and Baseball Hall of Fame great [[Bill McKechnie|Bill McKechnie]], who led the Pirates in [[1925|1925 World Series]] and the [[Cincinnati Reds|Cincinnati Reds]] in [[1940|1940 World Series]] to [[World Series titles|List of World Series champions]]. He was also a coach of the [[Cleveland Indians|Cleveland Indians]] in [[1948|1948 World Series]]. Several notable members of the [[Baseball Hall of Fame|Hall of Fame Baseball]], such as [[Roberto Clemente|Roberto Clemente]], [[Willie Stargell|Willie Stargell]], [[Bill Mazeroski|Bill Mazeroski]], [[Babe Ruth|Babe Ruth]], [[Ted Williams|Ted Williams]] and [[Mike Schmidt|Mike Schmidt]], have played at LECOM Park during their careers. The stadium also hosts [[minor league baseball|minor league baseball]] games for the [[Bradenton Marauders|Bradenton Marauders]], the Pirates' [[High-A|minor league baseball]] club in the [[Florida State League|Florida State League]].
title: LECOM Park

abstract: Dillon Stadium is a multipurpose facility in [[Hartford, Connecticut|Hartford, Connecticut]]. It has been host to concerts and sporting events. It was formerly the home of the [[New England Nightmare|New England Nightmare]] of the [[Women's Football Alliance (WFA)|Women's Football Alliance]]. It is currently undergoing a complete reconstruction and will serve as the new home of [[USL Championship|USL Championship]] club [[Hartford Athletic|Hartford Athletic]].
title: Dillon Stadium

abstract: The Estádio Algarve is an [[association football|association football]] stadium located between [[Faro|Faro, Portugal]] and [[Loulé|Loulé]], in Portugal. It was the former home of [[Farense|S.C. Farense]] and [[Louletano|Louletano D.C.]], having received some [[Olhanense|S.C.
