Olhanense]] and [[Portimonense|Portimonense S.C.]] matches during their respective stadiums' works of renovation. From 2004 to 2013, Louletano shared the stadium with [[Sporting Clube Farense|S.C. Farense]].
title: Estádio Algarve

abstract: Aggie Memorial Stadium is an outdoor [[football|American football]] stadium on the campus of [[New Mexico State University|New Mexico State University]] in [[Las Cruces, New Mexico|Las Cruces, New Mexico]]. The stadium is the home field of the FBS independent [[New Mexico State|New Mexico State University]] [[Aggies|New Mexico State Aggies football]]. The venue opened in September 1978 and the current seating capacity is 30,343. The artificial playing field sits at an elevation of 3,980 feet (1,213 m) [[above sea level|AMSL]]. It is the former home of NM State Aggies women's soccer.
title: Aggie Memorial Stadium

abstract: Located on the northern portion of campus, at 17th Street & East Stadium Way, the stadium opened on October 1, [[1966|1966 college football season]] with a [[seating capacity|seating capacity]] of 7,500. It replaced the original Mackay Stadium, formerly located in the bowl containing Hilliard Plaza, the Mack Social Sciences building, and the Reynolds School of Journalism. Both stadiums were named for the Mackay family, who were university benefactors in the early years of the school. The stadium currently seats 27,000 and has played to crowds in excess. The field sits at an [[elevation|elevation]] of [[above sea level|Metres above sea level]] and runs in a NW to SE configuration, with the [[press box|press box]] on the southwest sideline.
title: Mackay Stadium

abstract: Pratt & Whitney Stadium at Rentschler Field is a [[stadium|stadium]] in [[East Hartford, Connecticut|East Hartford, Connecticut]]. It is primarily used for [[football|American football]] and soccer, and is the home field of the [[University of Connecticut (UConn) Huskies|Connecticut Huskies football]]. In the fall of 2010, it was home to the [[Hartford Colonials|Hartford Colonials]] of the [[United Football League|United Football League (2009)]]. The stadium, which opened in 2003, was the first stadium used primarily by an [[NCAA|National Collegiate Athletic Association]] [[Division I-A (now FBS)|Division I (NCAA)#Football Bowl Subdivision]] team to open in the 21st century. The permanent stadium capacity is 40,000, consisting of 38,066 permanent seats with a standing-room area in the scoreboard plaza that can accommodate up to 1,934 people. It also has a game day capability to add approximately 2,000 temporary seats as it did for UConn football vs. Michigan in 2013. Connecticut played on campus at [[Memorial Stadium|Memorial Stadium (Storrs)]] in [[Storrs|Storrs, Connecticut]], before 2003.
title: Pratt & Whitney Stadium at Rentschler Field

abstract: Waldo Stadium is a [[football|American football]] [[stadium|stadium]] in [[Kalamazoo, Michigan|Kalamazoo, Michigan]]. It is primarily used for football, and has been the home of [[Western Michigan University|Western Michigan University]] [[Broncos football|Western Michigan Broncos football]] in rudimentary form since 1914, and as a complete stadium since 1939. It currently has a capacity of 30,200 spectators.
title: Waldo Stadium

abstract: It is the third-largest stadium by capacity in the [[Big 12 Conference|Big 12 Conference]] behind [[Darrell K. Royal - Texas Memorial Stadium|Darrell K. Royal - Texas Memorial Stadium]] and [[Gaylord Family Oklahoma Memorial Stadium|Gaylord Family Oklahoma Memorial Stadium]], and the third-newest in the conference, behind only [[Milan Puskar Stadium|Mountaineer Field at Milan Puskar Stadium]] of [[West Virginia|West Virginia Mountaineers football]] (which had its design based on Jack Trice Stadium) and [[Baylor's|Baylor University]] [[McLane Stadium|McLane Stadium]]. Including hillside seats in the corners of the stadium, the facility's official capacity is 61,500. The school announced in May 2014 a planned expansion to 61,500.
title: Jack Trice Stadium

abstract: Alexander Stadium is an international athletics stadium located within [[Perry Park|Perry Park (Birmingham)]] in [[Perry Barr|Perry Barr]], [[Birmingham|Birmingham]], [[England|England]], at . It has staged the [[Amateur Athletics Association|Amateur Athletics Association]] Championships, and was the venue of the 1998 [[Disability World Athletics Championships|Disability World Athletics Championships]]. It hosted one [[England Monarchs|England Monarchs]] game in 1998 with an attendance of 8,000. It hosts the annual [[British Grand Prix|British Grand Prix (athletics)]] and will be the main athletics venue of the [[2022 Commonwealth Games|2022 Commonwealth Games]].
title: Alexander Stadium

abstract: Delaware Stadium is a 22,000-seat [[multi-purpose stadium|multi-purpose stadium]] in [[Newark, Delaware|Newark, Delaware]], and is home to the [[University of Delaware|University of Delaware]] [[Fightin' Blue Hens|Delaware Fightin' Blue Hens]] [[football team|Delaware Fightin' Blue Hens football]]. The stadium is part of the [[David M. Nelson|David M. Nelson]] Athletic Complex, which includes the [[Bob Carpenter Center|Bob Carpenter Center]], Fred P. Rullo Stadium, the [[Fred Rust Ice Arena|Fred Rust Ice Arena]] and the [[Delaware Field House|Delaware Field House]].
title: Delaware Stadium

abstract: The Willows Sports Complex, currently known as 1300SMILES Stadium through [[sponsorship|Naming rights]], is a grass [[football|football]] stadium situated in [[Townsville|Townsville]], [[Queensland|Queensland]], [[Australia|Australia]]. It has been a predominantly [[rugby league|rugby league]] ground as the home ground of the [[North Queensland Cowboys|North Queensland Cowboys]] [[National Rugby League|National Rugby League]] club. The ground has also been used for [[rugby union|rugby union]] and [[soccer|soccer]]. From 2009 to 2011, [[A-League|A-League]] football club [[North Queensland Fury|Northern Fury FC]] called it home. Since inception as a rugby league ground, the ground has had sponsored naming rights: Stockland Stadium (1995–97), Malanda Stadium (1998) and Dairy Farmers Stadium (1999–2013).
title: Willows Sports Complex

abstract: Stade Geoffroy-Guichard is a [[multi-purpose stadium|multi-purpose stadium]] in [[Saint-Étienne|Saint-Étienne]], [[France|France]]. It is used primarily for [[football|football (soccer)]] matches, and tournaments such as the [[UEFA Euro 1984|UEFA Euro 1984]] and [[2016|UEFA Euro 2016]], the [[1998 FIFA World Cup|1998 FIFA World Cup]] and the [[2003 FIFA Confederations Cup|2003 FIFA Confederations Cup]]. It is also used for [[rugby union|rugby union]], and was a venue at the [[2007 Rugby World Cup|2007 Rugby World Cup]]. It is nicknamed "le Chaudron" (the Cauldron), or "l'enfer vert" (the Green Hell), an allusion to the colours worn by the local football team, [[AS Saint-Étienne|AS Saint-Étienne]], given during the team's heyday when it drew particularly large crowds (the record being set in 1985, with more than 47,000 spectators). More recently, its current capacity was 35,616 before the current renovations, which began in 2011 and have temporarily reduced this figure to 26,747. When the renovations are finished, the stadium will hold 42,000 seated spectators.
title: Stade Geoffroy-Guichard

abstract: The CFSB Center is an 8,600-seat [[arena|arena]] located in [[Murray, Kentucky|Murray, Kentucky]] near the intersection of Ky. 121 and U.S. 641. The arena is the home of the [[Murray State Racers|Murray State Racers]] Basketball teams. It was previously known as the Regional Special Events Center, or "RSEC", until the name was changed on September 17, 2010 following a $3.3 million donation from Community Financial Services Bank to Murray State Athletics. While the CFSB Center is commonly used for basketball, it was designed as a multi-purpose facility that also frequently hosts concerts, trade shows, and conventions.
title: CFSB Center

abstract: In 1937 the first stadium was constructed on the site of the current Südweststadion. The new stadium was named after [[Adolf Hitler|Adolf Hitler]] and could hold 14,000 people. During the Allied bombings of [[Mannheim|Mannheim]] and [[Ludwigshafen am Rhein|Ludwigshafen am Rhein]] during [[World War II|World War II]], the stadium was completely damaged and a new stadium had to be built. In 1946 the new foundations for the stadium were constructed and on November 11, 1950 the stadium was inaugurated. During that time it was considered to be one of West Germany’s most modern stadiums and several important West German matches were held at the stadium. When it was announced that West Germany would host the [[1974 World Championship Football|1974 FIFA World Cup]], the city of Ludwigshafen applied first as candidate venue at the organization committee. The committee finally favored [[Frankfurt’s|Frankfurt]] [[Waldstadion|Commerzbank-Arena]] instead of the Südweststadion. Between 1983 and 1989 [[SV Waldhof Mannheim|SV Waldhof Mannheim]] played her Bundesliga matches in the Südweststadion. After that, the stadium fell into disrepair. In 2007, the stadium was partially renovated.
title: Südweststadion

abstract: Ahmed Zabana Stadium () is a [[multi-purpose stadium|multi-purpose stadium]] in [[Oran|Oran]], [[Algeria|Algeria]]. It is currently used mostly for [[football|football (soccer)]] matches. It is the home ground of [[MC Oran|MC Oran]]. The stadium holds 40,000. Currently, a new stadium, called [[Olympic Stadium|Olympic Stadium of Oran]], is being constructed.
title: Ahmed Zabana Stadium

abstract: The Stade Vélodrome (), known for sponsorship reasons as the Orange Vélodrome, is a multi-purpose stadium in [[Marseille|Marseille]], [[France|France]]. It is home to the [[Olympique de Marseille|Olympique de Marseille]] football club of [[Ligue 1|Ligue 1]] since it opened in 1937, and was a venue in the [[1998 FIFA World Cup|Football World Cup 1998]], the [[2007 Rugby World Cup|2007 Rugby World Cup]] and the [[UEFA Euro 2016|UEFA Euro 2016]]. It occasionally hosts [[RC Toulon|RC Toulon]] rugby club of the [[Top 14|Top 14]]. It is the largest club football ground in France, with a capacity of 67,344 spectators. The stadium is also used regularly by the [[France national rugby union team|France national rugby union team]].
title: Stade Vélodrome

abstract: Subiaco Oval (; also known under [[naming rights|naming rights]] as Domain Stadium, and colloquially as Subi) is a disused stadium located in [[Subiaco|Subiaco, Western Australia]], a suburb of [[Perth|Perth]], Western Australia. Formerly the highest capacity stadium in Western Australia and one of the main stadiums in Australia, seating 43,500 people, the ground was the home of [[Australian rules football|Australian rules football]] in Western Australia, being the home ground for the [[West Coast Eagles|West Coast Eagles]] and [[Fremantle Football Club|Fremantle Football Club]], the two Western Australian teams in the [[Australian Football League|Australian Football League]] (AFL). The ground was also used for occasional [[West Australian Football League|West Australian Football League]] (WAFL) matches, including the competition's yearly [[grand final|grand final]]. The stadium also hosted [[Perth Glory|Perth Glory]] games, including two [[National Soccer League|National Soccer League]] grand finals, [[international rules|international rules]] matches, [[rugby union|rugby union]] games and [[rock concert|rock concerts]]. It was the home ground for the [[Western Force|Western Force]] between 2006 and 2009.
title: Subiaco Oval

abstract: Stade de France, listed as a [[Category 4|UEFA stadium categories]] stadium by [[UEFA|UEFA]], hosted matches at the 1998 FIFA World Cup, the [[UEFA Champions League finals|List of European Cup and UEFA Champions League winners]] in [[2000|2000 UEFA Champions League Final]] and [[2006|2006 UEFA Champions League Final]], and the [[1999|1999 Rugby World Cup]] and [[2007 Rugby World Cup|2007 Rugby World Cup]], making it the only stadium in the world to have hosted both a [[Football World Cup|FIFA World Cup]] [[final|FIFA World Cup Final]] and a [[rugby union World Cup|Rugby World Cup]] [[final|Rugby World Cup Final]]. The facility also hosted the [[Race of Champions|Race of Champions]] auto race in [[2004|2004 Race of Champions]], [[2005|2005 Race of Champions]], and [[2006|2006 Race of Champions]]. The stadium hosted the [[2003 World Championships in Athletics|2003 World Championships in Athletics]] and from 1999 to 2016 it hosted the annual [[Meeting Areva|Meeting Areva]] athletics meet. It also hosted seven matches at [[UEFA Euro 2016|UEFA Euro 2016]], including the [[final|UEFA Euro 2016 Final]], where France lost to [[Portugal|Portugal national football team]] 1-0 after extra-time.
title: Stade de France

abstract: Elland Road is a football stadium in [[Leeds|Leeds]], [[West Yorkshire|West Yorkshire]], England, which has been the [[home|Home (sports)]] of [[Leeds United FC|Leeds United FC]] since the club's formation in 1919. The stadium is the [[13th largest football stadium in England|List of football stadiums in England]], and the fourth largest outside the [[Premier League|Premier League]].
title: Elland Road

abstract: Estadio Sausalito (; Sausalito Stadium) is a [[multi-purpose stadium|multi-purpose stadium]] in [[Viña del Mar|Viña del Mar]], [[Chile|Chile]].
title: Estadio Sausalito

abstract: File:José Rico Pérez jornada1 temp.2010-11.jpg|Estadio José Rico Pérez, 2010 File:Estadio José Rico Pérez en obras.jpg|Estadio José Rico Pérez, 2010 File:Estadio José Rico Pérez, Alicante, España.jpg|External view of the stadium File:Banquillo Rico Pérez 2010.JPG|players bench
title: Estadio José Rico Pérez

abstract: The stadium was built in 1982 and is named after poet [[José Zorrilla y Moral|José Zorrilla y Moral]]. Prior to this, they played in the old [[Estadio José Zorrilla|Estadio José Zorrilla (1940)]].
title: Estadio José Zorrilla

abstract: Estadio Sergio León Chávez is a [[Multi-purpose stadium|Multi-purpose stadium]] in the city of [[Irapuato|Irapuato]].
title: Estadio Sergio León Chávez

abstract: Farum Park, currently known as Right to Dream Park, is a [[football|Football (soccer)]] stadium, located in [[Farum|Farum]], [[Denmark|Denmark]], and is the home ground of [[FC Nordsjælland|FC Nordsjælland]]. It has a capacity of 10,300 of which 9,800 are seated. Farum Park is the first stadium in the Danish Superliga with an artificial turf, installed in 2012. The grass is from Limonta Sport - a leading company in the production and distribution of synthetic grass for sports. Farum Park is a modern stadium with LED-banners, a hotel with 35 rooms and a fitness center.
title: Farum Park

abstract: The Estadio Cuscatlán is a [[football|association football]] stadium located in [[San Salvador|San Salvador]], El Salvador. It is the largest stadium in Central America with a capacity of 53,400 The stadium is the home ground of the [[El Salvador national football team|El Salvador national football team]].
title: Estadio Cuscatlán

abstract: Carrara Stadium (known commercially as Metricon Stadium) is a sporting venue on the [[Gold Coast|Gold Coast, Queensland]] in [[Queensland|Queensland]], [[Australia|Australia]], located in the suburb of [[Carrara|Carrara, Queensland]].
title: Carrara Stadium

abstract: In 2005, Reed Arena served as the site of men's and women's first round [[NIT|National Invitation Tournament]] games, as the men played [[Clemson|Clemson University]] and the women played [[Tulsa|University of Tulsa]].
title: Reed Arena

abstract: The Dolen Omurzakov Stadium is a [[multi-purpose stadium|multi-purpose stadium]] in [[Bishkek|Bishkek]], [[Kyrgyzstan|Kyrgyzstan]]. It is currently used mostly for [[football|football (soccer)]] matches. The stadium holds 23,000 and is currently the home ground of the [[Kyrgyzstan national football team|Kyrgyzstan national football team]], [[Dordoi Bishkek|FC Dordoi Bishkek]] and [[Alga Bishkek|FC Alga Bishkek]].
title: Dolen Omurzakov Stadium

abstract: The Utah Olympic Oval is an indoor [[speed skating|speed skating]] oval located southwest of [[Salt Lake City|Salt Lake City]], in [[Kearns, Utah|Kearns, Utah]]. The Oval was built for the [[2002 Winter Olympics|2002 Winter Olympics]] and it hosted the [[long track|long track speed skating]] [[speed skating|Speed skating at the 2002 Winter Olympics]] events for the 2002 games. Inside the facility the 400 meter skating track surrounds two international sized ice sheets, and is itself surrounded by a 442 meter [[running track|running track]]. Due to its high altitude, , and the associated low air resistance, ten Olympic records and nine world records were set at the Oval during the 2002 games, the largest number of world records ever set at one event.
title: Utah Olympic Oval

abstract: İzmir Atatürk Stadium () is a [[multi-purpose stadium|multi-purpose stadium]] in [[İzmir|İzmir]], [[Turkey|Turkey]]. It is currently used mostly for [[football|football (soccer)]] matches. The stadium holds 51,295 people. It was built in 1964, and most recently refurbished in 2005. İzmir football teams [[Karşıyaka S.K.|Karşıyaka S.K.]] and [[Göztepe A.Ş.|Göztepe A.Ş.]] occasionally use the stadium for high attendance matches.
title: İzmir Atatürk Stadium

abstract: Allen E. Paulson Stadium is a 25,000 seat on campus football [[stadium|stadium]] in [[Statesboro, Georgia|Statesboro, Georgia]]. It is home to the [[Georgia Southern Eagles football|Georgia Southern Eagles football]] team and the focal point of Erk Russell Athletic Park.
title: Paulson Stadium

abstract: The Arena das Dunas ("[[Dune|Dunes]] Arena") is a [[football stadium|Soccer-specific stadium]] in [[Natal|Natal, Rio Grande do Norte]], [[Brazil|Brazil]]. The arena can shelter 31,375 spectators, and was designed by sports architect Christopher Lee of [[Populous|Populous (architects)]]. The stadium hosted [[football|Association football]] matches for the [[2014 FIFA World Cup|2014 FIFA World Cup]] held in Brazil. During the tournament, it had a seating capacity of 42,000. It was built in place of the [[Machadão|Machadão]], which was demolished in 2011.
title: Arena das Dunas

abstract: Alex Box Stadium, sometimes pronounced as "Elec" or "Alec" Box was a [[baseball|baseball]] [[stadium|stadium]] in [[Baton Rouge, Louisiana|Baton Rouge, Louisiana]], United States. It was the home field of the [[LSU Tigers baseball|LSU Tigers baseball]] team. The stadium was located across the street from [[Tiger Stadium|Tiger Stadium (LSU)]], which is visible in right field. It was most notable for The Intimidator, a large billboard behind the right-field fence featuring the five years in which LSU won the [[College World Series|College World Series]].
title: Alex Box Stadium

abstract: Boothferry Park was a [[football|Association football]] stadium in [[Hull|Kingston upon Hull]], England, which was home to [[Hull City A.F.C.|Hull City A.F.C.]] from 1946 until 2002, when they moved to the [[Kingston Communications Stadium|KC Stadium]].
title: Boothferry Park

abstract: Nikos Goumas Stadium () was a [[multi-purpose stadium|multi-purpose stadium]] in [[Nea Filadelfeia|Nea Filadelfeia]], a northwestern suburb of [[Athens|Athens]], [[Greece|Greece]]. It was used mostly for [[football|football (soccer)]] matches and was the home stadium of [[AEK Athens F.C.|AEK Athens F.C.]].
title: Nikos Goumas Stadium

abstract: Gran Canaria Arena, originally known as Palacio Multiusos de Gran Canaria, is an [[indoor sporting arena|indoor arena]] located in [[Las Palmas|Las Palmas]], [[Canary Islands|Canary Islands]], [[Spain|Spain]]. The arena, opened in 2014 by [[Mariano Rajoy|Mariano Rajoy]], has a capacity of 9,870 spectators and is the home arena of [[CB Gran Canaria|CB Gran Canaria]].The first game in Gran Canaria Arena was the game of the 28th round of the [[2013–14 ACB season|2013–14 ACB season]] between [[Herbalife Gran Canaria|CB Gran Canaria]] and [[FC Barcelona|FC Barcelona Bàsquet]], played on 1 May 2014.
title: Gran Canaria Arena

abstract: Lillehammer Olympic Bobsleigh and Luge Track () is a [[bobsleigh|bobsleigh]], [[luge|luge]] and [[skeleton|skeleton (sport)]] track located at [[Hunderfossen|Hunderfossen]] in [[Lillehammer|Lillehammer]], [[Norway|Norway]], north of the town center of Lillehammer. It was completed in 1992 for the [[1994 Winter Olympics|1994 Winter Olympics]], where it hosted the [[bobsleigh events|bobsleigh at the 1994 Winter Olympics]] and [[luge events|luge at the 1994 Winter Olympics]]. It has since also hosted the [[FIBT World Championships 1995|FIBT World Championships 1995]] in skeleton and the [[FIL World Luge Championships 1995|FIL World Luge Championships 1995]], and hosted [[2016 Winter Youth Olympics|2016 Winter Youth Olympics]].
title: Lillehammer Olympic Bobsleigh and Luge Track

abstract: The Melbourne Rectangular Stadium, commercially known as AAMI Park, is an outdoor [[sport|sports]] stadium on the site of [[Edwin Flack Field|Edwin Flack#Field]] in the [[Sports and Entertainment Precinct|Melbourne Sports and Entertainment Precinct]] in the [[Melbourne City Centre|Melbourne City Centre]]. The stadium's major tenants are [[NRL|National Rugby League]] team [[Melbourne Storm|Melbourne Storm]], the [[Super Rugby|Super Rugby]] team [[Melbourne Rebels|Melbourne Rebels]], and the [[A-League|A-League]] teams [[Melbourne Victory FC|Melbourne Victory FC]] and [[Melbourne City FC|Melbourne City FC]].
title: Melbourne Rectangular Stadium

abstract: The shopping center and Arena Zagreb share a series of services such as a joint parking lot, multiplex cinema, wellness center, numerous restaurants, cafes, and stores.
title: Arena Zagreb

abstract: Alexandreio Melathron Nick Galis Hall, or Alexandreio Melathron Nikos Galis Hall ([[Greek|Greek language]]: Αλεξάνδρειο Μέλαθρον Νίκος Γκάλης Σάλα) is an [[indoor sports arena|indoor arena]] that is located in [[Thessaloniki|Thessaloniki]], [[Greece|Greece]]. It is also often referred to as the Palais des Sports (Greek: Παλαί ντε Σπορ).
title: Alexandreio Melathron Nick Galis Hall

abstract: The Heinz-Steyer-Stadion is a [[Football|Football (soccer)]] and [[athletics|Athletics (track and field)]] stadium in [[Dresden|Dresden]], which is currently used by the [[Dresdner SC|Dresdner SC]]. It has a capacity of about 30,000, but is currently restricted to about 5,000 for soccer matches (although it had attendances of more than 50,000 people in the 1930s). It was also the first stadium of [[Dynamo Dresden|Dynamo Dresden]]. It was the venue for Dynamo's first [[Inter-Cities Fairs Cup|Inter-Cities Fairs Cup]] match, against [[Rangers|Rangers F.C.]].
title: Heinz-Steyer-Stadion

abstract: Provost Umphrey Stadium (previously Cardinal Stadium) is a 16,000-seat [[multi-purpose stadium|multi-purpose stadium]] located on the campus of [[Lamar University|Lamar University]] in [[Beaumont, Texas|Beaumont, Texas]]. The stadium, home to the [[Lamar Cardinals football|Lamar Cardinals football]] team, is located next to the [[Montagne Center|Montagne Center]]. While primarily used for football, Provost Umphrey Stadium is also a concert venue with seating up to 20,000 for concerts. The stadium was completely renovated in 2009 and is designed to allow for a future expansion to 28,000.
title: Provost Umphrey Stadium

abstract: "Otkritie Arena", named after the sponsor [[Otkritie Holding|Otkritie Holding]], is the commercial name for the Spartak Stadium until 2019.
title: Otkritie Arena

abstract: Gamla Ullevi () is a [[football|association football]] [[stadium|stadium]] in [[Gothenburg|Gothenburg]], [[Sweden|Sweden]], that opened on 5 April 2009. The stadium replaced the city's previous main football stadium, also called [[Gamla Ullevi|Gamla Ullevi (1916)]], and is the home ground of [[GAIS|GAIS]], [[IFK Göteborg|IFK Göteborg]] and [[Örgryte IS|Örgryte IS]]. It is also the national stadium for the [[Sweden women's national football team|Sweden women's national football team]]. The new stadium was built on the ground of the now-demolished old stadium. The construction of the stadium was surrounded by controversy, regarding the cost of the project, the alleged low standard of the finished stadium, as well as its name.
title: Gamla Ullevi

abstract: Estadio Alfonso Chico Carrasquel is a [[baseball|baseball]] [[stadium|stadium]] based in [[Puerto la Cruz|Puerto la Cruz]], [[Venezuela|Venezuela]], which serves as home for the [[Caribes de Anzoátegui|Caribes de Anzoátegui]] of the [[Venezuelan Professional Baseball League|Venezuelan Professional Baseball League]]. At , the plot is only just big enough to house the stadium, with room for expansion to the north and north west, and only sufficient room on the other sides to allow movement of spectators and access to the stands.
title: Estadio Alfonso Chico Carrasquel

abstract: The HaMoshava Stadium (, Itztadion HaMoshava), also known as Petah Tikva Stadium, is a [[football|Association football]] [[stadium|stadium]] in [[Petah Tikva|Petah Tikva]], [[Israel|Israel]]. It was completed in 2011, and is used mainly for [[football|Association football]] matches and is home to both [[Hapoel Petah Tikva|Hapoel Petah Tikva F.C.]] and [[Maccabi Petah Tikva|Maccabi Petah Tikva F.C.]].The stadium has an all-seated capacity of 11,500 with an option for further construction of 8,500 on the south and north stands, totaling 20,000 seats.
title: HaMoshava Stadium

abstract: Campo de Fútbol de Vallecas (originally Nuevo Estadio de Vallecas and previously Estadio Teresa Rivero) is a [[football|soccer]] [[stadium|stadium]] in the [[Madrid|Madrid]] district of [[Puente de Vallecas|Puente de Vallecas]], [[Spain|Spain]]. It currently hosts [[football|Association football]] matches and is the home ground of [[La Liga|La Liga]] club [[Rayo Vallecano|Rayo Vallecano]]. The stadium holds 14,505 spectators and was opened on 10 May 1976. It was constructed between 1972 and 1976, and it also under the names Campo de Fútbol de Vallecas and Estadio Puente de Vallecas (The Bridge of Vallecas Stadium).
title: Campo de Fútbol de Vallecas

abstract: Estadi Montilivi is a multi-use [[stadium|stadium]] in [[Girona|Girona]], [[Catalonia|Catalonia]], [[Spain|Spain]]. It is currently used mostly for [[football|football (soccer)]] matches and is the home ground of [[Girona FC|Girona FC]]. The stadium holds 13,450 people.After their first promotion ever to La Liga, [[Girona|Girona FC]] expanded the stadium temporarily for hosting 13,450 spectators.
title: Estadi Montilivi

abstract: Poole Stadium is a [[greyhound racing|Greyhound racing in the United Kingdom]] venue and [[speedway|motorcycle speedway]] track located in the town centre of [[Poole|Poole]], Dorset in England. The stadium is owned by the [[Borough of Poole|Borough of Poole]]. It was built in the early 1930s in an attempt to provide a source of entertainment to the residents of Poole during the [[Great Depression|Great Depression]]. It is also often referred to as Wimborne Road, which is a road that runs adjacent to the stadium. During weekdays, the stadium's large car park is used to provide parking for [[Poole Hospital|Poole Hospital]]'s [[park and ride|park and ride]] scheme.
title: Poole Stadium

abstract: Thrum Hall was a [[rugby league|rugby league]] stadium on Hanson Lane in [[Halifax, West Yorkshire|Halifax, West Yorkshire]], England. It was the home of [[Halifax|Halifax R.L.F.C.]] for 112 years. The site on which the ground stood is now occupied by a supermarket.
title: Thrum Hall

abstract: First National Bank Stadium or simply FNB Stadium, also known as Soccer City and The Calabash, is a stadium located in [[Nasrec|Nasrec, Gauteng]], bordering the [[Soweto|Soweto]] area of [[Johannesburg|Johannesburg]], [[South Africa|South Africa]]. The venue is managed by Stadium Management South Africa (SMSA) and is a home ground of [[Kaizer Chiefs F.C.|Kaizer Chiefs F.C.]] in the South African [[Premier Soccer League|Premier Soccer League]] as well as key fixtures for the South African national football team ([[Bafana Bafana|South Africa national football team]]).
title: FNB Stadium

abstract: Studenternas IP is a multi-use stadium in [[Uppsala|Uppsala]], [[Sweden|Sweden]] and the home arena for the [[football|association football]] club [[IK Sirius Fotboll|IK Sirius Fotboll]] and in [[bandy|bandy]] for [[IK Sirius|IK Sirius]] in [[Elitserien|Elitserien (bandy)]] and several other bandy teams. The summer arena has a total capacity of 7,200 spectators and the winter arena 8,000. The [[bandy finals|List of Swedish bandy champions]] were played here from 1991 until 2012. Starting in 2018, the finals is once again played at Studenternas. The arena has a much bigger capacity during that weekend, for example 25 560 spectators saw the 2010 men's final. The summer arena will undergo a major upgrade between 2017 and 2020. The "new Studenternas" will have a capacity of 10 000 spectators.
title: Studenternas IP

abstract: Dælenenga idrettspark is a sports facility located at [[Grünerløkka|Grünerløkka]] in [[Oslo|Oslo]], [[Norway|Norway]]. It consists of an [[artificial turf|artificial turf]] [[football pitch|football pitch]], a club house and an indoor [[ice rink|ice rink]]—Grünerhallen. The facilities are owned by the [[Municipality of Oslo|Oslo]] and used and operated by [[Grüner IL|Grüner IL]], the local sports club.
title: Dælenenga idrettspark

abstract: Stadion Nikola Mantov () is a [[multi-purpose stadium|multi-purpose stadium]] in [[Kočani|Kočani]], [[Republic of Macedonia|Republic of Macedonia]]. It is mostly used for [[football|football (soccer)]] matches and is currently the home stadium of [[FK Osogovo Kočani|FK Osogovo]]. The stadium seats 5000 people.
title: Stadion Nikola Mantov

abstract: Estádio João Cardoso is a football stadium in [[Tondela|Tondela]], [[Portugal|Portugal]], with a capacity for 5,000 spectators. It is the home stadium of [[C.D. Tondela|C.D. Tondela]], currently playing in the Portuguese [[Primeira Liga|Primeira Liga]].
title: Estádio João Cardoso

abstract: Carrington Park is a [[rugby league|rugby league]] and [[soccer|soccer]] [[stadium|stadium]] in [[Bathurst|Bathurst, New South Wales]], [[New South Wales|New South Wales]], [[Australia|Australia]]
title: Carrington Park

abstract: Bart Kaufman Field is a baseball field in Bloomington, Indiana. It is home of the [[Indiana Hoosiers baseball|Indiana Hoosiers baseball]] team. The capacity of the facility is 2,500 spectators. It is named after Bart Kaufman, an alumnus who played in 1960-61-62. In 1961 he was the second-leading hitter (.452) in the Big Ten to longtime [[Detroit Tigers|Detroit Tigers]] player [[Bill Freehan|Bill Freehan]] of the [[University of Michigan|University of Michigan]]. Kaufman pledged $2.5 million to get the project going. Many teammates contributed to name the Indiana dugout after longtime baseball coach [[Ernie Andres|Ernie Andres]]. Much of the cost, reported to be in excess of $19 million including [[Andy Mohr Field|Andy Mohr Field]] for softball, was funded by proceeds from the [[Big Ten Network|Big Ten Network]].
title: Bart Kaufman Field

abstract: Rostov Arena () is an [[association football|association football]] stadium in [[Rostov-on-Don|Rostov-on-Don]], [[Russia|Russia]]. It is one of the venues for the [[2018 FIFA World Cup|2018 FIFA World Cup]]. It also hosts [[FC Rostov|FC Rostov]] of the [[Russian Premier League|Russian Premier League]], replacing [[Olimp – 2|Olimp – 2]]. It has a capacity of 45,000 spectators.
title: Rostov Arena

abstract: Penrith Stadium (known commercially as Panthers Stadium) is a [[rugby league|rugby league]] and [[association football|association football]] stadium located in [[Penrith, New South Wales|Penrith, New South Wales]], Australia.
title: Penrith Stadium

abstract: Myresjöhus Arena is a [[football|association football]] [[stadium|stadium]] in [[Växjö|Växjö]], Sweden and the home of [[Superettan|Superettan]] club [[Östers IF|Östers IF]]. The stadium is a part of a large redevelopment of the area formerly known as [[Värendsvallen|Värendsvallen]] into Arenastaden, which also includes a [[new ice hockey arena|Vida Arena]], floorball arena and a dedicated indoor athletics arena.
title: Myresjöhus Arena

abstract: The City Park Ice Rink () is a public ice rink located in the [[City Park|City Park (Budapest)]] of the Hungarian capital [[Budapest|Budapest]], between the [[Heroes' Square|Hősök tere]] and the [[Vajdahunyad Castle|Vajdahunyad Castle]]. Opened in 1870, it is the largest and one of the oldest ice rinks in Europe. In summer months the area is filled up with water to create a pond, which is primarily used for boating, but also hosted several special events, such as the snowball fight world record attempt in 2009 or the Art on Lake exhibition in 2011.
title: City Park Ice Rink

abstract: Swindon Stadium, also known as the Abbey Greyhound Stadium, is a [[Greyhound Board of Great Britain|Greyhound Board of Great Britain]] regulated [[greyhound racing|Greyhound racing in the United Kingdom]] track and [[speedway|Motorcycle speedway]] track located in [[Blunsdon|Blunsdon]], [[Swindon|Swindon]], England.
title: Swindon Stadium

abstract: Alex Box Stadium, Skip Bertman Field is a [[baseball|baseball]] [[stadium|stadium]] in [[Baton Rouge, Louisiana|Baton Rouge, Louisiana]]. It is the home stadium of the [[Louisiana State University Tigers college baseball|LSU Tigers baseball]] team. The stadium section (and [[LSU's previous baseball stadium|Alex Box Stadium (1938)]] 200 yards to the north) were named for Simeon Alex Box, an LSU letterman (1942), Purple Heart and Distinguished Service Cross recipient, who was killed in North Africa during [[World War II|World War II]]. On May 17, 2013, prior to a game against Ole Miss, the [[field|Pitch (sports field)]] was named and dedicated in honor of former LSU head baseball coach and athletic director, [[Skip Bertman|Skip Bertman]].
title: Alex Box Stadium, Skip Bertman Field

abstract: The Patliputra Stadium at the Patliputra Sports Complex is a multi-purpose stadium in [[Kankarbagh|Kankarbagh]], [[Patna|Patna]], [[Bihar|Bihar]]. The first Women World Cup Kabaddi Championship was held here in its inaugural year, in which 16 countries had participated. It had also hosted the seven league matches of new [[Pro Kabaddi League|Pro Kabaddi League]] with its home team as [[Patna Pirates|Patna Pirates]] from 7 to 10 August in 2014.
title: Patliputra Sports Complex

abstract: The Kalinga Stadium is a multi-purpose stadium in [[Bhubaneswar|Bhubaneswar]], [[Odisha|Odisha]], India. Its foundation stone was laid by former chief minister of Odisha Late [[Biju Patnaik|Biju Patnaik]] in 1978. It is situated in the heart of [[Bhubaneswa|Bhubaneswar]]r near Nayapalli area. It has facilities for athletics, soccer, field hockey, basketball, tennis, table tennis basketball, volleyball, Wall climbing and swimming. Other features of the stadium includes an 8-lane synthetic athletics track, a sports hostel, gymnasium and the India's first newly built olympic standard pink and blue hockey turf.
title: Kalinga Stadium

abstract: Eirias Stadium (), known for sponsorship reasons as Stadiwm Zip World, is a [[rugby union|rugby union]] stadium that is part of the outdoor complex of the Eirias Events Centre in [[Eirias Park|Eirias Park]], [[Colwyn Bay|Colwyn Bay]], [[Wales|Wales]]. It is home to the [[Principality Premiership|Welsh Premier Division]] team, [[RGC 1404|RGC 1404]]. The stadium had been used for low key community sporting events, until its redevelopment in 2011, where it now can host international televised events.
title: Eirias Stadium

abstract: Gradski Stadium Kumanovo (, Gradski stadion Kumanovo) is a [[multi-purpose stadium|multi-purpose stadium]] in [[Kumanovo|Kumanovo]], [[Republic of Macedonia|Republic of Macedonia]]. It is used mostly for [[football|football (soccer)]] matches and is the home stadium of [[FK Kumanovo|FK Kumanovo]] and [[FK Goblen|FK Goblen]]. It holds 2,000 people.
title: Gradski Stadium Kumanovo

abstract: The Pavilion at Ole Miss is a multi-purpose [[arena|arena]] on the campus of the [[University of Mississippi|University of Mississippi]] in [[Oxford, Mississippi|Oxford, Mississippi]]. The $96.5 million multipurpose arena is home to the [[University of Mississippi|University of Mississippi]] [[Rebels|Ole Miss Rebels]] [[men's|Ole Miss Rebels men's basketball]] and [[women's|Ole Miss Rebels women's basketball]] [[basketball|basketball]] teams, with seating for up to 9,500 people. The Pavilion replaced the [[Tad Smith Coliseum|Tad Smith Coliseum]] in January 2016; the opening game, on January 7, saw the Rebels men defeat [[Alabama|2015–16 Alabama Crimson Tide men's basketball team]] 74–66.
title: The Pavilion at Ole Miss

abstract: Bowman Gray Stadium is a [[NASCAR|NASCAR]] sanctioned asphalt flat oval [[short track|Short track motor racing]] and longstanding [[football|American football]] stadium located in [[Winston-Salem, North Carolina|Winston-Salem, North Carolina]]. It is one of stock car racing's most legendary venues, and is referred to as "NASCAR's longest-running weekly race track". Bowman Gray Stadium is part of the [[Winston-Salem Sports and Entertainment Complex|Winston-Salem Sports and Entertainment Complex]] and is home of the [[Winston-Salem State University|Winston-Salem State University]] Rams football team. It was also the home of the [[Wake Forest University|Wake Forest University]] football team from 1956 until [[Groves Stadium|Groves Stadium]] (later [[BB&T Field|BB&T Field]]) opened in 1968. Bowman Gray Stadium was a popular venue for high school football in the 1970s and 1980s. Parkland and R.J. Reynolds High Schools shared Bowman Gray Stadium as their home field for high school football until the two schools built their own facility (Deaton-Thompson Stadium) in 1994.
title: Bowman Gray Stadium

abstract: DirecTV Arena, is an entertainment and sports venue, located in [[Tortuguitas|Tortuguitas]], [[Greater Buenos Aires|Greater Buenos Aires]], [[Argentina|Argentina]]. It is owned and operated by [[DirecTV|DirecTV]] & ALG Sports. It made its grand opening in October 31 2015, with a concert by [[Sting|Sting_(musician)]].
title: DirecTV Arena

abstract: Estadio Ganzábal is a [[football|football (soccer)]] [[stadium|stadium]] in [[La Felguera|La Felguera]], [[Langreo|Langreo]], and is the [[home|Home (sports)]] of [[UP Langreo|UP Langreo]].
title: Estadio Ganzábal

abstract: Knight Stadium broke ground in 2016. It opened in 2017. In 2018 the final touches were made with the addition of a knight statue.
title: Knight Stadium

abstract: The Bell Centre ([[French|French language]]: Centre Bell), formerly known as the Molson Centre (or Le Centre Molson), is a sports and entertainment complex in [[Montreal|Montreal]], [[Quebec|Quebec]], Canada. It opened on March 16, 1996, after nearly three years under construction. It is best known as the home of the [[National Hockey League|National Hockey League]]'s [[Montreal Canadiens|Montreal Canadiens]] ice hockey team, and it has the largest arena capacity to regularly host an NHL team.
title: Bell Centre

abstract: Lambeau Field is an outdoor athletic stadium in the [[north central|East North Central States]] [[United States|United States]], located in [[Green Bay, Wisconsin|Green Bay, Wisconsin]]. The home field of the [[Green Bay Packers|Green Bay Packers]] of the [[National Football League|National Football League]] (NFL), it opened in [[1957|1957 Green Bay Packers season]] as City Stadium, replacing the original [[City Stadium|City Stadium (Green Bay)]] at [[East High School|Green Bay East High School]] as the Packers' home field. Informally known as New City Stadium for its first eight seasons, it was renamed in August 1965 in memory of Packers founder, player, and long-time head coach, [[Curly Lambeau|Curly Lambeau]], who had died two months earlier.
title: Lambeau Field

abstract: Comerica Park is an open-air [[ballpark|baseball park]] located in [[Downtown|Downtown Detroit]] [[Detroit|Detroit]]. It serves as the home of the [[Detroit Tigers|Detroit Tigers]] of [[Major League Baseball|Major League Baseball]], replacing [[Tiger Stadium|Tiger Stadium (Detroit)]] in 2000.
title: Comerica Park

abstract: The Dome at America's Center, or The Dome, is a [[multi-purpose stadium|multi-purpose stadium]] used mostly for concerts and major conventions in [[St. Louis|St. Louis]], [[Missouri|Missouri]], United States. Beginning in Spring 2020 the Dome will serve as the home stadium for St. Louis' ([[XFL|XFL (2020)]]) football team. The stadium, previously known as the Trans World Dome from 1995 to 2001, and then as the Edward Jones Dome from 2002 to 2016, was constructed largely to lure an NFL team back to St. Louis and to serve as a convention space.
title: The Dome at America's Center

abstract: Leichhardt Oval is a football stadium in [[Leichhardt, New South Wales|Leichhardt, New South Wales]], [[Australia|Australia]]. It is currently one of two home grounds for the [[Wests Tigers|Wests Tigers]] [[National Rugby League|National Rugby League]] team (the other being [[Campbelltown Stadium|Campbelltown Stadium]]), and is the former longtime home of the [[Balmain Tigers|Balmain Tigers]], who used the ground from 1934-1994 and 1997-1999.
title: Leichhardt Oval

abstract: Reckling Park is the [[baseball|baseball]] stadium at [[Rice University|Rice University]] in [[Houston, Texas|Houston, Texas]], USA. It serves as the home field of the [[Rice Owls baseball|Rice Owls baseball]] team. The stadium was built on the site of Cameron Field, Rice's home from 1978–99, in time for the 2000 season. The Owls have hosted 10 [[NCAA|National Collegiate Athletic Association]] regional and five super regional tournaments at Reckling Park, including one of each in their national championship season of 2003 and in the years of other College World Series appearances, 2002, 2006, 2007, and 2008. The stadium was named for its principal donor, former Rice player Tommy Reckling.
title: Reckling Park

abstract: Brookvale Oval (commercially known as Lottoland) is a sporting ground located within Brookvale Park at [[Brookvale, New South Wales|Brookvale, New South Wales]], [[Australia|Australia]]. The ground is owned by [[Northern Beaches Council|Northern Beaches Council]] and is primarily used by the [[Manly Warringah Sea Eagles|Manly Warringah Sea Eagles]] [[rugby league|rugby league]] team. Brookvale Oval has an approximate capacity of 23,000 people. By the end of the 2016 season, Brookvale had played host to 664 first grade premiership games.
title: Brookvale Oval

abstract: Bud Walton Arena (also known as the Basketball Palace of Mid-America) is the home to the [[men's|Arkansas Razorbacks basketball]] and [[women's|Arkansas Razorbacks women's basketball]] [[basketball|basketball]] teams of the [[University of Arkansas|University of Arkansas]], known as the [[Razorbacks|Arkansas Razorbacks]]. It is located on the campus of the University of Arkansas in [[Fayetteville, Arkansas|Fayetteville, Arkansas]] and has a [[seating capacity|seating capacity]] of 19,368, which is the fifth largest for an on-campus arena in the [[United States|United States]].
title: Bud Walton Arena

abstract: With a capacity of approximately 13,500 people, Cazaly's Stadium is the largest oval stadium in Cairns and features a main grandstand relocated from the [[Brisbane Cricket Ground|Brisbane Cricket Ground]] in the late 1990s. It is used by the [[Queensland Cricket Association|Queensland Cricket Association]], [[Queensland Rugby League|Queensland Rugby League]], and [[AFL Cairns|AFL Cairns]]. The stadium has hosted matches in the [[Australian Football League|Australian Football League]], [[National Rugby League|National Rugby League]], and [[A-League|A-League]], as well as [[Test|Test cricket]] and [[One Day International|One Day International]] cricket.
title: Cazaly's Stadium

abstract: The Ferrell Center is an [[arena|arena]] in [[Waco, Texas|Waco, Texas]]. Built in 1988 and located adjacent to the [[Brazos River|Brazos River]], it is home to the [[Baylor University|Baylor University]] Bears basketball and volleyball teams. It is named for Charles R. Ferrell, a Baylor student and legacy who died in 1967, and whose family's estate was a major benefactor of the arena. The building replaced the [[Heart O' Texas Coliseum|Heart O' Texas Coliseum]] as the school's primary indoor athletic facility.
title: Ferrell Center

abstract: Mestalla Stadium ( , ) is a [[football|football (soccer)]] [[stadium|stadium]] in [[Valencia|Valencia]], Spain. The stadium is the home ground of [[Valencia Club de Fútbol|Valencia CF]] and has a capacity of 49,500 seats. The North Stand of the stadium is known for its very steep section.
title: Mestalla Stadium

abstract: Doubleday Field is a [[baseball|baseball]] [[stadium|ballpark]] in [[Cooperstown, New York|Cooperstown, New York]] named for [[Abner Doubleday|Abner Doubleday]] and located two village blocks from the [[National Baseball Hall of Fame and Museum|National Baseball Hall of Fame and Museum]].
title: Doubleday Field

abstract: The Estadio Monumental is a [[soccer|soccer]] Stadium in [[Macul|Macul]], south-east of the centre of the [[Chile|Chilean]] capital [[Santiago|Santiago]]. It serves as the home ground of [[Colo-Colo|Colo-Colo]], and on occasions also for other clubs and the national football team. The stadium has a current spectator capacity of 47,347. The actual playing field is named after [[David Arellano|David Arellano]], the founder of Colo-Colo, therefore, on occasions the whole stadium is referred to as Estadio Monumental David Arellano.
title: Estadio Monumental David Arellano

abstract: Alerus Center is named after a local financial institution, [[Alerus Financial|Alerus Financial]], which purchased the building's naming rights. Prior to opening, the facility had been referred to as the Aurora Events Center.
title: Alerus Center

abstract: The DW Stadium is a sports stadium in [[Wigan|Wigan]], [[Greater Manchester|Greater Manchester]], England. The ground is owned and managed by Wigan Football Company Limited, which is 78% owned by Wigan Athletic and it is used by [[Wigan Athletic|Wigan Athletic F.C.]] [[football|association football]] club and [[Wigan Warriors|Wigan Warriors]] [[rugby league|rugby league]] club, the rugby league club having a 50 years lease on tenancy to play games at the stadium. Built and opened in 1999, it is named after its main sponsor, [[DW Sports Fitness|DW Sports Fitness]]. In [[UEFA|UEFA]] matches, it is called Wigan Athletic Stadium due to UEFA regulations on sponsorship.
title: DW Stadium

abstract: The Emirates Stadium (known as Ashburton Grove prior to sponsorship, and as Arsenal Stadium for [[UEFA|UEFA]] competitions) is a [[football|association football]] stadium in [[Holloway, London|Holloway, London]], England, and the home of [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal F.C.]]. With a capacity of 60,260 it is the [[third-largest football stadium in England|List of football stadiums in England]] after [[Wembley Stadium|Wembley Stadium]] and [[Old Trafford|Old Trafford]].
title: Emirates Stadium

abstract: The Estadio Tecnológico was a [[multi-purpose stadium|multi-purpose stadium]] located in [[Monterrey|Monterrey]], [[Nuevo León|Nuevo León]], [[Mexico|Mexico]], located on the campus of the [[Monterrey Institute of Technology and Higher Education|Monterrey Institute of Technology and Higher Education]] (ITESM). It hosted soccer and American football games during its 67-year existence, from 1950 to 2017.
title: Estadio Tecnológico

abstract: West Side Park was the name used for two different [[baseball|baseball]] parks that formerly stood in [[Chicago|Chicago]], [[Illinois|Illinois]]. They were both home fields of the team now known as the [[Chicago Cubs|Chicago Cubs]] of the [[National League|National League]]. Both [[park|baseball parks]] hosted baseball championships. The latter of the two parks, where the franchise played for nearly a quarter century, was the home of the first two world champion Cubs teams ( and ), the team that posted the best winning percentage in Major League Baseball history and won the most games in National League history (), the only cross-town World Series in Chicago ([[1906|1906 World Series]]), and the immortalized [[Tinker to Evers to Chance|Tinker to Evers to Chance]] double-play combo. Both ballparks were what are now called "wooden" ballparks.
title: West Side Park

abstract: Canadian sprinter [[Percy Williams|Percy Williams (sprinter)]] set a world record in the [[100 metres|100 metres]] with a time of 10.3 seconds at Varsity Stadium during the [[Canadian Track and Field Championships|Canadian Track and Field Championships]] in 1930.Varsity Stadium has for its entire history been host to the University of Toronto's collegiate Canadian football team, the [[Varsity Blues|Toronto Varsity Blues]]. However it was, until the opening of [[Exhibition Stadium|Exhibition Stadium]] in 1959, the home of the [[Toronto Argonauts|Toronto Argonauts]] of what would become the [[Canadian Football League|Canadian Football League]]. Although it has not hosted a meaningful CFL game in almost half a century, it still holds the record for the number of times any stadium has hosted the Canadian professional football championship game, the [[Grey Cup|Grey Cup]]. Capacity of the stadium has varied with time, but peaked at about 22,000 in the 1950s although, with the use of temporary bleachers, a record crowd of 27,425 watched the Edmonton Eskimos defeat the Montreal Alouettes 50–27 in the [[1956 Grey Cup|1956 Grey Cup]] final.
title: Varsity Stadium

abstract: Situated in the central part of Singapore, Bishan Stadium is part of the Bishan Sports and Recreation Centre, which includes [[Bishan Sports Hall|Bishan Sports Hall]] and [[Bishan Swimming Complex|Bishan Swimming Complex]].
title: Bishan Stadium

abstract: Dedeaux Field is a [[college baseball|college baseball]] [[stadium|stadium]] in [[Los Angeles|Los Angeles]], [[California|California]], U.S., on the west end of the campus of the [[University of Southern California|University of Southern California]]. The home field of the [[USC Trojans|USC Trojans baseball]] of the [[Pac-12 Conference|Pac-12 Conference]], it has a [[seating capacity|seating capacity]] of 2,500.
title: Dedeaux Field

abstract: The Nelson Mandela Bay Stadium is a 46,000-seater stadium in [[Port Elizabeth|Port Elizabeth]], [[Eastern Cape|Eastern Cape]], South Africa.
title: Nelson Mandela Bay Stadium

abstract: Estadio Rommel Fernández Gutiérrez, named after the Panamanian football star [[Rommel Fernández|Rommel Fernández]], is a multi-purpose stadium located in [[Panama City|Panama City]]. It is used for different sports, but mainly for the conduct of [[football|association football]] (soccer) games. It was inaugurated February 6, 1970. It was designed to accommodate the [[XI Central American and Caribbean Games|XI Central American and Caribbean Games]] in 1970. Through further reforms, the stadium managed to reach the current capacity of 32,000 spectators all seated, now the largest stadium in Panama, above the [[Estadio Rod Carew|Estadio Rod Carew]] of baseball. It is part of Sports City [[Irving Saladino|Irving Saladino]].
title: Estadio Rommel Fernández

abstract: Landskrona IP (short for "Landskrona Idrottsplats", "Landskrona Sports Ground"), locally known as "I.P." the second home of [[Landskrona BoIS|Landskrona BoIS]] football club. The venue is owned by [[Landskrona Town|Landskrona]] but its only tenant is "BoIS", as the club is labeled locally. The arena was inaugurated in the summer of 1924, replacing the old Landskrona sports ground [[Banan|Banan (sports ground)]].The stadium is almost only used for football, and after the strange demolition of the western stand in 2011, it holds approximately 10,000 attenders (of which 3500 are covered seats) The terraced stands on the north and east side has never had any roofs. Aside from Landskrona BoIS' home games, has one Swedish friendly cap been played at the arena, as well as some matches in the UEFA 1974 Youth tournament. Perhaps better known, is the fact that the arena hosted all of the [[Faroe Islands|Faroe Islands]] home qualifications games for the [[UEFA Euro 1992|Euro 1992]].
title: Landskrona IP

abstract: Owlerton Stadium, sometimes referred to as Sheffield Sports Stadium, is a [[greyhound racing|Greyhound racing in the United Kingdom]] track in [[Owlerton|Owlerton]] near [[Hillsborough|Hillsborough, South Yorkshire]] in [[Sheffield|Sheffield]], [[South Yorkshire|South Yorkshire]], England. Greyhound Racing takes place on Tuesday, Friday and Saturday evenings and every Monday and Thursday afternoon. There is a modern glass-fronted Panorama Restaurant accommodating up to 300 people, executive suites, fast food facilities and a number of bars.
title: Owlerton Stadium

abstract: KR-völlur is a football [[stadium|stadium]] in [[Reykjavík|Reykjavík]], [[Iceland|Iceland]].
title: KR-völlur

abstract: SeatGeek Stadium is a [[soccer-specific stadium|soccer-specific stadium]] at 71st Street and Harlem Avenue in [[Bridgeview, Illinois|Bridgeview, Illinois]], about twelve miles southwest of downtown [[Chicago|Chicago]]. It is the home stadium of the [[Chicago Fire Soccer Club|Chicago Fire Soccer Club]] of [[Major League Soccer|Major League Soccer]] (MLS), the [[Chicago Red Stars|Chicago Red Stars]] of the [[National Women's Soccer League|National Women's Soccer League]] (NWSL), and the [[Chicago Bliss|Chicago Bliss]] of the [[Legends Football League|Legends Football League]] (LFL). The stadium has also hosted the [[Chicago Machine|Chicago Machine (MLL)]] of [[Major League Lacrosse|Major League Lacrosse]]. Originally named [[Toyota|Toyota#Sports]] Park when it opened on [[June 11|June 11]], 2006, the facility has a capacity of 20,000 and was developed at a cost of around $100 million. The [[naming rights|naming rights]] agreement with [[SeatGeek|SeatGeek]] went into effect following the [[Fire's 2018 season|2018 Chicago Fire season]].
title: SeatGeek Stadium

abstract: The Halliwell Jones Stadium is a [[rugby league|rugby league]] stadium in [[Warrington|Warrington]], [[England|England]], which is the home ground of [[Warrington Wolves|Warrington Wolves]]. It has also staged [[Challenge Cup|Challenge Cup]] semi-finals, the [[European Nations Final|Rugby League European Nations Cup]], the [[National League|Rugby League National Leagues]] Grand Finals' Day and two games of the [[2013 Rugby League World Cup|2013 Rugby League World Cup]].
title: Halliwell Jones Stadium

abstract: Construction of Bežigrad Stadium for the [[Roman Catholic|Roman Catholic]] youth sport association [[Orel|Orel (movement)]] began in 1925. It was designed by the architect [[Jože Plečnik|Jože Plečnik]]. It takes its name from the [[Bežigrad|Bežigrad]] district in Ljubljana, where it is located. It stands west of Vienna Street (Dunajska cesta) and north of Samo Street (Samova ulica).
title: Bežigrad Stadium

abstract: Belmore Sports Ground, formerly known as Belmore Oval, is a [[multi-purpose stadium|multi-purpose stadium]] in [[Belmore, New South Wales|Belmore, New South Wales]], [[Australia|Australia]]. The park covers and from 1951 has contained the Belmore Bowling Recreation Club green. It is close to [[Belmore railway station|Belmore railway station]].
title: Belmore Sports Ground

abstract: Folsom Field is an outdoor [[football|American football]] [[stadium|stadium]] in the [[western|Western United States]] [[United States|United States]], located on the campus of the [[University of Colorado|University of Colorado Boulder]] in [[Boulder|Boulder, Colorado]]. It is the home field of the [[Colorado Buffaloes|Colorado Buffaloes football]] of the [[Pac-12 Conference|Pac-12 Conference]].
title: Folsom Field

abstract: New Britain Stadium is a [[baseball|baseball]] venue in [[New Britain, Connecticut|New Britain, Connecticut]], [[United States|United States]]. It is the home of the [[New Britain Bees|New Britain Bees]] of the [[Atlantic League of Professional Baseball|Atlantic League of Professional Baseball]]. Opened in 1996, the stadium seats 6,146 spectators.
title: New Britain Stadium

abstract: El Molinón is the oldest professional football field in Spain. It has been in use since at least 1908, and is located on the site of an old [[watermill|watermill]], hence the stadium's name, the [[Asturian|Asturian language]] word for "big mill".[[Real Sporting|Real Sporting]] started to use El Molinón as official ground in 1917. The first official match was held on April 22, 1917 between Real Sporting and [[Arenas Club de Getxo|Arenas Club de Getxo]] as part of the [[1917 Copa del Rey|1917 Copa del Rey]]. Arenas won 0–1. On August 5 of that same year, the first great renovation of the stadium was finished.
title: El Molinón

abstract: Wilderspool Stadium was a [[rugby league|rugby league]] stadium in [[Warrington|Warrington]], [[England|England]]. The ground was [[Warrington RLFC's|Warrington Wolves]] old ground before moving to the [[Halliwell Jones Stadium|Halliwell Jones Stadium]].
title: Wilderspool Stadium

abstract: Griffiths Stadium is a [[stadium|stadium]] located on the grounds of the [[University of Saskatchewan|University of Saskatchewan]] in [[Saskatoon, Saskatchewan|Saskatoon, Saskatchewan]]. The current stadium was opened on June 23, 1967 to host the [[Saskatchewan Huskies|Saskatchewan Huskies]] football team. There was previously a Griffiths Stadium 200 metres to the east of the current location from October 3, 1936 until the new site was opened.
title: Griffiths Stadium

abstract: Millett Hall is a basketball arena in [[Oxford, Ohio|Oxford, Ohio]]. It is home to the [[Miami University|Miami University]] men's and women's basketball, and women's volleyball teams. It is also the home of the ROTC program and various university events. It is named after Miami University's 16th President [[John D. Millett|John D. Millett]]. The original construction cost was approximately $7.5 million. It is located on the northern part of Miami's campus, near [[Yager Stadium|Yager Stadium (Miami University)]]. The arena opened its doors on December 2, 1968, against [[Adolph Rupp|Adolph Rupp]]'s [[Kentucky Wildcats|Kentucky Wildcats]]. A crowd of 9,135 saw the Wildcats win 86-77. Miami's first win came on December 4, 1968, an 86-67 win over [[Bellarmine|Bellarmine University]].
title: Millett Hall

abstract: Bartow Arena is an 8,508-seat multi-purpose [[arena|arena]] in [[Birmingham|Birmingham, Alabama]], in the [[U.S. state|U.S. state]] of [[Alabama|Alabama]]. It is home to the [[University of Alabama at Birmingham|University of Alabama at Birmingham]] (UAB) [[Blazers|UAB Blazers]] [[men's|UAB Blazers men's basketball]] and women's [[basketball|basketball]] teams as well as the women's [[volleyball|volleyball]] team. The arena is named after [[Gene Bartow|Gene Bartow]], the coach who built the school's men's basketball program from scratch over the last quarter of the 20th century. UAB initially played their games at the [[Birmingham–Jefferson Convention Complex|Birmingham–Jefferson Convention Complex]] Arena, but moved its games to the on-campus facility beginning with the 1988–89 season.
title: Bartow Arena

abstract: EPRU Stadium, also known by its original name of Boet Erasmus Stadium, was a [[stadium|stadium]] in [[Port Elizabeth|Port Elizabeth, Eastern Cape]], [[South Africa|South Africa]]. The letters "EPRU" in the name represent the Eastern Province Rugby Union, the company behind the stadium's historic primary tenants, the [[Mighty Elephants|Eastern Province Elephants]]. The original name Boet Erasmus Stadium was named after Boet Erasmus, a former mayor of [[Port Elizabeth|Port Elizabeth]]. The stadium held a capacity of 33,852 people and served primarily as a venue for [[rugby union|rugby union]] matches but also hosted a number of [[football|association football]] fixtures.
title: EPRU Stadium

abstract: Browne Park is a rectangular football stadium located in the [[Rockhampton|Rockhampton, Queensland]] suburb of [[Wandal|Wandal, Queensland]], [[Queensland|Queensland]], [[Australia|Australia]]. The stadium has been the home of rugby league football in Central Queensland since the 1980s and today also hosts rugby union and soccer matches. It hosted a match of the [[2008 Rugby League World Cup|2008 Rugby League World Cup]].
title: Browne Park

abstract: Loftus Versfeld Stadium is a [[rugby|rugby union]] and [[soccer|soccer]] stadium situated in the [[Arcadia|Arcadia, Pretoria]] suburb of [[Pretoria|Pretoria]], [[Gauteng|Gauteng]], [[South Africa|South Africa]]. The stadium has a capacity of 51,762 for rugby union and it is occasionally used for football matches.
title: Loftus Versfeld Stadium

abstract: The Estádio Luso Brasileiro, formerly known as Ilha do Urubu,Arena Petrobras, Arena Botafogo and Estádio da Ilha do Governador, is a [[football|Association football]] stadium inaugurated on 2 October 1965 in [[Ilha do Governador|Ilha do Governador]] neighborhood, [[Rio de Janeiro|Rio de Janeiro]], Rio de Janeiro state. The maximum capacity of the stadium is of 6,437 spectators, expanded to 17,250 due to renovations made by [[Botafogo|Botafogo de Futebol e Regatas]] so it can use it as its home ground for the [[2016 Brazilian Série A|2016 Campeonato Brasileiro Série A]] and once again expanded to 20,113 made by [[Flamengo|Clube de Regatas do Flamengo]] in 2017. The stadium is owned by [[Portuguesa|Associação Atlética Portuguesa (RJ)]] and was also the home ground of [[Flamengo|Clube de Regatas do Flamengo]] and Botafogo during the [[2005 Brazilian Série A|2005 Campeonato Brasileiro Série A]]. Nowadays, the stadium has returned with its official capacity after the end of the partnership with [[Flamengo|Clube de Regatas do Flamengo]] in the middle of 2018
title: Estádio Luso Brasileiro

abstract: Estádio Olímpico Monumental (Monumental Olympic Stadium, in English), also known as Estádio Olímpico de Porto Alegre (Porto Alegre Olympic Stadium) and Estádio Olímpico (Olympic Stadium) until 1980, is a [[football|football (soccer)]] stadium in the city of [[Porto Alegre|Porto Alegre]], in the [[Brazil|Brazilian]] state of [[Rio Grande do Sul|Rio Grande do Sul]], with a maximum capacity of 45,000 people. The stadium is owned by [[Grêmio Foot-Ball Porto Alegrense|Grêmio Foot-Ball Porto Alegrense]]. Inaugurated in September 19, 1954, the stadium was the home field of the [[Grêmio|Grêmio Foot-Ball Porto Alegrense]] football club before being the team moved to [[Arena do Grêmio|Arena do Grêmio]] in December 2012. Currently, the venue is not in use by the club and suffers from lack of maintenance.
title: Estádio Olímpico Monumental

abstract: Bloomfield Road is a [[football|association football]] stadium in [[Blackpool|Blackpool]], Lancashire, England, which has been the home of [[Blackpool F.C.|Blackpool F.C.]] since 1901.
title: Bloomfield Road

abstract: Estadio Corregidora is a stadium in [[Querétaro City|Querétaro City]], [[Mexico|Mexico]]. Named for [[Mexican War of Independence|Mexican War of Independence]] heroine [[Josefa Ortiz de Domínguez|Josefa Ortiz de Domínguez]] ("La Corregidora"), it has a capacity of 33,162 and is located on the outskirts of the city of [[Querétaro|Santiago de Querétaro]], north of [[Mexico City|Mexico City]]. This venue is used mostly for [[football (soccer)|football (soccer)]] games. It is the home of the team [[Querétaro FC|Querétaro FC]] and hosted the [[1986 FIFA World Cup|1986 FIFA World Cup]].
title: Estadio Corregidora

abstract: Stadion Feijenoord (), more commonly known by its nickname De Kuip ( the Tub, is a [[stadium|stadium]] in [[Rotterdam|Rotterdam]], [[Netherlands|Netherlands]], that was completed in 1937. The name is derived from the [[Feijenoord district|Feijenoord district]] in Rotterdam, and from the club with the same name (although the club's name was internationalised to Feyenoord in 1973).
title: De Kuip

abstract: Korketrekkeren (direct translation: "The Corkscrew") is a [[tobogganing|tobogganing]] track and former [[bobsleigh|bobsleigh]] and [[luge|luge]] track in [[Oslo|Oslo]], [[Norway|Norway]]. The tobogganing track runs between [[Frognerseteren|Frognerseteren]] and [[Midtstuen|Midtstuen]] and is operated as a public venue by the municipality. Return transport to the top of the hill is undertaken by riding the [[Oslo Metro|Oslo Metro]]'s [[Holmenkollen Line|Holmenkollen Line]]. Tobogganing in the area started in the 1880s, with several roads being used during winter evenings. [[Auto racing|Auto racing]] took place in the hill in 1921 and the following year it saw its first luge tournament. The first major tournament was the [[FIL European Luge Championships 1937|FIL European Luge Championships 1937]]. Tobagganing also took place in the nearby Heftyebakken, but from 1950 Korketrekkeren became the sole tobogganing hill and Heftyebakken was used for [[cross-country skiing|cross-country skiing]].
title: Korketrekkeren

abstract: Estadio La Romareda is the home stadium of [[Real Zaragoza|Real Zaragoza]], in [[Zaragoza|Zaragoza]]. It was inaugurated on September 8, 1957, with a game between Real Zaragoza and [[CA Osasuna|CA Osasuna]] (4–3). The official capacity is 34,596, with an average attendance of around 30,000 for Real Zaragoza matches.The stadium has gone through various upgrades, in 1977 and in 1982, when it was a [[1982 FIFA World Cup|1982 FIFA World Cup]] venue. The stadium was also used for [[football|Football at the 1992 Summer Olympics]] group matches and a quarterfinal during the [[1992 Summer Olympics|1992 Summer Olympics]]. It became an all-seater stadium in 1994.
title: La Romareda

abstract: Estádio Nacional de Brasília Mané Garrincha, also known as Estádio Nacional Mané Garrincha, Estádio Nacional de Brasília, Arena Mané Garrincha or simply Mané Garrincha, is a football stadium and multipurpose [[arena|arena]], located in the Brazilian capital of [[Brasília|Brasília]], [[DF|Distrito Federal (Brazil)]]. The stadium is one of several structures that make up the Poliesportivo Ayrton Senna Complex, which also includes the [[Nilson Nelson Gymnasium|Nilson Nelson Gymnasium]] and [[Nelson Piquet International Autodrome|Autódromo Internacional Nelson Piquet (Brasília)]]., among others. Opened in 1974, the stadium had a total capacity of 45,200 people. After the reconstruction of 2010 – 2013, the capacity was increased to 72,788 people, making it the second-largest stadium in Brazil and one of the largest in [[South America|South America (continent)]].
title: Estádio Nacional Mané Garrincha

abstract: Städtisches Waldstadion, known as OSTALB ARENA for sponsorship purposes, is a [[multi-purpose stadium|multi-purpose stadium]] in [[Aalen|Aalen]], [[Germany|Germany]]. It is currently used mostly for [[football|football (soccer)]] matches and is the home stadium of [[VfR Aalen|VfR Aalen]]. The stadium is able to hold 14,500 people.
title: Städtisches Waldstadion

abstract: Post Office Road, (currently known as the L.D. Nutrition Stadium for sponsorship purposes), is a [[rugby league|rugby league]] ground in [[Featherstone|Featherstone]], near [[Pontefract|Pontefract]], [[West Yorkshire|West Yorkshire]], [[England|England]]. It is the home of [[rugby league|rugby league]] club [[Featherstone Rovers|Featherstone Rovers]]. The ground's current capacity is 9,850.
title: Post Office Road

abstract: The Robertson Oval is a multi-use sports facility in [[Wagga Wagga|Wagga Wagga]], [[New South Wales|New South Wales]], [[Australia|Australia]]. It primarily hosts [[cricket|cricket]], [[Australian rules football|Australian rules football]] and [[rugby league|rugby league]] matches. A grass embankment runs around three-quarters of the oval with a 350-seat grandstand and social club on western side of the ground. Plans are in place for a 3–5 million dollar redevelopment of the arena. As the oval is located in the heart of Wagga Wagga [[CBD|Central business district]], the AFL and [[New South Wales Cricket Association|New South Wales Cricket Association]] will use the oval after redevelopment preferring it to other regional venues.
title: Robertson Oval

abstract: Arena do Grêmio is a multi-use [[stadium|stadium]] in [[Porto Alegre|Porto Alegre]], [[Rio Grande do Sul|Rio Grande do Sul]], [[Brazil|Brazil]]. It was inaugurated on December 8, 2012.
title: Arena do Grêmio

abstract: TVF Burhan Felek Sport Hall, () is a volleyball arena located in [[Üsküdar|Üsküdar]] district of [[Istanbul|Istanbul]], [[Turkey|Turkey]] and reopened on 19 November 2010. It is owned by the Municipality of Kadıköy District and operated by the Directorate of Youth and Sport of [[Istanbul Province|Istanbul Province]].
title: TVF Burhan Felek Sport Hall

abstract: Stožice Stadium () is a [[multi-purpose|Multi-purpose stadium]] stadium located in [[Ljubljana|Ljubljana]], [[Slovenia|Slovenia]]. It was designed by Slovenian Sadar Vuga d.o.o. architects and is the biggest football stadium in the country. It is one of two main stadiums in the city and lies in the [[Bežigrad|Bežigrad, Ljubljana]] district, north of the city centre. The stadium is part of the [[Stožice Sports Park|Stožice Sports Park]] sports complex.
title: Stožice Stadium

abstract: Perry Barr Stadium (also known as Perry Barr Greyhound Stadium and previously as Alexander Sports Ground(s)) is a [[stadium|stadium]] and a [[Greyhound Board of Great Britain|Greyhound Board of Great Britain]] regulated [[greyhound racing|greyhound racing]] track on Aldridge Road in [[Perry Barr|Perry Barr]], [[Birmingham|Birmingham]], [[England|England]]. The track is operated by the [[Greyhound Racing Association|Greyhound Racing Association]], which is a subsidiary of the National Asset Management Agency, who also own the stadium. Racing takes place every Saturday evening, in addition to their four [[ARC|Arena Racing Company]] fixtures.
title: Perry Barr Stadium

abstract: BBVA Compass Stadium is an American [[multi-purpose stadium|multi-purpose stadium]] located in [[Houston|Houston]], [[Texas|Texas]] that is home to the [[Houston Dynamo|Houston Dynamo]], a [[Major League Soccer|Major League Soccer]] club, the [[Houston Dash|Houston Dash]] of the [[National Women's Soccer League|National Women's Soccer League]], and to [[Texas Southern Tigers football|Texas Southern Tigers football]]. The stadium is the result of combined commitments of $35.5 million from the city of Houston and $60 million from the Houston Dynamo. Harris County agreed to pay for half of the land in exchange for the ability to jointly own the stadium after its completion date in May 2012. BBVA Compass, a subsidiary of [[Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria|Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria]], is the stadium's sponsor company.
title: BBVA Compass Stadium

abstract: Stadion Albert Flórián was a sports stadium in [[Budapest|Budapest]], [[Hungary|Hungary]]. The stadium was the home of the [[association football|association football]] club [[Ferencvárosi TC|Ferencvárosi TC]]. The stadium had a capacity of 18,100. Formerly known as Üllői úti stadion for its location, it had been renamed for [[Ballon d'Or|Ballon d'Or]] winner club legend [[Flórián Albert|Flórián Albert]] in 2007. Today, the stadium's place is occupied by the newly built [[Groupama Arena|Groupama Arena]].
title: Stadion Albert Flórián

abstract: The GS Champions Park is the training center of [[FC Seoul|FC Seoul]]. It is located in [[Guri|Guri]], east of nearby [[Seoul|Seoul]].
title: GS Champions Park

abstract: The Astelena fronton, nicknamed Cathedral of Basque Hand-pelota, is a [[fronton|Fronton (court)]] located in [[Eibar|Eibar]], [[Gipuzkoa|Gipuzkoa]], [[Basque Autonomous Community|Basque Country (autonomous community)]], Spain.
title: Astelena fronton

abstract: Barcroft Park is a baseball venue located in [[Arlington, Virginia|Arlington County, Virginia]], US. The field is home to the [[George Washington Colonials baseball|George Washington Colonials baseball]] team of the [[NCAA|NCAA]] [[Division I|NCAA Division I]] [[Atlantic 10 Conference|Atlantic 10 Conference]]. The field holds a capacity of 1,000 spectators. The field is officially designated Barcroft Park Field #6 and includes a new turf field by FieldTurf, bullpens, enclosed dugouts, bleachers, lights, scoreboard, and pressbox.
title: Barcroft Park

abstract: Peterborough Greyhound Stadium is a [[greyhound racing|greyhound racing]] track located in [[Fengate|Fengate, Cambridgeshire]], less than a mile from the centre of [[Peterborough|Peterborough]], England.
title: Peterborough Greyhound Stadium

abstract: The Stadio Sandro Cabassi opened in 1928 and has played host to [[Carpi F.C. 1909|Carpi F.C. 1909]]. After Carpi's [[Serie A|Serie A]] promotion for the [[2015–16|2015–16 Serie A]] season, they played in [[Modena F.C.|Modena F.C.]]'s [[Stadio Alberto Braglia|Stadio Alberto Braglia]] in order to follow minimum capacity rules in Serie A. Following their relegation after the season concluded, they moved back.
title: Stadio Sandro Cabassi

abstract: Páirc Mac Uílín is a [[Gaelic Athletic Association|Gaelic Athletic Association]] playing field in [[Ballycastle|Ballycastle, County Antrim]], [[County Antrim|County Antrim]], [[Northern Ireland|Northern Ireland]]. It is the home of the [[McQuillan GAC Ballycastle|Ballycastle McQuillan GAC]] club, one of the most successful teams in the county.The grounds have two full size pitches, floodlight facilities, a training area, a Hurling wall as well as multi-purpose clubrooms. The club also has a wind turbine installed on site.
title: Páirc Mac Uílín

abstract: Pelaw Grange Stadium is a [[Greyhound Board of Great Britain|Greyhound Board of Great Britain]] regulated [[greyhound racing|greyhound racing]] track located at North Lodge in the [[English|England]] county of [[Durham|County Durham]], between [[Chester-le-Street|Chester-le-Street]] and [[Gateshead|Gateshead]]. The stadium has a restaurant and a number of bars and has been owned by the McKenna family since January 1965.
title: Pelaw Grange

abstract: Iradier Arena, also known as Plaza de Toros de Vitoria-Gasteiz, is an [[arena|arena]] and [[bullring|bullring]] in [[Vitoria-Gasteiz|Vitoria-Gasteiz]], [[Spain|Spain]]. It is primarily used for [[bullfighting|bullfighting]] and [[basketball|basketball]], and was the home to the [[Baskonia|Saski Baskonia]] while the [[Fernando Buesa Arena|Fernando Buesa Arena]] was expanded. It opened in 1941 and holds 10,625 spectators.
title: Iradier Arena

abstract: Headingley Rugby Stadium, (known as Emerald Headingley Stadium due to sponsorship), shares the same site as [[Headingley Cricket Ground|Headingley Cricket Ground]] and is home to both [[Leeds Rhinos|Leeds Rhinos]] and [[Yorkshire Carnegie|Yorkshire Carnegie]] rugby teams. Headingley is also the [[5th largest rugby league stadium in England|List of Rugby League stadiums in England]].
title: Headingley Rugby Stadium

abstract: The Morningside Arena Leicester, previously known as the Leicester Arena, is a multi-purpose built sports arena located in [[Leicester|Leicester]], [[England|England]]. The arena has a seating capacity for 3,000 spectators. The arena's main tenants are the basketball team [[Leicester Riders|Leicester Riders]].
title: Leicester Arena

abstract: The Troy Softball Complex, built in 2002 on the campus of [[Troy University|Troy University]], is the home stadium for the [[Division I (NCAA)|Division I (NCAA)]] [[Troy Trojans softball|Troy Trojans softball]] team. In 2014, the entire complex underwent a $3 million renovation project. The official seating capacity is 800, with 120 of the seats being chairback seating. The Dodd Center was built in 2014 during the renovation, which houses coaches offices, player lounge, and locker rooms, and indoor batting cages. In the opening game of 2014, Troy hosted [[Auburn|Auburn University]] at the newly renovated field, finishing in a 5-5 tie with the Tigers.
title: Troy Softball Complex

abstract: The Stade d'Angondjé is a stadium in [[Angondjé|Angondjé]], a suburb of [[Libreville|Libreville]] in [[Gabon|Gabon]]. It is referred to as Stade de l'Amitié. The stadium build was expected to take 20 months and was funded by the Gabonese and Chinese governments.
title: Stade d'Angondjé

abstract: Clay Gould Ballpark (formerly Allan Saxe Stadium and Arlington Athletic Center), the home field of the [[UT Arlington Mavericks|Texas–Arlington Mavericks baseball]], is located on the campus of The [[University of Texas at Arlington|University of Texas at Arlington]] (UT Arlington). The stadium has a seat capacity of 1,600. Clay Gould Ballpark is located at the intersection of West Park Row Drive and Fielder Road.
title: Clay Gould Ballpark

abstract: Riddle–Pace Field is a [[baseball|baseball]] venue in [[Troy, Alabama|Troy, Alabama]], [[United States|United States]], home to the [[Troy Trojans baseball|Troy Trojans baseball]] team. The grandstand seating capacity is 2,000. The venue features an outfield viewing area for tailgaters, a patio area for fans above the home dugout, and a large black wall with a video board and score board system. The wall has become known as the "Monster".
title: Riddle–Pace Field

abstract: Clyde Williams Field was an outdoor stadium on the campus of [[Iowa State University|Iowa State University]] in [[Ames, Iowa|Ames, Iowa]]. It was the home of the [[Iowa State Cyclones football|Iowa State Cyclones football]] and [[track and field|Iowa State Cyclones track and field]] teams.
title: Clyde Williams Field

abstract: The Mayagüez Athletics Stadium is 13,000 capacity [[stadium|stadium]] in [[Mayagüez|Mayagüez, Puerto Rico]], [[Puerto Rico|Puerto Rico]] opened in 2010. <SEP> The stadium is owned by City of Mayaguez, and operated by [[Puerto Rico Sol|Puerto Rico Sol]]. It hosted the [[athletics|Track and field athletics]] and [[soccer|Football at the 2010 Central American and Caribbean Games]] games of the [[2010 Central American and Caribbean Games|2010 Central American and Caribbean Games]]. In 2019 the stadium will host invitational tournament [[Puerto Rico Cup|Puerto Rico Cup]]. <SEP> The stadium has a soccer field based on the requisites of [[International Federation of Association Football|FIFA]], it will also have a 400-meter track which complies with the parameter of the [[International Association of Athletics Federations|International Association of Athletics Federations]].
title: Mayagüez Athletics Stadium

abstract: Gressbanen or Vestre Holmen is a stadium located at [[Holmen|Holmen, Oslo]] in [[Oslo|Oslo]], [[Norway|Norway]]. During summer it has [[artificial turf|artificial turf]] and is used for [[association football|association football]], while during winter it has [[artificial ice|artificial ice]] and fields [[bandy|bandy]]. The complex also contains a smaller training field with gravel during summer and natural ice during winter. Gressbanen is the home venue of [[IF Ready|IF Ready]], whose bandy team plays in the [[Norwegian Bandy Premier League|Norwegian Bandy Premier League]] and who fields 35 recreational football teams.
title: Gressbanen

abstract: Perth Stadium, also known by naming rights sponsorship as Optus Stadium, is a [[multi-purpose stadium|multi-purpose stadium]] in [[Perth, Western Australia|Perth]], located in the suburb of [[Burswood|Burswood, Western Australia]]. It was completed in late 2017 and officially opened on 21 January 2018.
