The stadium has a capacity of over 60,000 people, making it the [[third-largest stadium in Australia|List of sports venues in Australia]] (after the [[Melbourne Cricket Ground|Melbourne Cricket Ground]] and [[ANZ Stadium|ANZ Stadium]]). The stadium can be extended up to 65,000 seats for rectangular sports.
title: Perth Stadium

abstract: The Rideau Skating Rink was an indoor skating and [[curling|curling]] facility located in [[Ottawa|Ottawa]], [[Ontario|Ontario]], Canada. Consisting of a curling rink and a skating rink, it was one of the first indoor rinks in Canada. The Rideau Rink was scheduled to open on January 10, 1889, but unseasonably mild weather postponed the grand opening to February 1. It opened in January 25, 1889 for select V.I.P's although this was a misunderstanding and should not have denied entry to season ticket holders. It was located on Theodore Street, (now Laurier Avenue) at Waller Street, at the present location of the Arts Hall of the [[University of Ottawa|University of Ottawa]], near the [[Rideau Canal|Rideau Canal]].
title: Rideau Skating Rink

abstract: The Kuala Lumpur Stadium () or Bandar Tun Razak Stadium is a [[multi-purpose stadium|multi-purpose stadium]] in [[Bandar Tun Razak|Bandar Tun Razak]], [[Kuala Lumpur|Kuala Lumpur]], [[Malaysia|Malaysia]]. It is currently used mostly for [[football|football (soccer)]] matches. It is the current home stadium of [[Kuala Lumpur|Kuala Lumpur FA]] and [[Malaysia|Malaysia national football team]].
title: Kuala Lumpur Stadium

abstract: Swissporarena is a multi-use [[stadium|stadium]] in [[Lucerne|Lucerne]], [[Switzerland|Switzerland]], completed in 2011. It is used mostly for [[football|football (soccer)]] matches and hosts the home matches of [[FC Lucerne|FC Lucerne]] of the [[Swiss Super League|Swiss Super League]]. The stadium has a capacity of 16,800 spectators, including an away fans' section fitted with 390 rail seats for [[safe standing|safe standing]]. It replaced the demolished [[Stadion Allmend|Stadion Allmend]].
title: Swissporarena

abstract: Birkebeineren Ski Stadium () is a [[cross-country skiing|cross-country skiing]] and [[biathlon|biathlon]] venue located in [[Lillehammer|Lillehammer]], [[Norway|Norway]]. Situated from the town center and at [[above mean sea level|above mean sea level]], it has two stadium areas, one for cross-country and one for biathlon. The former has a capacity for 31,000 spectators, and the latter for 13,500. The venue was built for the [[1994 Winter Olympics|1994 Winter Olympics]], costing 83.6   million [[Norwegian krone|Norwegian krone]] (NOK). It was subsequently used by the [[1994 Winter Paralympics|1994 Winter Paralympics]] for [[Paralympic Nordic skiing|Paralympic Nordic skiing]] and [[Paralympic biathlon|Paralympic biathlon]]. After the games, ownership was transferred to the municipal [[Lillehammer Olympiapark|Lillehammer Olympiapark]]. The venue has since been used for one [[Biathlon World Cup|Biathlon World Cup]], three [[FIS Cross-Country World Cup|FIS Cross-Country World Cup]] and nine [[FIS Nordic Combined World Cup|FIS Nordic Combined World Cup]] tournaments, the latter with the ski jumping competition taking place at the nearby [[Lysgårdsbakkene Ski Jumping Arena|Lysgårdsbakken]]. Birkebeineren is scheduled to host the [[2016 Winter Youth Olympics|2016 Winter Youth Olympics]].
title: Birkebeineren Ski Stadium

abstract: The Matthew Knight Arena (MKA) is a 12,364-seat, multi-purpose [[arena|arena]] in [[Eugene|Eugene, Oregon]], [[Oregon|Oregon]], [[United States|United States]]. It is home of the [[University of Oregon|University of Oregon]] [[Ducks|Oregon Ducks]] [[basketball|basketball]] teams, replacing [[McArthur Court|McArthur Court]]. It is located on the east side of campus at the corner of Franklin Boulevard and Villard Street, a gateway to campus as people arrive from [[I-5|Interstate 5]]. The arena was originally intended to be ready for the start of the 2010–11 basketball season, but instead opened for the men's basketball game against the [[USC Trojans|USC Trojans men's basketball]] on January 13, 2011. It is named for chief donor [[Phil Knight|Phil Knight]]'s son, Matthew Knight, who died at the age of 34 in a scuba diving accident. The arena cost $227 million and was designed as collaboration between [[TVA Architects|TVA Architects]] of [[Portland|Portland, Oregon]] and [[Ellerbe Becket|Ellerbe Becket]] of [[Kansas City|Kansas City, Missouri]], [[Missouri|Missouri]]. Hoffman Construction Company of [[Portland|Portland, Oregon]] was the general contractor.
title: Matthew Knight Arena

abstract: Eklavya Sports Stadium is cricket stadium located in [[Agra|Agra]], [[Uttar Pradesh|Uttar Pradesh]] state of [[India|India]]. The stadium is named after very famous student of India at the time of "[[Mahabharata|Mahabharata]]", [[Eklavya|Eklavya]].
title: Eklavya Sports Stadium

abstract: The Markham Pan Am Centre is a multi-purpose [[community|community centre]] and [[aquatics|aquatic sports]] centre located in the new [[downtown|Downtown Markham, Ontario]] area of [[Markham|Markham, Ontario]], [[Ontario|Ontario]], Canada. The facility was designed to host the [[badminton|badminton]], [[table tennis|table tennis]] and [[water polo|water polo]] events for the [[2015 Pan American Games|2015 Pan American Games]], held in nearby [[Toronto|Toronto]] in July and August, 2015. This venue also hosted the table tennis competition in the [[2015 Parapan American Games|2015 Parapan American Games]]. During the Pan Am and Parapan American Games the venue was known as the Atos Markham Pan Am / Parapan American Centre.
title: Markham Pan Am Centre

abstract: Mata Elang International Stadium or MEIS is an international music [[stadium|stadium]] located at [[Ancol Dreamland|Ancol Dreamland]], [[Jakarta|Jakarta]], [[Indonesia|Indonesia]]. The stadium opened in early 2012. It is located inside [[Ancol Beach City|Ancol Beach City]], a lifestyle and entertainment center. It is one of the biggest indoor stadiums in [[Southeast Asia|Southeast Asia]].
title: Mata Elang International Stadium

abstract: Harlow Stadium is a [[greyhound racing|greyhound racing]] track located in [[Harlow|Harlow]], [[Essex|Essex]], England. The stadium also has executive suites, a restaurant, a number of bars and conference and banqueting facilities.
title: Harlow Stadium

abstract: Doncaster Greyhound Stadium is a [[greyhound racing|Greyhound racing in the United Kingdom]] track located in [[Stainforth|Stainforth, South Yorkshire]], near [[Doncaster|Doncaster]], England.
title: Doncaster Greyhound Stadium

abstract: Malappuram District Sports Complex Stadium, also known as Manjeri Stadium or Payyanad Stadium is an [[athletics|athletics (sport)]] [[stadium|stadium]] in [[Manjeri|Manjeri]], [[Kerala|Kerala]], [[India|India]]. The stadium is part of [[Malappuram District Sports Complex & Football Academy|Malappuram District Sports Complex & Football Academy]], under the management of Malappuram District Sports Council. It was selected as one of two stadiums, along with the [[Jawaharlal Nehru Stadium|Jawaharlal Nehru Stadium, Kochi]], to host the [[group stages|2013–14 Indian Federation Cup Group Stage]] of the [[2013–14 Indian Federation Cup|2013–14 Indian Federation Cup]]. The stadium hosted groups B and D.
title: Malappuram District Sports Complex Stadium

abstract: The Nagyerdei Stadion is an [[all-seater|all-seater stadium]] [[asymmetric|Asymmetry]] [[football|association football]] [[stadium|stadium]] in [[Debrecen|Debrecen]], Hungary and home to [[Debreceni Vasutas Sport Club|Debreceni VSC]] (the seats behind the goals are 'Vario' or 'Rail' seats to facilitate [[safe standing|safe standing]] at domestic matches). With space for 20,340 spectators, Nagyerdei stadion has the third largest capacity of any Hungarian football stadium, preceded by [[Puskás Ferenc Stadion|Puskás Ferenc Stadion]] and [[Groupama Aréna|Groupama Aréna]] and the second largest [[Nemzeti Bajnokság I|Nemzeti Bajnokság I]] stadium after [[Groupama Aréna|Groupama Aréna]]. The stadium primarily hosts Debreceni Vasutas Sport Club's home matches. It was opened on 1 May 2014 and the first official match was played between Debrecen and [[Újpest|Újpest FC]] in the [[2013–14 season|2013–14 Nemzeti Bajnokság I]] which ended with a 3-1 victory for the host team.
title: Nagyerdei Stadion

abstract: Borisov Arena is a [[football-specific stadium|football-specific stadium]] in [[Barysaw|Barysaw]], [[Belarus|Belarus]] and is the home stadium of [[FC BATE Borisov|FC BATE Borisov]] and the [[Belarus national football team|Belarus national football team]]. The stadium's official capacity is 13,126.
title: Borisov Arena

abstract: Albertsons Stadium is an outdoor athletic stadium in the western United States, located on the campus of [[Boise State University|Boise State University]] in [[Boise, Idaho|Boise, Idaho]]. It is the home field of the [[Boise State Broncos|Boise State Broncos football]] of the [[Mountain West Conference|Mountain West Conference]]. Known as Bronco Stadium for its first 44 seasons, it was renamed in May [[2014|2014 Boise State Broncos football team]] when [[Albertsons|Albertsons]], a chain of grocery stores founded by Boise area resident [[Joe Albertson|Joe Albertson]], purchased the naming rights.
title: Albertsons Stadium

abstract: The Gangneung Oval ([[Korean|Korean language]]: 강릉 스피드 스케이팅 경기장) is a [[speed skating oval|speed skating rink]] in [[South Korea|South Korea]], which was used for the [[speed skating competitions at the 2018 Winter Olympics|Speed skating at the 2018 Winter Olympics]]. The building of the oval was started in September 2013. The venue consists of a double track 400 metre rink and has a capacity of 8000 seats. It has three floors above ground and two underground levels. The original plan was to build the venue at the [[Gangneung Science Park|Gangneung Science Park]], but because there was limited space due to the number of local businesses taking the opportunity to relocate, the oval was built in the [[Gangneung Olympic Park|Gangneung Olympic Park]], in the vicinity of the [[Gangneung Ice Arena|Gangneung Ice Arena]] and [[Gangneung Hockey Centre|Gangneung Hockey Centre]].
title: Gangneung Oval

abstract: In March 2016, the Calgary Stampede organization announced plans to demolish the Stampede Corral to make way for a $500 million expansion of the adjacent [[BMO Centre|BMO Centre]]. Stampede officials said that the Corral was no longer up to code, and it wouldn't have been worth the expense to renovate it.
title: Stampede Corral

abstract: Ostseestadion is the home stadium of [[F.C. Hansa Rostock|F.C. Hansa Rostock]], a [[German|Germany]] football club, located in the city of [[Rostock|Rostock]].
title: Ostseestadion

abstract: On November 19, 2005, the playing field at the stadium was named in honor of former Auburn coach and athletic director [[Pat Dye|Pat Dye]]. The venue is now known as Pat Dye Field at Jordan–Hare Stadium. The stadium reached its current [[seating capacity|seating capacity]] of 87,451 with the 2004 expansion and is [[the 10th largest|List of NCAA Division I FBS football stadiums]] stadium in the [[NCAA|National Collegiate Athletic Association]]. By the end of the 2006 season, it was estimated that 19,308,753 spectators had attended a football game in Jordan–Hare. Jordan–Hare Stadium regularly makes lists of the best gameday atmospheres and most intimidating places to play.
title: Jordan–Hare Stadium

abstract: Amon G. Carter Stadium is an open-air football [[stadium|stadium]] on the campus of [[Texas Christian University|Texas Christian University]] in [[Fort Worth, Texas|Fort Worth, Texas]]. It is the home stadium of the [[TCU Horned Frogs football team|TCU Horned Frogs football]]. It is named after [[Amon G. Carter|Amon G. Carter]], a prominent Fort Worth businessman, newspaper publisher, and city booster. It has several popular nicknames, the most popular being "The Carter" and "Hell's Half Acre" (a reference to the site in Fort Worth's wild west past, which was located near the stadium, as well as the difficulty opposing teams have winning in the stadium).
title: Amon G. Carter Stadium

abstract: Williams–Brice Stadium is the home [[football|American football]] [[stadium|stadium]] for the [[South Carolina Gamecocks|South Carolina Gamecocks]], the college football team representing the [[University of South Carolina|University of South Carolina]] in [[Columbia, South Carolina|Columbia, South Carolina]]. It is currently the 20th largest college football stadium in the NCAA and is located on the corner of George Rogers Boulevard and Bluff Road adjacent to the South Carolina State Fairgrounds.
title: Williams–Brice Stadium

abstract: Boone Pickens Stadium (previously known as Lewis Field) has been home to the [[Oklahoma State University Cowboys football|Oklahoma State Cowboys football]] team in rudimentary form since 1913, and as a complete stadium since 1920. The facility is the oldest football stadium in the [[Big 12 Conference|Big 12 Conference]] but was left largely neglected and enjoyed only modest renovations throughout its near-century of existence.
title: Boone Pickens Stadium

abstract: The Estádio Cidade de Coimbra is a [[stadium|stadium]] in [[Coimbra|Coimbra]], [[Portugal|Portugal]]. This stadium belongs to the Municipality of Coimbra and is mainly used by the [[Académica de Coimbra|Associação Académica de Coimbra - O.A.F.]]'s [[football|soccer]] team. Until 2003, it was called the Estádio Municipal de Coimbra (), or the Estádio do Calhabé, after the name of its location in Coimbra.
title: Estádio Cidade de Coimbra

abstract: Mineirão (), officially Estádio Governador Magalhães Pinto (Governor Magalhães Pinto Stadium) is the largest [[football|association football]] stadium in the state of [[Minas Gerais|Minas Gerais]]. It was established in 1965, and it is located in [[Belo Horizonte|Belo Horizonte]].
title: Mineirão

abstract: Fifth Third Arena is a 12,012-seat basketball [[arena|arena]] in [[Cincinnati|Cincinnati]], [[Ohio|Ohio]], United States. The number of seats in the arena was reduced from the initial 13,176 seat design to 12,012 in honor of the number 12 jersey of Hall of Famer Oscar Robertson. The arena opened in 1989 and is located on the campus of the [[University of Cincinnati|University of Cincinnati]]. It primarily serves as the home venue for the [[Cincinnati Bearcats men's basketball|Cincinnati Bearcats men's basketball]], women's basketball, and women's volleyball teams and hosts other events. It is located in the Myrl H. Shoemaker Center, which was also the name of the arena until 2005, when it was [[named|naming rights]] for Cincinnati-based [[Fifth Third Bank|Fifth Third Bank]])
title: Fifth Third Arena

abstract: Navy–Marine Corps Memorial Stadium is an open-air [[stadium|stadium]] located off the campus of the [[United States Naval Academy|United States Naval Academy]] in [[Annapolis|Annapolis]], [[Maryland|Maryland]]. Opened in 1959, it serves as the home stadium of the [[Navy Midshipmen|Navy Midshipmen]] [[college football|Navy Midshipmen football]] and [[lacrosse|Navy Midshipmen men's lacrosse]], and the professional [[Chesapeake Bayhawks|Chesapeake Bayhawks]] of [[Major League Lacrosse|Major League Lacrosse]]. The stadium is also the host of the [[Military Bowl|Military Bowl]].
title: Navy–Marine Corps Memorial Stadium

abstract: The Estadio León, unofficially known as Nou Camp, is a mid-sized football stadium with a [[seating capacity|seating capacity]] of 31,297 built in 1967, and located in the city of [[León, Guanajuato|León, Guanajuato]], in the [[Bajío|Bajío]] region of central Mexico. This sport facility is used mostly for football matches and is the home of the [[Club León|Club León]].
title: Estadio León

abstract: Dreamstyle Stadium, formerly known as University Stadium, is an outdoor [[football|American football]] [[stadium|stadium]] located on the south campus of the [[University of New Mexico|University of New Mexico]] in [[Albuquerque|Albuquerque]]. It is the home field of [[New Mexico Lobos|New Mexico Lobos]] [[football|New Mexico Lobos football]], which competes as a member of the [[Mountain West Conference|Mountain West Conference]]. The stadium opened in September 1960 and currently has a [[seating capacity|seating capacity]] of 39,224. The playing surface, named Turner & Margaret Branch Field, is oriented in the north-south configuration that is traditional for football venues. The stadium sits nearly a mile above sea level, at an elevation of 5,100 feet (1554 m).
title: Dreamstyle Stadium

abstract: White Hart Lane was a [[football|Association football]] stadium in [[Tottenham|Tottenham]], North [[London|London]] and the home of [[Tottenham Hotspur Football Club|Tottenham Hotspur F.C.]] from 1899 to 2017. Its capacity varied over the years; when changed to all-seater it had a capacity of 36,284 before demolition. The stadium was fully demolished after the end of the [[2016–17 season|2016–17 Tottenham Hotspur F.C. season]].
title: White Hart Lane

abstract: The Den (previously The New Den) is a [[football|association football]] stadium in [[Bermondsey|Bermondsey]], south-east [[London|London]], and the home of [[Millwall Football Club|Millwall F.C.]]. It is situated adjacent to the [[South London railway line|South London Line]] originating at , and a quarter-of-a-mile from [[the Old Den|the Old Den]], which it replaced in 1993. Built on a previous site of housing, a church and the Senegal Fields playgrounds, it has an all-seated capacity of 20,146, with the highest match attendance during the [[2017-18 season|2017-18 Millwall F.C. season]] being 17,614.
title: The Den

abstract: Hillsborough Stadium, often referred to as Hillsborough, is a 39,732-capacity [[association football|association football]] [[stadium|stadium]] located in [[Owlerton|Owlerton]], a north-western suburb of [[Sheffield|Sheffield]], [[England|England]]. It has been the home ground of [[Sheffield Wednesday|Sheffield Wednesday F.C.]] since its opening in 1899.
title: Hillsborough Stadium

abstract: Pepsi Center is a multi-purpose [[arena|arena]] located in [[Denver|Denver]], [[Colorado|Colorado]], USA. The arena is home to the [[Denver Nuggets|Denver Nuggets]] of the [[National Basketball Association|National Basketball Association]] (NBA), the [[Colorado Avalanche|Colorado Avalanche]] of the [[National Hockey League|National Hockey League]] (NHL), and the [[Colorado Mammoth|Colorado Mammoth]] of the [[National Lacrosse League|National Lacrosse League]] (NLL). When not in use by one of Denver's sports teams, the building frequently serves as a concert venue.
title: Pepsi Center

abstract: Angel Stadium and its surrounding parking lot are roughly bounded by Katella Avenue to the north, the [[Orange Freeway|Orange Freeway]] to the east, Orangewood Avenue to the south, and State College Boulevard to the west. Located near the eastern boundary of the parking lot is the landmark [["Big A" sign|Big A Sign]] and electronic marquee, which originally served as a scoreboard support. The [[halo|Halo (religious iconography)]] located near the top of the 230' tall, 210-ton sign is illuminated following games in which the Angels win (both at home and on the road), which gives rise to the fan expression, "Light that baby Up!"
title: Angel Stadium

abstract: The Suwon World Cup Stadium was one of the venues of the [[2002 FIFA World Cup|2002 FIFA World Cup]], and held the following matches:
title: Suwon World Cup Stadium

abstract: Avaya Stadium is a [[soccer stadium|soccer-specific stadium]] in [[San Jose|San Jose, California]], [[California|California]], [[United States|United States]], and is the home of [[Major League Soccer|Major League Soccer]]'s [[San Jose Earthquakes|San Jose Earthquakes]]. The stadium is located on the Airport West site that is located to the west of [[San Jose International Airport|San Jose International Airport]].
title: Avaya Stadium

abstract: Leigh Sports Village is a development southwest of Leigh town centre, on the north side of the Leigh arm of the [[Leeds and Liverpool Canal|Leeds and Liverpool Canal]], close to [[Pennington Flash Country Park|Pennington Flash Country Park]] and accessed from the A579, Atherleigh Way and by pedestrian routes from the town and surrounding area. The scheme was initially developed to contribute to the regeneration of Leigh and provide modern facilities for local sports clubs, schools and the local community.
title: Leigh Sports Village

abstract: Yarrow Stadium is situated in the central suburb of [[Westown|Westown]] in [[New Plymouth|New Plymouth]], [[Taranaki|Taranaki region]], [[New Zealand|New Zealand]], with main vehicle access off Maratahu Street. Named the third best rugby stadium on earth by New Zealand Rugby World magazine in May 2009, Yarrow Stadium (known as Stadium Taranaki for the Rugby World Cup 2011) conforms with the [[International Rugby Board|International Rugby Board]]'s "clean stadium" policy.
title: Yarrow Stadium

abstract: Campbelltown Stadium, formerly Orana Park and Campbelltown Sports Ground, is a multi-use [[stadium|stadium]] in [[Leumeah|Leumeah, New South Wales]], [[New South Wales|New South Wales]], [[Australia|Australia]], owned by [[Campbelltown City Council|City of Campbelltown (New South Wales)]]. It is the full-time home ground for the [[Western Suburbs Magpies|Western Suburbs Magpies]] District [[Rugby league|Rugby league]] Football Club and is one of three home grounds for the [[Wests Tigers|Wests Tigers]] [[Rugby league|Rugby league]] Football Club. The stadium has a nominal capacity of 20,000, with a recorded highest crowd figure of 20,527 for a game between Wests Tigers and [[North Queensland Cowboys|North Queensland Cowboys]] in [[NRL season 2005|NRL season 2005]]. It is located adjacent to [[Leumeah railway station|Leumeah railway station]] and [[Wests Leagues Club|Western Suburbs Magpies]].
title: Campbelltown Stadium

abstract: Bowlin Stadium is a [[softball|softball]] stadium in [[Lincoln, Nebraska|Lincoln, Nebraska]]. It can accommodate up to 2,500 fans. It features 750 chairback seats and berm seating behind both dugouts and in the infield. There is also a two-level press box which provides seating for up to 25 members of the media. The press box also includes a media work room and three booths capable of accommodating radio and television representatives.
title: Bowlin Stadium

abstract: Odsal Stadium, is a sports stadium in [[Odsal|Odsal]], [[Bradford|Bradford]], West Yorkshire. The stadium is currently home of the [[Bradford Bulls|Bradford Bulls]] Rugby League team as well as previously home to the [[speedway|motorcycle speedway]] team [[Bradford Dukes|Bradford Dukes]], as well the football team [[Bradford City|Bradford City]] following the [[Valley Parade fire|Bradford City stadium fire]]. Odsal has also been a venue for baseball, basketball, [[kabbadi|kabbadi]], [[show jumping|show jumping]], tennis, live music and international Rugby League. It is also the [[largest rugby league stadium in England|List of Rugby League stadiums in England]].
title: Odsal Stadium

abstract: Traeger Park (currently known under naming rights as TIO Traeger Park) is a sports complex located in [[Alice Springs|Alice Springs]], [[Northern Territory|Northern Territory]], [[Australia|Australia]], and is named after [[Alfred Hermann Traeger|Alfred Hermann Traeger]]. The park was officially opened by Anne Catherine Smallwood (nee Traeger) Alfred's younger daughter. The primary stadium in the complex caters for [[Australian rules football|Australian rules football]] and [[cricket|cricket]] and has a capacity of 10,000. The complex also has a small baseball stadium.
title: Traeger Park

abstract: The record attendance for O'Brien field was 12,600 on November 9, 1980 vs. Northern Iowa. The all-time Win-Loss-Tie record at O'Brien Stadium is 178-90-3 as of the end of the 2018 football season.
title: O'Brien Stadium

abstract: Stade Chaban-Delmas is a sporting [[stadium|stadium]] located in the city of [[Bordeaux|Bordeaux]], [[France|France]]. It was the home ground of [[FC Girondins de Bordeaux|FC Girondins de Bordeaux]]. Since 2011, it has also hosted matches of [[Top 14|Top 14]] rugby team [[Union Bordeaux Bègles|Union Bordeaux Bègles]].
title: Stade Chaban-Delmas

abstract: The Sears Centre is an 11,000-seat multi-purpose arena in [[Hoffman Estates, Illinois|Hoffman Estates, Illinois]], a northwest [[suburb|suburb]], 25 miles from [[Chicago|Chicago]]. The arena has 43 luxury suites on two separate levels. It was estimated to attract over 750,000 visitors annually.The arena is currently home to the [[Illinois Recreational Cheerleading Association's (IRCA)|Illinois Recreational Cheerleading Association's (IRCA)]] State Championship and the [[Windy City Bulls|Windy City Bulls]], the [[Chicago Bulls|Chicago Bulls]]' affiliate in the [[NBA G League|NBA G League]].
title: Sears Centre

abstract: The Saskatoon Minor Football Field at Gordon Howe Park (formerly known as Gordie Howe Bowl) is a football stadium located in [[Saskatoon|Saskatoon]], [[Saskatchewan|Saskatchewan]], Canada. It was opened September 30, 1960, built on land repossessed by the city in 1931 for unpaid taxes. It is the home of the [[Saskatoon Hilltops|Saskatoon Hilltops]], who play in the Prairie Football Conference of the [[Canadian Junior Football League|Canadian Junior Football League]] and is also used for high school football. It is located on the southwest corner of the city. The park is named after [[Gordie Howe|Gordie Howe]], a Saskatoon native and member of the [[Hockey Hall of Fame|Hockey Hall of Fame]].
title: Saskatoon Minor Football Field

abstract: Pavelló Girona-Fontajau is an [[indoor arena|indoor arena]] in [[Girona|Girona]], [[Catalonia|Catalonia]], northern [[Spain|Spain]], that holds 5,500 [[people|people]]. It is primarily used for [[basketball|basketball]] and is the home arena of [[Uni Girona CB|Uni Girona CB]] and [[Bàsquet Girona|Bàsquet Girona]].The building was designed in 1993 by the architects [[Esteve Bonell|Esteve Bonell]] and Josep M. Gil and was opened on September 4th, 1993. It is structured in two levels, one for the public (the high level) and another, of which use is restricted to the sportsmen (the low level), with differentiated entries.
title: Pavelló Girona-Fontajau

abstract: Estadio Alberto Gallardo is a [[football|association football]] [[stadium|stadium]] in the [[Rimac District|Rimac District]] of [[Lima|Lima]], [[Peru|Peru]], named after [[Alberto Gallardo|Alberto Gallardo]], a former Peruvian football player and manager who played several years for Sporting Cristal. It is the home of football club [[Sporting Cristal|Sporting Cristal]]. The stadium was built in the 1960s along the [[Rímac River|Rímac River]] for local football use and originally named Estadio San Martín de Porres. Many clubs playing in the [[Primera División|Peruvian Primera División]], [[Segunda División|Peruvian Segunda División]], and district leagues of San Martín de Porres were among the many tenants the stadium had. In 1995, Sporting Cristal—one of the regular first division tenants of the stadium—decided to lease the venue from the Instituto Peruano del Deporte. The club recently signed a new lease contract for 10 years and will expire in 2022. The stadium itself has hosted few high-risk matches due to the limited access to the stadium and the low capacity of 20,000.
title: Estadio Alberto Gallardo

abstract: Estadio Óscar Quiteño is a [[multi-purpose stadium|multi-purpose stadium]] in [[Santa Ana|Santa Ana, El Salvador]], [[El Salvador|El Salvador]].
title: Estadio Óscar Quiteño

abstract: Olympia Park is a [[multi-purpose stadium|multi-purpose stadium]] located in [[Rustenburg|Rustenburg, North West]], [[South Africa|South Africa]]. Not to be confused with the [[Royal Bafokeng Stadium|Royal Bafokeng Stadium]], where the [[2010 FIFA World Cup|2010 FIFA World Cup]] games were played, it is currently used mostly for [[football|Association football]] and [[rugby|Rugby union]] matches; it was utilized as a training field for teams participating in the 2010 FIFA World Cup.
title: Olympia Park

abstract: Allan A. Lamport Stadium, also known as the Den, is a [[multi-purpose stadium|multi-purpose stadium]] on [[King Street West|King Street (Toronto)]] in the [[Liberty Village|Liberty Village]] neighbourhood of [[Toronto|Toronto]], [[Ontario|Ontario]], Canada. It is the home field of the [[Toronto Wolfpack|Toronto Wolfpack]] and the [[Canada national rugby league team|Canada national rugby league team]]. The 9,600 [[seating capacity|seating capacity]] stadium is also used for [[soccer|association football]], with the playing surface dually marked for both soccer and [[field hockey|field hockey]]. The stadium was named for long-time [[Toronto|Toronto]] politician [[Allan Lamport|Allan Lamport]], who was associated with sporting activities in the city.
title: Lamport Stadium

abstract: The Richmond Olympic Oval () is an indoor multi-sports [[arena|arena]] in the [[Canadian|Canada]] city of [[Richmond, British Columbia|Richmond, British Columbia]]. The oval was built for the [[2010 Winter Olympics|2010 Winter Olympics]] and was originally configured with a [[speed skating rink|speed skating rink]]. The venue has since been reconfigured and now serves as a community multi-sport park and includes two [[ice hockey rink|ice hockey rinks]], two running tracks, a [[climbing wall|climbing wall]], a [[rowing tank|rowing tank]] and a flexible area which can be used for, among other sports, [[basketball|basketball]], [[volleyball|volleyball]], [[indoor soccer|indoor soccer]] and [[table tennis|table tennis]].
title: Richmond Olympic Oval

abstract: Joan C. Edwards Stadium is a [[football|American football]] stadium located on the campus of [[Marshall University|Marshall University]] in [[Huntington, West Virginia|Huntington, West Virginia]], United States. It can hold 38,227 spectators and includes twenty deluxe, indoor suites, 300 [[wheelchair|wheelchair]]-accessible seating, a state-of-the-art press-box, 14 concession areas, and 16 separate restrooms. It also features . of artificial turf and 1,837 tons of structural steel. It also houses the [[Shewey Athletic Center|Shewey Athletic Center (Marshall University)]], a fieldhouse and a training facility. The new stadium replaced [[Fairfield Stadium|Fairfield Stadium]], a condemned off-campus facility built in 1927 in the Fairfield Park neighborhood.
title: Joan C. Edwards Stadium

abstract: Maverick Stadium is a 12,500-seat [[multi-purpose stadium|multi-purpose stadium]] on the western edge of [[University of Texas at Arlington|University of Texas at Arlington]] campus.
title: Maverick Stadium

abstract: Pete Beiden Field at Bob Bennett Stadium, formerly Varsity Park, is a [[baseball stadium|baseball stadium]] on the campus of the [[California State University, Fresno|California State University, Fresno]] in [[Fresno, California|Fresno, California]], United States. It was built in 1966. The field is the home of the [[Fresno State Bulldogs|Fresno State Bulldogs baseball]] [[baseball team|baseball team]] and named after former Fresno State baseball coach [[Pete Beiden|Pete Beiden]]. The park was redesigned in 1983 and now holds 5,757 people. Prior to the 2002 opening of [[Grizzlies Stadium|Chukchansi Park]], the park also was the home of the [[Fresno Grizzlies|Fresno Grizzlies]] [[minor league|minor league]] baseball team of the [[triple-A|Triple-A (baseball)]] [[Pacific Coast League|Pacific Coast League]].
title: Pete Beiden Field at Bob Bennett Stadium

abstract: Palacio Municipal de Deportes de Granada is an [[arena|arena]] in [[Granada|Granada]], [[Spain|Spain]]. Opened in 1991, the arena holds 9,507 people and it is primarily used for [[basketball|basketball]] and the home arena of [[Fundación CB Granada|Fundación CB Granada]], since 2015. The arena hosted the [[1999 UEFA Futsal Championship|1999 UEFA Futsal Championship]] and the [[Group A|EuroBasket 2007#Group A]] in [[EuroBasket 2007|EuroBasket 2007]].
title: Palacio Municipal de Deportes de Granada

abstract: Groundbreaking for Brooks Stadium was held on July 30, 2002. Phase I of the stadium construction contained 6,408 seats, while the foundation and infrastructure of the stadium was designed to support future expansion to 20,000 seats. The stadium was formally dedicated on September 6, 2003, as the Chanticleer football team opened its inaugural game vs. Newberry College in front of a crowd of more than 8,000. On October 7, 2006, the field was named James C. Benton Field to honor the family for a large donation they made to the Coastal athletics program earlier in the year.
title: Brooks Stadium

abstract: Greer Field at Turchin Stadium is a [[baseball|baseball]] [[stadium|stadium]] in [[New Orleans, Louisiana|New Orleans, Louisiana]]. It is the on-campus home the [[Tulane University|Tulane University]] [[Green Wave college baseball|Tulane Green Wave baseball]] team. The stadium was named for Robert Turchin, a [[World War II|World War II]] veteran and 1943 graduate of Tulane, and his wife, Lillian Turchin, who headed the drive in 1990 to build it. In 2008, at the official reopening, "Greer Field" was added to the name in honor of Phil Greer, chair of the Board of Tulane.
title: Greer Field at Turchin Stadium

abstract: Estadio Polideportivo Sur has been an important venue for concerts in Medellín.
title: Estadio Polideportivo Sur

abstract: Fehérvári úti Stadion is a multi-use [[stadium|stadium]] in [[Paks|Paks]], [[Hungary|Hungary]]. It is currently used mostly for [[football|football (soccer)]] matches and is the home stadium of [[Paksi FC|Paksi FC]]. The stadium is able to hold 5,000 people.
title: Fehérvári úti Stadion

abstract: Sør Arena ("South Arena") is a [[football|football (soccer)]] [[stadium|stadium]] located at Torsvika in [[Kristiansand|Kristiansand]], [[Norway|Norway]]. The [[all-seater|all-seater stadium]] has a capacity of 14,563 people, and serves as the home ground of [[Tippeligaen|Tippeligaen]] side [[IK Start|IK Start]]. It was designed by [[Kjell Kosberg|Kjell Kosberg]], and is architecturally similar to [[Aker Stadion|Aker Stadion]]. The venue has seen concerts by [[Elton John|Elton John]], [[Dolly Parton|Dolly Parton]] and [[A-ha|A-ha]], among others.. [[UEFA|UEFA]] refers to the stadium as Kristiansand Arena.
title: Sør Arena

abstract: Lynn Road was a [[football|association football]] ground in the [[Newbury Park|Newbury Park, London]] area of [[Ilford|Ilford]], [[London|London]]. It was the home ground of [[Ilford F.C.|Ilford F.C.]] from 1904 until 1977 and hosted [[football|Football at the 1948 Summer Olympics]] matches during the [[1948 Summer Olympics|1948 Summer Olympics]].
title: Lynn Road

abstract: The 'Antel Arena' is a multipurpose [[indoor arena|indoor arena]] that is located in the neighborhood of [[Villa Española|Villa Española]], [[Montevideo|Montevideo]], [[Uruguay|Uruguay]]. The arena has a capacity of 15,000 people for [[concerts|concerts]], and 10,000 people for [[basketball|basketball]] games.The arena is owned by [[ANTEL|ANTEL]], after they reached an agreement with the city of Montevideo, which granted them the rights to the arena for 30 years.
title: Antel Arena

abstract: BB&T Ballpark at Historic Bowman Field is a [[minor league|Minor League Baseball]] [[baseball stadium|Baseball park]] in [[Williamsport, Pennsylvania|Williamsport, Pennsylvania]], in the United States. It is home to the [[Williamsport Crosscutters|Williamsport Crosscutters]] of the [[New York–Penn League|New York–Penn League]]. Official [[seating capacity|seating capacity]] is 2,366. Opened in 1926, Bowman Field is the second-oldest ballpark in minor league baseball. It is also the home field for the Wildcats of the [[Pennsylvania College of Technology|Pennsylvania College of Technology]].
title: BB&T Ballpark at Historic Bowman Field

abstract: Stadio Nereo Rocco is a [[football|Association football]] [[stadium|stadium]] in [[Trieste|Trieste]], [[Italy|Italy]]. It is currently the home of [[Triestina|U.S. Triestina Calcio 1918]], named after former player and manager [[Nereo Rocco|Nereo Rocco]]. The stadium holds 32,454.
title: Stadio Nereo Rocco

abstract: Rotorua International Stadium is a [[multi-purpose stadium|multi-purpose stadium]] located on Devon Street West in the Westbrook suburb of [[Rotorua|Rotorua]], [[New Zealand|New Zealand]]. It is currently used mostly for [[rugby union|rugby union]] and [[rugby league|rugby league]] matches, being one of three home stadiums for the [[Bay of Plenty Rugby Union|Bay of Plenty Rugby Union]] (the others being [[Baypark Stadium|Baypark Stadium]] and [[Tauranga Domain|Tauranga Domain]] in [[Tauranga|Tauranga]]).
title: Rotorua International Stadium

abstract: Estadio Defensores del Chaco is a [[multi-purpose stadium|multi-purpose stadium]] in [[Asunción|Asunción]], [[Paraguay|Paraguay]]. It is currently used mostly for [[football|football (soccer)]] matches. The stadium once had a 50,000+ capacity, however over the years the stadium has undergone remodeling, dropping the capacity to 42,354. The stadium was again renovated in 2015.
title: Estadio Defensores del Chaco

abstract: Pioneer Oval is located in the town of [[Parkes, New South Wales|Parkes, New South Wales]] [[Australia|Australia]]. It was carved out of a hill in eastern Parkes during the depression years and has evolved into one of country New South Wales' premier sporting arenas, playing host to major local, regional, national and international sporting events.
title: Pioneer Oval

abstract: Downing Stadium, previously known as Triborough Stadium and Randall's Island Stadium, was a 22,000-seat [[stadium|stadium]] in [[New York City|New York City]]. It was renamed Downing Stadium in 1955 after John J. Downing, a director at the [[New York City Department of Parks and Recreation|New York City Department of Parks and Recreation]].
title: Downing Stadium

abstract: The La Crosse Center is a multi-purpose [[arena|arena]] in downtown [[La Crosse, Wisconsin|La Crosse, Wisconsin]], built in 1980. The arena can seat between 5,000 and 7,500, depending on the type of event.
title: La Crosse Center

abstract: The Stadio San Nicola () is a multi-use all-seater stadium designed by [[Renzo Piano|Renzo Piano]] in [[Bari|Bari]], Italy. It is currently used mostly for [[football|association football]] matches and is the home stadium of [[F.C. Bari 1908|F.C. Bari 1908]]. The stadium itself resembles a 'flower'. To create this particular design, the stadium consists of 26 'petals' and upper tiers of the higher ring which are separated by 8-metre empty spaces, sufficient to guarantee satisfactory security conditions.
title: Stadio San Nicola

abstract: The Colonels football team has found success playing at Roy Kidd Stadium, possessing a 191-43-1 home record.
title: Roy Kidd Stadium

abstract: Lancaster Park, previously known as Jade Stadium and AMI Stadium, was a sports stadium in [[Waltham|Waltham, New Zealand]], a suburb of [[Christchurch|Christchurch]] in New Zealand. The stadium was closed due to damage sustained in the February [[2011 Christchurch earthquake|2011 Christchurch earthquake]]. The Hadlee Stand and Tui Stand have been demolished and the start of the Paul Kelly Motor Company Stand and the Dean's Stand have had demolition start on them as of July 2018.
title: Lancaster Park

abstract: Cardinal Stadium, formerly known as Papa John's Cardinal Stadium, is a [[football|American football]] stadium located in [[Louisville, Kentucky|Louisville, Kentucky]], United States, on the southern end of the campus of the [[University of Louisville|University of Louisville]]. Debuting in 1998, it serves as the home of the [[Louisville Cardinals football|Louisville Cardinals football]] program. The official [[seating capacity|seating capacity]] in the quasi-horseshoe shaped facility was 42,000 through the [[2008 season|2008 Louisville Cardinals football team]]. An expansion project that started after the 2008 season was completed in time for the [[2010 season|2010 Louisville Cardinals football team]] has brought the official capacity to 55,000. An additional expansion project aiming to close the open end of the horseshoe to add 6,000 additional seats was announced on August 28, 2015, with the goal of opening within 2 years.
title: Cardinal Stadium

abstract: Tulane Stadium was an outdoor [[football|American football]] stadium located in [[New Orleans|New Orleans]], that stood from 1926 to 1980. It is officially the Third Tulane Stadium and replaced the [["Second Tulane Stadium"|Tulane Stadium (1917)]] where the Telephone Exchange Building is now located. The former site is currently bound by Willow Street to the south, Ben Weiner Drive to the east, the Tulane University property line west of [[McAlister Place|McAlister Place, New Orleans]], and the Hertz Basketball/Volleyball Practice Facility and the Green Wave's current home, [[Yulman Stadium|Yulman Stadium]], to the north.
title: Tulane Stadium

abstract: Davis Wade Stadium, officially known as Davis Wade Stadium at Scott Field, is a stadium primarily used for [[American football|American football]] located just outside the city limits of [[Starkville, Mississippi|Starkville, Mississippi]], United States, on the campus of [[Mississippi State University|Mississippi State University]]. It serves as the home venue for the [[Mississippi State Bulldogs football|Mississippi State Bulldogs football]] team. Originally constructed in 1914 as New Athletic Field, it is the second-oldest stadium in the [[Football Bowl Subdivision|NCAA Division I Football Bowl Subdivision]] behind [[Georgia Tech|Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets football]]'s [[Bobby Dodd Stadium|Bobby Dodd Stadium]], and the fourth oldest in all of college football behind [[Penn|Penn Quakers football]]'s [[Franklin Field|Franklin Field]], [[Harvard Stadium|Harvard Stadium]], and Bobby Dodd Stadium. As of 2016, it has a seating capacity of 61,337 people.
title: Davis Wade Stadium

abstract: Senator Thomas J. Dodd Memorial Stadium is a [[stadium|stadium]] in [[Norwich, Connecticut|Norwich, Connecticut]]. It is primarily used for [[baseball|baseball]], and, in 2010, became the home of the [[Connecticut Tigers|Connecticut Tigers]] of the [[New York–Penn League|New York–Penn League]]. It was the home field of the [[Connecticut Defenders|Connecticut Defenders]] [[minor league|minor league]] baseball team until 2009 when the Defenders announced their move to [[Richmond, Virginia|Richmond, Virginia]] to be the [[Richmond Flying Squirrels|Richmond Flying Squirrels]]. It was built in 1995 and has a [[seating capacity|seating capacity]] of 6,270. It is named for Eastern Connecticut native [[Thomas Dodd|Thomas J. Dodd]] who was a [[United States Senator|United States Senator]] and Representative from Connecticut, and the father of U.S. Senator [[Christopher Dodd|Christopher Dodd]].
title: Senator Thomas J. Dodd Memorial Stadium

abstract: Vikingskipet ("The Viking Ship"), officially known as Hamar Olympic Hall (), is an indoor multi-use sport and event venue in [[Hamar|Hamar]], [[Norway|Norway]]. It was built as the [[speed skating rink|speed skating rink]] for the [[1994 Winter Olympics|1994 Winter Olympics]], and has since also hosted events and tournaments in [[ice speedway|ice speedway]], [[rally|rallying]], [[association football|association football]], [[bandy|bandy]], [[ice sledge speed racing|ice sledge speed racing]], [[flying disc|flying disc]] and [[track cycling|track cycling]]. The arena is also used for [[concert|concerts]], [[trade fair|trade fair]] and the annual computer party [[The Gathering|The Gathering (computer party)]]. It is the home arena of [[Hamar IL|Hamar IL]] bandy team. The venue is owned by [[Hamar Municipality|Hamar Municipality]], and along with [[Hamar Olympic Amphitheatre|Hamar Olympic Amphitheatre]] is run by the municipal Hamar Olympiske Anlegg. Vikingskipet has a capacity for 10,600 spectators during sporting events and 20,000 during concerts.
title: Vikingskipet

abstract: Stade Canac is a [[stadium|stadium]] in [[Quebec City|Quebec City]], [[Quebec|Quebec]]. It is used primarily for [[baseball|baseball]] and is the home field for the [[Quebec Capitales|Quebec Capitales]] of the [[Canadian-American Association of Professional Baseball|Canadian-American Association of Professional Baseball]] (Can-Am) [[minor league|minor league]] baseball team.
title: Stade Canac

abstract: UC Health Stadium is a stadium in [[Florence, Kentucky|Florence, Kentucky]]. It is primarily used for [[baseball|baseball]] and is the home field of the [[Florence Freedom|Florence Freedom]] of the [[Frontier League|Frontier League]], an [[independent baseball league|independent baseball league]]. It originally opened in 2004 as Champion Window Field and holds 4,500 people.
title: UC Health Stadium

abstract: Stade Aimé Giral is a [[multi-purpose stadium|multi-purpose stadium]] in [[Perpignan|Perpignan]], [[France|France]]. It is currently used mostly for [[rugby union|rugby union]] matches and is the home stadium of [[USA Perpignan|USA Perpignan]].
title: Stade Aimé Giral

abstract: Moorabbin Oval, also known by its sponsorship name of RSEA Safety Park, is an [[Australian Rules Football|Australian Rules Football]] ground in the city of Melbourne, Victoria, Australia at Linton Street in the suburb of [[Moorabbin|Moorabbin, Victoria]].
title: Moorabbin Oval

abstract: Westfalenhallen (English: Halls of [[Westphalia|Westphalia]]) are three multi-purpose venues located in [[Dortmund|Dortmund]], Germany. The original building was opened in 1925, but was destroyed during World War II. New halls were built, the Große Westfalenhalle opened in 1952. The capacity of the arena is 16,500. The Kleine Westfalenhalle served also for balls, exhibitions and concerts, such as the [[Dortmunder Philharmoniker|Dortmunder Philharmoniker]], until the [[Opernhaus Dortmund|Opernhaus Dortmund]] was opened in 1966.The [[Bundesliga|Bundesliga]] was founded at the Westfalenhallen in 1962.
title: Westfalenhallen

abstract: The Estádio Olímpico Nilton Santos, formerly the Estádio Olímpico João Havelange (; ), is a [[multi-purpose stadium|multi-purpose stadium]] located in the [[neighbourhood|bairro]] of [[Engenho de Dentro|Engenho de Dentro]] in [[Rio de Janeiro|Rio de Janeiro]], [[Brazil|Brazil]]. It is used mostly for [[football|association football]] matches and athletics and is the home stadium of the football club [[Botafogo|Botafogo de Futebol e Regatas]]. The stadium was built by a [[consortium|consortium]] under the leadership of [[Odebrecht S.A.|Odebrecht S.A.]], from 2003 through to 2007, opening in time for the [[2007 Pan American Games|2007 Pan American Games]]. It hosted the [[athletics|athletics (sport)]] competitions at the [[2016 Summer Olympics|2016 Summer Olympics]] and the [[2016 Summer Paralympics|2016 Summer Paralympics]].
title: Estádio Olímpico Nilton Santos

abstract: Podgorica City Stadium ([[Montenegrin|Montenegrin language]]: Stadion pod Goricom) is an all-seater [[multi-purpose stadium|multi-purpose stadium]] in [[Podgorica|Podgorica]], [[Montenegro|Montenegro]]. Mostly used for [[football matches|association football]], it has a [[seating capacity|seating capacity]] of 15,230. The planned capacity of stadium, after the next reconstruction of the east stand, is over 18,000. The stadium is the home ground of [[Montenegrin national football team|Montenegro national football team]] and [[FK Budućnost Podgorica|FK Budućnost Podgorica]] ([[Montenegrin First League|Montenegrin First League]]).
title: Podgorica City Stadium

abstract: Karađorđe Stadium () is a [[multi-purpose stadium|multi-purpose stadium]] in [[Novi Sad|Novi Sad]], [[Vojvodina|Vojvodina]], [[Serbia|Serbia]]. It is currently used mostly for [[football|football (soccer)]] matches and is the home ground of [[FK Vojvodina|FK Vojvodina]]. The stadium is one of the most modern stadiums in Serbia and has one of the best pitches in the country. The stadium has a total of 14,458 [[seats|seating capacity]] after new renovations were made in 2013. The stadium is also the home ground for the Serbian U-21 football team.
title: Karađorđe Stadium

abstract: Surakul Stadium (; ) is a [[multi-purpose stadium|multi-purpose stadium]] in [[Phuket Province|Phuket Province]], [[Thailand|Thailand]]. It is currently used mostly for [[football|football (soccer)]] matches. The stadium holds 15,000 and was built in 1959.
title: Surakul Stadium

abstract: Rodney Parade is the home ground of [[Dragons|Dragons (rugby union)]] regional [[rugby union|rugby union]] team and rugby union club [[Newport RFC|Newport RFC]]. It is also the home ground of [[Newport County|Newport County A.F.C.]] [[football|Association Football]] club, and is the second-oldest sports venue in the [[Football League|Football League]], after [[Deepdale|Deepdale]]. However, stadium capacity is reduced for football matches.
title: Rodney Parade

abstract: The venue was originally built for staging large music concerts. Initially called the Autódromo, it could accommodate up to 50,000 people. Since 2000, it has been used as a baseball stadium as well, because the only other major baseball stadium in Mexico City ([[Parque del Seguro Social|:es:Parque del Seguro Social]], formerly [[Parque Delta|:es:Parque Delta]]) was demolished to build a shopping mall (the shopping mall is named Parque Delta and features a baseball theme). Foro Sol is the second largest concert venue in Mexico City; the largest, [[Estadio Azteca|Estadio Azteca]], has a capacity of 105,064.
title: Foro Sol

abstract: Stadion Z'dežele is a [[football|football (soccer)]] [[stadium|stadium]] in [[Celje|Celje]], [[Slovenia|Slovenia]]. It is the home ground of [[NK Celje|NK Celje]] since 2003. Prior July 2017, the stadium was named Arena Petrol.
title: Stadion Z'dežele

abstract: Unipol Arena (previously known as Futureshow Station and PalaMalaguti) is an [[indoor sporting arena|indoor arena]] located in [[Casalecchio di Reno|Casalecchio di Reno]], [[Province of Bologna|Province of Bologna]], [[Italy|Italy]]. The seating capacity of the arena for [[basketball|basketball]] games is 11,000 people, and the seating capacity for [[concerts|concerts]] is 18,000 people. It was opened in December 1993. It is currently home to the [[Virtus Bologna|Virtus Bologna]] basketball team.
title: Unipol Arena

abstract: Lupton Stadium, the home of [[TCU Horned Frogs baseball|TCU Horned Frogs baseball]], opened in 2003 and replaced the TCU Diamond, the Horned Frogs' home from 1962 to 2002. The TCU Diamond was adjacent to [[Amon G. Carter Stadium|Amon G. Carter Stadium]] and [[Schollmaier Arena|Schollmaier Arena]], where the Sam Baugh Indoor Practice Facility is now located.
title: Lupton Stadium

abstract: The Coffs Harbour International Stadium (known as the C.ex Coffs International Stadium under a sponsorship arrangement) is an [[Australia|Australian]] [[stadium|stadium]] located in the coastal city of [[Coffs Harbour|Coffs Harbour, New South Wales]], [[New South Wales|New South Wales]].
title: Coffs Harbour International Stadium

abstract: The Gocheok Sky Dome () is a [[dome|domed]] [[baseball stadium|baseball stadium]] located in [[Gocheok-dong|Gocheok-dong]], [[Seoul|Seoul]], [[South Korea|South Korea]]. It is the home ballpark for the [[Kiwoom Heroes|Kiwoom Heroes]]. The stadium is primarily used for [[baseball|baseball]] and has a capacity for 16,813 spectators for baseball games. The stadium replaced [[Dongdaemun Baseball Stadium|Dongdaemun Baseball Stadium]] and opened on 15 September 2015. It also serves as a concert venue, with a capacity for around 25,000 spectators.
title: Gocheok Sky Dome

abstract: The John and Ann Rhoads Softball Stadium (frequently shortened to Rhoads Stadium) is a [[college softball|college softball]] stadium located on the campus of the [[University of Alabama|University of Alabama]] in [[Tuscaloosa, Alabama|Tuscaloosa, Alabama]]. It serves as the home field of the [[Alabama Crimson Tide softball team|Alabama Crimson Tide softball]] and is located on the corner of 5th Avenue and Campus Drive on the northeast corner of campus. The Crimson Tide's all-time record at Rhoads Stadium is 316–50 (), and the official capacity of the stadium is 3,940. After they played their first season at Sokol Park and at Bowers Park for both the 1998 and 1999 seasons, the Crimson Tide opened Rhoads Stadium on February 23, 2000, with a 7–1 victory over the [[UAB Blazers|UAB Blazers]].
title: Rhoads Stadium

abstract: Investors Group Field is a football stadium in [[Winnipeg|Winnipeg]], [[Manitoba|Manitoba]], Canada. The stadium, which opened in 2013, is located on the [[University of Manitoba|University of Manitoba]] campus next to [[University Stadium|University Stadium (Winnipeg)]]. Owned by Triple B Stadium Inc., a [[consortium|consortium]] of the City of Winnipeg, the Province of Manitoba, the [[Winnipeg Football Club|Winnipeg Blue Bombers]] and the University of Manitoba, the stadium is home to the [[Winnipeg Blue Bombers|Winnipeg Blue Bombers]] of the [[Canadian Football League|Canadian Football League]] (CFL), [[University of Manitoba Bisons|University of Manitoba Bisons]] [[football|U Sports football]] team, and the [[Winnipeg Rifles|Winnipeg Rifles]] ([[CJFL|CJFL]]). It will also be home to [[Valour FC|Valour FC]] of the [[Canadian Premier League|Canadian Premier League]] beginning in 2019.
title: Investors Group Field

abstract: Sunderland Greyhound Stadium is a [[greyhound racing|Greyhound racing in the United Kingdom]] track situated at [[Fulwell|Fulwell, Sunderland]] in the [[City of Sunderland|City of Sunderland]] and [[English|England]] county of [[Tyne and Wear|Tyne and Wear]]. The stadium is owned by ARC and racing takes place every Wednesday and Friday evening as well as an additional BAGS meeting on Tuesdays, Thursdays and Sundays. The circumference of the track is 378 metres.
title: Sunderland Greyhound Stadium

abstract: Nottingham Greyhound Stadium is a [[greyhound racing|Greyhound racing in Great Britain]] track and stadium on the outskirts of [[Nottingham|Nottingham]], England.
title: Nottingham Greyhound Stadium

abstract: Mazzella Field is a 2,400 seat [[soccer-specific stadium|soccer-specific stadium]] on the campus of [[Iona College|Iona College (New York)]] in [[New Rochelle, New York|New Rochelle, New York]]. It is home to the [[Iona College Gaels|Iona Gaels]] [[soccer|Association football]], [[rugby|Rugby football]], and [[lacrosse|lacrosse]] teams, as well as the Women's [[New York Magic|New York Magic]] of [[United Women's Soccer|United Women's Soccer]].
title: Mazzella Field

abstract: Zdzisław Krzyszkowiak Stadium () is a multi-use [[stadium|stadium]] in [[Bydgoszcz|Bydgoszcz]], [[Poland|Poland]]. It was completed in 1960 with a capacity of about 35,000-45,000 on wooden benches. The stadium was completely rebuilt in 2007–2008, and the current [[seating capacity|seating capacity]] is 20,247 people. It is currently used for [[football|football (soccer)]] matches and [[track and field|track and field]] events. The stadium is named after Polish Olympic gold medal-winning runner [[Zdzisław Krzyszkowiak|Zdzisław Krzyszkowiak]].
title: Zdzisław Krzyszkowiak Stadium

abstract: The TSB Bank Arena (formerly known as the Queens Wharf Events Centre) is an [[indoor arena|indoor arena]], located in [[Wellington|Wellington]], [[New Zealand|New Zealand]].
title: TSB Bank Arena

abstract: John Euliano Park, formerly Jay Bergman Field, is a baseball stadium located on the main campus of the [[University of Central Florida|University of Central Florida]] in [[Orlando|Orlando, Florida]], [[Florida|Florida]], [[USA|United States]]. The stadium serves as the home of the [[UCF Knights|UCF Knights]] [[baseball team|UCF Knights baseball]].
title: John Euliano Park

abstract: Bob Ford Field is a football stadium in [[Albany, New York|Albany, New York]] that is owned and operated by the [[University at Albany, SUNY|University at Albany, SUNY]] and hosts the school's [[football|American football]] [[team|Albany Great Danes football]], as well as their soccer program. The stadium, with an initial seating capacity of 8,500, opened on September 14, 2013 when [[Albany|2013 Albany Great Danes football team]] made its debut in [[Colonial Athletic Association|Colonial Athletic Association]] football against [[Rhode Island|2013 Rhode Island Rams football team]]. It replaced [[University Field|University Field (Albany)]] as the school's current stadium and is named after [[Bob Ford|Bob Ford (American football)]], who was head coach at Albany from 1970 until retiring at the end of the 2013 season.
title: Bob Ford Field

abstract: Bear Stadium is a [[baseball|baseball]] venue in [[Conway|Conway, Arkansas]], [[Arkansas|Arkansas]], [[USA|United States]]. It is home to the [[Central Arkansas|University of Central Arkansas]] [[Bears|Central Arkansas Bears]] [[college baseball|college baseball]] team of the [[NCAA's|National Collegiate Athletic Association]] [[Division I|Division I (NCAA)]] [[Southland Conference|Southland Conference]]. Rebuilt in 2009, the facility has a capacity of 1,000 spectators.
title: Bear Stadium

abstract: Buriram Stadium, known for sponsorship purposes as Chang Arena is a 32,600-seat [[football|association football]] [[stadium|stadium]] in [[Buriram|Buriram Province]], [[Thailand|Thailand]]. The stadium is the home of [[Thailand|Thailand]]'s 2011, 2013, and 2015 treble champions, [[Buriram United|Buriram United F.C.]]. Chang Arena is the largest club-owned football stadium in Thailand. Its nickname is "Thunder Castle", the fifth castle of Buriram Province.
title: Chang Arena

abstract: Mordovia Arena () is a [[football|association football]] stadium in [[Saransk|Saransk]], [[Mordovia|Mordovia]], [[Russia|Russia]] built for the [[2018 FIFA World Cup|2018 FIFA World Cup]]. It also hosts [[FC Mordovia Saransk|FC Mordovia Saransk]] of the [[Russian Professional Football League|Russian Professional Football League]], replacing [[Start Stadium|Start Stadium (Saransk)]]. It has a capacity of 44,442 spectators. The total area of the facility is 122,700 sq m.
title: Mordovia Arena

abstract: Arena Pantanal is a multi-use [[stadium|stadium]] in [[Cuiabá|Cuiabá]], [[Brazil|Brazil]]. Completed on 26 April 2014, it is used mostly for [[football|Association football]] and hosted four group stage matches during the [[2014 FIFA World Cup|2014 FIFA World Cup]]. During the World Cup, the arena had a capacity of 41,390, and currently can seat 44,003 spectators.
title: Arena Pantanal

abstract: Ataköy Athletics Arena (), is an [[indoor sporting arena|indoor arena]] for [[track and field athletics|track and field]] events located in [[Ataköy|Ataköy, Bakırköy]], [[Istanbul|Istanbul]], Turkey.
title: Ataköy Athletics Arena

abstract: Aishbagh Stadium is a [[field hockey|field hockey]] stadium in [[Bhopal|Bhopal]], [[Madhya Pradesh|Madhya Pradesh]], [[India|India]]. It has a seating capacity of more than 10,000 people.
title: Aishbagh Stadium

abstract: Pamukkale University Arena () is an indoor multi-purpose sport venue that is located in the [[Pamukkale University|Pamukkale University]], [[Denizli|Denizli]], [[Turkey|Turkey]]. Opened in 2014, the hall has a seating capacity of 5,000 spectators. It is home to [[Denizli Basket|Denizli Basket]], which plays currently in the [[Turkish Basketball Second League|Turkish Basketball Second League]].
title: Pamukkale University Arena

abstract: Tissot Arena is a combined [[multi-purpose stadium|multi-purpose stadium]] and arena in [[Biel/Bienne|Biel/Bienne]], Canton of Bern, Switzerland. It consists of a [[football|Association football]] stadium, an [[ice hockey arena|ice hockey arena]], an outdoor [[ice skating rink|ice skating rink]] and a [[curling|curling]] hall. It is currently used by [[Swiss Challenge League|Swiss Challenge League]] football club [[FC Biel-Bienne|FC Biel-Bienne]] and [[National League A|National League A]] ice hockey club [[EHC Biel|EHC Biel]].
title: Tissot Arena

abstract: Tom Black Track at LaPorte Stadium is home to the [[University of Tennessee|University of Tennessee]] [[Volunteers|Tennessee Volunteers]] [[men's and women's outdoor track and field teams|Tennessee Volunteers track and field]]. It is located in the heart of the university's campus in [[Knoxville, Tennessee|Knoxville, Tennessee]].
title: Tom Black Track at LaPorte Stadium

abstract: Reading Stadium (Oxford Road) was a [[greyhound racing|Greyhound racing in the United Kingdom]] stadium in [[Reading|Reading, Berkshire]].
title: Reading Stadium (Oxford Road)

abstract: Holon Toto Hall was opened in March 2015. In 2016, the arena hosted the [[Rhythmic Gymnastics European Championships|2016 Rhythmic Gymnastics European Championships]]. The arena has been used as the home arena of the [[Israeli Basketball Super League|Israeli Basketball Super League]] club [[Hapoel Holon|Hapoel Holon]].
title: Holon Toto Hall

abstract: Dunkin' Donuts Park is a 6,121-seat [[baseball park|baseball park]] in [[Hartford, Connecticut|Hartford, Connecticut]]. It is the home field of the [[Hartford Yard Goats|Hartford Yard Goats]] of the [[Eastern League|Eastern League (baseball)]]. The stadium has a total capacity of 6,850 people, including standing room, which was reached numerous times during its inaugural season of 2017. It was planned to open for the 2016 season on April 7, but numerous constructions delays postponed this opening and forced the Yard Goats to play the entire season on the road. The stadium opened in time for the team's 2017 home opener on April 13.
title: Dunkin' Donuts Park

abstract: Joe Miller Field at Cowgirl Diamond is the home [[stadium|stadium]] for the [[Division I (NCAA)|Division I (NCAA)]] [[McNeese State Cowgirls softball|McNeese State Cowgirls softball]] team. Located on the campus of [[McNeese State University|McNeese State University]] in [[Lake Charles, Louisiana|Lake Charles, Louisiana]], the stadium has a 1,200 [[seating capacity|seating capacity]]. Seating consists of partially covered bleacher seating. The stadium has field lighting, bullpens, dugouts, and a press box. An indoor training facility, the "H.I.T" or House of Indoor Training, located outside the right field fence, allows hitting practice in all weather conditions. A Daktronics electronic scoreboard includes a message board. The initial home game was played on March 14, 2003 against the [[Southern Miss Golden Eagles softball|Southern Miss Golden Eagles softball]] team.
title: Joe Miller Field at Cowgirl Diamond

abstract: Maine Road was a football stadium in [[Moss Side|Moss Side]], [[Manchester|Manchester]], England, that was home to [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City F.C.]] from 1923 to 2003. It hosted [[FA Cup semi-finals|FA Cup Semi-finals]], [[Charity Shield|FA Community Shield]] matches, a [[League Cup final|1984 Football League Cup Final]] and [[England|England national football team]] matches and, because of its high capacity, gained the nickname Wembley of the North. Maine Road holds the record for the [[second highest attendance|List of record home attendances of English football clubs]] for a club in their normal home stadium in English club football, set in 1934 at an FA Cup sixth round match between Manchester City and [[Stoke City|Stoke City F.C.]].
title: Maine Road

abstract: Mountaineer Field at Milan Puskar Stadium (commonly known as Mountaineer Field or Milan Puskar Stadium) is the [[football|American football]] [[stadium|stadium]] for the [[West Virginia Mountaineers|West Virginia Mountaineers football]] [[NCAA|National Collegiate Athletic Association]] [[Division I|Division I (NCAA)]] [[FBS|Football Bowl Subdivision]] football team. The stadium is located in [[Morgantown|Morgantown, West Virginia]], [[West Virginia|West Virginia]], on the health sciences campus of [[West Virginia University|West Virginia University]].
title: Mountaineer Field at Milan Puskar Stadium

abstract: Cheney Stadium is named for [[Ben Cheney|Ben Cheney]], a local businessman who worked to bring minor league baseball to [[Tacoma|Tacoma, Washington]] and also was put in control of the project. Cheney Stadium was constructed in 42 working days after the [[San Francisco Giants|San Francisco Giants]] had committed to moving their Triple-A affiliate from Phoenix if the city could open the stadium for the beginning of the 1960 season. Construction included light towers and wooden grandstand seats from [[Seals Stadium|Seals Stadium]] in San Francisco. The wooden grandstand seats are still in place today.
title: Cheney Stadium

abstract: Designed by [[architect|architect]] Studio Hutter, the Stadio delle Alpi was originally built in 1990 to host matches for the [[1990 FIFA World Cup|1990 FIFA World Cup]] as a replacement for the aging Stadio Olimpico, then known as the Stadio Comunale. The stadium's original capacity was 69,041 fans. However, due to [[FIFA|FIFA]] rules regarding the segregation of home and away supporters, the actual capacity was reduced to 67,229.
title: Stadio delle Alpi

abstract: Rupp Arena is an [[arena|list of indoor arenas]] located in downtown [[Lexington, Kentucky|Lexington, Kentucky]], [[U.S.|United States]] Since its opening in 1976, it has been the centerpiece of [[Lexington Center|Lexington Center]], a convention and shopping facility owned by an arm of the Lexington-Fayette Urban County Government, which is located next to the Lexington [[Hyatt|Hyatt Regency Hotel, Lexington]] and [[Hilton|Hilton Lexington/Downtown]] hotels. Rupp Arena also serves as home court to the University of Kentucky men's basketball program, and is named after legendary former Kentucky coach and [[University of Kansas|University of Kansas]] alumnus [[Adolph Rupp|Adolph Rupp]]. With an official capacity of 23,500, it is currently the largest arena in the United States designed specifically for basketball. In Rupp Arena, the [[Kentucky Wildcats men's basketball|Kentucky Wildcats men's basketball]] team is second in the nation in [[college basketball|college basketball]] home attendance. The only other basketball-specific arena in US history larger than the arena is the is Thompson boling who had at one tine seating capacity of 24,535. Rupp Arena also regularly hosts concerts, conventions and shows.
title: Rupp Arena

abstract: Central Energy Trust Arena is the current name of the 180,000 square metre publicly owned recreational complex just west of the [[Palmerston North|Palmerston North]] city centre in the [[Manawatu-Wanganui|Manawatu-Wanganui Region]] region of [[New Zealand|New Zealand]].
title: Central Energy Trust Arena

abstract: The Estadio Alberto J. Armando (formerly the "Estadio Camilo Cichero") is an [[association football|association football]] [[stadium|stadium]] located in [[La Boca|La Boca]] district of [[Buenos Aires|Buenos Aires]]. Widely known as La Bombonera (; ) due to its shape, with a "flat" stand on one side of the pitch and three steep stands round the rest of the stadium. It has a capacity of 49,000.
title: La Bombonera

abstract: With its 76,092 ([[all-seater|all-seater stadium]]) capacity and Olympic size, it was granted the "5-star sports complex" title by the [[UEFA|UEFA]] in 2004, enabling it to host the finals of UEFA events. The [[2005 UEFA Champions League Final|2005 UEFA Champions League Final]] between [[Milan|A.C. Milan]] and [[Liverpool|Liverpool F.C.]] was played at the Atatürk Olympic Stadium on 25 May 2005. The stadium is also certified by the [[IAAF|International Association of Athletics Federations]] and [[IOC|International Olympic Committee]] as a first-class venue for track and field, and has hosted several European athletic competitions. On 30 May 2020, the stadium is scheduled to stage its [[second Champions League final|2020 UEFA Champions League Final]].
title: Atatürk Olympic Stadium

abstract: Kroger Field, formerly known as Commonwealth Stadium, is a stadium in [[Lexington, Kentucky|Lexington, Kentucky]], United States, located on the campus of the [[University of Kentucky|University of Kentucky]] that primarily serves as the home field for the [[Kentucky Wildcats football|Kentucky Wildcats football]] team. The stadium is located at the corner of Alumni Drive and University Drive in Lexington. The playing surface is named C.M. Newton Grounds in honor of retired UK athletic director and former baseball and basketball player [[C.M. Newton|C.M. Newton]]. Built in 1973, it is the newest football stadium in the [[Southeastern Conference|Southeastern Conference]], as measured by date of original construction. The original capacity for the stadium was 57,800. In the stadium's first game, played on September 15, 1973, the Wildcats defeated the [[Virginia Tech Hokies|Virginia Tech Hokies football]] 31–26
title: Kroger Field

abstract: The Riverside Stadium is a football stadium in [[Middlesbrough|Middlesbrough]], [[England|England]], which has been the home of [[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough F.C.]] since it opened in 1995. Its current capacity is 34,000, all seated, although there is provisional planning permission in place to expand that to 42,000 if required.
title: Riverside Stadium

abstract: Kyle Field is the [[football|American football]] [[stadium|stadium]] located on the campus of [[Texas A&M University|Texas A&M University]] in [[College Station, Texas|College Station, Texas]], [[United States|United States]]. It has been the home to the [[Texas A&M Aggies football|Texas A&M Aggies football]] team in rudimentary form since 1904, and as a permanent concrete stadium since 1927. It is known as the "Home of the [[12th Man|Traditions of Texas A&M University]]".
title: Kyle Field

abstract: Dell Diamond is the home [[stadium|stadium]] of the [[Round Rock Express|Round Rock Express]], the [[Triple-A|Triple-A (baseball)]] [[Minor League Baseball|Minor League Baseball]] affiliate of the [[Houston Astros|Houston Astros]] major league [[baseball|baseball]] team. On April 16, 2000, the then-[[Double-A|Double-A (baseball)]] affiliate Express played their first home game at the stadium.
title: Dell Diamond

abstract: Arizona Stadium is an outdoor [[college football|college football]] stadium in [[Tucson, Arizona|Tucson, Arizona]], on the campus of the [[University of Arizona|University of Arizona]]. It is the home field of the [[Arizona Wildcats|Arizona Wildcats football]] of the [[Pac-12 Conference|Pac-12 Conference]].
title: Arizona Stadium

abstract: The Kenneth P. LaValle Stadium is the main stadium for [[Stony Brook University|Stony Brook University]] in [[Stony Brook|Stony Brook, New York]], [[New York|New York (state)]], [[United States|United States]]. Construction began in 2000 at a cost of approximately $22 million. With a capacity of 12,300 people (10,300 seating and 2,000 standing), it is the largest outdoor facility in [[Suffolk County|Suffolk County, New York]]. The stadium is home to the [[Division I|Division I (NCAA)]] [[Stony Brook Seawolves|Stony Brook Seawolves]] and their [[football|Stony Brook Seawolves football]], men's soccer, women's soccer, [[men's lacrosse|Stony Brook Seawolves men's lacrosse]], and [[women's lacrosse|Stony Brook Seawolves women's lacrosse]] teams.The stadium opened on September 14, 2002. It was named in honor of New York state senator [[Kenneth LaValle|Kenneth LaValle]] on October 19, 2002. LaValle played a key role in the development and creation of the stadium. The stadium consists of a three-tier press box on the east side, as well as six luxury suites, a press box, television and radio booths, and a camera deck on the roof.
title: Kenneth P. LaValle Stadium

abstract: The Montagne Center, built in 1984, is a 10,746-seat multi-purpose [[arena|arena]] in [[Beaumont, Texas|Beaumont, Texas]] designed especially for the basketball program. The Montagne Center is currently home to the [[Lamar University|Lamar University]] [[Cardinals|Lamar Cardinals basketball]] and [[Lady Cardinals basketball|Lamar Lady Cardinals basketball]] teams. The arena was previously the home of the [[Lady Cardinals volleyball|Lamar Cardinals and Lady Cardinals#Volleyball]] team until renovations to [[McDonald Gym|McDonald Gym]] were completed in 2006-07.
title: Montagne Center

abstract: USC had planned to build an on-campus indoor arena for more than 100 years. Before the Galen Center, USC basketball had been played at a variety of locations, including the neighboring [[Shrine Auditorium|Shrine Auditorium]] stage, the old [[Pan-Pacific Auditorium|Pan-Pacific Auditorium]] in the [[Fairfax District|Fairfax District, Los Angeles, California]], and from 1959 onward at the [[Los Angeles Memorial Sports Arena|Los Angeles Memorial Sports Arena]].The final push to build the new facility began in 2002, when [[Louis Galen|Louis Galen]], a successful banker and longtime Trojan fan, and his wife Helene donated $10 million to the new center immediately after USC football [[quarterback|quarterback]] [[Carson Palmer|Carson Palmer]] won the 2002 [[Heisman Trophy|Heisman Trophy]]. The Galens donated an additional $25 million to the project to have the building named after them and later upped their donation an additional $15 million to make sure that a connected practice facility would also bear their name, bringing the total donation to $50 million. Previously, the USC men's and women's basketball teams practiced at the smaller, on-campus North Gym. The Galen Center replaced the [[Los Angeles Memorial Sports Arena|Los Angeles Memorial Sports Arena]] as the home for USC men's and women's basketball.
title: Galen Center

abstract: JPS Field at Malone Stadium is a [[stadium|stadium]] in [[Monroe, Louisiana|Monroe, Louisiana]], United States, on the campus of the [[University of Louisiana at Monroe|University of Louisiana at Monroe]]. It is primarily used for football and is the home field of the [[ULM Warhawks|Louisiana–Monroe Warhawks football]]. The stadium, named for former coach [[James L. Malone|James L. Malone]], opened in 1978 and has a seating capacity of 27,617 people. The field is named JPS Field, for a local company, JPS Aviation/JPS Equipment Rental. The field was named after the company after they agreed to fund installation of a new [[FieldTurf|FieldTurf]] playing surface in 2014.
title: JPS Field at Malone Stadium

abstract: The Sapporo Dome opened in 2001 with 41,580 seats. This stadium hosted 3 games during the [[2002 FIFA World Cup|2002 FIFA World Cup]], [[Germany|Germany national football team]] vs [[Saudi Arabia|Saudi Arabia national football team]], [[Argentina|Argentina national football team]] vs [[England|England national football team]] and [[Italy|Italy national football team]] vs [[Ecuador|Ecuador national football team]]; all three matches were in the first round.The Dome hosted the opening ceremonies to the [[2007 FIS Nordic World Ski Championships|2007 FIS Nordic World Ski Championships]] on February 22 and hosted the closing ceremonies of the championships on March 4. It also made history as being the first venue where both indoor and nighttime skiing events took place for the first time on a world championship or [[Winter Olympic Games|Winter Olympic Games]] level with competitions in the [[cross country skiing|cross country skiing]] sprints (men's and women's individual, and men's and women's team) and the cross country portion of the 7.5   km sprint event in the [[nordic combined|nordic combined]]. In order to generate snow, the stadium used its turf conversion hovering system to facilitate the snow making process for the skiing competitions. The opening ceremony featured [[Maki Ohguro|Maki Ohguro]], a local artist from Sapporo, Japanese drum demonstrations and other performances paying tributes to local customs and traditions. For the championships, [[seating capacity|seating capacity]] was reduced to 30,000.
title: Sapporo Dome

abstract: In 1994, the [[air-supported roof|air-supported structure]] collapsed in a snowstorm. Since this had occurred on numerous occasions before, it was replaced by a more permanent metal roof. Prior to November 18, 2006, the basketball, volleyball and wrestling team utilized the UNI-Dome, before the construction of the [[McLeod Center|McLeod Center]]. The McLeod Center is directly south of the UNI-Dome and connected by a covered walkway. The UNI-Dome attendance record for football is 17,190, which was set on October 17, 2009, during a Panthers homecoming game against the Missouri Valley rival [[Southern Illinois|Southern Illinois Salukis]].
title: UNI-Dome

abstract: Arena AufSchalke (currently known as Veltins-Arena ( for sponsorship reasons) is a [[football|association football]] stadium in [[Gelsenkirchen|Gelsenkirchen]], [[North Rhine-Westphalia|North Rhine-Westphalia]], Germany. It opened on 13 August 2001, as the new home ground for [[Bundesliga|Bundesliga]] club [[FC Schalke 04|FC Schalke 04]].It hosted the [[2004 UEFA Champions League Final|2004 UEFA Champions League Final]] and five matches at the [[2006 FIFA World Cup|2006 FIFA World Cup]], including a quarter-final. It has a capacity of 62,271 (standing and seated) for league matches and 54,740 (seated only) for international matches. The stadium has a [[retractable roof|retractable roof]] and a retractable pitch. The naming rights to the stadium were sold on 1 July 2005 to German brewery [[Veltins|Veltins]].
title: Arena AufSchalke

abstract: Reese Court is a 6,000-seat multi-purpose [[arena|arena]] in [[Cheney, Washington|Cheney, Washington]], on the campus of [[Eastern Washington University|Eastern Washington University]]. It is home to the [[EWU Eagles|Eastern Washington Eagles men's basketball]] [[basketball|basketball]] [[team|team]] and replaced [[Eastern Washington Fieldhouse|Eastern Washington Fieldhouse]] in 1975. It was the host venue of the 2004 [[Big Sky Conference|Big Sky Conference]] men's basketball tournament, and is located southwest of the football stadium, [[Roos Field|Roos Field]].
title: Reese Court

abstract: Teddy Stadium (, Itztadion Teddy) is a sports [[stadium|stadium]] in [[Jerusalem|Jerusalem]], [[Israel|Israel]]. Four football teams currently use the stadium: [[Beitar Jerusalem|Beitar Jerusalem F.C.]], [[Hapoel Jerusalem|Hapoel Jerusalem F.C.]], [[Hapoel Katamon Jerusalem|Hapoel Katamon Jerusalem F.C.]], and [[Beitar Nordia Jerusalem|Agudat Sport Nordia Jerusalem F.C.]]. The stadium also serves the [[national team|Israel national football team]] for some select home matches.The stadium is named for long-time Jerusalem mayor [[Teddy Kollek|Teddy Kollek]], who was in office during the time of its construction and was one of its prominent advocates.
title: Teddy Stadium

abstract: [[Bridgend Ravens|Bridgend Ravens]] moved to The Brewery Field in 1920 after their former home Quarella Ground was acquired for building purposes. The club's first stay at the Brewery Field ended in the 1928/29 season, when the ground was purchased by a Greyhound Racing Syndicate who organised greyhound racing meetings from 1929 and was still active in 1932. Bridgend RFC returned in 1935 only to go into exile yet again in May 1949 after being evicted after a rugby league team had signed up to take the lease of the ground, but eventually returned in 1957 with the ground in a poor state of repair. Most of the outside fencing was laid to the ground, essential services including water, heating, lighting and drainage were wrecked and needed to be completely re-installed.
